My daughter Abbey and I dove straight in and were flabbergasted at the perfection of this pork cutlet Korean slaw concoction!!  The wifey couldn't stand our looks of amazement and continued to dive in and eat the other half on her own. Much to our dismay.
We met an Alex/Adam Schifrin upon our second visit and this young man was a wonderful ambassador for the brand. I implored him to contact me should his lovely boss ever look toward Detroit as a possible spot for a restaurant. If so, I'm in like Flynn!!

There are so many gluten free options here. They have a separate gluten free menu that you should ask your waiter for. They have in-house made gluten free bread! I got the Pulled Pork Sammie. Very flavorful but the pork was a little tough.

I liked it, I didn't love it. We waited over an hour for a table after being told the wait was 30-40 minutes. No big deal - it was the weekend brunch rush so a wait was to be expected. My party of 2 was seated at the end of the counter and we waited a bit to put in our drink order - a chai latte and Arnold Palmer, no booze on this trip.

The chai was good if a little one note (mostly cinnamon) and I wish it had been hotter. The Arnold Palmer was great.

Then we waited. And waited. And waited some more to put in our food order. Again, brunch rush - waiting is to be expected - but we sat with closed menus for 10 minutes while our server closed out other checks.

We ordered salads each and biscuits and gravy for me, goat chili for my companion. The server asked if we wanted our salads first - we said sure.

5 minutes later, our "entrees" come out, no salads in sight. Again, these things happen, but our server came to check up on us and was like,"Oh, that's funny!" when she realized the salads were MIA.

The salads came up shortly after. They were good but just a standard Caesar salad with lackluster croutons. My biscuit was out of this world amazing, fluffy and buttery, but the pork and mushroom gravy desperately needed salt. The goat chili was unusual and tasty with a nice smoky heat that built up with every bite.

For some reason, we were denied a carafe of water. Literally every other party had one and I asked another server for water when our server went missing. We got a pitcher and then it was taken away from us moments later when our server came to refill our glasses.

The uneven service and lack of attention to detail was unfortunate because there is a lot of good to be had here - but I just can't justify the wait for so-so service. I'll consider giving it another try with a bigger party and more of a festive mood, or might just swing by on a weekday morning for coffee and pastries.

We came go Little Goat for a cocktail while we were killing time go get into Au Cheval - that was a 4 hour wait. We were presently surprised and happy to find that there were actually some seats at the bar at little goat that could accommodate us.

This place has a national reputation based upon its parent restaurant - girl in the goat. The overall atmosphere of the place is a diner like experience. I have to say that I did not look at the dining menu because we were waiting for our table at our intended location.

Funny thing here is that my friend strangely was playing with the straws that are used for cocktail glasses however he wasn't playing with his own straw-  he was playing with the group of straws that were being kept when a drink is made. The bartender kindly asked him to stop playing with the straws but then had to take about 50 or 60 of them out and throw them away because they have been touched by his hands. He was naturally embarrassed/horrified and deservedly so. I want to take the bartender for not making a big deal out of what he was doing. Great job!

ohmuhgoooodddddddd. I went with a friend and we just ordered several plates. My favorites were the pulled pork nachos and the pineapple gazpacho. I honestly couldn't tell you what else we had because I just focused on those two delicious, beautiful, perfect plates deserved all my attention. We sat there for a while just chatting and munching and honestly, it was the best way to enjoy Little Goat Diner. If you walk next door to the bar area, and you are a smoker like me, you can marvel at all the rubs and sauces while grabbing a drink. This place is just my everything.

Lucky that we got a booth by window. Food was good but the sides kinda out-performed my main dishes. Pork belly was awesome at the beginning. The more you have though it gets salty and those crispy edges slightly hurt you mouth.

pics.caption: Pork Belly Fries. Delicious but do share.

review.des: Great find! I loved everything I ate from the eggs to the pancakes. All four of us were very impressed with the fresh ingredients and taste.  I give this a major  up.

Ordered a bunch of popular menu items including Little Piggy Went to China, Pork Belly and Shrimp, Brussels sprouts and Okonomiyaki. Same problem as the Girl and Goat: food is way too salty. The meat is over-seasoned and you can't really taste its flavor other than an overdose of salt. The shakes here are decent though. The cookies and cream shake was a blast.

This is hands down, one of my favorite restaurants in the city. Go here and order the nachos immediately.

I've been here 5 or 6 times in the last year and it's a rare west loop spot that I will go wayyyy out of my way for.

The service is good, the waits can be long, it can be loud and really crowded, but the food is so excellent in every way and makes it 100% worth it.

Milkshakes? The best I've ever had. Unreal.

Shrimp and grits? Fresh and bright and so delicious.

NACHOS? My favorite dish ever and I simply cannot believe how good it is

Everything my friends have ordered while I've been with them, sandwiches etc., has been amazing as well.

Every time I come to Chicago I have to make a pit stop here for breakfast. First off the ambiance is great, looks like a Midwest diner except for its brand new and extra trendy-- photo-booth right by the entrance. There is a coffee shop connected in the back of the restaurant which also holds extra seating.

The service is always friendly, and fair warning there is ALWAYS a wait so best to make a reservation.

The prices are very fair and I always end up ordering so much extra food because I just want to try a bite. They have amazing breakfast food and then sandwiches salads and other yummy original favorites. I would come back here again and again with anyone or even alone.

The bi bim bop bowl is amazing for breakfast, just a fair trace of Korean flavor but delicious and filling. It has cauliflower rice mushrooms and you can place two eggs however you'd like on it, it also has some yummy bacon! The club is filling and everything you'd want on your sandwich. The side of hash browns has melted cheese on the bottom and the sausage patties have a sweet taste and are the item I order EVERY time I'm here!

Came here with my parents and boyfriend on Sunday, after the Hot Chocolate 5k. As to be expected for a party of four near 11 a.m., we were quoted a two hour wait. Luckily we were seated after forty minutes. Food and service were both great, I ordered the Parathas Burrito while my boyfriend ordered the Everything is Everything Crumpets. Both were great without being overwhelmingly heavy, although I couldn't finish my order.

Also had some of the goat blend coffee, which I liked. It's a lighter roast than I usually drink, but was good and easy to drink black. Will definitely be back!

We put in our name for the busy diner and walked into the bar for a drink. With room at the bar we ate there!  The bartender was friendly and knew the beers. He let us sample a Pilsner. I opted for the milk stout. The homemade delicious nachos with shredded beef, sour cream and guacamole were to die for. The chili fries were so delicious, too. The three of us had beers with heavy carbs for lunch at the bar!  Good service. Great food. Good times!

Absolute favorite brunch place in Chicago. I bring friends and visitors for all occasions. This was the first place my boyfriend and I went when we first came to Chicago together back in 2016. We didn't have a reservation, but we were able to sit along the bar with a view right into the kitchen. As it was the first of many food stops, we chose only a few items on the menu: bacon, sourdough pancakes, and the pork belly pancake to share. While the bacon was proper, the sourdough pancakes were delicious, it was the pork belly pancake that blew our minds! We didn't speak the whole time we ate that dish. Since then, I've been to Little Goat several times. I've deviated from the pork belly pancake twice. Once for the everything-is-everything pancakes and for a breakfast special, both well worth it, but I always go back to the pork belly.

We've never had a bad experience with a waiter - we've even seen Stephanie Izard in the kitchen.

The Power Move When Dining with a Group: As soon as your waiter comes, order coffee (they serve Dark Matter), one cinnamon roll, and the tempura mashed potatoes. Those two dishes are perfect to share amongst 6 and it sets the bar high.

Keep in Mind: On the weekend, it can get a little loud. If you have any diners who are particular about loud restaurants, they may have an issue.

pics.caption: Bullseye French Toast, Cornbeef Hash, Tempura Mashed Potatoes, Hashed Browns, Pork Belly Pancake.
Sourdough pancakes, pork belly pancakes, side of bacon.

review.des:
I came here with a group of friends for breakfast/brunch, and was definitely not a fan. I can't figure out what all the hype is about or why this place seems to be so popular, other than being a Stephanie Izard restaurant. It was a hot, sunny, heat-index kind of summer day in Chicago when we went, and the restaurant itself was also SUPER hot - we never got to stop sweating and it almost felt nice to walk back out into the blistering sunny heat.

I was underwhelmed by the menu - it seemed like it was trying too hard to be trendy, and everything on was overly complicated with too much going on. I definitely would not plan on trying to find lighter/healthier fare here, I thought I was just getting some breakfast potatoes but ended up with a bowl full of french fries. I did also get a side of scrambled eggs, and those were truly delightful... I just wished there was something that looked good to go with said eggs. My mimosa also came in a tiny child-sized cup... I'll probably just skip it next time. Our server, however, was delightful.

I loved Girl and the Goat so I was pumped for Little Goat Diner since breakfast food is my jam. I had a really tiring night and was half asleep at arrival but the food invigorated my soul. We ordered the this little piggy went to China, the bullseye French toast, pork belly Home fries, and the fatoush salad. The waitress was very nice and helpful in giving us the most popular dishes which we then ordered.

I love every component in bullseye French toast separately but I wasn't sure if it would all be good together. I really had no reason to worry because it was amazing. Brioche with a soft egg in the middle was prime and the honey fried chicken worked well with the sweetness of the toast and berries. Definitely my favorite dish. This little piggy went to China had a good Szechuan taste but may not be for those who aren't used to the numbing spice. The fatoush salad was surprisingly good and had a strong presence. The pork belly home fries came with a great aioli but is skippable. I also had bites of the dark chocolate pancakes, bacon, and hash browns and I was very happy with all of them. I wish I lived in Chicago so that I could come back and try the other dishes since they have an expansive menu.

Pretty wild to see the empire of Stephanie Izard and the West Loop/Fulton Market neighborhood grow side by side over the years. The first time this place opened, I was ecstatic that there is now a place to eat in the mornings on what is now called Restaurant Row. Today, of course there's numerous places to grub in the mornings now.

Neighborhood nostalgia aside, LGD is quite a breakfast/brunch experience. Take one good look a the menu and you might question how the hell do those things mix well? I don't know, but just friggin eat it and you won't be disappointed usually.

It's actually been a while since I've dined here. The menu has expanded, a bakery has been added but the crowd of diners has only expanded. Much like Izard's empire...

As a yelper that has tried a variety of food from different restaurants all over the world, I did not enjoy my experience at the Little Goat Diner and would not recommend this diner to anyone.

To begin, the hostess was not accommodating​ at all. My sister made the reservation for us to sit at the diner, however, when I arrived I told the hostess that I had back pain and could not sit at the diner bar comfortably. Instead of trying to be hospitable, she would not accommodate​. She told me that the only way I could get another seat was if I waited in line, AGAIN, for 35 minutes. I thought that was rude and uninviting​, considering that I already waited 40 minutes to be seated the first time and there were plenty of tables to be seated at.

Also, I feel as though the employees/waiters at the restaurant​ are miserable. Specifically, I feel this way because my server disappeared for 20 minutes and when she returned, she had tears in her eyes and looked as though she had been crying for awhile. When I asked if she was fine, she said everything is okay but that there is a lot​ going on in the restaurant at the moment. Further, I noticed this theme was recurrent​ when speaking with other employees that work there. As an individual that has a lot​ of experience with human resource management, it is easy for me to decipher whether an environment is extremely negative with poor management.

As for the food, I did not enjoy it much. We tried the best two dishes on the menu, which are the bull's eye french toast and the little piggy. The dishes do look appetizing​, and I thoroughly​ enjoyed its appearance​. However, the taste was completely off. Each dish felt as though it had a clash of ingredients, ​as if something was throwing the taste off. Although the chef's skills seem spectacular due to his or her's ability to place an egg in between each piece of toast. Still, I do not feel as though the sweet onion brioche and syrup flavor complimented the french toast at all. The hot cocoa did taste good though, fairly decent compared to everything else at the restaurant.

Although the food does not taste good and the employees seem like they are treated badly by management, the diner's decor is impressive. The only reason why I gave this restaurant​ any stars was because the employees work hard and the decor is wonderful. Very rarely do I give restaurants​ bad reviews, however, ​I feel as though this restaurant is horrible and malodorous​.

Also, I noticed that the restaurant was packed a bit, but I could guarantee that this is the type of place people come to once due to its location (since neighboring restaurants are always full- au cheval) and social media marketing, but never return. Therefore, I would not recommend this restaurant because the quality of food and service you receive​, is not worth the money you are paying at the end.

Caveat:  I can't give fraction stars so let me add that this a 3.5 Star review out of 5.  So with that let's begin.

So many goats on this strip close to the Fulton market foodie area of Chicago and knowing that Girl and the Goat would be a "no-goat" (sorry), we settled for their "diner" offering across the street of the above name.  We waited at the adjoining bar which serves up excellent cocktails and specialty sodas which my 11 year old really enjoyed.  I ordered their craft Manhattan and it was a solid effort, and so too was wifey's gin cucumber lime something or other..... I just call these drinks her "spa treatment" to which she had two!!

I've seated outside we were dutifully and pleasantly served by a busy but attentive staff that were helpful in helping us round out our menu choices.
We started with the crispy shrimp appetizer, the crab dip and the pork nachos.  See pictures. The crispy shrimp was a decent starter as the shrimp was flavorful, fresh and served with a tangy cocktail sauce.  They lost me on the crab dip..... I searched for some crab flavor or chunks of real crab (Old Bay was in there somewhere) and sadly it was a rather bland and over-emulsified mush that warranted only one bite.  I've had better crab dips out of a jar from the supermarket so here's hoping they rethink this one.

The pork nachos were huge, but they arrived tepid which means they were sitting around for a while before they got to us.  They came served atop house made flour tortilla chips which as a personal preference is not my fav as they lacked flavor but the table seemed to like them so I'd call them adequate.  As a main I ordered the signature "goat almighty" burger.  Refer to photo.  When this beast arrived I was immediately reminded of the many "Guy Fieri" food stops where he marvels at the size only to take a huge messy bite thus pleasing his masses of culinary dotards that love that sorta thing (cue eye roll).  The burger comes with three layers of meat: beef, pulled pork and goat brisket" in between a fresh bun and adorned with onion rings, cheese and jalapeños.  All this silliness aside, I enjoyed the meat combo which I paired with a light Grenache.  This is a good shareable sandwich and worthy of a photo op for you food bloggers out there.

I probably won't be back to Little Goat anytime soon as I'll keep trying Girl and the Goat or other Chicago offerings, but it was a nice enough time and their menu is expansive and interesting enough to please anyone.

Keeping it real from Parker, CO..... Robbo

pics.caption: Spacious, bustling and stylish diner vibe

review.des:
On a night of gridlocked traffic and insane wait times elsewhere, Little Goat came to the rescue! I was able to make a late reservation for 9:15 PM on a Saturday. We hadn't eaten since about noon so we were all pretty ravenous. Despite saying that I was so hungry I could eat my own arm, I barely put a dent in the huge portions that Little Goat offers.

I ordered the Fat Club minus the ham and the Tempura Mashed Potato. The ingredients of the sandwich were quality, but it was really a pretty standard deli sandwich. I couldn't taste the special sauce, so I'm not sure what it was. It is, however, large enough for two people at least. One quarter of the sandwich housed about as much meat as I put on an entire piece of bread and nearly as many toppings. You will not be hungry if you order this. The potatoes were a delight - you get two mashed potato patties dipped in batter and fried, then topped with crispy slaw and laid in a pool of asian BBQ sauce and ranch.

My boyfriend got the burger and mac and cheese (so creamy!) and his mom got the Machos Nachos. She was the clear winner among us. The house-made chips are among the best I've ever had (maybe the best?) and the twist of what we thought was cinnamon was completely unexpected and delicious. While it's listed as a snack, four people could share the plate and walk away full. I absolutely need to return to demolish* them.

*Eat part of it and then lie in the fetal position for two hours because I took five too many bites.

Service was great and I loved the upscale twist on a diner. It's relaxed like a casual greasy spoon and has the booth/counter set-up, but the color palate and detailed touches elevate it to something more.

Prices were honestly much more affordable than I anticipated with it being an affiliate of Girl and the Goat, and they're especially reasonable considering the sheer amount of food you get. The food isn't going to bowl you over in the same way as GATG, but they're more likely to be a thing you'll work into your regular rotation if you're so lucky as to live nearby.

Beautiful cozy place with great service! Food flavors are different, you can get a combination of sour and salty in one meal. They serve a local roasted coffee Dark Matter, so good coffee as well. Our friendly server Carl was very helpful explaining all the ingredients that we couldn't understand.  You'll have a great experience at this diner.

It's a great hop & skip down from Girl in the Goat so if your not in the mood for a longer wait there - skip over here. The dishes are lighter and tasty with less of a dress code. The service is on par and the drinks are quickly brought by which is wonderful. Casual and relaxing with realistically affordable prices for prime fair. Most bites taste international - lots of artwork to enjoy and big booths to stretch out in.

The wait can sometimes be a bit longer depending on the time of day - however staff will do the best to seat everyone quickly and the service comes so quickly it is not much of a bother and will give you a chance to preview the menu while you wait. Oh, Milkshakes. Get one!!!

Cute little place with friendly people! It has a nice "feel". Relaxed, yet upbeat. I love lattes so why not try one here, too!

I decided on the little goat latte-- steamed goats milk and caramel latte. YUUMMMM. Didn't know what to expect with the goats milk but it didn't taste any different, just seemed "lighter" to me, which is a plus! Would most definitely get again!

My husband ordered the Reuben and all he could do was shake his head in appreciation and acceptance of how it tasted! Ha ha!

I got the creole chicken Sammie! I expected it to be super spicy and was pleasantly surprised that it wasn't too overbearing! Toasty, plush bun...Crispy, nicely seasoned chicken and those pickled diced jalapeños were great!

And those smoked fries taste JUST LIKE river chips you get at the fair but with less crunch of course!

It was good, but not great. I liked how original everything is, like how the eggs Benedict had some spicy Asian influence to it, and the breakfast sausage was a Szechuan (?) style. The bulls eye chicken and waffles had some special syrup (I really need to start writing these right after my meals instead of waiting so long and forgetting the details).
This place gets packed, but the service is still fast and friendly. Even though I only gave 3 stars, I will definitely be going back to try them again.

Stopped by Little Goat for a late lunch/early dinner around like 3:45pm on a Saturday and the place was still busy! We got seated at the counter which was pretty nice. Vibes in here are like half diner with the counter seating and then half Santa Monica Summer House with the the booths and tables.

Started the meal off with some cocktails. I had the Spiced Pear Punch and my friend had an Old Fashioned. Cocktails were delish! The Spiced Pear Punch was tasty and boozy.

For food, I went with my tried and true diner order of All American Burger with Slagel beef and side of fries. The burger was a nice, hearty size but fry portion was skimpy (and the burger doesn't come with fries!). My friend ordered off the breakfast options (served all day) and got the Bull's Eye French Toast. I had serious food envy. The Bull's Eye French Toast is like a spin off of chicken and waffles but so much better. The chicken was crispy and every component of the dish just works with each other.

Definitely want to come back and get the Bull's Eye French Toast all to myself. Little Goat has good food and getting a reservation is much easier than some other spots in the neighborhood.

This is a nice gem on Randolph and over the span of 2 years we have visited for brunch only on 3 occasions.  Reservations are mostly recommended, although after a long 24 call in the hospital walking in on a week morning around 8am has never been an issue and we are seated quickly.
The service is so friendly and attentive I can't say enough about the front of the house - they are working their butts off and it shows they care about how we feel.  The food is top notch - playful diner food is probably the best way to capture it, with an Asian brush stroke on some dishes for which Chef Izard has come to be known.  The portions are plentiful and there is no chance you will leave hungry.  Cinnamon buns are top notch and the Elvis waffle was really tasty and rich.  This restaurant has warmed my heart and filled my belly after long nights at the hospital -- with the post meal nap inevitable and welcomed!!!

One of my favorite diners ever! Never had anything bad from this place. This was one of the most unique shrimp and grits recipes you'll ever find and it was fantastic!

We always come for breakfast and usually try to come during the week to avoid long wait times. My wife and I love all of Stephanie Izard's restaurants and her "diner" is no exception. All the dishes are familiar, but with her twist on the recipe and we always love coming back to try new dishes.

pics.caption: Shrimp and Cheesy Grits // rock shrimp, braised pistachio, grumpy goat grits

review.des: I loved the asian take on American food. I had high expectations as all I ever hear about in chicago are the goat trio. I ordered the bimbimbop bowl and was actually shocked to see It naturally came with cauliflower rice...my healthy senses were tingling. My dad was raving over the corned beef. I'd want to try everything to get a little taste of what they have to offer as a unique brunch place!

I've come here many a time. Mixed reviews.

Here's what's excellent:

1. Goat Milk Hot chocolate
2. Coffee special with lemon and sesame oil
3. Fat Elvis Waffles
4. Lox omelet special
5. Crab dip (as for cucumber slices instead of ritz crackers if you are watching your carbs)
6. Goat chilli (this is borderline exceptional)

What's not great:

1. They seat people funny. I hate it when you have a reservation at a place and you check in first and someone who came in after you gets seated before you. It's just not a good look.
2. Little piggy went to china: this dish is overdone. the flavor starts out good, but then is so intense it just about kills your tongue for the rest of the day.
3. Fat Club...The quality of sandwich meat is not great. Shouldn't a place like this be using real turkey?...also...it strangely felt like it needed mayo...the secret saucy isn't saucy enough. Also, can a lady get some fries? chips? anything on the side?

It's a short walk from my house so I will be back, but I wish they would get the little details together.

I tend to be skeptical when a popular restaurant opens up a spin-off, especially one so close by such that it almost seems to be a consolation prize for those who weren't able to get a reservation to the OG.

But we were so impressed by the Girl and the Goat, we were curious to explore Stephanie Izard's second project. The menu is brimming with character, full of cute pictures and whimsical names such as "Cereal killers" for the breakfast section.

Some fusion items (read: pork belly with scallion pancakes and bok choy salad) may sound like a hodgepodge to purists, but the Little Goat does a fine job creating a carefully orchestrated mashup of Asian influences with traditional diner food. I do wish there were more goat items, but there were enough intriguing menu choices that ordering was a difficult enough decision.

I usually do not order grilled cheese at restaurants as it's fool-proof comfort food that can't really go wrong, but the Little Goat's GRILLED CHEESE ($13) was quite exceptional. The blend of gjetost (goat cheese) and cheddar was full-bodied and unique but not overwhelming. The filling was interspersed with savory guanciale (an Italian cured meat), compounded with bacon gouda bread grilled to the perfect crisp, finished off with apple-tomato relish as a curve-ball--a little sweet and almost a teaser as homage to the Chicago deep dish. (Either that or I'm just over-interpreting my grilled cheese).

Boo is a burger fan and got the CHOP CHAE ($13) under the burger section, though there was no warning that the burger arrives deconstructed. It was more of a patty with a egg over a blend of japchae noodles, assorted Asian vegetables, and umami mayo. Though the burger patty was somewhat dry, overall I was quite impressed that they pulled off a japchae burger.

The ambiance is a modern take on the traditional diner, with neutral tones and trendy furniture replacing the traditional red bar stools and checkered patterns. Service was friendly, and the wait on a Saturday night wasn't as ridiculous as some other places around the area. Overall, I enjoyed our visit to the Little Goat, a memorable dining experience with an upscale, global interpretation of diner classics.

Little Goat was our best meal on our short trip to Chicago, making reservations ahead is a must! We didn't make ours til about 1 week out, which meant the only seating was 8:15am for our party of 5 (including our toddler). We arrived in Chicago after midnight so it was tough, but the staff was welcoming and the food didn't take long. Plus the large booths were comfy and great for a bouncy 2.75 year old ;-)

For food, I had the shrimp and grits - a bit salty, but flavorful. Very mild spice and it was very stew like. My husband had the bulls eye French toast which is a egg in the hole style with pre-chopped pieces of fried chicken breast (think the sized pieces like you'd get in a salad). I know it's messier, but with both our dishes I would have preferred shrimp in the shells and chicken on the bone. I feel like at what's considered an upscale diner they'd have large prawns perhaps or show you that the shrimp have been grilled or something. Do midwesterners prefer this style i wonder? We got waffles for my daughter, but she ended up mostly eating the dark chocolate chip pancakes my husband decided to splurge on for the table to share!

Overall it was an enjoyable meal, very grateful that friends treated us to a nice breakfast.

So MANY good things about Little Goat.

We typically visit on weekend mornings. Get there early and you'll beat the rush - this includes parking! Although Valet is available.

You'll walk in and your first impression will be that of a cute diner with just enough nostalgic throwback to give you some hipster mid-century modern feels. This is a classy place, enjoy it.

The menu holds great selections - whether you are coming in for breakfast or would rather 'brunch-it', you can opt for either your standard morning fare or dive into a burger. There's something for everyone here.

A few favorites of mine:
- This Little Piggy Went to China. If you're in for something a little different, get this. This was my inaugural dish and it blew my mind. It has a bit of heat to it and accompanied by those tongue tingling Chinese flower peppercorns. It's good.

- If you're looking for something a bit sweeter, go for the Bull's Eye French Toast. There's a lot to enjoy here with your traditional french toast but with some chicken tenders, berries and just all around good stuff. It's a perfect blend of that sweet and savory.

- THE PANCAKES. Ok, recently I've become a bit of a connoisseur of pancakes. Little Goat has this art of pancake perfected. They are sourdough and amazing. Get the blueberry for the full-effect.

There are so many other good selections... be sure to also check out the specials for those items you may not see for long. You can't go wrong with Little Goat.

Cute place in Chicago. Must try this out. It gets busy, but luckily my girlfriend and I did not have to wait long. We got seated immediately outside. Food was great, service was good and everything else in between. Parking is available as well as valet.

Omg!!! Absolute deliciousness!!! I had
This little piggy went to China, it was an explosion in my mouth of delicious flavors! Will travel to Chicago from Miami again.

We had a reservation for 4:30pm and only had to wait about 10 minutes to get seated. Theres a cute little photo booth that kept us entertained while we waited. Our server wasn't the friendliest of people which is probably why my 4 stars isn't a 5 stars. I'm all about customer service and our server was very short and didn't seem like she wanted to be there. Also probably because my Hemingway tasted mostly like grapefruit juice and not enough rum, but i'll excuse that for now. Let's move on to the food though. The goat chili cheese fries were my favorite thing ever. The fries are shoestring so they have the perfect crunch to them, and the goat cheese tasted so good with their chili. I ordered the bimbimbap and it was tasty. The fried chicken sandwich is bomb and has a spicy twist to it. Overall, it was a cute little upscale diner with a lively vibe that serves breakfast all day, which is pretty AWESOME. The logo is also the cutest thing ever. I definitely liked the Girl and the Goat way better, but this place is good too if you're looking for a casual Chicago experience.

pics.caption: The fried chicken sandwich, super good and has a hint of spice
My bimbimbap with sunny side up egg
The reuben, the kimchi really makes the flavors pop

review.des: We made a reservation so I'm not sure how long the regular wait would be. Looking at the menu I was a little apprehensive because the asian/ American diner fusion are so vastly different I didn't know if it was actually tasty or overhyped for its creativity/being the little sister of the Bib Gourmand rated restaurant The Girl & The Goat.  The Hot Crab Dip is popular so we got that as the appetizer, and the Shrimp and Pork Belly entree. Both were superb. We got these foods because we came for dinner but definitely would like to try their breakfast/other menu items- but based on my experience I think all of their food will be yummy despite how it might read on paper. Service was awesome too! Truly a 5 star experience.

It's unique flavors and Asian infusion were delicious. I ordered the little piggy that went to China and we also got the French toast and pork belly fries. I loved the twist on every day brunch items.

Not only is the service great, but the best cinnamon roll in the planet is baked at this place.  I have never and I dare to say that I will never have a better cinnamon roll than this one.  I swear I would come back to Chicago just for this!  A must do!

Great food, great vibe, super relaxed and casual. We enjoyed some of their unique takes on traditional dishes... like their scallion pancake. My husband absolutely loved that dish so much, and will come back just to eat it. The machos nachos were basically hardcore and so super crunchy and delicious, and the fatoush salad was flavorful and filling.

But people, we must talk about something really important here -- the choco taco. Let's talk about how I haven't had a choco taco in over a decade due to food allergies, and how the choco taco they have here is a) gluten-free, and b) A-M-A-Z-I-N-G! It's the little things in life that bring the simplest of pleasures, and this choco taco is no joke. You MUST order it!

All in we ordered two drinks, and appetizer, two entrees, smoked fries, and a dessert and the bill was wayyyyyyyyy reasonable. So basically we had an amazing meal at an amazing price. Can't beat that! (Oh, and we had leftovers. I call that a WIN!)

Ended up here cause the other goat across the street had no table for us

The diner was like no other. Every item on the menu was uniquely crafted. Can not recommend the crab dip enough. Very friendly staff as well.
Very good beer selection.

I love their sister restaurant, Girl and the Goat, so I was looking forward to trying out the diner. All things considered, I really liked my experience here.

The only negative is that everything was super salty. This may be down to my own personal taste but the other person I was with also agreed that my meal was very salty.

I had the patty melt and goat chilli cheese fries. Both looked great and tasted great but as mentioned above, was incredibly salty. I couldn't finish my meal on this occasion but I've heard great things about this place and will definitely come back to see if this was just an off night for them. I refuse to believe that so many people were wrong about this place being great lol!

Besides the excessive salt: Great location. Great ambience. Friendly staff.

Definitely worth a go if you're in the area :)

I was very excited to try this restaurant, and I wanted to try all the things so I skipped breakfast before heading to a 12:15 lunch reservation.

When I arrived at 12:03, the place was clearly bustling and had an hour and 25min wait. Definitely expecting to wait until at least the reservation, I began to grow crotchety when the clock ticked to past 12:25 and we had not yet been sat. We finally received our table by 12:30 but proceeded to wait for a server to come to our table until almost 12:40. Luckily, my dining partner and I already knew exactly what we planned to eat and drink, so we ordered it all in one shot (pre-research is a crucial tactic).

Our server was actually awesome, very kind and approachable, and she brought out our food in about 15 minutes.

I ordered the Everything is Everything Crumpets, which was...Everything. It was a unique take on bagels and lox but the use of crumpets (a much softer breakfast bread) made it much easier to pile on all of the provided toppings.

I also ordered a side of the pork belly homefried which were incredibly rich, but excellently fatty.

Overall, the food was amazing even though the service was slow. Once we initially made contact with our server, though, the experience kept getting better from there.

Little Goat is the restaurant I've been to the most in the West Loop. I have it in my rotation of places I take friends that visit from out of town. I've been going here for years and I've only tried a small portion of the menu. My favorites include the biscuit. I'm from the south and I have very high standards for biscuits and it took me a while to find a place that I thought did them well. My other favorites are the machos nachos, fish tostadas, and dark chocolate chip crunch pancakes.

What I appreciate about the restaurant is how accommodating they can be about some of the dishes. I went with a friend with a lot of dietary restrictions and they were really great about accommodating her needs even if it meant giving us a build your own nachos!

The only thing that I've had that wouldn't get again were the mash potato balls but I don't think they even have that anymore. The food can be heavy so come hungry and it great for sharing with friends! They've also got an extensive vegetarian menu.

Excellent food. Nice service.

Their smoked french fries? Gift from God.

Be prepared for a wait if you don't have a reservation.

I had a great breakfast here. They cater to gluten free diets and dairy free. They have completely different menus for this purpose. I had the hash with corned beef. The way they shred the potatoes are so delicate and thin. We also had the summer squash. It had a wonderful texture and was topped with puffed rice. Anna was a wonderful waitress. She gave recommendation and great explanations of the meal.

pics.caption: Smoked Corned Beef Hash with Eggs

review.des:
Great affordable option near Girl & the goat!

Omelette and goat patty melt were both so good!!!

It's a loud place, but great food and location. They have a pretty extensive gluten free menu.

Walk to the Allis for a drink or to dessert at BomboBar.

The little goat has a very large and extensive menu and all the options couldn't be more different. I tried the okanomyaki and hated it (unfortunately) ... the pancake itself was good but didn't like the sauces or taste. My mom had the little pig went to China and that was amazing, and the cinnamon roll was amazing, so I just think that it really depends on what you like and what you order. They still get a 4 for great service and an inventive menu

pics.caption: The This Little Piggy Went To China

review.des:
Go here. Now. Go again and again and again. Eat all of your meals here in one day.  I am so sad I no longer live in Chicago, even sadder that I could have been within walking distance of this amazing place.  I expected it to be good, I was unprepared for how freaking incredible it was!

Get the goat chili cheese fries! Holy mother of god you will not be disappointed.  They're pretty much everything that is right in this world. The bahn mi burger jumped out at me and I decided to go with it.  Delicious! The textures and flavors and freshness. Everything was perfection.  My companion has the fish tostadas and she she kindly shared - wow! Very good.

I want to go back.  I want to pack up my family and move back to Chicago so this can be our go to spot.  

Also, our server - Marlene (I think!) - she's fantastic!

pics.caption: Goat chili cheese fries.  You want these - you have no idea how much you need these in your life.
My awesome friend insisted I have one if her fish tostadas - you get three! Super generous portion.
The incredible bahn mi burger with beef.

review.des:
Ok seriously, the hype is real and warranted!!

Most of my 5 star reviews are for hole in the wall places, but Little Goat Diner is super popular and not extremely cheap and still warrants 5 stars based on the food alone. I ordered the bullseye toast and it was seriously the most delicious thing I've ever eaten for brunch - the fried chicken was perfect, and I usually find breakfast fried chicken too greasy or fried. This chicken was cut in bite-sized chunks and battered in a very flavorful and semi-sweet batter. The toast itself was perfection, as was of course the runny egg in the middle!

We also ordered hash browns for the table, which were a perfect crispy consistency and the cheese was merged into the dish perfectly. My dining partners ordered the chocolate pancake and the...dish with smoked salmon I forget what it was called...and they both heartily enjoyed their dishes as well as their coffees with goat milk.

Additional star for how cute the restaurant is, being able to make reservations easily on OpenTable, and for the wonderful service. A must try in the Goat Trifecta!

It takes a lot to earn a 5-star review from me, but this place is well deserving. Stephanie Izard is one of my favorite Top Chef contestants, so we had to try this out on my recent trip to Chicago. It truly is a legit, 50's style diner, but with an elevated menu.

I had the Crispy Creole Chicken Sandwich with smoked fries. The sandwich was very crispy with a house-made bun. Delicious. The smoked fries reminded me of the old-school diner fries. We also had the french toast, which was on sweet onion brioche bread, smothered in chicken and strawberries. Completely blown away.

This place did not let us down. Unlike some of the other places we visited in Chicago, the staff here was extremely friendly, with quick service. Highly recommended.

The Not Chinese Broccoli (AKA regular broccoli with szechuan vinaigrette. sesame. peanuts) was  perfectly charred  and tasty! (It was everything last nights mushy cauliflower at a different restaurant wasn't -- so much so that i told the server they redeemed charred veggies for me!)

Pork belly and chive pancake (scallion pancake. house hoisin. bok choy salad. ginger maple dressing) was amazing - and huge portion with slaw and Asian crunchies over the top. Especially great at only $13!

Flavors exploding in both meals in the best way!

Against my better judgement, i stuffed a small rhubarb-strawberry pie (literally an entire 6" pie!) my pie-hole, and rolled myself back onto the El to go back to my hotel, totally stuffed and totally happy.

Cute modern-Dine interior with a pleasant buzzy loudness

My friendly waiter was unobtrusive but great bringing drink refills and clearing plates efficiently.

A very pleasant, delicious, fun place to eat!
This place is my favorite of the three! Their sandwiches are awesome. The drinks amazing. The mezcal one was awesome. Fries taste as if smoked

Loved this place!

Hit this spot for brunch with my friend and really enjoyed it. The food was good, the service great and fast, and the atmosphere was great. I would've given 5 stars, but I'm not feening to go back and have another brunch there - food was good, not great. Still, I definitely recommend for a fun brunch.

3 experience. Rounding up to 3.5 because of service, and also because you're paying for creative dishes.

Pro tip 1: they serve brunch all day! Love that option.
Pro tip 2: I think you can actually reserve seats ahead of time through the Yelp app! Or was it their website? Regardless, that is in option if you come here with a large group!
Pro tip 3: they have a coffee shop right next door! It's also owned by them, with a bar seating.

My +1 and I only waited about 5 minutes before we were seated. Mind you, we came on a weekday around 12 PM. It was pretty packed, but turn over is quick!

We ordered:
1. Bulls Eye French Toast: egg, crispy chicken, sweet onion brioche, bbq maple syrup ($16) //
+1 why is it called Bulls Eye? Because when you slice into it, you hit the jackpot: yolky egg!
+1 Liked the maple syrup- had a good balance of bbq in it to balance our savory and sweet.
-1 Bread was a bit too soggy for my liking. Not your typical french toast texture.
-1 Pretty small portion for how much it costed.

2. This Little Piggy Went to China: sesame cheddar biscuit, sunny side eggs, szechuan pork sausage, chili garlic chive sauce, gooseberries ($14) //
+1 I love the chili garlic chive sauce! To be honest, it tastes like something you can get at 99 ranch from the jars...
+1 Liked the biscuit!
-1 Sausage did not taste that great. Tasted like the lean sausage from Lou Malnati's.
-1 What gooseberries?

Overall,
+1 Great presentation
+1 Good service
+1 creative dishes
+1 nice ambiance

-1 Pretty pricey
-1 Small portions

Give it a try if you are craving brunch!

pics.caption: This little piggy went to china

review.des: First of all, the decor and atmosphere is so perfect. I love the vibe of this diner! My group sat at a shared table with no wait, but the place was so packed. There are so many options on the menu and coming here for a late lunch, we were starving. My family ordered The Fat Club, The Tonkatsu, and the Goat Chili. Everything was so delicious and the portion sizes are huge. As busy as it as, the service was still excellent. We never had to wait for anyone to come to our table. I would highly recommend paying a visit to Little Goat Diner. You won't leave hungry or unsatisfied.

After having such a good meal at girl&the goat the night before, I was so excited to try little goat diner.  I ordered the "little piggy went to china" and really did not like it.  The szechuan flavor just did not match with breakfast food.  I felt like I was eating dumplings.  

My friend's foods were also not that great.  The only thing that was good and was the mac&cheese.

Fluffy pancakes drizzled with yummy granola. I LOVE their oatmeal too. and their granola and yogurt with compote are all homemade. I love this place. I like to come mid-day on a weekday for a brunch on my own and get work done at their counter and watch the geniuses at work! I've even seen Stephanie there a couple times. (She offered some water to my dog, super sweet). Love this place over and over again!

After eating at the Girl and The Goat last weekend (spoiler, we loved it!) we decided to venture to Little Goat Dinner.  Although a different atmosphere, they still offer quality food. It was very busy on a Saturday afternoon so we waited for about 40 mins to sit at the counter. I actually really enjoyed the counter seating because we got to see all the awesome food as it was coming out.  FYI- didn't order them, but Nachos looked amazing. Will be ordering them next time.

Service was super friendly as I have to come to expect from these restaurants. We ordered the Goat Chili Cheese Fries to start. They were sooo good- in fact I ate way too many of them before my main meal. I then ordered the Grilled Cheese and my hubs had the Okonomiyaki we think (more on that later).

The Grilled Cheese was good, but I've had better. It was super flavorful but was missing the cheese overload I was looking for (I really like cheese, hence the cheese fries earlier). If you're meh on cheese, this might be the right one for you. My husband ordered the Okonomiyaki and liked it, but I'm not sure that is what he actually ate. The man next to me ordered the same thing and it looked similar to my husbands meal but not the same ( I wasn't able to give a full inspection as I'd have liked as the man seemed apprehensive about me staring at his food).  His had meat on it. My husband's had no meat but had an egg on it.  Not sure which one was correct, but whatever he ate, it was good.

I would certainly come back here but next time I will make a reservation and wear stretchier pants.

I chose Little Goat Diner for my birthday dinner this year, and it was great. Our server was genuinely friendly and gave great recommendations.

If I had to recommend one item on the menu it would be the tempura mashed potatoes. Order them. Actually, order multiple orders, and you'll still want more. The batter used was flavorful and perfectly crisp, and the pickled slaw garnish was a perfect compliment in both flavor and texture.

My daughter ordered the nachos. Little Goat makes their own masa chips, and they are really, really good. Probably some of the best nacho chips I've ever had.

Others at the table ordered the scallion pancake with pork belly, the side of Mac and cheese, and the pork gotta. Everyone was very happy.

I ordered the bullseye french toast, and to be honest, it was the only item on the table that I was disappointed with. Really good french toast should have a slightly brûléed texture and flavor, but this dish was just soggy. I only ate part of one piece. Kind of a bummer when you have high hopes for your own birthday dinner.

Because it was my birthday, our server brought out a mini vanilla milkshake with a candle. It was enough for everyone at my table to have a couple of bites. Very festive and very tasty.

pics.caption: Nachos with no peppers or onions, because kids.

review.des:
Came here on a Sunday at around 7pm and there was no wait. We were seated by the counter in front of the kitchen which was pretty loud and unpleasant but it was reasonable.  The service was great. The waitress was attentive and helpful.  We ordered the pork belly fries, los drowned and the kilgus goat patty melt.  The two sandwich were delicious and a unique twisted on the classics.  The pork belly fries was a tad too salty for my liking.  

I liked the atmosphere, upscale dinner, and the bathrooms were clean.

I need to come back and try out their breakfast foods!

pics.caption: Goat patty melt $13 really liked the sweetness the pickles added really delicious!
Los drowned $14 really delicious braised beef!

review.des:
This place had gotten so much hype, that I HAD to try it. Most of the time, when people hype up a place, I leave a little disappointed...but not Little Goat! This place was outstanding! On a Friday afternoon, this place was PACKED. 1.5 hour wait list and all. Thankfully my husband, myself, and mom were able to scoop a few bar seats and eat there.

The menu is diverse and has something for  everyone. We started with the crab dip that was out of this world! Real crab meat, cheesy, and hot..what more could you ask for? I got the Apple cinnamon pancakes that were delicious and well-priced! I even took home leftovers (anyone who knows me knows that never happens). Everyone raves about the hashbrowns but to be honest I didn't like them. They had a weird oily aftertaste, but everyone else was on the bandwagon.

The pastries look so delicious, but we resisted. We were so stuffed!

Can't wait to go back! Next time we will make a reservation...

I came here during a trip to Chicago the food is really good and unique! You will find combinations here unlike anything else you have tried.  Definitely recommend.

We started with the fried pickles and onion rings and they were battered to perfection and not overly oily.

I got a burger that I cant seem to remember the name of it tasted like a Vietnamese sandwich pretty good!

pics.caption: Vietnamese style burger.  (don't remember the name).

review.des: Beautiful space and always amazing hospitality. Separate vegan menu with so many wonderful options so that every time I come here I can order something different instead of 'the one vegan option.'

Awesome tastes, super busy but the wait was reasonable. The 20 min promise, however, was at least 30 min, and at least 1 hr and 20 min from walking in til the time food was in front of us. (-1 star for lack of order/information around seating times.)
The portions are generous. I saw many couples splitting food. The two of us got a goat burger (no bun, nice lettuce) fried chicken (surprisingly good! Recommended by wine spectator they said?) and a bowl of goat chili and took home 2 small meals worth.  I got their drink special of cinnamon and masala, one only, and it was small but potent. My son said he could still smell the spice on me the next morning!  The food was just really, really good. Definitely would be happy to go again.

pics.caption: Goat burger, no bun, chicken. Creative & generous use of slivers of fried onion.Goat chili perfectly balanced,great flavor garnishes

review.des:
Food: 3/5
Service: 4/5
Ambiance: 3.5/5
Overall: Id give it another chance to try some other dishes but I wasn't overly impressed my first time here.

The extended review...

Food:

Fat Elvis waffles - As I read this on the menu it was the toppings that make It appealing.  The actual dish itself though was a little disappointing.  The waffles were a little bit soft...I tend to like them crispier.  The toppings made the dish really sweet which usually I am for but I think it was more sweet than I expected.

Mocha cake - the cake was ok.  Fairly moist and the frosting was fairly light.  After eating the waffles might not have been a good idea since I was overloaded with sugar that point.  

Service: friendly and attentive service.

Ambiance: very casual and very busy!  Be sure to expect a wait when you go for brunch.

pics.caption: Fat Elvis waffles - not as crispy as I would have liked

review.des: The bomb Bull's Eye French Toast version of chicken & waffles was mouth-wateringly great! All the flavors went delish! No runny eggs for me. Great service & well-lit space! Bustling for weekday lunch. Great!

pics.caption: The bomb Bull's Eye French Toast version of chicken & waffles was mouth-wateringly great! All the flavors went delish! No runny eggs for me.

review.des: After waiting an hour (I completely understand they're a popular restaurant so I didn't mind the wait so much), my friend and I were finally seated. I felt so bad for the waitstaff because it was obvious they were feeling very swamped. They were so incredibly friendly and nice, but the dining experience was horrible. It was so incredibly hot in the restaurant that the hosts had to walk around and fan people with menus to keep all the patrons cool. On top of that, by the time we got our food, my friend and I were starving but we still didn't finish our food because it was mediocre at best. My meal was so salty that I felt sick eating it, especially in such a hot restaurant.

When it comes to diner menu creativity, Little Goat Diner really thinks outside the box. Here you'll find a variety of classic diner foods with a twist. They incorporate unique elements from around the world into classic American diner items. I tried the paratha burrito and the bulls eye French toast. Both were excellent and very substantial.

The Paratha burrito is a great vegetarian option. The "burrito" has egg inside and it's topped with a mixture of leafy greens, smashed avocado and beans. The orange sauce ties all the flavors together nicely.

The bulls eye French toast really hits the spot for a completely indulgent meal. The French toast is wonderfully moist, soaked in sweet syrup and has an egg at the very center. As if that's not rich enough on its own, It's topped with pieces of fried chicken.

I also tried their LIttle Goat latte, which is made with goat milk. It was my first time having a goat milk latte and I absolutely loved it. It's very creamy and has an earthy, natural saltiness to it.

The space is really nice inside, feels very spacious and modern. It makes for a great spot to come with friends and family if you're looking to kick your breakfast/brunch/breakfast-all-day game up a notch. The prices here are higher than average diner places.

Came with a few friends for brunch and was very impressed. Not only did all the food look great, but it tasted great too! The menu was super unique and had lots of options I wanted to try. Friends ordered the fried chicken sandwich, los drowned, everything crumpets and cinnamon roll. I had the pork belly pancake and it was amazing - flavors and textures were all on point. The pork belly was juicy, coleslaw was crunchy, scallion pancake was soft inside and crispy outside and packed with flavor. Will definitely return next time I'm in Chicago!

pics.caption: Fried chicken sandwich and everything everything crumpets
Cinnamon roll - haha already ready to dig in. They waited so I could snap a pic.

review.des:
The Little Goat Diner does not disappoint. Chef Izard created this great place that has awesome interpretations of great diner foods.

The decor was awesome. Very diner-chic. The staff here is really fun and they tell you truth about heir favorite items on the menu instead of saying, "I love everything."

The fun thing to check out is the bar and bakery right next door. They sell seasonings, marinades and sauces as well as yummy pastries. Love this place.

This place is intense! I do not remember feeling so unhealthy after my Girl & the Goat meal... But, hey, sometimes you just gotta go all out, and this is the place to do it. I came with my boyfriend and ordered the veggie burger "American" style (cheddar, lettuce, tomato, special sauce, onion, brioche bun). He ordered the fried chicken with a biscuit and PQM bacon on the side (Can you tell how healthy he is?) We shared the mac and cheese to start and finished the meal with a slice of rhubarb pie a la mode. My boyfriend is crazy because when we first ordered he said, "You should get fries with your burger because it doesn't come with any." But I knew better and I told him to chill. I'm glad I stuck with my guns because food coma does not even begin to cover how you feel leaving this place... That said, wonderful service and this place is also very family friendly!

pics.caption: Fried chicken (biscuit optional) - my boyfriend asked for syrup to put on his

review.des:
This is more of a 3.5 stars review.

I came here because the girl and the goat had a super long wait. It was a Wednesday evening and there was a decent amount of people already inside, but my party of 5 only had to wait about 15/20 minutes for our table which was pretty awesome.

I liked that they still had brunch/breakfast items to serve. I saw that this place is pretty big on brunch, so to have that still available late in the night was exciting. Of course, I didn't try that but instead tried the pork torta sandwich. Which was all right. I mean it tasted good but it was really messy to eat. I noticed that my friend who had the tonkatsu sandwich had the same problem. The tonkatsu on the other hand was oddly sour and not very satisfying to eat. I guess I should have expected that since that was more of a "fusion" item on the menu.

The fries on the other hand were really good! The portions are large too so you won't go home hungry. The waitress and the rest of the staff were really attentive and helpful as well. Maybe if I'm in chicago again, I'll come back for brunch.

I came to this spot after having tried Girl and the Goat the night before. They are owned by the same chef and are across the street from each other.

The menu offers dishes for the adventurous palate (but also has "safer" options as well). They offer classic dishes with their own twist, such as chicken and french toast instead of waffles, or the sloppy goat and goat chili. It's also more affordable than Girl and the Goat and portions seem more generous.

I personally ordered the okonomiyaki, a Japanese savory pancake with pork belly, topped with an egg and drizzled with sauces similar to what you'd find on takoyaki. Pancake itself was so soft and burst with flavors. I also tried my mom's dish, This Little Piggy Went to China. It reminded me of an Asian inspired eggs benedict. It's a bit on the salty side, but I love salty so fine by me.

Great customer service from our waitress, who had such an upbeat energy and answered all our questions. Would definitely recommend this spot to anyone.

Warning, I did not really order a meal here but we stopped on a Sunday while waiting for a table at Au Cheval.  We sat outside and had a few drinks, mules was good, and their fried pickles and onions rings.  The batter was tempura like, but unfortunately it was mostly batter so the pickle and onion taste got lost.

Peanut butter-butter for the banana waffles is a must. You will melt in your seat that's how amazing they are. Giving 4 stars because the other two dishes we ordered were good but didnt blow me away like the waffles did.

Came here for brunch on my birthday and was absolutely wowed - great experience from start to finish.

First off, their coffee was delicious. As I was sipping my cold brew, they brought out an absolutely DELICIOUS cinnamon bun with a candle in it. Adorable, so good.

I had the "this little piggy went to China" brunch dish and oh my lord was it good. Perfect mix of sweet, salty, savory, tangy. Super filling, but didn't leave me feeling like I needed to be rolled out of the restaurant.

Also stole some of my boyfriends pork belly home fries -- awesome. Should have stolen more.

This place is great- go go go if you're in the area. Make a reservation first, as they were pretty crowded on a Thursday around 1 pm, so I imagine they're crazy on weekends.

pics.caption: This little piggy went to China

review.des:
This is my second time to Little Goat and it was good.

First, the drinks that we ordered were tasty and refreshing (melon? Spritzer and a grapefruit mimosa). The mimosa was a little small but still good.

Next, my friend and I split the breakfast burrito and the goat Almighty burger. The burrito was excellent; it had a great sauce, greens, eggs, and a lovely wrap that was more like a fold over than a burrito. It was a good mix of salty and a little sour. Would love to get it again. Next, while the goat almighty looked impressive and sounded delicious, it was sort of a disappointment. There are 3 different meats (beef, pulled pork, goat patty) and onion rings + pickles, cheese, and sauces. In theory it should've been incredible but it was honestly overwhelming and sort of impossible to eat. The only way was to deconstruct the burger and at that point it was just like eating different meats. The flavors weren't as great as other items on the menu and it didn't meet my expectations.

Lastly, our server was great, friendly, and I have no complaints there.

Overall a great restaurant I'd go to again but definitely was let down by that burger.

I've done it -- I've completed the "Goat" trifecta and Little Goat was my last stop. All 3 of Izard's restaurants are impeccable. From the service, to the decor, to the menu, it's an all-encompassing sensory experience.

We were able to get a reservation day-of on a Sunday for dinner. I had no idea this was possible with any of the Goat restaurants and I'm so pleased that it is.

For starters, Little Goat is adorable. The logo, the lighting, the offset bar. I love it. The service is amazing: attentive hosts, bartenders, and waitstaff. 10/10 and this is before the food even gets here.

This menu is a little intimidating. I highly recommend checking it out before going so you have an idea of what you want to get. It's a breakfast-all-day type of place, but there's also an incredible lunch/dinner menu.

We started with the goat chili cheese fries and boy, they were RICH. Perfectly crispy fries, drenched in a creamy cheese sauce with chunks of goat hiding under every fry. Beans, tomatoes, and chickpeas complete the goat chili topping to these fries. Absolutely order these - but prepare to be full before your entree arrives.

For my main course I went with the Sloppy Goat. This is one incredible sandwich. The bread is perfect: fluffy on the inside, crunchy on the outside, and toasted to golden perfection. The goat itself is drenched in a sauce that I don't know how to describe besides TASTY. The real star of this dish is the rosemary slaw. This may seem crazy, but believe me. This slaw completes the dish. I want to eat this slaw every day. It's crunchy, creamy, refreshing. I had to leave a few bites just to take home so I can eat it again.

My friends ordered the Los Drowned, the grilled cheese with apple tomato soup, and the Goat Almighty. It all looked delicious. One thing I'll say is that the Goat Almighty is a beast of a dish. It should come with a warning on the menu (or from your waiter!!!).

Sadly we did not order a dessert - next time!

Of all the Goat restaurants, Little Goat absolutely puts up a fight against Girl and the Goat and Duck Duck Goat. At around $13 per main dish, Little Goat is perfectly reasonable to go to without needing a reason to go.
Great place for brunch! Laid back, cute inside, big menu. The food is pretty decent. There are lots of choices. Nothing was super memorable, but just solid good food.

This place was great we only had a 25 minute wait when they quoted 35-45 on a Saturday around 2:00pm. Our server immediately recommended her favs since it was our first time we ordered the root beer float, tempura mashed potatoes, cheeseburger, patty melt and the los drowned. All were a little messy, but full of flavor and finger licking good. Big portions make everything perfect for sharing.

pics.caption: This butterscotch root beer is amazing!

review.des:
Without a doubt one of my favorite brunch places ever. As one would expect from one of Stephanie Izard's brainchildren, you won't find the dishes here anywhere else. Ingredients you would've never expected to go together are harmoniously combined to form dishes that are nothing less than exquisite.

Service is always great and the servers provide excellent suggestions and descriptions of each dish. The decor perfectly complements the food and the room warms up (not temperature-wise) when the sun's out thanks to the large windows enclosing the atrium, both on the side of the building and in the ceiling.

Naturally, given the popularity, you'll inevitably be faced with a wait, but it's well worth it. They'll text you, so you can use the time to wander to a nearby consignment store (as I've done) or explore the surrounding dining haven to figure out what your next meal is going to be.

Came here for breakfast off a rec from many other friends who had traveled the area.

Was here early right when they opened so that I could get a quick start to my day.

Server was super sweet and attentive. I ordered the okonomiyaki and has browns. Serving size is huuuuuuge. If you're eating solo - like I was - you'll be stuff before you get halfway through any of your dishes. The okonomiyaki was delicious - crispy when needed and soft when appropriate. The waitress gave me an array of hot sauces to try (I can't remember them now because it was so long ago) but they were both amazing and complimented the dish well. Hash browns were cooked to perfection and so crunchy.

Definitely would recommend to anyone trying to get a fulfilling breakfast with a twist.

What a fun and delicious place for dinner. Wait staff was excellent, fast and friendly. We opted for one waiter favorite and one off the fly last minute pick. Both ended up flavorful, great presentation and mouth watering. I hope to be back in the near future to try some more.

This was the best plate of nachos in all of the worlds existence. I can't even begin to describe all the different ways you could form a nacho and each one was equally as delicious. The 6 of us shared this and spoiled our lunch.

It was so worth it.

This is definitely one of my top 3 favorite brunch places in Chicago!

The atmosphere is really cute and fun, and the service is both friendly and fast.

The menu is super unique, with everything from bacon maple syrup to parathas to curried cauliflower.

I've had the dark chocolate crunch pancakes which were so good. The perfect amount of decadent! I've also had the parathas burrito, which sounds like a really random combination when you read the description, but is actually incredible.

Can't wait to come back and try more! The only thing I haven't liked on the menu is the hash browns. They were too crunchy and not super flavorful.

Solid spot for the first food stop on my Chicago trip.

My friend and I came around 9 am on a Saturday after arriving early on a red eye, and the wait for two was around 10 minutes. There is both indoor and outdoor seating, and when you check in, you can specify which area you prefer.

We ended up getting seated outside which was fine as it was a fine summer day outside in early Sep. I was super excited when I saw the smoked corned beef hash with eggs ($14) on their brunch menu, as that's my go-to brunch dish. My friend ordered the parathas burrito ($13) as he had never seen anything like it before and was curious about it. We also ordered a side of hash browns ($6) as I had seen multiple glowing reviews about it on Yelp.

The corned beef hash was different from any hash I've had in the past. The hash was long and stringy and was mixed with many individual slices of corned beef. You can see better in my pictures what the dish looks like. What took me by surprise, though, is that the portion size was HUGE. Maybe it's because I live in San Francisco, but I swear I've never been served such a large amount of corned beef hash before. I was already full at the halfway mark and it was a struggle to finish as much as I could since I couldn't take away leftovers.

My friend's paratha burrito was...interesting. We both expected it to come rolled up in typical burrito style, but it was more like an open faced sandwich with all the ingredients on top of the paratha. He ate it with a fork and knife and said it was only okay taste-wise.

Our side order of hash browns arrived halfway into the meal, and I was dismayed to see the ginormous size of the dish. It definitely could have been a main meal for someone if they didn't mind only eating potatoes for brunch. Again the potatoes are cut into long strings, which seems to be the norm here. We both ate a couple bites of it to try it out, and while it was pretty amazing, that's all we could manage.

Service was a bit slow, but as we weren't in a rush, we were content to soak in the Chicago sun and enjoy our juice and coffee.

pics.caption: Corned beef and hash with eggs ($14)

review.des: Finding this place as one of the most famous places to visit we had to try it. It's an interesting place with a different and unique menu. They did a wonderful job with the decor and ambiance. The food was different but good! The little piggy went to china had a very unique combination but a good taste after all. The service was great and friendly. For sure a place to try if you are in the area.

pics.caption: The little piggy went to china

review.des: The goat concept of this diner is adorable. We came here for dinner and I got the infamous pork and shrimp pasta which turned out to be delicious. Apparently this is seasonal, and I truly enjoyed it. The portions are generous, I took it home and it was still good the following morning. For appetizer, we had a hot crab dip, which I found rather creamy. It reminded me of an artichoke dip - kinda creamy. Otherwise it was good. So, I asked if we were missing out on not ordering a goat- and apparently we weren't. So I didn't feel terrible.

pics.caption: Hot crab dip w/ cream cheese and goat cheese + ritz crackers

review.des:
Was visiting Chicago and decided to wait for a table at this location instead of the popular the girl and the goat, which seemed impossible to get into without a reservation. Fare warning - this was also quite busy. We did go on a Friday night and it was about a 1.5 hour wait for 2.  We waited at the bar but got lucky and found 2 open seats 20 minutes later and ended up sitting the bar and ate there. We ordered Mac and cheese, fish tostadas, and the goat almighty without pork.

Mac and cheese - was good but your basic Mac and cheese.  Nothing special but was still good i felt you're craving some.

Fish tostadas- excellent! The chickpea salad was a great twist to a tostada dish and the white fish was fresh. It was a very flavorful and filling option. Came with 3 pcs.

Goat almighty- i don't eat pork so I ordered without. It comes with goat meat and beef. And onions and it's huge. there's a lot going on. I barely finished half of it. With that said, I did have the first two options while waiting for the burger. But the meats were tender and delicious. The sauces were so good and went well with the meats. I ended up eating it with a fork and left the bread because it just was difficult to eat as a burger. Defiantly worth trying out - share!

The Moscow Goat was like the classic mule with a grapefruit twist - it's a tart and light pink girly drink that punches you in the face.

The pork belly home fries we ordered were super crispy on the outside yet creamy on the inside. The pork belly itself was kind of like thick cut bacon, but with an incredible crunchy texture - I wish they were more generous with their portions! The whole pile was drizzled with tangy, creamy mayo and garnished with parsley and sliced banana peppers.

This chic diner is perfect for basic bitches like myself. The interior is decorated just like a diner, but with a clean, modern twist. There are huge, comically round low intensity light bulbs hanging everywhere. Towards one end there's a large counter where you can see all of the commotion going on in the kitchen. Fat mirror columns add more natural light to the restaurant on a cloudy day such as when we visited, and not-your-grandma's flower patterned wallpaper gives the whole place a girly, Instagram-worthy touch. There's also a rooftop!

We had to wait 45 minutes on a Saturday to enjoy lunch, but we made the most of it by walking around in the meantime.

pics.caption: Pork belly home fries and the Moscow Goat!

review.des: My second time at this joint, and the Parathas Burrito (under the Cereal Killers section) blew me away. I wasn't expecting the fresh salad mound on top, and it was so full of flavor. Big size, too! The beer selection wasn't very extensive, lacking in the darker beers with a single stout, but the other cocktails looked nice. I've also had the Goat Chili, and that was a nice side if you're looking to really fill up. So many exciting and unique menu items, kudos to Chef Izard!

Where do I even begin?! When I reminisce about my experience here I get the warm fuzzies inside. Ok on to the real reason your reading my review...

Short version- sit at the bar. Anything you order will blow your mind. Service was fantastic.

Actual deets-

What we had: my boyfriend ordered the tonkatsu sandwich- basically the asian inspired version of a pork tenderloin sandwich. It was huge, but absolutely amazing. Would definitely get again and again. I had the reuben. Reuben's are not my normal go to but I saw them keep coming out of the kitchen and they looked phenomenal, so I thought what the heck. I am so glad i did. Bread was crunchy, corned beef was super flavorful, great amount of sauce and house sauerkraut. What more could you ask for? Also, if you order ANYTHING you MUST order the tempura fried mashed potatoes. I'm pretty sure I don't have to tell you why...

Why sit at the bar? Because you get a first hand look at everything everyone else is ordering. I always want to know what the food looks like before I order, so this was a definite perk.

End of story.... go here and you won't be disappointed!

I am a huge fan of Little Goat and came here a ton when it first opened as Stephanie Izard is one of my favorite Chicago chefs, never realized I never wrote a review -- but I've tried plenty of the items such as the brendade and pork belly, bull's eye french toast, crab dip, chili, sloppy goat and many others (that may have since rotated off the menu?). I love the atmosphere of this place, a very friendly diner, very approachable and casual. Sometimes there's a wait, but usually it's bearable as they have a lot of seating.

Their foods often have an Asian twist which I like, and I like how they have a lot of sweet and savory dishes, my personal favorite of the bunch is bull's eye french toast, it's perfectly soft and has strawberries on it. The crab dip is a great comfort food as well, it's not too salty and gets really addicting at first bite. Little Goat's chili is very good as well and its found in various dishes, I'm not a huge fan of chili but it's strong tasting and delicious. I haven't been here for a while, but definitely want to come back to try some of the new dishes on the menu!

I absolutely love this restaurant- it's a new staple for when I visit Chicago. The menu is delicious, and the waitstaff are knowledgeable and helpful with the menu. We ordered the fish tostadas and the Reuben- both were absolutely delicious. The Reuben was piled high and packed with flavor- the fish tostadas were also GIANT and super filling. We ordered the Mac n cheese as a side, and I'll be honest... I'd fly back to that restaurant for the Mac n cheese any freakin day of the week. It was so delicious and creamy, topped with crunch breadcrumbs. So. Good! For dessert we opted for the ice cream sundaes the restaurant made in these adorable old fashioned diner glasses (makes sense, of course) and they were huge. The only frustrating part is that we couldn't really customize our sundae- or add any extra ingredients... so that part was a bummer. Overall, I highly recommend this place, hands down. We had a blast.

The food was amazing, but come hungry the portions are HUGE!!

The buzzing atmosphere makes for a great time and our server was hilarious.

Some people love huge portions, I wish we had shared, it wasn't the kind of food that keeps overnight.

My friends and I popped into Little Goat because Au Cheval had a 2 hour wait at 12:30 on a friday afternoon (i'll get there one day). The hostess who sat us was a little rude and seemed frustrated with us because we had one extra person but I guess I can understand because they were busy.
Off the bat, I noticed the Asian inspiration in several of the dishes which I thought was unique and fun for a diner. To start, we ordered the fried pickles which were out of this world. They were fried almost like tempura style and were actually quite light. I ordered the Banh Mi style burger for my main course, and opted for the goat burger and a fried egg on top. It was absolutely excellent. I especially loved the addition of mint. It offered such a unique flavor which isn't typical for a burger. I would absolutely visit Little Goat Diner again. Hopefully next time they aren't out of the cinnamon buns :)

I keep avoiding this review. I've been here a dozen times now and I keep going with people who LOVE this place. And I keep finding myself underwhelmed. It's fine. It's mediocre.
