Someone ordered me a patty melt saying it was the best they had ever had. It was fine. Mediocre. I had forgotten about it until I looked back at the menu.

I had the Reuben that someone raved about. I only remember because of my notes.

The biscuits and gravy were not to my taste but I can see someone else enjoying them.

The macho nacho are what originally brought me here. My coworkers were so thrilled by this but it left me with a "meh" feeling.

I get the appeal of the place but overall I think it's vastly overrated.

We went with a group of 14 (several little kids) and were taken care of very well.

Everyone loved their food. Kids portions however were small and pricy- our kids kept on eating and eating and we ordered a few extras for them.

I had the shrimp and grits- absolutely delicious with great depth of flavor.

Cinnamon bun was average. One of the best menu items has got to be the hash browns. Do yourself a favor and order them.

Overall had a great experience except everyone left feeling disappointed in the coffee...but you came pretty close to perfection Little Goat and we'll be back.

Very delicious sandwich I had here for dinner! My friend and I ended up near the West Loop. Although we had initially intended on getting dinner elsewhere, I'm so happy we got to eat at Little Goat Diner! We got there around 5PM and thankfully there wasn't a wait for us to get seated. The menu online is cutely presented, and I wish I could have tried more after finding out that this is the sister restaurant of the infamous Girl and the Goat across the street!!

I decided to get the Los Drowned sandwich (or sammiche as they call it here) and my friend got the Pork Belly pancake. Both of our sandwiches were SO SO DELICIOUS. I mean the flavors were on point and unlike anything I've had before. I could see a lot of Asian flavor influences on the menu like in the Pork Belly pancake (which was an open-faced scallion pancake topped with lots of pork belly chunk goodness, a nice citrusy/acidic bok choy salad, and some crunch) and the "kimchi" mayo in my braised beef sammiche. The cut of beef was so tender that I thought I was eating a quality prime rib sandwich! Generously large sandwich. It was served with au jus, which I've never had before so I might be wrong, but it tasted a little bland and greasy.

The items on the menu are so diverse and interesting that I wish I could have tried more. Would highly recommend! Don't be fooled by your preconceived notion of "breakfast food" which is served all day on the menu, and gloss over it like I did!

Great place for breakfast! Came in on a Friday morning around 9AM and there was plenty of seating and service was somewhat quick. I got the Dark Chocolate Chip Crunch pancakes and they were amazing! Perfect amount of fluffiness and somehow the chocolate cream that they serve on the side did not overwhelm the dish at all and complimented it quite nicely. We ordered carafes of mimosas for the whole table and the OJ-Champagne ratio was on point. Would definitely come back to try a savory dish for breakfast!

Great food but can do with better service. My wife and I have eaten there 10+ times and one of them the servers acted as we didn't exist. Took 10-15 minutes to get water. Another 10 to get our order in. They did give us some free dessert which was very sweet of them.

Overall I would recommend - great food all the bread is backed fresh daily, good breakfast food, trendy diner that won't break the bank.

Really enjoyed my time here! Tried the fat club and was in love, but definitely too big for me to eat! We also tried the grilled cheese and enjoyed it. Would come back to try more, but definitely has a regular diner feel. Service was good!

Great comfort food....wonderful breakfast and brunch options. Waffles, grits and eggs are all wonderful Hash-browns are a must add side.
Also offers terrific late night bites...sandwiches, salads and burgers.

For me this place is perfect!
Both the food & the service are always impressive. A definite must whenever possible!
I invite all of you to visit this place!
Came here for brunch while visiting Chicago. Line was out the door, but wait was totally worth it. Service was great and the meal was incredible; one of the best burgers I have ever had!

We expected so much more from this place to be truthful. It was very loud with the music blasting that I had to put my ear plugs on and almost shout for my party of six to hear me. Service was fairly slow and we were trying to figure out who our waitress or waitress was for our table. The food portions were way to big . It was like an order could feed three or four people. The food was average . We wouldn't come here again.

3.5 stars for the food.
4 stars for the service.
A regular diner.
Nothing extraordinary about it.
I didn't feel like trying other dishes.

This place never disappoints. I had a friend visiting from out of town, and I brought him knowing it would be a hit. They have a huge selection on their menu for brunch and lunch, and the pricing is definitely fair for the amazing quality and quantity of food. I would definitely make a reservation, because there always is a wait. We had one and our table was even running a bit behind, but the staff was very friendly and apologetic. I'll definitely be back again.

We rented the room upstairs for about 40 people and the execution and food was so thoughtful! We enjoyed drinks on our private deck overlooking Chicago and then were brought back into the dining room where the chefs prepared food in our own kitchen.

Some folks, including me, were slated to have the vegetarian version of the menu and it was so good that all the meat eaters asked to have a second taste of my dishes! While others had scallops I had the falafel. It looked and was plated exactly like the scallops and it was the best falafel I've had in my life. My main dish was some oriental sesame and avocado garlic noodles and on of my guests put down his salmon and had to force me to give him a second go at my dish! All 40 people raved about the food and dessert and all 40 got their appetizers, drinks, dishes (sea bass, short ribs, scallops), desserts in perfect harmony. The service was friendly and worked like a synchronized swim team.

This place specializes in meat dishes. But, if their vegetarian dishes for me were THAT good, imagine how good their specialty dishes are.

pics.caption: Our menu for 40 people. We had about 4 people with vegetarian options which were also phenomenal.
Our own kitchen chef staff. These lady chefs are champions!

review.des:
This was my first stop arriving to Chicago. We were very glad we made reservations because it was pretty busy when we arrived.

Coming here hungry, we ordered the goat almighty and the pork belly fries. The goat almighty was literally a feet tall packed with beef, pork and goat, topped with pickle, jalapenos, piri piri sauce, and a masa chip. Had to use a fork and knife until 2/3 of the way before we can hold that burger and took a bite. It was huge! The beef was super tender, the goat was in a patty but you can taste the gamey-ness of it. The pork was shredded like pull pork. I love that there was a piece of masa  chip to help absorb some of the juice so that the bottom bun was not mushy. It also add a nice crunch to the  burger. Even it was a big dish that  easily feed 2-3 people, it was surprisingly not heavy. The only critique I had was that meat was bland. It could definitely use some kind of seasoning. On the other hand, the pork belly fries was overly salty. I can only eat a few bites of it before drinking water. They did not use traditional fries, but roasted potatoes which was a little unexpected but it was all good. The pork belly was fat, crunchy and plump but still overly salted. I am still drinking water now as we speak.

Service was good, our waitress was knowledgeable and nice. Overall, even though the price is a little high for a diner, the portion justified it. Coming here with high expectations because it's from the famous chef, Stephanie Izard, it did not disappoint. Definitely a must if you want some comfort food with a twist. Also, you have to come to see the goat icon, its super cute :)

Loved this diner! The plates were reasonably priced for how popular it is.

///Little piggy went to china
-Amazing, sweet gooseberries which complemented the hearty biscuit/pork
-Over easy egg was a great touch!

///Corned beef hash
-Stringg hash browns but still crispy delicious
-Corned beef was tender and juicy

///Little goat latte
-Tastes like goat milk
-A little oily!

We both enjoyed our meals very much.

We had reservations which were wide open and able to toggle to a later time the morning of! However, there was a line/wait when we showed up- I would recommend a reservation.

pics.caption: Delicious little piggy went to china! Gooseberries were so sweet and amazing

review.des:
What is it about Little Goat Diner that I love it so much? Is it the relaxed atmosphere that feels quirky, lively, and like a family gathering all at once? Or the expansive menu that covers everything from breakfast (served all day!) to sandwiches to fried chicken to goat and to international foods covering Korean, Mexican, Mediterranean, Chinese? Everything on the menu is a creative interpretation of a classic and they are all done really well.

Although impossible to get into on weekends unless you make a reservation fairly well in advance, I've been there for breakfast, brunch, dinner, and late night desserts. The best part is that their menu items fit every part of the day! My standout faves are

Bi bim bop breakfast bowl with cauliflower rice. This captures the flavor and essence of a favorite Korean dish with a base of cauliflower rice, pickled veggies, mushrooms, sprouts and two sunny  side eggs on top. So yummy, so filling and yet light because of the cauliflower rice.

Fat Elvis waffles are an awesome brunch treat - waffles, banana, peanut butter and bacon. How can you go wrong?

Fried chicken with biscuit - the fried chicken was perfectly done and the giant biscuit that comes along with it perfectly buttery and crumbly. It's amazing they have a bakery on the premise.

Crumpets - this is such a rare find on American menus but so delightful as a lighter option for breakfast pastry.

One Twisted Sundae - one of the best and biggest sundaes I've ever had! A chocolate brownie topped with indulgent dulce de leche ice cream, sprinkled with pieces of crunchy pretzels and finished with mounds of whipped cream. A huge portion so perfect for sharing!

Service is friendly and they are also really accommodating with children. One of my fave spots in Chicago that I will return to again and again!

I've been to Little Goat a couple of times but it was always for something light. I only got an appetizer or desserts each of those time, which were already amazing  and it meant I had to return for a meal.

We came in for Lunch on a beautiful Sunday afternoon and luckily the wait was short. The menu has lots of option and everything sounds amazing but I think we were all in the mood for burgers. Its your standard diner fares but taken to a couple of notches up. It combines flavors that you might not have thought would ever be together but they worked so well. We were in the mood for burgers. Our order was: Patty Melts, Goat Almighty, a special and an order of fried pickle and onions.

The patty melts were delicious both the beef and goat patties. The Goat Almighty is really ALMIGHTY. Its a burger made of beef brisket, with a goat patty ( took off the pork) but its too much burger for one person. It all goes together really well but it was just too much for me to handle. But hands down my favorite were the onion rings. The onions are marinated in a dressing and fried to perfection in a tempura batter. Definitely worth getting.

Overall: Service was great and food was great. There is still a lot left to try so will be back!

Little Goat Diner is the smaller Stephanie Izard restaurant compared to Girl & The Goat and Duck Duck Goat but this is not to be overlooked. Little Goat is a spin on classic American diner's with a modern twist. I've had their meatloaf and classic hamburger....both were so good and reasonably priced as well. Little Goat is a must try in the West Loop.

We ordered EVERYTHING.... no really EVERYTHING.

My boyfriend was sooo excited to get their oversized hash browns and was so busy eating his eggs that when he came to it, there was a gross layer of fat and it was so hard that we considered donating it to the Blackhawks to use as a puck.

I don't know, I think this was more hype than actually really good food. I walked away a bit disappointed.

Wednesday lunch walking at 11:30.

Food was a 10
Service was a 10
Waited 35 mins for my Turk club sand. Rut row

Got:
double espresso but had to ask for the lemon peel, it was so good I got another. Lamb chili loaded fries were amazing. Turkey club was great but took almost 40 mins. No manger visit. Deserved to be comp'd in my eyes (14 yrs in restaurants).

At the high level, Little Goat delivered 100% on our needs last night. If you like Kimchi, I have one recommendation for ordering the Rueben.
What we wanted and got was family friendly experience, quality food, interesting flavors.
3 adults, 3 children under 6 years, probably not a waitresses favorite table. Danielle was top notch. She was patient with many questions , our slow order pace, and she was was always helpful.

The highlights:
1. fried onions and pickles. So the pickles AND the ONIONs were pickled. Kind of a sweet and sour thing. Stimulates the appetite vs deadening it. I enjoy fried onions, but I never order, 'cause I scarf them up and feel worse later.
2. Cheese fries with chili and other stuff. Maybe some vinegar in this too. Not the usual cheese fry, definitely a good share.
3. I don't know what they put in the chicken fingers, but the young ones devoured almost every morsel including the fruit and veggies.

4. My one beef (or cabbage) was the Rueben with Kimchi. As a girl and goat diner you expect small portions and Kimchi forward flavor. This was gargantuan smoked corn beef and a tiny bit of kimchi. So if you want a more flavorful Rueben, ask for less beef, more Kimchi.

And yes, entrees are huge. Unless you have a teenagers metabolism, or have been chopping wood all day, be prepared for leftovers.

PS just ate the other Rueben half for lunch cold. More flavor, and the kimchi had more crunch. I still think I'd request less beef and more kimchi next time. Chhees

While visiting Chicago, my husband and I decided to try Little Goat Diner and we were not disappointed! We started out with their ooey gooey cinnamon roll and it was one of the best we ever had! My husband had the corn beef hash and enjoyed it a lot; and I had a special of the day with fried egg, bacon, avocado, and a summer tomato medley, with a side of hash browns. All of my food was absolutely delicious!! I recommend trying brunch here while you're in Chicago!

Yes yes yes yum yum yum!  I've walked by Little Goat so many times and finally got to experience it!  I was surprised by how authentically diner-ish it was.  Like, most hip places will say they're a "cafe" or a "diner" or an "eatery," but those terms become become so vague that you can't be sure.  Little Goat, on the other hand, has leather-bound booths, root beer floats, and surprisingly juicy chicken fingers.  

This may come as a surprise, because nobody obsessed over broccoli, but this diner has an Asian fusion broccoli side that I will be dreaming about for weeks.  BURSTING with flavor, perfectly cooked.  I'm salivating.

I would give it 4 stars but it is rather noisy.  

Big portions!   Pickles and onion rings really good, breading was thick.  Food was delicious and service was great

This is a good spot for breaky, lunch or din. The menu seems weird because it has a lot of different items - but it is ALL delicious. They also offer vegan, dairy-free and gluten-free menus, if you're into any of that.

Came in today for a late lunch and we sat outside. They have a lovely sidewalk patio with some trees so you can be shaded and comfy while stuffing face. Haven't been to the rooftop but they do have one! With string lights!!

Today we got the crispy chicken sandy, whitefish tostadas and hash browns. Everything is crazy good (I didn't even have to ask for condiments with the sandy) but the HASHBROWNS are the best hashbrowns ever made, mayb. They are v stringy and cooked with some kind of mystery goat cheese that cooks down to make them both crispy and gooey, but you can't see it! Which is why I call it mystery cheese. Just try them they're great. And the butterscotch root beer float, obv.

I really wanted to LOVE LOVE this place but unfortunately it fell a tad below my expectations. It was still very good, but a little pricey for what it is. I ordered the sourdough pancakes ($11) which tasted and looked just like normal pancakes that I could get anywhere. My group enjoyed their dishes but everything is ala cart so you're going to pay extra for coleslaw or fries with your sandwich... that seemed a bit much.

The ambiance is very cool inside and I adore their logo! We had a reservation for 1:30 but  they didn't seat us until 1:50 which is also unfortunate. Our server was very nice and knowledgeable and helped us pick our dishes.

Although it was good, it was nothing extraordinary to warrant their steep prices.

This place is really nice, and our waitress was so kind and funny. I got the bullseye French toast and I was really underwhelmed. I expected it to be heavy, which it was. Somehow the flavors didn't marry well together... it just wasn't good. It wasn't photogenic, either. The one thing it was... is soggy. I'd probably go here again but try something else... my boyfriend got the corned beef hash. He liked it! It looked good, but i didn't try any.

We made a reservation ahead and it was super convenient because when we arrived at the place was packed and they sat us right away.
We order the soup of the day, which was a Red Pepper and it was more like a cream than a soup but it was unbelievably tasty! My fav dish of the day by far along with the Cesar Salad.
My hubby had the Banh Mi Style burger and he wouldn't stop saying how delicious it was.
However, I ordered the fish tostadas and they were meh! And I believe it was because I imagine something else. For me it was a plain flavored dish, so I'll have something different next time.
I'm giving them 4 stars since service was super slow and our waiter even though was very nice, was a bit off, he kept forgetting things that we asked or ordered and had to asked him over again.

Excellent adventure to a new restaurant. Would definitely go back again. Hostess and waitstaff were great. Meghan was our waitress, she was extremely knowledgeable and accommodating. We discuss a shellfish allergy with her and she let us know ingredients in dishes we ordered.
Bim bob bowl and biscuits and gravy were both excellent!!

I really want to love Little Goat, but their food is just too weird.

I came here once about a year ago and wasn't totally in love, so when a friend suggested coming here, I jumped at the chance to try it again. All of the goat restaurants are so popular! It had to be just me, right? Unfortunately, without even knowing, I think I ordered the same thing both times: Los Drowned. There were too many pickled veggies on top, and it was just plain hard to eat. My friend and I shared the chili cheese fries, and these were weird too. The chili had almost Indian-like spices in addition to a heck of a lot of salt. Five fries in, it was overpowering.

Little Goat tries to combine diner style with creative menu choices, and sometimes funky food works. But here, for me, the food is just a miss. Overall, the restaurant is okay but I wouldn't come here again.

Came here on a Sunday morning around 9am and was lucky that we didn't have to wait! The restaurant was already packed with people, but the hostess decided to let us sit at the communal table corner, where it felt like we basically had the whole table to ourselves!

The service was great, and we got our food fairly quickly. My party of 4 shared 3 dishes: Little Pigs went to China, Okonomiyaki pancakes, and the strawberry and fried chicken french toast. Just like all other Yelp reviews and pictures about this place, Little piggies went to China is definitely a must try! The scallions and sauce that they pour on the eggs were perfect, and the szechuan pork patty they used were VERY flavorful. The Okonomiyaki pancakes don't get as much hype comparing the other two dishes, but were definitely worth mentioning. In my opinion it was even better than the french toast. The texture was soft but not soggy, and the flavor was amazing.

It was overall a great experience, and the restaurant is located at a very nice part of town. Lots to see around, and would definitely recommend this place for brunch! Cute decor as well! :)

pics.caption: Strawberry and fried chickem french toast!

review.des:
Finally got the chance to go to Little Goat after a year! Reservations are a must. The wait can be almost two hours for a weekend brunch without a reservation. I came here on a weekday at 11 and it was still fairly packed. The spacious restaurant boasts natural lighting and white decor. Service was quick and fast.

Their menu offers traditional breakfast items like pancakes, but their most popular dishes are more unique. I ordered the two most popular items, This Little Piggy Went to China ($14) and the Bull's Eye French Toast ($16). The flavors were definitely a lot more pronounced than most brunch places I've been to. The Little Piggy had an Asian influence, and I could definitely taste it. The combo of the bread, eggs, sausage was brought together by the chili garlic chive sauce. Not the most typical brunch dish, but I enjoyed it nonetheless. The Bull's Eye French Toast was a little less appealing. The chicken was crisp to perfection, but the overall syrup was too sweet. I wasn't a fan of the soggy bread or the eggs in the middle. It was hard finishing the dish because of the sweetness.

I will admit Little Goat is a little too hyped, but I recommend coming here at least once!

pics.caption: Bull's Eye French Toast and This Little Piggy Went to China

review.des:
This place is very curated to fit where it is on Randolph Street. I don't like that it advertises itself as a "diner" because what diner charges what they do? I get the theme and the a la carte ordering fitting into how diners operate, but I digress.

The food overall was pretty good, I had the tonkotsu sammie and the smoked fries. The fries were fantastic albeit a bit too salty. On the other hand the sandwich was very flavorful, but the plain white bread - while tasty, was a bit of a let down especially since the ingredients in the sandwich started getting the bread soggy as I was halfway through and I eat fast. So, I guess it wouldn't be a good idea to have any leftovers.

The service was good and it was nice to see they even had a house beer, a nice and unexpected touch. It's a great place to come to if you're looking for flavor and a nice ambiance. Would highly recommend getting dropped off or public transit here as parking can be a nightmare / cost as much as a whole meal.

The hash brown was amazing, they have a Japanese style dish which is okonomiyaki, this was great. Also they have Chinese style dish which I forgot the name, was fantastic. They serve brunch until night. The neighborhood was awesome and also the atmosphere. Little loud to talk but def it s a good place to hang out.

Not sure why it took four visits for this review but here goes. I love brunchin' here because the menu appeals to every palette, making it an easy choice for any dining companion. Adventurous eaters, traditionalists and those who are somewhere in between.

There are also gluten free pastries made daily and food items for those with dietary restrictions. And while my favorite menu item is no longer offered (taco salad), I enjoyed trying the blueberry pancakes this visit. The oatmeal crumbles was a nice touch.

Of the items I have tried, these are my suggestions:

- Elotes
- Rueben
- Chili
- Hashbrowns w/ cheese
- Blueberry Pancakes  
- Bull's Eye French Toast served w/ chicken & fresh strawberries

*****A limited number of reservations are offered on OpenTable and valet parking is available for $16 (3 hours).

pics.caption: A single blueberry pancake and hashbrowns.......

review.des: Thank God for my real estate agent for bringing me and my partner here for brunch one Sunday. Because this place is always busy, we sat at the bar (which is full service) and ordered the fish tacos and okonomiyaki. Although I didn't love the tacos (too fried, kind of cold), my partner DEVOURED his pork belly pancake and vowed to return soon. The best part of the meal, however, was the bartender. He was incredibly friendly, patient, and knowledgable. Great staff and great vibe!

Honestly, I was a little disappointed after reading all the reviews.  Made a stop here on my way to the airport. Had a side Caesar salad and the nachos.

The salad was very small for a $7 side. It was simple, but had a bit of lemon rind mixed which made it more refreshing and interesting than normal Caesar salads.

The nachos were huge!  Enough for 2 or 3 people to eat dinner off of. They look fantastic, but flavors wise, I've had better. The chips seemed stale and the chips are topped with a white cheese sauce that completely disappointed. The cheese cause was almost like Alfredo, something made with flour so it was a little gritty. Could have used some spicy.  I did eat at an odd time, 3 pm, so not sure if I got old chips and cheese. I definitely think the chips were rebaked.

Service was mediocre. Order a gin and tonic (not specifying liquor) and waitress charged me for Hendricks - $12, the price of a specialty cocktail here. Waitress seemed bothered to be there.
Such a great experience! I've been hearing about this place for a while and it did not disappoint. Great service and atmosphere. I added sausage to the Spanish omelette - on point.

pics.caption: A picture is worth a thousand words, right? Spanish Omelette and Bull's Eye French Toast. Great service and awesome food

review.des: the nachos were bomb!! the tortilla chips are super crispy and not your typical nacho chips, seems like it's fried in house almost (could be wrong). it's definitely big enough to share with 2-4 people depending on how much you eat/what else you order.

This is my one of my top five favorite restaurants in Chicago. Great service, great food, great drinks, great space. Plus, they serve breakfast all day, which is amazing. Little Goat really embodies the theme of upscale, gourmet diner.

I love the fried pickles and onion rings (and sauces that come with), tempura mashed potatoes, chocolate chip pancakes, fattoush salad, pork belly home fries, mac and cheese, and fish tostadas -- you really can't go wrong here. I've also been with a bigger group (I think 10-12ish people?) and they were super accommodating of people arriving at different times and splitting the bill 4 or 5 ways.

The Little Goat Diner gets 5 stars for me. I actually ordered togo because the wait was an hour. However, the shrimp and grits and sourdough pancakes are bomb! I def recommend ordering those too items.

We came here for my husband's birthday breakfast with 4 kids and 4 adults. The food was fantastic not one of us ordered the same dish and we were all very pleased! They even gave my husband an oversized Cinnabon with sprinkles for his bday and the kids gobbled it up! Our waiter couldn't have been nicer and they were very kid friendly! We will be back again and again and again! Thank you!

These goats are taking over Chicago and in a very smart way!
The sister restaurant to Girl and the Goat, just across it's sister has to be the best diner in town! Serves breakfast all day! But also has lunch and dinner items in their menu.
If you like goat cheese, goat milk and all things goat, you better come here and indulge because every dish is memorable!
They have a little goat latte that of course is made with goat milk. But they can do just about anything with coffee you ask them to.  
Decor of the place is simple, a modern take on a diner with a nice simple chandelier in then middle that hangs. There are booths to sit at, regular tables, high tables and by the bar. If you're open to and don't want to wait a long time for your table the offer comunal seating at their bigger tables.
There's also a bakery inside it that could nexts and you can see the bakers doing what they do best. I like this because it also shows you the cleanliness of the place.
Food! As mentioned above the menu is very diverse and has something for everyone.
The goat almighty burger is delicious!!!!!! A must try for sure when you come here. It's HUGE! Can easily be shared because it was three different types of meat including a goat patty, two huge onion rings, a great tasting green sauce and some delicious buns!
The crab dip... is to die for! Picture eating a crab cake, but smooth and you have it with ritz crackers! Yes! Delicious.
Biscuit and gravy is also very very good, the bullseye French toast is another must get item.
In summary, if in Chicago, please check this place out. You won't regret it, if there's a long wait, it's worth it! I promise you that food will make you forget how long you had to wait

Just because the chef hand-picked trash from a trashbin in Seoul and then hand-picked trash from a trashbin in Mexico and then hand-picked trash from outside of a downstate Illinois county fair, and then fried it up and threw it onto a plate, doesn't mean you get to call it Korean-Mexican-American fusion cusine.

Their fried pickle appetizer felt like the chef had a real laugh. 'Oh, let the bourgeois eat what the common Midwesterners eat. Hem hem hem.' The worst thing about this dish is that it's not even in the deliciousness ballpark as the original, cheap fried pickles at state fairs.

I'm puzzled about the intention behind the tonkutsu. Deep-fried meat stacked in between dry white bread is something that would take about $3 to make. Drenching it in questionable sauce does nothing to disguise this garbage fire.

I also want some answers about the pork belly. They threw a bunch of shredded cabbage and mayonnaise over a tiny slab of pork and a pancake. Why?

Their kimchi burger was the peak of their offerings, and they've stripped that off the menu to instead offer a bunch of paltry hamburgers without eggs inside. Little Goat Diner was good a year ago, but it looks like they're now running a fascinating new experiment on how much trash they can serve customers before the customers stop coming altogether.

Finally, here's are two items that should never be placed side-by-side: miso, and a banana split. Another two items that should never be placed side-by-side: customers trying to eat a meal in peace, and the 35-degree gusts of wind that assault them every time people use the revolving door.
Food was awesome and the atmosphere is exquisite. They did however forget to put in one of our entrees but gave it to use at no cost once the mistake was brought to their attention.

We stopped here for breakfast on our trip to Chicago. We were able to make a reservation online that morning, and were seated right away when we got there. Everything on the menu sounded great but we got the omelette of the day (mushrooms and cream cheese), pork belly home fries, and the Little Piggy Goes to China. All super flavorful and cooked perfectly. The restaurant itself is very comfortable with lots of room to move around. Also lots of natural light which I appreciated. Very cute brunch spot! If we lived in Chicago we'd be regulars.

Made reservations for a Sunday Morning and we were seated right on time. Great service. Tonkatsu for me. Club for hubby. Chocolate crunch malted pancakes for child #1. Regular pancakes for child #2. Carafe of Mimosas to share. Mac and cheese and smoked fries to share. Tonkatsu sandwich was fantastic. If I could, I would have wanted more of the Asian bbq and less slaw. I had a bite of the crunchy pancakes, and they were good, but rich. Hubby liked his club. The portions were very large, and we wasted the Mac and cheese and fries, which were both very good. If I could order all over again, we would have shared the Tonkatsu sandwich and Mac and cheese so we wouldn't have wasted so much food. The Mac and cheese was good, and very rich. The smoked fries were very good. I would definitely visit again.

This place was great for brunch. I had the breakfast burrito. The Indian bread that it is wrapped in is delicious! I loved the sauce that came with it as well. My mom had the special which was a pork belly biscuit. She said it was delicious. It was good but dry. Fries were okay. Reminded me of in-n-out. We also split a cinnamon roll. I wish they would have under baked it a little to make it more gooey.

The service at the table was excellent. Our server was friendly and took great care of us. However, the two girls doing the seating are horrible. I had made a 9:30am reservation. We showed up on time and were told to wait when there were plenty of empty table and booths. We waited 15 min before being seated, and I think the only reason we were seated was because we reminded the hostess that we had a reservation. I don't see the point in making a reservation if you're not going to honor it when we arrive. Really disappointed in that aspect and would've given it another star if we had been seated at our reservation time.

I absolutely love this place. I have been here twice for lunch. There is wait almost always so you might want to get a reservation. The food is amazing, ambience is great, vibrant, bright and lively and the service is great too, a bit slow but eh - its fine. I usually go here prepared to be there for aboutan hour and half from start to finish.

I have had paraths burrito, spanish omlette and dark chocolate chip crunch pancakes and all of the them taste amazing. The egg in the paraths burrito is always perfectly cooked, the salad and the sauce to go with it taste amazing. Its just the perfect texture with the creamy sunny side up egg, cruncy salad, little bit of paratha with a bite and the tangy sauce... perfect bite! The spanish omlette was amazing too, and the chocolate chip pancakes - very rich, chocolate perfectly dark, pancakes just sweet to contrast the dark chocolate and those little chocolate pearls add some crunch to the bite.

So when you are in the mood for some amazing brunch food walk right into this place and I promise you will not be disappointed.

pics.caption: Parathas Burrito - My go to order!! Yummmm

review.des: Food was unique, and good. I enjoyed the crudités platter and the chicken kebabs with tzaziki sauce.  My husband really enjoyed the kale salad we got and shared -portion was big. The naan bread on the side was delish!

Yum !! Met a friend for brunch and couldn't decide oh what to order ... I got the Elvis waffle... waffle with peanut butter,banana and syrup (minus the bacon as I'm vegetarian )

Two huuuge waffles and so delicious ..can't wait to go back and try their other veggie options

Back when I was working remotely, I read on the Internet somewhere that this is "one of the best places to work remotely in Chicago." That they even have rooftop seating with great views of the city.

Lol, I went in (before the winter time) and my first impression was that it looked like a regular restaurant and not a cafe-style eatery that's accommodating in terms of space, outlets, etc. Plus, it was busy and loud. *I've since learned to fact check those "Best Places to ????? In Chicago" blog posts.*

I figured I'd try the place anyway, so I inquired about the rooftop seating. The hostesses told me that was only for private events. Okay...so I asked what would be the estimated wait time for a table for one. She seemed a little annoyed that I'd even ask for a table for one during rush hour by the look on her face, but she took down my info and told me it would be about a 45 min wait.

I sat down to wait, but after about 5 mins I was annoyed by my interaction with the hostess, plus I did have work to do and it was def not going to get done there, so I decided to step out. I guess the hostess knew I wasn't coming back because I never got a call/text about my table.

Oh my little goat! Okay before I delve into the delicious food and atmosphere I have to give some major love to Jessica! They say first impressions are lasting and while I believe in second impressions Jessica did not need a do over. I had a reservation which I strongly urge anyone to make especially during brunch. I was greeted by Jessica who asked if I wanted to sit inside or the outside patio. Mother Nature was at her finest and it was a perfect summer day so I couldn't resist the urge to sit outdoors. Jessica mentioned that it might be a bit of a wait because it's summer and of course everyone wants to secure one of those coveted seats.

Fortunately I did not have to wait long and was seated within minutes of my reservation. In all honesty I could have waited twenty minutes given how pleasant and attentive Jessica was. I had the opportunity to sit back and watch her with other customers and she was flawless. Thank you Jessica for adding some extra sunshine to an already perfect day!

Okay so onto the food! I started with a cup of coffee which I have to say is one of the best tasting coffees I've had in a while. It was rich and I probably could have enjoyed it without any milk.  I decided on the Bullseye French Toast thanks to all the fabulous reviews from my fellow Yelpers. This French Toast did not disappoint. It is made with sweet onion brioche, a sunny little egg is baked in which I some how missed in all the reviews I read so imagine my surprise! The toppings were crispy chicken and strawberries with a drizzle of BBQ maple syrup. The brioche was cooked perfectly which I'm grateful for because sometimes French Toast is a bit chewy or dry. The chicken and BBQ maple syrup were a nice twist and paired well with the strawberries.

They have an extensive menu which I'm definitely looking forward to checking out when I return to Chicago.

Note: You can take the pink or green line and exit at Morgan and it's a pleasant walk to Little Goat.

review.des:
Delicious food & fantastic service. Came on a Friday at 11am with a reservation as I'd heard the wait could be an hour and a half plus. Per our server's suggestion we got the this little piggy went to China, the smoked fries, and an off the menu tuna sammie - which he told us they're actually bringing back.

Such a great brunch spot. Would definitely be regulars if we lived in Chicago.

Came here late on a not so busy evening and we were sat down immediately. The staff is kind and charming. The drinks are absolutely fantastic. The chicken pot pie was the best I've had in a really long time. The prices are super reasonable. I fully intend on coming back to this place in the future. The experience was amazing.

After failing to get a reservation at Girl and the Goat during our visit to Chicago I booked a table at the next best restaurant: Little Goat Diner. Little Goat Diner is also ran by Bravo's Top Chef, Stephanie Izard, and features unique and innovative takes on classic comfort food. The unforgettable combinations left me wanting to book another trip to Chicago just so that I can eat here again!

I made a reservation for Sunday morning at 8:30am. This was probably unnecessary as there was no wait this early on a Sunday, but by 9am a line started to form out the door so I would highly recommend making a reservation if you are not an early riser.

We started our meal off with the most amazing coffee. I ordered a macchiato, my husband order the razzle chai latte, and my sister ordered the little goat latte. My macchiato was great but my husband's and sister's coffee beverages were mind blowing. If you like goat's milk/goat cheese you must order one of these tangy and sweet coffees. They were unlike anything I have tried before and I now wish all coffee shops offered the option of goat's milk!

My sister ordered the most popular dish on the menu, The Bull's Eye French Toast. This life changing dish includes sweet onion brioche bread with a sunnyside egg cooked in the middle (think eggs in a basket). The french toast is topped with strawberries, diced fried chicken strips and bbq maple syrup. I hate myself for not ordering this dish. I had several bites off my sister's plate and the sweet and savory combination was so addictive!!!

I ordered The Little Piggy Went to China. My dish included a sesame cheddar biscuit with szechuan pork sausage, sunnyside eggs, strawberries and chili garlic chive sauce. I absolutely loved my dish, but it was a little too early in the morning for the chili garlic chive sauce. I would definitely order this dish for lunch instead of breakfast.

My husband isn't much of a breakfast eater so he just ordered the pork belly home fries. This side dish was HUGE and is meant to be shared with an entire table. Fried potatoes are combined with large chunks of pork belly, pickled peppers, fish sauce vinaigrette and garnished with cilantro. This dish puts all other home fries to shame!

I will definitely be dining at the Little Goat Diner next time I visit Chicago!!!

pics.caption: This Little Piggy went to China: sesame cheddar biscuit, Szechuan pork, chili garlic chive sauce & strawberries.
Bull's Eye French Toast with eggs, fried chicken, sweet onion brioche and bbq maple syrup. Heaven!
Pork Belly Home Fries with pickled peppers, cilantro and a fish sauce vinaigrette.

review.des:
So disappointed, as I wanted to love this place as much as I do Girl and the Goat. Went a few hours ago for lunch and honestly, the service just killed it for us.

We waited awhile for our server to greet us, she never shared her name (we had to ask later when trying to flag her down). Our table was set up incompletely: 6 of us and only 2 had forks and only 4 had side plates. We ordered and then things just went downhill. First 3 of the kids meals came out, then it took over 5 minutes for an adult meal and the other kids meal, then OVER 5 minutes for the final adult meal to come out. Kids were done! We had also asked the guy who dropped off the first round for the forks we were missing, he said okay and then walked right off to the kitchen and started running food again!

Food was good. At least there's that. I had the Pork Belly Pancake on a scallion pancake. Delicious and sweet meat. My sister had today's special, the Fish Tostadas. Huge portion and perfectly fried fish. We shared the fried pickles: flavorful batter, very crispy and lightly battered. I also had the Goat Chili, which was spicy and oh so good! We also had a cinnamon roll brought out, which one of the kids exclaimed they "loved, loved, loved."

The kids had the grilled cheese (huge portion for 1), several orders of pancakes and a Mini Dogs, which unfortunately wasn't mini and was instead a huge hot dog on a hoagie bun, cut in half ... so big an average 6 year old couldn't get her mouth around it.

We ordered the cake of the day, Devils Food, for the 4 kids to split. Moist and super rich! My sister had the Dairy Free Chocolate Shake, which we found to be a bit thick and more similar to the consistency of a ganache. I had to wait over 5 minutes after everyone else's dessert for mine to arrive ... but when it did finally make it to the table, my Pork and Toffee Shake was delish! Huge chunks of Toffee and I thoroughly enjoyed it.

Took forever to flag down our server, Minty, who approached us with absolutely no sense of urgency at any point in the meal. She did notice the final adult meal missing after 10 minutes, but kind of late at that point for her to finally stop by.

So, food= pretty good, kitchen times= stunk,
Service= stinky, too.

A few other things, there were mosquitos in the photo booth and flies in the restaurant between our booth and the next. Turn offs!!

What compelled me to visit Little Goat Diner (and Girl and the Goat) was honestly because I love watching food network, and finally realized it was one of Iron Chef Stephanie Izard's restaurants.

I came here around 5:30 on a weekday without reservation, and easily managed to get seated immediately. I think it may have been luck though since it quickly became crowded for the dinner rush.

Crispy creole chicken Sammy: Chicken was seasoned extremely well. But, it was shame that there was SO much tartar sauce masking the delicious flavor. I had to scrape some of it off to really appreciate it.

Goat almighty: It sounded delicious. It tasted delicious. For once in my life though, I think I can say that there may have been too much meat. It all tasted good, but the flavor became a bit monotonous. That is definitely a sandwich capable of sharing between 2 people.

Smoked Pork and Toffee Crunch Shake (To-Go): One of those sweet/salty desserts. It was a very addicting, decadent vanilla shake. It would have been better had we eaten it with a spoon for how thick it was. They only had regular-sized drinking straws which were unable to take up the toffee bits so we were left with a mound of the delicious toffee at the end which would have tasted better had it been mixed in.

I think everything was done well, but I wasn't necessarily wowed by anything enough to come back again for dinner. I would however, consider trying the breakfast menu, which also sounds like it has some unique twists.

Good service, very tasty creative creations that don't break the bank, beautiful family farm ambience. Cocktails on point. Super busy but reasonable wait time in the city with rsvp. Limited parking in such a busy area, which is fun to bar hop and explore.

Loved this place! We went for brunch on a Saturday, and I highly recommend checking it out the brunch was delicious. Even though it was packed (we made a reservation on open table) our server was super chill and took her time to chat and recommend dishes since it was our first time there. The iced coffee was good and in a giant cup so I was very pleased with that (love me some iced coffee). T Bloody Mary was good as well, also in a very large cup...must be their thing :) We will definitely be back!

I was so ready to give this place 5 stars but sadly, I think this place is all hype.  The service is ok at best. The food leaves much to be desired and is hit or miss. I understand it's a goat theme, but some combinations in this restaurant just didn't work. It seemed like some of the dishes were just thrown together just for the sake of being creative, while compromising quality.

I got the fish tostadas which has pretty good flavor. My fiancée got the los drowned which was supposed to have braised beef but it was super chewy and inedible. The fries with the goat chili were actually very good though.  The worst thing in the menu is the little goat latte. It uses goat milk, which sounds interesting but tastes terrible. I love goat cheese but goats milk is not my cup of tea. If you like goats milk, maybe you'll love it. I just feel goats milk is more savory and didn't work in a sweet latte. My friend also got the chocolate milk (which was $5) and that was super watered down (again, adding the goats milk didn't help.)

While our actual waitress was very sweet, the other staff weren't as attentive. Twice we had to ask someone to fill our waters because we had gone so long without any during our meal. Also, I asked for a new fork once they brought our food and I never got one. I think the staff was overwhelmed at it being so busy.

Normally, I don't really mind the service if the food is good, but even the food couldn't save this one. I say skip this one all together. Maybe Girl and the Goat will be better.

Found this place of course on yelp looking for a different breakfast spot to try.  Located on the corner of the street with great views  

Walked in and the place was decorated nice and very cleans and friendly staff.

The breakfast was very good and very creative on types of dishes made to eat

I ordered the bulls eye French toast and wow i was impressed.  French toast with a egg in the middle and to top it is chicken and strawberries and surprise surprise they all went together and made a fantastic dish.  

This is a must try spot when in the area

Awesome food. Plan on being in food comma as this place has large portions and the taste is too good to stop. Would start recommending things I ate but everyone else's food around me looked good also so don't want to limit any options. Good spot to check out.

The two dishes we ordered: This Little Piggy Went to China and Bull's Eye French Toast - are both tantalizing and unique! The Little Piggy is an asian fusion dish with biscuits and asian style sauce; while the French toast is like a typical fresh toast dipped in syrup until we discovered running egg yolk in the 'eye' of the toast. This place is good for a brunch hangout, but I would recommend booking ahead to avoid the long wait!

My first time here! Went during lunch hour, it was busy but we only had to wait about 5-10 minutes to get seated. Our server was very chill and knowledgeable and knew what to recommend to first timers! I initially wanted mushroom ragout but its only available after 5pm including couple more dishes. So i ended up getting poke burger, crab dip and okonomiyaki.

Crab dip came out first, it was so-so. Then i got my burger and okonomiyaki and it was delicious!! Okonomiyaki was definitely different from the original recipe but i think they purposefully did that to make it in to theirs. It was still very surprisingly delicious! And the poke burger...omgshhhhh i definitely recommend this burger. It very light.. non greasy... yet hearty!

We didn't realize how delicious it was going to be. We started eating, then paused to take photos so I could post a review. Order the blue plate, little pig goes to China, or the hash. It's not your regular hash. Americanos were great.

The only problem is that I couldn't eat more items on the menu.

We enjoyed this spot - when we couldn't get into Girl and the Goat. Sat at the bar and had great service. The club sandwich was truly awesome. And we watched desserts being made through a window - they looked delicious.

I am so sad to write a poor review for Little Goat. I was super excited to eat here. My husband and I made reservations, but when we got there our seats were given away. It had rained and so they put everyone who was outside inside. Which isn't a huge deal, but I am diabetic and can't have too big of a gap between meals. I finally asked to speak with a manager, who was very friendly and patient and found us seats at a communal table that runs the middle of the restaurant. My sugar was too low by then, and after waiting for over 5 minutes for a server we just flagged someone down and got a coke for me. Finally our waitress came, and she was very efficient after that. My husband ordered the smoked friend chicken and I ordered the chicken tenders and macaroni and cheese. My husband liked the interesting flavor of his chicken, but they were the smallest pieces of chicken I had ever seen. He had a huge biscuit, that was quite dry. The best dish on the table was his coleslaw. The MAC was decent, had a creamy texture to it. The chicken tenders were terrible. Thick, slightly sweet and slightly burnt batter and over cooked too firm/not juicy chicken. I asked for hot sauce to combat the sweetness, and all they had was in house apricot or chipotle sauce. I can appreciate they make them in house, but it did not help my chicken. I finally gave up eating it. We spent around $40 on this meal, which is a frustrating feeling when the food is not up to par. I saw a lot of people win breakfast so perhaps I ordered the "wrong" thing. Bummer.

pics.caption: Tiny pieces of smoked fried chicken

review.des:
+1 for cute, modern, hip atmosphere
+1 for having a vegan menu
+2 for delicious food (except the fried pickles/onion rings which had way too much breading)
+1 for prompt service and taking reservations
-1 for calling a beef patty on noddles a "burger" and saying something is "banh mi" style when it's just a sandwich

We waited an hour and a half and it was worth every minute. Everything I tried was solid. Stand outs included the blueberry pancakes with oatmeal crumble and the goat chili--which had a wonderfully flavorful broth and tasty non-greasy crumbled goat meat. Between the hashbrowns (which apparently had cheese in them, but I couldn't detect any) and the tempura mashed potato I would go with the tempura mashed potato. I tried the walnut sour spritz which was perfectly balanced--a little sweet, a little boozy, a little nutty. It actually wasn't sour at all. My entree was the Parathas burrito which I'd get again. It was extremely filling and not too terribly heavy. This experience makes me want to try one of Chef Lizard's other restaurants.

Came here for brunch. Had to wait even though we had a reservation but def was worth it. I got the fried chicken French toast. Was a very interesting and tasty combo. Glad I tried it. Wife got the chicken sandwich which was delicious. We got the chocolate chip pancakes to share for the table and they were perfect. Service was good too. Would come here again.

You will not go wrong with the bulls eye French toast - a combination of sweet and savory dish. This is a place where in there's the fusion of American and Asian dishes also. The goat dishes are cooked nicely without any tangy taste. If you are a type of person who loves to try and be adventurous with your food, this is the right place to go. For those who wants to play it safe but with the company of people who are adventurous with food - you can also enjoy their Mac and cheese, their chicken or their all American burger. A place that will satisfy both adventurous and non-adventurous food lovers.

Come here for brunch. That's really all I have to say.

Ok, I'll say a little more.

My boyfriend and I decided last minute on a Saturday we wanted to go out for brunch which can be quite the feat in Chicago without a long wait. We ended up at Little Goat because we'd heard good things about it but also because they had same day reservations available. When we made the reservation it said we may have to sit at the counter, which we were fine with, but ended up getting a table outside. Score!

They have a super cute cafe connected to the diner where you can get coffee while you're waiting. The coldbrew is strong and delicious.

I got the Fat Elvis Waffles (amazing), my boyfriend got the This Little Piggy Went to China (also amazing) and we split a side of the hash browns (INCREDIBLE). I could have had the hash browns (they're filled with cheese!) as my meal. So good.

We will definitely be back again for brunch and to try the rest of their menu.
