This Little Piggy Went to China -

review.des:
One of the best diners I've ever been to! The menu is full of unique dishes and offers a few twists on the usual staples you would find at diners normally. My wife and I ordered the Okonomiyaki and Shrimp & Cheesy Grits, both very delicious. I also ordered the Little Goat Latte, which was interesting but probably wouldn't order again (made with goats milk, personally not a fan of it. I do love goat cheese though).

Service was great, location is great, and ambiance is great. I definitely recommend any adventurous lovers of breakfast food to try Little Goat Diner!
Very nice burgers - big portion of fries with them will fill you up! Very delicious food and service was very friendly and helpful
Great food, super efficient for lunch. Was able to get in, eat a great meal and get out in a small amount of time. Wide open concept in dinning area makes the room a little loud.

Delicious menu, bright location, worth getting out of bed early on a weekend day! My only complaint is that they're always out of the cinnamon rolls when I'm there! Everything tastes fresh and the service is good and polite. Again, it's worth getting out of bed early on a weekend!

So I finally tried little goat again after a year because I've had pretty awful previous experiences. Previously the food has just been ok and the service was awful and slow. They also messed up the bill and charged my card triple what it should have been! Not only that, but I had to call them 10 times over 3 months for them to correct the error. The management office never returned my calls and when I finally got a hold of them, they were not even apologetic!  Hopefully they have since changed their management.

Anyway, I gave it another try and our waitress was really great. I was pleasantly surprised with the service and the food was good, but it is just not my style. I know it's a diner, but I just always feel SO unhealthy when I eat here. And not in a satisfied way...but in a gluttonous way. I do love the ambiance and the beer selections are great!
This will still be an every once in a while spot for me.

Was super excited to check out one of my favorite Top Chef's restaurants...sadly disappointed. Crab dip app tasted of minimal to no crab; ritz crackers better served on the side vs in the hot dip as they became soggy. I really enjoy chop chae, so chop chae burger it was, meh. Everything is ala carte, got a side of $9 Mac and cheese. Was it worth $9??? Eh, debatable. Highlight was the Reuben; Kim chi was a surprisingly pleasant addition. Reserved seats at the counter, was seated immediately before our reservation time. Service was forgettable. Was cool to watch the cooks/chefs in action, looked to be a well oiled machine. Too bad the food was not as I had hoped. But if you're ever in the Windy City, check it out for yourself and decide.

Weekend in Chicago and I wanted to have a nice brunch and I came across this place. Here is my review:

AMBIANCE/ DECOR

What a beautiful place. It gives you that diner feel but with a modern twist. Perfect ambiance if you want to take friends from out of town or if you are like me from out of town.

FOOD

There some traditional diner food but since you are there, you might as well get their unique dishes. Some of the dishes are Asian inspired dishes with some fusion twist to it. Recommend the Yum, the waiters will know what you are talking about. Also the Cinnamon buns are delicious and perfect for sharing. Also asks for the today's special. You might want someone out of the menu.

SERVICE

The waiters were friendly and nice and gave us some tips of what to order. They were also attentive during our time there

OVERALL

Very nice place with great ambiance and food. Also the prices are fair for the quality and portioning. Great choice for breakfast/ brunch.
The Little Goat Diner offers fresh food and great drinks. The design- decor is top notch. The service was top notch.

Little Goat is a solid diner to eat at when you are in the area. We usually stop in when we are waiting for a table at another nearby restaurant. It's a great place to sit and order some appetizers and drinks while you wait.

For this visit, we decided to share the hot crab dip and the pork belly fries. The dip was filling and tasty. It comes with ritz crackers-I would prefer to soak up all of this deliciousness with bread, but the buttery crackers pair well with the cream cheese and crab dip.

The pork belly fries aren't really "fries". I would say they are more like pork belly -tato chunks. The potatoes are thicker, and sometimes that awesome pork belly flavor from the meat morsels can get lost in the sea of taters. However, the portion is very filling and the pickled jalapeños add an extra oomph of tastiness.

I paired my food with some Vandermill Totally Roasted. I love that they have this on draft, along with a decent list of other beers. Service is good, especially for how crowded it gets in here. Yup, Little Goat is alright in my book. I appreciate being able to nosh on some tasty fare while waiting to go nosh on even more tasty fare somewhere else.

I wanted this place to be good, but I was disappointed.
Since it was my first time I asked our server what were some of his recommendations. He recommended the Springy Shrimp and Pork Belly so that's what I got. We also ordered Fat Elvis Waffles and Goat Chili Cheese Fries.

Our appetizer (the cheese fries) were pretty good the first couple of bites but got very heavy towards the end. Then our entrees came, but it wasn't what I ordered. He gave me the Pork Belly Pancake instead of the Shrimp and Pork Belly. I had to wait 30min for him to come back because he kept disappearing and was chatting with other customers. He didn't even acknowledge that he got my order wrong and said he thought that's what I ordered originally. After another 25-35min my correct order came out. By now I am not even hungry anymore and was tired of waiting for decent service.

My friend's Fat Elvis Waffles were pretty good though. My two dishes (even the mistake dish) was not good. The pork belly was so hard and dry. The Shrimp and Pork Belly dish was super salty too. If you come here make sure NOT to order any of the Asian fushion dishes. I had plenty of good Asian fusion dishes and this is NOT the place to order it. It's called a "diner" for a reason so stick with the breakfast/burger entrees.
Service is much better than its sister reataurant. Food is more filling, tastier, and more affordable.
These guys are making cocktails like they have a higher purpose. Come join. Negroni like Nona.

We ate a late breakfast here on a Friday around 11am. There was a significant wait since we didn't have a reservation but there were seats open on the bar side and a full menu is available there. My husband and I both ordered a breakfast - me, traditional eggs and bacon and him, biscuits and gravy. We also ordered the hash browns, which we shared...and still did not eat all of what was served! Nothing spectacular about our meals, but we were being conservative in our choices. Service was very good. Now, let's talk about the cinnamon rolls! Literally, the best I've ever had. Warm, gooey center with plenty of icing but it was not overwhelmingly sweet. It was just right! SO GOOD! Even my hubby agreed and he's not a big sweets person at all. The prices were reasonable for a big city joint. We spent less than $50, including the tip.

Little goat was good! Our server was fantastic! There were maybe only a few things I would tweak.

My favorites were the BBQ sauce that came with the tempuras mashed potatoes. I would put more of it on the plate and put it on top of the potatoes so I would maximize my sauce ratios. I got the chicken pot pie and it was the best pot pie I have ever had. As an adult, I usually don't like pot pies. I am so glad I gave this one a shot! I got the pisco party cocktail and it was great. This was my first introduction to pisco so the fruit vibes in the cocktail made the welcome smooth. My husband enjoyed his banh mi burger. I give props to little goat for not over cooking the burger like 75% of places do.

I would change the Mac and cheese. It was soupy white cheese with shell noodles. I personally would have added something for texture and maybe something chili pepper based to build flavor. There were also too many hard caramel chunks in the "corny" sundae.

Overall, this is diner food elevated with some decor elements of a classic 50's diner with modern decor bits as well. I would definitely try girl and the goat if I could plan ahead better!

pics.caption: Chicken pot pie, banh mi burger, tempura potatoes, and chili

review.des: The call is the Goat but it's not the greatest of all time. It's nothing crazy. I would be willing to try the breakfast there but the dinner wasn't worth waiting. We had the rueben, los drowned, and fried pickes/onions. I was trying to gauge the room for what other people were eating and it seemed very balance. I guess i understand why people enjoy the variety but for me the quality wasn't there. Service and ambience were great, but cooking and cocktails were underwhelming.

Girl and the Goat menu was too adventurous for my fam, so I opted for brunch here to get some of the Top Chef Stephanie I experience. Interesting tasty items.

Food: 4, Service: 4, Atmosphere: 4
Cost to worth it rating: 4 (most breakfast entrees $11-14)
Return worthiness: yes
Kids menu: yes
OpenTableable: yes. Definitely make a reservation to avoid the long wait for brunch.
Eve award: best biscuit and jam combo

Highlights:
- Biscuit and blueberry jam: large fluffy square biscuit and the most delicious blueberry jam to go with it. Not sure what put this over the top, but one of the best I've had (and my hub is from the South so I've had my fair share). 5+ stars
- French toast: not an ordinary French toast but the most custardy textured puffy French toast with an egg embedded in it toad in the hole style. But it doesn't stop there, pieces of tasty fried chicken tenders are on top along with strawberries and syrup! This was my hub's order but I may have stole quite a bit after he offered me a try bite. ;-) 4.75 stars
- Corned beef hash: not much of a twist here with thin slices of meat, huge pile of hash browns, and 2 eggs of your choice on top. Extra attention was on the hash browns which were ever so thin to enable more crispy surface area within. 4 stars.
- Brunch beverages: unique offerings outside of a standard mimosa or Bloody Mary which I appreciated. I got a walnutty drink with bubbles which was boozy and tasty.
- Atmosphere: lively diner vibe. Friendly staff.

Midlights:
- Dessert menu: with the bakery next door was expecting more items than a pie, shakes, and sundaes.

Lowlights:
- They were so busy for Sunday brunch, we checked in for our reservation a few minutes our time and they said they were cleaning the table. 15-20 minutes later, we still weren't called and when I checked in the girl looked over at the table which was clean and empty and apologized. Understand it was busy but would have been nice if they would have offered us something extra or off of our bill for the wait. We had bags with us so should have been apparent that we were off to the airport right after.
- Don't have bagels after 11 or 12. My son's fave.

Fun spot. With so many great food options in Chicago, not sure I'd rush back but I definitely wouldn't veto it if someone suggested it. Especially for the biscuits and jam.

Seems like this is one of the go-to brunch places in Chicago, so as a tourist this weekend, you already know I had to go! We came on a Saturday for lunch and thank goodness we made a reservation -- people were coming in and leaving after hearing that the wait would be "45 to an hour."

The menu features pretty classic diner food -- all day breakfast, some sandwiches, and some entrees. I decided to go with the corned beef hash with the eggs over medium. It was really good! I did wish the pieces of corned beef were a bit smaller, but it's easy enough to cut up with a knife. The potatoes were good, but I also wish they were crispier. However, the dish was still really flavorful and not too salty or oily!

What I wish I really got was the bullseye toast that everyone was talking about. My friend got it and I tried a bit and it is just the perfect combination of sweet and savory. And putting the egg INSIDE?!? Revolutionary.

Though the restaurant was crowded, service was fast and friendly. We were able to get in and out in about an hour, and didn't feel rushed by the staff at all, even though the line was clearly building. I'm sure most of the people coming here are tourists, but it's definitely worth the hype!

Little Goat has been on my list of places to try and it did not disappoint! I write this in a lot of my reviews...but, I always go into restaurants owned by top chefs/celebrity chefs a little apprehensive because you never know if it's hype or if their food is the real deal! And I will say Stephanie Izard is the real deal!

I went in with a party of 5 on a Saturday night. Our wait was minimal and we told the hostess we had a couple more people joining us. She was very accommodating and said she would seat us in a large booth. During  our wait, we went to the bar area to grab a drink. I decided to get a cocktail instead of a beer and what a great choice it was! I ordered the Fresa Fresca! Mmmmm...it was tequila, lemon, agave, and strawberry black pepper shrub! It was perfectly made...not overly strong and not weak! Before you knew it, our table was ready and I didn't get a chance to order another one. I mean let's be real, as soon as we were seated at our table, I could only focus on the drool-worthy menu!

Everything sounded so good and that is a nightmare for someone like me who has a difficult time choosing food options! :) Luckily, I was with people who were willing to share...so, I could try multiple items! Yippeee! :)

Little Goat serves breakfast ALL day. I wasn't feeling breakfast that particular night, which made my decision a bit easier. My friends and I decided to split the following:

Appetizer
- Machos Nachos - braised pork, beans, pickled peppers, cheese, sour cream, avocado! These were very tasty! I believe the chips are house made. I would totally share these again.

Sammiches
- Los Drowned - OMG - braised beef, havarti cheese, avocado, pickled peppers and onions and chi mayo. This was a savory and memorable sammich!

- Fish tostadas - Fried whitefish, avocado, chickpeas, onion, shallot aioli, and a harissa vinaigrette! This was also tasty!!!

Next time, I plan on trying the sloppy goat and some breakfast items!

My hubby had the This Little Piggy Went to China and he loved it. He barely spoke during the meal and killed his entree!

The service was great! Like I said, they were accommodating and gave us a larger booth since we had an addition to the party. The server was friendly and she asked us if there were any allergies in the group.

Ambiance is nice. It's wonderful food, but doesn't have that foo-foo vibe! You can go in dressed to the nines or in your favorite sports team's hoodie! Love it!

I can't wait to go back!

Every May I'm in Chicago and every May I say to myself, "I have to get to Little Goat Diner". Every year I fail, until this year...

I made it my mission, I'm going! And I did! And thank GOD I did.

Little Goat Diner, much like most popular Chicago restaurants doesn't necessarily require reservations, but don't go expecting to be seated immediately. Luckily for us, the wait was under an hour.

It's called a diner, but this isn't your typical greasy spoon. Think of your local diner from back home if they won the lottery. Still has somewhat of a diner charm but with much more style and dimly lit.

Our waiter was amazing. We asked for recommendations and he basically broke down the entire menu which is deceivingly large. They have breakfast all day which is a plus, but I opted for the club sandwich with their smoked fries. As an appetizer we all shared the nachos.

Nachos- Woah! This is a meal in itself. Homemade chips that definitely aren't your average Tortilla chip. These thick, crunchy delights are topped with pork, guacamole, cheese, and more! Everyone had to her "oh em gee" look on their face upon first bite.

the Club had turkey, ham, tomato, lettuce and guacamole on toasted bread. Super tasty, especially if you love sandwiches and boy do I. The fries were so addictive that when someone tried them I wanted to give them an evil stare. Don't touch my fries, man!

Such a good meal overall. Great service, amazing food, great atmosphere and I cannot wait to come back and try something else!
Love the food.  Inside is a bit under-whelming, so the quality of the food came as an excellent surprise.  Would recommend.

We stumbled upon this fantastic diner while wandering through Chicago looking for a place to get a cup of coffee on a Saturday morning.   They were open so we went inside to grab a bite to eat.

The menu consists of an eclectic array of dishes, ranging from simply sweet (Fat Elvis Waffles) to exotically savory (Curry Cauliflower & Eggs).  

They have a GF menu as well.   Every dish was fantastic.  I had the daily special -a weird breakfast sandwich with turkey, red pepper, fried egg, and blueberries.   It was absolutely delicious.  

I also recommend the hash browns, they are spun off the potato and look almost like angel-hair pasta.  

The service was excellent, and an extra-spicy Bloody Maria finished off the breakfast perfectly.

Nice environment, airy open ceiling, spacious seating with plenty of room between other parties. Friendly wait staff that were very attentive. Sandwiches are good sized portions for sharing. Brussels sprouts not very big if you intend to share. Moderate pricing. Would like to have a few more dessert options that were non ice cream. Overall above average diner food.

pics.caption: Los Drowned- braised beef, avocado, havarti cheese, pickled peppers and onions, chi mayo on a hoagie roll- big enough to split
Brussels sprouts- with fish sauce vinaigrette, toasted almonds and crispy onions- a little too salty for me
Dinner and side options all day

review.des:
Elvis waffles: outstanding combo!
Tempura mashed potatoes: unique & worth it
Pigs went to China: too die for.

High-quality, interesting food combos paired with the hip ambience of a diner on W. Randolph & you've got yourself a great place for a first date, second date, or family meal!

After being told it would be a 2 hour wait at another establishment, we decided to walk down the street and stumbled upon this gem. There was a 45 min wait but we found ourselves two spots at the bar and avoided the dreaded wait list. We ordered the Okonomiyaki and the Macho Nachos and we were not disappointed. The Okonomiyaki ( forgot how to spell it) was an amazing discovery and I am so glad we decided to skip a burger and order this little piece of heaven. It was sweet, it was salty, it was the bomb. The Macho Nachos were simply amaze balls and I couldn't stop until the plate was empty. The mixture of beans, guacamole, pickled onions, pork, and house made chips will definitely have me returning for more and singing it's praises to all that will listen. Do yourselves a favor and get to the Little Goat!
7/2/18 To die for goat patty melt! It just melts in your mouth with gooey deliciousness. Also tried the fried chicken...very good. The fish tostada was outstanding and I'm not normally a fan.

The staff here is both lazy and incompetent. It's disappointing because the food (though overpriced) is great.

The hostess told us there would be a half hour wait for 2 people when there were not even kidding 8 tables open and 6 open counter seats. We saw her turn away about 4 other parties of 2 insisting there was a wait. We waited for about 15 mins and finally spoke up. She then said "oh well the counter isn't set, I guess I can do it." Like yeah... I guess you can, isn't that part of your job?

We then waited for another 10 minutes for someone to greet us. The staff was congregating around the computer screens, chatting and avoiding eye contact.

Awful service this time and the next 3 times I went I had similar disappointment involving oblivious, lazy staff too self involved (even drunk once) to care about the job they were hired to do. This place needs a new floor manager stat. They are losing business by not turning tables and being attentive, let alone giving a damn.

C-I-N-N-A-M-O-N ROLLS!! get em while they last they make 50 a day and run out fast. Staff is great coffee is great. Patio is beautiful in summer. Pro tip- the bar in the back is same menu and full service. Corn beefed hash is huge and wicked good and I'm Irish Catholic so I can judge that. My girlfriend got the pancakes and she didn't talk to me while she ate them so I can tell you they're bomb too. Holla!!!!

Stopped by for breakfast on a Wednesday but made a reservation on open table just in case there was a wait. When we arrived it was busy but still plenty of seating. The hostess stand however was not doing a great job of managing things. I waited behind one other person but a group of 3 got in front of us both and the host seated them first anyways. After taking his sweet time seating them while not addressing either of us he turns to me first but I kindly let him know the girl next to me arrived before us. The restaurant was not really busy yet we were greeted (or not greeted) by a semi frazzled and not too friendly face. But my ranting aside, the food was good and the decor felt fresh yet comfortable.

We ordered the dark chocolate chip pancakes, this little piggy meet China, the oatmeal, a regular coffee, and a little goat latte.

The pancakes were tasty with the right balance of sweet and slight bitter from the dark chocolate. The little piggy meet China was a breakfast sandwich covered in their version of a Sichuan sauce w a mild amount of the numbing peppercorns. It was a very unique and well balanced dish. The oatmeal I only had a small taste of because it was for my toddler. She didn't like it because she has the typical refined toddler palate. I had a taste and the steel cut oats were very creamy and all the flavors really meddled well together. I also had the little goat latte which uses goat milk and tons of spices. It tasted like a chai latte on steroids. The flavor profile was very unique but extremely tasty. I wished I had opted for the whipped cream because that would have been that hit of sugar it needed. I should have known that each component of each dish/drink has been thought out and I should not alter or substitute.

Little goat diner may not be for everyone but for me it was the perfect fusion of the typical w an unexpected twist.

5 stars for food and concept but only 3 stars for service. The guy at the hostess stand was a hot mess and not very friendly, our waitress was efficient but had an air of forced friendliness that was very off putting. Little goat diner is admittedly a refined diner but what should feel like a fun, casual, and fresh dining experience is colored by the unfriendly staff. Perhaps they were taught to be more formal, which I don't mind but it felt forced and unhappy in such a fun concept restaurant.

I went to this diner per a coworker's recommendation and I was not disappointed. I went and made reservations for dinner and was promptly seated. Ordered the little pig went to china and I gotta say never did I imagine that strawberries with a savory dish could taste so good. :)

Will definitely stop by again when I am in town.

pics.caption: This Little Piggy Went to China - I never couldve imagined that strawberries with a savory dish could taste so good!

review.des:
Disclaimer - I'm a big top chef and love girl & the goat, like little goat and indifferent to duck duck goat.

Went here for a brunch with a reservation and still waited a bit. Which is fine except the guy running the front desk was super frazzled and kept forgetting the name on our reservation, fake it til you make it!

I like that it's Asian fusion but I found the little miss piggy went to China way too salty. I don't like duck duck goat because I found everything too salty but I never thought that about little goat til this brunch.
I was chugging my cold brew and eating the Cinnabon bun on the side to even out the flavor.

Service was great and I always join the brunch vibe but need to recalibrate the flavor.

We approve of Little Goat! After much deliberation, we went with the Bull's Eye French Toast (Rosemary French Toast, with an ooey gooey egg hidden inside, topped with crispy fried chicken, strawberries and syrup) paired with crispy hash browns, filled with white cheddar cheese. Adorable spot, great team (all smiles), and the best place to sit is at the counter where you can see everyone's order come out and *drool* while you wait!

Much nicer than any other diner. Ordered the pork belly scallion pancake & it was delicious!! Friend ordered the okonomiyaki which was absolutely bursting with flavor. Food was an 11/10 would highly recommend. Nice diner aesthetic. However, it was rather loud and hard to hear. Service was slow as well. Would give 4.5 stars!!!

Excellent food and great location. Staff was very polite and friendly. Ordered a Spanish Omelette with Fat Elvis Waffle...good stuff.
Would definitely go back and try more stuff. It's a popular spot for Sunday Bfast/Brunch among locals. So be there early or expect 30 mins of waiting time.
nice little place. creative foods that aren't too over the top. cheap prices and really good food

Little Goat is so much fun, well worth the wait. The diner doesn't look and feel like what I'm used to in NYC, but it is more like a modern upgrade to the diner style dining.

Their fusion flavors is full of surprises and it blends together in ways that I can't even explain! The menu descriptions sounds like a simple, boring dish, but the name and final product is something that has you giggling and excited for the next visit. The perfect blend of American and Asian flavors is something that I've always been on the search for and Little Goat hits every spot of it!

Must order: This Little Piggy Went to China, Bull's Eye French Toast.

Only four stars because service could have been slightly better. I got a hint of neglect, took a while to get the bill. Otherwise, I'd be all for it. Expect a wait, there's always a wait.

Another great and actually affordable spot on Randolph! This place is always packed, so make a reservation if you can, or be prepared to hang out for more than an hour's wait.
I went here with a large party for a birthday lunch and while there was a 100% approval rating from my co-workers on the food, I did notice quite a lot of disparity in the size of the food portions. Everyone received a greater portion than you could typically expect on Randolph Street, but we were all served at the same time, and yet by the time we decided to get the check, some of us had finished cleaning our plates over 20 minutes earlier and some people only managed to get about halfway through their sandwiches. In order to get the most out of your Little Goat experience (and not leave craving something from BomboBar across the street) you probably need to do a little research.  Pick a few items you are interested in and comb through those public Instagram photos!
A quick way to estimate it is probably to go by your choice of meat. I had the Pork Belly Scallion Pancake, which only had one smallish slice of pork belly, which I obviously ate first (as one must do) and then I was stuck with a plate of savory pancake and cabbage, which was tasty, but still...
Right next to me there was the much recommended "This Little Piggy Went to China" featuring Szechuan Pork Sausage, which was very well garnished but essentially the same size as a McDonald's breakfast biscuit. On the other end of the spectrum, there is the Los Drowned (braised beef) and The Fat Club (turkey), which were both so huge that they had to take the other half to go. All that disparity was found in items that are only separated by a $1 difference in price, so choose wisely!

The nachos were not only the best nacho dish I have ever had but, the actual nachos themselves were fantastic.  Crispy, crunchy and thick enough to withstand the condiment and cheese onslaught

The dish is CHICAGO on a plate.  Cheesy and pork and fried and so over the top that I couldn't eat a quarter of the plate.  

Menu looks like a best of greatest hits of comfort food. If the other dishes are anywhere near as good as it reads or the nachos well,  it's time to pack a bowl and strap on the old feed bag.   Damn,  I regret my limited appetite as I wish I had ordered the patty melt, or the goat chili, or the cheese fries, or the pot pie, or the blue plate special.

Already had dinner across the street from girl and the goat and decided to have dessert by the bar area in little goat.
The chocolate taco was a nice touch with the sweet and salty combination but the winner hands down was the pork and toffee milkshake!

pics.caption: Chocolate Choco Taco - Pork and Smoked Pork & Toffee Crunch

review.des: Best brunch I've ever had. Little Goat knows how to bring big, punchy flavor that is plated with finesse.  We had "This little piggy went to China" as well as a daily special that was a mole quesadilla made with Bourbon County Brand Stout. Both were phenomenal with hearty portions. We had the pork belly potatoes as well, and it was plenty to share. Service was perfect. Will definitely be back!
soo good. Super trendy. friendly staff. Had the Okonomiyaki which was super different but amazing. And I had their grown up shake, highly recommend.

How does this place get so many good reviews.  I just had the worst lunch ever.
Service: 0,  waiter never came by to refill my water.  He didn't stop by to ask if I needed anything.  I would have complained to him right away.   The food took about 1/2 an hour to come out.  
Food: 1
I ordered a Caesar's salad with added fried chicken.  The chicken was dry and rock hard.  They were probably have been sitting out for a while.  The romaine lettuce were all wilted.  How can you screw up a salad order.
Pork belly waffle fries:  I got potatoes wedges.  Don't look like waffle fries to me.  The only good part of that "fries" was the pickled jalapeños.  
So disappointed and angry for such a nasty meal.  I've had such a bad experience years before and I decided to try them  again since au cheval has an hour wait.  Big mistake!!  Same crappy service and food!!

Great brunch spot! I had the little piggy went to China because I heard such good things about it. The chive biscuit was SO tasty with the over easy egg and pork. The blackberries were also a unique touch! Definitely an imaginative plate. All of the flavors worked really well together! Will be back.

This is a great option if you're looking for the Girl and the Goat on a budget! Much of a more daytime-diner feel but with an interesting menu. Large selection of breakfast food during all their hours

I usually come here when I don't know what to eat. Great for lunch and brunch. A lot of interesting sandwiches so don't be afraid to try something new. Love their spin on a katsu (breaded pork cutlet) sandwich. It's my usual go to.

Awesome vegan menu. It's not a ton of options, but everything is tasty. The avocado toast is always good. The ingredients change seasonally. We always get it. The pasta and scallion pancakes change with the season, too. The vegan home fries are AMAZING. They are probably the best part. Also, the vegan chocolate shake is quite good.

I have to take one star off just for the comfort of the restaurant. It is always so noisy that you can barely hear the people at your table. Also, it is quite cold near the windows in winter, and a lot of the booths are right there. I feel like it is designed to be noisy, but I really dislike that part. Also, valet is more expensive than the meal!

While there are certainly better vegan restaurants, this is one of the only places that pleases both vegans and people who insist they need meat. It's very decent food, with some exceptional dishes. The other place I'd recommend (and give 5 stars) is Casa Yari.

Love this place!

Every time I've been here is a delight - great service, food, and environment. The oatmeal is a revelation and literally the best oatmeal I've ever had.

The cafe next door is also great. Try the barista special (it's currently sesame iced coffee), the little goat coffee, and daily bagels.

This place has been on my list every trip I've made to Chicago. We didn't make reservations and were in the area walking around looking for breakfast. The wait was only 30 min which was shocking.

Ordered:
Bagel and cream cheese- great nyc style bagel
Drowned Sandwich which was beef brisket and delicious (but meh) and the "little piggy goes to China". The little piggy on paper sounds weird but wow. Jalapeño cheddar biscuit, pork fennel sausage patty with a sunny side up egg. It was soaked in this Asian sauce, topped with strawberries. INSANE  

At first glance the menu was overwhelming. I'm a huge fan of this restaurant group but this menu is displayed unlike the others. I honestly had a hard time deciding on what to order...nothing really was jumping out at me for that ORDER THIS NOW moment.

Enjoyed brunch. Happy to check it off my list

pics.caption: The little piggy goes to China

review.des:
We had a late lunch on a Thursday afternoon. The place is very cute with kind of a hipster vibe. The menu is large and varied. My hisband had the beef noodle salad, which he enjoyed. I had the Fattoush, kind of a Mediterranean thing. It was good, but undoubtedly the strangest salad I've ever eaten due to the quinoa sprinkled liberally through the entire salad.  It gave everything a seedy texture. Despite this, it tasted good enough.
The reasons for three stars are these. The service was meh...server wasn't unfriendly, but not friendly either. The whole place is incredibly noisy and very loud. Very poor acoustics with a high ceiling and a giant skylight. We couldn't have a conversation without yelling!

On day 2 of our Chicago visit we landed at the Little Goat diner for brunch and it certainly did not disappoint.  I ordered this little pig goes to China and can I just say that I'm still craving it a day later!!!  Every dish we had was top notch a by far the best food we had in Chicago.  Everyone must check this eatery out ASAP!

This place was so good, I loved being here. My group was coming from the airport and we just whimsically chose this place and made a reservation for the next available time slot they had (which was about 30 min out and it was like a 10 min walk for us). We arrived earlier than our reservation and they sat us immediately. They let us leave our luggage at the front so we wouldn't have to carry it around the restaurant.

The service was so good. Our server (and his shadow) were so sweet. They knew the menu super well and could help us choose what we wanted to drink and eat.

THE FOOD WAS AMAZING. I think they have an Asian fusion kick inspiration, which as an Asian, I kinda stayed away from lol but it definitely looked innovative with lots of kimchi and spice. I got the chicken and waffles AND IT WAS SO GOOD - the chicken was in small bits so you didn't have to cut it yourself and it came with syrup and and strawberries, which I was a little wary of at first, BUT THE COMBINATION TOGETHER WAS PERFECT omgg I don't remember what my other friends got but I tried a bit and they were also very good (I have pics though!) would definitely recommend and would come again if I could.

pics.caption: The beautiful inside of the place~
I can't remember what this is but it's pretty popular item lol

review.des: This place was amazing!!! We went for my husband bday. The server was on point with his recommendation for food. For starters we had the sweet potato bread yum. Then we had the goat empanadas! Delicious!!! Then we have the goat ribs!! Omg fall off the bone yum!!! Then we have the pig face pork! Omg we mixed it up and it was great! And lastly we had the pork shank. We were stuffed liked a tick! The service was amazing they were constantly giving us water and clean plates. We loved we will be back.

I was not optimistic about being wow-ed by this place - because what if this was one of those over-hyped places? But I'm SO glad I was proven wrong. If you are looking for unconventional, creative brunch food that emphasize on bold flavors, this is your place.

Make a reservation. I don't care which meal you're going for because this place is so popular. I made reservation at 11:45am on a Sunday and got seated immediately. The interior of the restaurant is like a hybrid between a traditional diner and a modern chic restaurant - well-lit, crowded, but comfortable. I got That Little Piggy Went To China and the Bull's Eye French Toast. Buttery, soft sesame biscuit, oozy yolk from the fried egg, finished with a spicy kick from the chili oil, the little-piggy dish is definitely playing a different game than your traditional biscuits and sausage breakfast plate. The french toast was pretty mind-blowing as well: thick-cut sweet onion brioche bread, with two eggs cracked in the middle, drizzled with maple syrup and topped with chunks of fried chicken - it's savory and sweet that hypothetically won't work, but realistically a delicious party in your mouth.

TLDR this place is very good and probably one of my favorite brunch places in town!

pics.caption: Little Piggy Went To China, Bull's Eye French toast

review.des:
I've been to The Girl and the Goat, and I absolutely loved it. So I had high hopes for Little Goat Diner, and it didn't fail me. This was one of the first place I made reservations here when my boyfriend and I decided to go to Chicago.

I made reservations here about 1.5 months in advance (I'm a huge planner). We got there around about 10 minutes before our reservation time and we had to wait a little bit. Probably 15 minutes we were finally seated. Our waitress was okay, not super friendly. She disappeared for a little bit, where she kind of just hung out by the other servers for a little bit before she came back to take our order. A little weird, because the place was PACKED.

The food took a little while to get out. But when it finally did, it was AMAZING. I ordered the Bull's Eye French Toast. I've never had anything like it, onion brioche for the french toast, fried chicken and strawberries on top with an egg in the middle of each slice. The flavors blended so well together. The sweetness and the savory were great, I loved the strawberry with the fried chicken mixed in with some of the yolk. The chicken was fried perfectly, I loved it. My boyfriend got the okonomiyaki with pork belly and a side of bacon. It looked tasty, although he was a little underwhelmed with the amount of pork belly in it.

The food here was AMAZING. I love the creativity of the dishes and how well the flavors go together. I saw that they had a table set up for an 18 person table. I'm super glad we got there before them, I'm not sure how well they would do with a large table like that.

I loved the food here, and I can't wait to come back and try more food! I like that you can make reservations here! And they try hard to get you in there when they can. Hopefully the service is a little bit more friendly, but if you're visiting Chicago like we were, you definitely want to try this place out for brunch!
Meh. It was alright. Toast was kinda pricey. Not for me. Just not for me. Service was good. Food was okay but I expected better.

Overall great place and would recommend this restaurant.  If you've ate at girl n the goat before be prepared to be underwhelmed it's a step down from that home run restaurant.

Got there early had went to the bakery side very cool ambience like an old school dinner but modern.  I went to order a Kombucha which they had on the chalkboard but he said they were out.  

We were seated at our table a bubbly Australian waitress with a lot of tattoos served us, she was great friendly and knew the menu very well.  I asked for a few recommendations she recommended the "goat almighty". It's a $20 goat burger topped with pork, fried onion ring, cheese, and steak.  I was hungry thought I could tackle a hearty burger until I saw it .  This sandwich  was massive, you need a fork and knife.  While it was large it was actually manageable. Flavored were great, spicy, and the goat was not gamy or anything like that.  

My wife ordered the paracha burrito she said it was good.  I tasted it the salad in too had good citrus and acidity to it.

My cousin ordered the little pig went to china, this was the table favorite.  It was creative, tasty and executed well.  Sesame biscuit was spot on.  Not crumbly or chalky tasting very moist.  The sauce is perfect not overly salty good balance to the sausage and egg.

We also got the chili cheese goat fries.  This is why I'm giving LG 4 stars.  I didn't care for them.  The fries in general could have been done better.  They were thin I'm a fan of a little thicker and crispier fries.  The goat cheese didn't have a lot of taste to it and the goat chili just didn't have enough chili powder flavor to it.  I would pass on this next time.

Be prepared to wait.

pics.caption: Ranch for the kids chicken fingers was out of this world.  Too 3 thinks we liked about this restaurant.

review.des:
TL,DR - weekends looking at 45 min - 1hr wait. recommend their drinks and coffee. "This little piggy went to china" plate is a bit salty just a heads up. Interior is nice and clean and dimly lit. I enjoyed the place, if it return it will be for the drinks and only when wait time is reasonable.

Food - 3/5
Service - 3/5
Vibe - 4/5

I was not sure if this place was a diner or a bar. The front of the place serves as a diner and towards the back they have a solid bar. Full bar to be exact.

Interior has a nice oldies but modernized dinner feel to it, we put our name down and gave a phone number, this allows you to walk around other places and grab a drink, and they're pretty good about sending you a heads up 10 mins before your table is ready so you can head back.

Service - Was a little slow but would assume due to a busy night. Needless to say our order was taken and food came out rather quickly.

Food - Lots of flavor, i ordered a "This Little Piggy Went to China" Sesame cheddar biscuit. Sunny side eggs. Szechuan pork sausage. Chili garlic chive sauce. Gooseberries, something different for me and had good flavor a bit overwhelming and hoped that the sweet would cancel out the saltiness of the other ingredients but dint happen. the dish was too salty for me and struggled to finish.

Espresso was very strong! just how i like it, so thumbs up on that.

Little Goat is a feast for your eyes! Upon waiting for a seat at the bar, I checked out their gift ware and baked goods. I was excited for a potentially epic meal based upon all the hype.

I ordered The Pig Goes to China and spiced caramel cider. It all sounded exquisite and others around me also wanted to order the same.

Upon being served, the dish looked and smell divine. It truly was a feast for my nose and my eyes. The first few bites were amazing -- powerful punches of sweet, salty, and richness. After a few bites, I felt beyond overwhelmed from the dish, questioning myself if I could even finish the dish. I tried to wash down this feeling with the caramel cider but that too became too much for me to handle. Downing a glass of water, all my senses were on overload. I had to stop and just push the dish away. I forced a few more bites just because I waited too long to just walk away with most left on my plate.

This is my 4th experience at a Top Chef-owned restaurant. Each has been similar -- dishes sound, look, and smell exceptional but the actual taste is overpowering. It's difficult to eat beyond a few bites -- perhaps an old habit from their Top Chef experiences where judges only taste a bite or two, not the entire dish.

First of all, when I walked in, I fell in love with the decor. So southern (I'm from Tennessee) and so cozy.

Next, our waiter was ridiculously hot, had good conversation, and was extremely helpful.

I ordered the Patty Melt and what was their "Dr. Pepper", called a pepper elixir (it tasted like Dr. Pepper with a cough syrup aftertaste). I was a little disturbed that everything was served "a la carte", which for me, meant I only got a patty melt for $13 dollars and that didn't include a side of any kind. Had to order that separate.

Food was amazing, service was okay, (waiter only checked on us twice and we were there for about an hour), and the location was easily accessible by foot or by the subway.

Would definitely come back again, but I would bring more money.

I was finally able to come back after 4 years and wow! It's even better than I remembered.
The ambiance is nice, very pretty and lively crowd.

The food was delicious! Everyone loved their meals. What we ordered:

This Little Piggy went to China: So yummy and flavorful! I've never eaten anything like this. The cheesy biscuit, Szechuan sauce, sausage and egg were perfection.

Goat Almighty: Tender meat which was good. not as big as the last time I went which could be a pro or con haha

Bull's Eye French toast: Amazing as well. The chicken was crispy and paired with the onion brioche was a flavor I'll never forget.

I didn't try the Chop Chae but my dad really liked it!

I love how the whole menu is available all day. I'm recommending it to all my friends. I will be back!!

The flavors really came together in an breathtaking manner.
The restaurant has classic American cafe style decoration. Perfect for after-work dinner or a weekend brunch. The menu is inspired by the fusion of classic American food and different Asian cuisine. The lamb burger I ordered managed to extract the best of both worlds. The flavor is refreshing yet familiar. The only problem I had was the serving size, as a young professional in his early 20s, I am constantly starving after work and I found the portion not quite satisfying.

The reason I am posting this many stars is because of the service we received during our lunch here. When we first arrived the hostess said that we couldn't get a booth. Unless we waited another 30 minutes to be seated. The employees also seemed very stressed and it did not appear to have a good work environment. To a level where our waitress disappeared for at least 20 mins and came back with tears in her eyes. Her co-workers were complaining about her being gone and didn't seem supportive, sadly.

The food was good and aesthetically pleasing but the flavor was a bit off. For example, I got a special item for that time called a ropa, this tasted okay, but the flavor was too sweet for its own good. In all honesty, I wouldn't come back here. But if your in the area stop by the cafe and get the hot chocolate which was very good.

I have been wanting to try a Stephanie restaurant and was really excited when I got the chance with a company lunch on this particular Monday. The atmosphere here is fun and casual- I love the diner feel and the decor of this place. The wait staff was excellent, and the menu was interesting. It was all wonderful, but I think I just ordered the wrong dish....

I should've known better and ordered a dish with goat in it. However, my eyes automatically went to the bi bim bap dish on the breakfast side. My first mistake was to look at the breakfast side during lunch hour I guess. I was between this and one of the salads and was prompted by our waitress to choose the bi bim bap dish. I was pretty disappointed when it came out. The dish was very liquidy- I felt like I was eating soup. And as a native Korean (where this dish originally sprouted from), the dish was not to my liking because it was so different than what I was used to. Kind of flavorless to be honest. My hungry eyes looked to everyone else's dishes with jealousy...

I did have a nice hot tumeric ginger tea though. This had a nice pang. Like I said earlier though, everything was great except for my dish choice. I look forward to coming again and ordering the right dish this time around.

Ate here for lunch by default.  We tried to eat at Au Cheval, but we weren't willing to wait for 1.5 hours.  Little goat is just down the street...
The decor is great, very bright, airy and friendly staff.  Instead of waiting for a table, we sat at the actual cocktail bar area.  I had the "bibimbap," which uses cauliflower instead of rice. It was interesting.  I can't say I enjoyed it, but to be fair, I grew up eating the traditional Korean version, so I probably wasn't the demographic the dish was aimed at.  The other dish we tried was the OKONOMIYAKI, which was better, but not something I would recommend.  However, I would still be willing to go back and give this place another try.
On a side note, as I sat there waiting for my food,  I watched the 2 busy bartenders work - making cocktails, mimosas, clearing dishes, delivering food, taking payments, using the POS, and it occurred to me that during the entire 45 minutes, I never saw either one of them wash their hands.

Totally affordable and interesting take on a diner... good to try for an adventure but something missed the mark for me.

We split the crab dip that everyone raves about... the cream cheese and crab mixture was hot and bubbly on the top and a little cold on the inside. Dipping with ritz crackers was nice but it really wasn't too special.

The goat chili was a unique take on chili but I think it wasn't my favorite. The best part were the crunchy potato sticks on the top.

Los drowned, the sandwich we ordered, has the hints of fantastic that everyone mentions for this diner. A beautiful bread, braised beef with minimal fat, avocado and picketed veggies, cheese... it was like a fancy Philly cheesesteak and really stood out.

Service is impeccable, the space is cool and hipster, and price is affordable. I would go back for more of an adventure and try the breakfast foods and more sandwiches.

I would definitely recommend you make reservations. My party of 4 decided to take a chance with no reservation and were lucky enough to be seated outside within 5 minutes. Everything here is ordered a la carte, i.e if you want fries with your sandwich you have to order them separately. That being said for the price they charge for their menu items, the portions are small! I did enjoy my food but I highly doubt I will be back.

The goat milk Carmel latte is amazing! I got it iced but would love to try it hot, come winter. Awesome atmosphere and bonus for outdoor seating as well. The blueberry pancakes with the vanilla crumble were delicious!

This is a great diner-style addition to the West Loop! It was my first of the 'goat' restaurants to visit, and after much hype it did not disappoint. Greatest of all time, amirite?

I had the fattoush salad, a cup of seasonal soup, and shared some of the fries with my friends. The salads are quite large and easy to split if you want to get that and something else.

Every sandwich looked amazing-- I would love to come back and try more.
The hummus changed my life!!!! Cajun chicken Sammy was killer and the fat club crushed it!! A absolute must when in town.

I've heard a lot about this place and I was really excited to check it out. I was honestly disappointed. Everything was average (specially the food). I ordered the 'Fish Tostadas' and all I could barely taste the fish, I only tasted the fried batter and the fried tostada. In short it was heavily fried with minimal flavor. I had to order chill sauce to make it eatable. I also ordered the 'Veggie Quesadilla' which was a little better than the tostadas. In all, it was just an average meal, probably gonna be a pass for the next time.
PS- from my experience they heavily emphasize on fried food.

Heard about this place online and wanted to try it while I was visiting Chicago. I did read that the wait times were long and when we got there around 6pm on a Friday the wait time for indoor seating was 2 hours, but luckily for us there was outdoor seating right away! The food is a fusion of American brunch and asian street food, which was a refreshing mix. I got the Japanese streetfood pancake and it tasted like a takoyaki! Would definitely come here again if I was in the area!

Awesome place to go in for lunch! I had a cup of broccoli cheddar soup & the vegan avocado toast ~ delicious! The Halloween decorations were really creative & I felt comfortable going in & sitting on my own at the bar. Cool atmosphere

This place is out of the box when it comes to taste. The ambience is very nice and the service is excellent but some of the food wasn't what we expected. The breakfast dishes we tried were traditional meals taken to a new level. I felt the dishes were a bit overdone with spice palates; I feel some dishes could have been taken down a notch.

Girl and the Goat is among my all-time favorite restaurants and I was so stoked to see a diner spot from Izzard. I love a good diner!

This was fine but not as interesting or good as I was expecting. Certainly, I knew that it would be an entirely different experience than G&tG, but I was hoping the same melding of delicious flavors and playful recipes would be in play. We did get interesting-sounding dishes but in the end they were just okay, and priced as though they were excellent. Would I go again? Probably, if in the area, but I wouldn't make a destination out of it again.
Flavourful and unique dishes. Hot spot in the west loop. Be prepared to wait even if you have a reservation.

I went here looking for a fairly ordinary breakfast, and that was probably my mistake.  This is an upscale "diner" that operates differently than a regular breakfast place.  The food was interesting and delicious, but a little more pretentious than I needed at that hour. For later in the day, I'll bet it's wonderful.

We received good service at the restaurant but the food was pretty disappointing. Other than the biscuit and gravy, none of us like the food we ordered. The omelette was dried and bland. The meat in Beef Noodle was salty (could only taste soy sauce) but the noodles were bland. The macaroni and cheese and goat cheese fries weren't as good as expected. Chances are we won't come back since there're so many good restaurants in Chicago.

Popped in for a simple breakfast with my friend. I wanted something healthy but then again not (I was conflicted because everything sounded so perfectly delicious- it didn't help that we sat right by the kitchen so could see every item that people were ordering) so I left my decision to Yelp! I decided to read the first review that popped up and get the same thing the last reviewer mentioned. So I ended up getting the breakfast paratha burrito! I'm Indian and parathas are an Indian thing. It didn't disappoint, the black bean corn salad on top was the perfect amount of healthy I wanted and the paratha was stuffed with two perfectly cooked eggs. Only thing I wished was that it had more of an Indian kick to it which would've brought the flavors full circle, which Is why I rate it at 4
Overall was deeeelish.

Making it here was such a milestone considering it's basically all anyone in the West/South Loop area talks about.  I went with some friends on a Tuesday around 4pm so we got seating right away which I know can be rare.  My only complaint is probably that the service was slow even though they didn't seem packed so I don't know how that would play out when they're busy. I didn't get any of their main dishes on this trip, but it's all diner food as you could probably guess.  I was amazed at the extent of the menu and they had a lot of customizable options for burgers and other dishes.  I got the hot chocolate and a cinnamon roll (I think they usually only serve these during the morning since they run out)  which was smothered in icing.  What's not to love about that?  I think I enjoyed the whipped cream a little more than the actual hot chocolate (little grains at the bottom of the mug, might've just been the mix).  And maybe share the cinnamon roll it was very enjoyable but definitely 3 full days worth of sugar :).

Do you like your breakfast or meal served with a side of attitude and "go fu$k yourself" hipster-tude?  If so, THIS PLACE IS FOR YOU!

Lots of people eat here.  (Lots of people also wore MC Hammer-pants going to the gym,too).  But guess what?  Chicago has a plethora of great diners, restaurants and other places that want to serve you a great meal with a smile!  

And the food?  Eh.  The most I can say if you like your dishes over-indexed on flavor and ingredients, this should be .   (I like Jackson Pollack paintings too--I just don't want to eat one for breakfast.  Nor do I need the top flavor found in hanging trees in your local cab to don my eggs).  

The Goat isn't much above the McDonalds turn-style service, so save yourself a few bucks, a little time and lots of other options in the city of great food.  

Don't say I didn't warn you if you choose to wait....

I just love love all the food here and have left so satisfied every time I've visited. I most recently had the "piggy" meal with Chinese sausage and Szechuan chili sauce on a cheddar chive biscuit. It was very good though a little heavy on the Szechuan sauce. We also had a malt milkshake and I could have drank the entire thing in one sip it was that good. And the barista special for the season is a sesame lemon sweet cream latte that I just can't get out of my mind. I'm docking one star for service which has been slow to nonexistent the past few times I've visited. But the food is amazing and I'm glad to brave the crowds and mediocre service to continue returning.

This is such a cute brunch place! Thank you Stephanie Izard, once again! If you love this Top Chef/Iron Chef as much as I do and would like to check out another of her restaurant, come here for brunch!

You MUST make reservations in advance or else you'll be waiting for at least 45 minutes for a table. Trust me, it's worth planning in advance. And even if you have a reservation, plan to wait a little bit because this place will be packed.

This casual restaurant has a huge menu! Don't worry, you can order anything on the menu anytime. That's right, you can eat brunch for dinner or vice versa. Their portions size is just as large as the menu. You definitely won't go home early.

I highly recommend the This Piggy Went to China, Bull's Eye French Toast and Parathas Burrito. This Piggy Went to China is an asian fusion biscuit with egg and sausage. You'll love the chili garlic sauce and how savory it is. It's small size is very deceiving. I love how the Bull's Eyes French Toast has an egg incorporated into each toast and how it's topped with strawberries. You don't even need to ask for maple syrup on the side because it's drenched in it. The Parathas Burrito is surprisingly good. It's a sunny side egg wrapped in an indian flat bread topped with a whopping amount of avocado, salad, red kidney beans and pickles. The menu description doesn't even adequately describe how good it is. The side of orange sauce and the pickled vegetables make the dish. You can't go wrong with their special omlettes either.

Their tonkatsu sandwich, goat chili fries and machos nachos are humongous! Their sandwiches are a little on the small side, which make you want more. Be sure to order a side dish if you order a sandwich. I recommend the reuben and los drowned sandwiches. Avoid the pork belly pancake - it's small.

Everyone is super nice here. Don't be afraid to ask for recommendations! Service is quick and efficient.  

Overall, you can't beat the ambience, service and food at Little Goat Diner. It's definitely worth the hype - if you make a reservation and know what to order. I'm a huge fan and would definitely recommend it if you're looking for a brunch place.
Very good Sunday breakfast place. Waitress was friendly. Go early, it gets crowded. If you don't like little kids with your meals, this isn't the place for you.

Fairly average cuisine - probably my least favorite of Chef Izard's restaurants in the area (Duck Duck Goat is by far the best).  Most of the items on the menu are very heavy - best advice is to share the dishes and don't over order.  The drinks and coffee are good.  Outdoor seating is nice.

10/27/17
The more casual sister restaurant to Girl and the Goat. A diner that is so much more than that. A photo booth while you are waiting, one side is a coffee/ pastry shop the other serves full meals. We had to have reservations for lunch. The goat chili was recommended by the server, and they should know. I was hesitant but went with it and was so glad I did. Excellent, elevated grill cheese, mac and cheese and craft cocktails. Not an inexpensive linch but enjoyable nonetheless. $89 for three of is.

Went here for breakfast this morning for the first time! I heard great things from other people and It definitely lived up to its reviews. We had the Spanish omelette and It tasted authentic. The sausage patties were great and the pork belly potatoes tasted delicious. Other tables had food that looked even better than ours! Our only regret was not ordering more adventurous food cause everyone else's looked so delicious.

This is the second time I've been to Little Goat for brunch and the second time I've been very pleased and left stuffed and happy.  We ordered fried pickles and onions as an appetizer and when it was delivered to the table, it was only onions.  Turns out the kitchen ran out of pickles but none of the waitstaff knew.  They comped the appetizer which was nice since the fried pickles were what we wanted to try!  I got the sourdough pancakes which were simple but really well done and delicious.  Two people in my party ordered the Fat Elvis waffle which had a HUGE scoop of peanut butter butter on top- they both loved it.  My other friend ordered the pork belly pancake and tempura mashed potatoes.  Tempura mashed potatoes are a genius idea and worth trying.  Little Goat has been packed both times I've gone with a line out the door of people waiting for a table.  Make a reservation if you can or be prepared to wait- it is worth it.

I had the grilled cheese and a apple tomato soup. It was good but a bit too savory for my palette. There are not much pescatarian options. You should try the place at least once, especially if you are craving breakfast food at any time of the day.

OMG this was my first visit to one of the goat trio of restaurants (Girl & the Goat, The Little Goat, Duck duck Goat) and I'm sorry I won't have the opportunity to eat at the other two (or here again). I'm glad I don't live closer or I'd likely be diving into the pork fat home fries, biscuits, SE Asian-inspired breakfast dishes and sandwiches every weekend. Our server was friendly, helpful, patient and offered a variety of suggestions. I'd describe the decor as retro contemporary if such a thing exists. If not, know it's hip and pleasing.

Consistently stellar dishes, wait times can be exceedingly long with very limited space to wait, and in my experience service tends to be a little spotty.

One of my favorite things about Little Goat Diner is they constantly offer specials with seasonal ingredients that are totally distinct from anything else on the menu.  My go to here has always been the parathas burrito. For a non-meat dish it is so satisfying.  Also, love love love the tempura mashed potatoes because...hello what's not to love!?! The nachos are insane. Anything on the menu that features goat is bombtastic.

Like I said, the wait can be somewhat lengthy but honestly it's worth it.  Coffee is bottomless but you're probably gonna have to flag down a server to get topped off.

What do you do when you want to go to Girl & The Goat but are traveling with kids?
Go across the street to Little Goat Diner.

The menu items are adventurous & interesting while the kids menu is familiar & safe.
A win-win!

Mac & cheese for my grade-schooler!
Pancakes for my toddler!

For me? The Los Drowned braised beef torta combining Mexican accents of guacamole & pickled veggies reminiscent of escabeche.

There was also okonamiyaki on the menu!
The server recommended it but I'm not a fan of okonamiyaki. However, I was delighted by the eclectic choices on the menu.

Our sever was amazing. He was attentive & helpful! I wish we got his name.

We sat outside on the sidewalk & enjoyed our meal watching the people & cars pass by.

I'd definitely return here upon future visits!

This may be a case of "Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice, shame on me." On a recent trip to Chicago, after reading all the positive reviews of Stephanie Izard's restaurants, my husband and I visited Duck Duck Goat. Suffice it to say we had a bad experience.

Not easily dissuaded from the glowing press on the Goat Group, we decided to try again with lunch at The Little Goat Diner. While it was a better experience than Duck Duck Goat, it was still fairly unimpressive. Here's my take:

The Good:
Freshly squeezed grapefruit juice - delicious - and a big fat latte - also delicious
Goat chili - well seasoned with surprising heat and great flavor

The Middling:
A dairy-free menu. On the one hand, it's reassuring to know that my food will, in fact, be dairy-free, and I appreciated that. On the other hand, the menu was rather limiting and communicated that the kitchen wasn't willing to make simple alterations - for instance taking cheese off a sandwich - to make a regular menu item dairy-free.
The Pork Torta and the Smoked Corned Beef Hash with Eggs - two big 'ole piles of food that were good enough but not great.

The Not-So-Good:
Seating at the end of a counter-top table in the bar area left my husband staring down the table at four other couples - just kind of weird.

In the end, I guess goats may not be our thing.

My only regret here was that I could not finish off every bite. I ordered the whipped feta toast off the fresh sheet. I wasn't sure what to expect but it was really fantastic. The hash browns are worth the splurge.

Coffee was also great. Bloodymary had something different going on. I wasn't a fan but maybe you will be.

Hopefully I will be back through again to hit this place up for dinner. As a west coaster, I am always on the search for tasty late night options, and this definitely fills that bill, and then some.

Me & my hubs were looking for a new brunch spot in the city and stumbled upon little goat. The ambiance is great, we waited less than 25 mins to be seated on a Sunday around 1pm. Their brunch menu has lots of options I ordered everything is everything crumpets - the first bite or two were yum, the more I ate I started feeling sick - the salmon was SO salty and lox was pretty greasy. The combined combo left me with a not so good after taste.

First time here. Had the Los Drowned Sammich and Fish Tostadas. So many flavors. Wished I had room for dessert but it was not to be :(
Definitely on my list of restaurants to return to the next time I'm back in Chicago.

We tried to go to the Girl & the Goat, but they were closed for a private event. We tried:

Not Chinese Broccoli: American broccoli sautéed with garlic, peanuts, pickled red peppers, sesame seeds, Sichuan peppercorn. Broccoli was perfectly crunchy & the broccoli heads soaked up the sauce. Very tasty. This dish was recommended by the server.

Asparagus: sautéed perfectly, crunchy, and covered in a mayo based sauce. Wonderfully seasoned. Also a dish recommended by the server.

Reuben with bacon, sauerkraut & kimchi on rye: a bit salty from the corned beef, bacon, sauerkraut, & kimchi, but the flavor was somewhat balanced by the havarti cheese. Very flavorful and delicious. Bread was perfectly crispy and browned. Outstanding dish, which was also recommended by the server.

Beef short rib: our least favorite dish, flavor was decent, but not amazing, meat was very tender, covered with sautéed pea shoots, asparagus, and onions & diced pepper on a bed of puréed & thinned avocado (note: This dish can only be ordered after 5pm).

Service: excellent, attentive, friendly, and quick

Atmosphere: causal, fun & modern decor, plenty of booths along the perimeter of the restaurant. We went during off peak hours, so we were seated immediately.

Final verdict: a solid choice, definitely would visit again

Been to Little Goat a couple times now and every time I go I kinda wonder why I don't visit more frequently.

Despite being a dinner, the food is upscale, often with a bit of an Asian twist, and the menu is huge so there's definitely whatever you're looking for. Everything from breakfast foods (eggs, pancakes, even cereal) to normal dinner items.

My favorites include the okonomiyaki, pork belly pancake sandwich, and tonkatsu. Obviously all have an Asian flavor and are incredibly delicious. My girlfriend has gotten a couple of the burgers and they're certainly unique combinations - unique in a good way, she's really liked them.

Only knocks I have against Little Goat are the side dishes, then to be a little pricey and both the fries and chili weren't all that impressive. The fries especially, too Smokey and kinda soggy.

But overall, Little Goat is fantastic. Definitely recommend and be aware it gets busy.
I went there with my friends and everything we ordered was loaded with flavor. I enjoyed it so much. Will definitely be back soon seeing that I don't work too far away from it.

I would have given the restaurant three stars....the staff was really nice.

Our waitress was amazing and recommended the Crispy Shrimp Cocktail. That appetizer had an amazing flavor. For dinner I had the springy shrimp and pork belly, and it was missing something. It was lacking in flavor, and now that I've rechecked the menu I realize it may have been missing the tamarind vinaigrette. The dish disappointed me and it uses the same noodles for sopa de fideo, which has more flavor. For dessert we had the cake do the day, the fudge cake, that was amazing! The layered were filled with cookies! The cocktails we had were ask tasty. The main dish was the only disappointment for the night, but overall I may go one more time to give their main dishes a second chance but to also have that amazing appetizer.

4 stars because the food was amazing but the service staff was super pushy and made our group feel rushed. We were literally in and out in an hour. Plus, valet is $14, which is a little high for a one hour meal.

I had the Creole Crab Crumpets and they were absolutely scrumptious. All of the flavors balanced so well. There were ample clumps of crabmeat. Bloody Marys were nice and spicy. Iced coffee came in a very large glass.

Reservations highly recommended.

pics.caption: CREOLE CRAB CRUMPETS - $15.00 sunny side eggs . chili sauce . holy trinity

review.des:
I've been planning for this day several weeks in advance. We were looking for a brunch place and had other plans for dinner (hence no reservation at the Girl and the Goat). We found the Little Goat Diner on open table and based on the reviews of yelpers and friends, we decided to give this place a try. You walk in and say. Ok, it's a diner. waffles, pancakes, some sandwiches sure. Standard fare. But really, this diner is anything but standard. If you're coming the day of without a reservation forget it. Every person I told that we were going to this diner were raging about it. They talked about their amazing experiences so we were definitely excited to give it a try.

The menu is large from sweet to savory. Isn't that always the toughest decision debating between the two? I usually get my decision down in under 2 minutes but this time I had to peruse the choices over a few times before I decided. Even then, I had to choose two dishes but luckily I was there with a couple other people to share.

We ordered the okonomiyaki which is apparently a Korean street dish much like a savory pancake. Well worth the try. The tonkatsu sandwich was awesome and were you looking for something sweet? The grape pancakes were to die for. Who would have thought that flour and grapes coming together could be so amazing?

Love love loved this place. They think outside of the box and actually make good stuff. Make a reservation here for brunch if you are around. It'll bound to be one of your happiest memories in Chicago ;)

I was helping my girlfriend move out of Chicago and this was the last place we ate before we left because I really enjoyed Girl and the Goat (we'll probably be back to the city to visit, but still significant).

We got the okonomiyaki, bull's eye French toast, and the smoked pork and toffee crunch milkshake. The okonomiyaki and the French toast itself were good but the chicken and the milkshake were amazing. I'd probably come back here just for milkshakes and desserts, actually. The salty pork made the toffee taste even sweeter; very indulgent but you're at a diner, after all.

The service we received was a little abrupt and we were seated in a high-traffic area where my elbow was grazed by a passerby every once in a while, so I would probably ask for a booth next time.

I thought this place was different than Girl and the Goat, and it's probably meant to be, both in atmosphere and cuisine. Still, a positive experience and I'd be happy to come back here again.

This vibe and menu are nothing like the name-sake restaurant, Girl and the Goat. With that said, yes the food is awesome. Yes, the service is great. The menu is very inspired and the premise is just a great meal. It is a diner though, it vibe and menu, so I don't necessarily recommend for dinner.

There are people that rave about this place, but I didn't have the experience others seem to have had. We had seven of us for breakfast, we made reservations in advance, and they still tried to cram us into a booth for six...four of us on one side was way to small and they refused to move us to the larger open table next to us which sat empty nearly our entire breakfast.

5 of us ordered the French Toast with the cooked egg in it. 3 of those plates came out with the egg completely raw (clear whites), one was sent back, and when we mentioned it to the manager, we just kind of got a shrug and a "I'll talk to the chef" with nothing else done. Big letdown for how much hype. Wasn't terrible but definitely wasn't up to what I had heard. Maybe just a one off?

Great service and great food! Also had the spicy mezcal drink and it was excellent.  Justin was fantastic and recommended great sides like the mac and cheese and broccoli. I wish we had this place in Miami! Thank you!

Had the opportunity to go to dinner here with some friends and I'm not sure what the hype is about this place.  The food is well made but nothing wowing, ambiance is nice albeit extremely loud (maybe the loudest restaurant I've ever been to), and the service is brisk.  What this restaurant gets right is the overall vibe of being casual food but in an upscale venue that makes it fun for groups.  

For food we had the goat burger bahn mi, the shrimp and grits, club sandwich, and the smoked fries.  The goat burger was mediocre especially for the price.  The flavors were overpowered with acid, there was no salty pate or ham, there was no real fresh herb flavor, it was just goat and pickled acidity.  I've had lamb burgers throughout the city that are head and shoulders better and at a better price.  The burgers here are all around 13 dollars with no sides which is a little ridiculous.  For overall burger experience shake shack even kicks this places ass.  

The shrimp and grits were better, the grits were excellent and the shrimp was really fresh and tasty.  My only qualm is the sauce which is similar to a sauce piquant is one note.  There's no body to the sauce it doesn't have the richness you expect from shrimp and grits.  Again traditionally this is made with Tasso or andouille and those ingredients and smoky flavor profiles were missing.  
The texture and body of the sauce sink the dish a bit.

The club was a club, not sure why our friend ordered it, nothing special there.  The smoked fries are good but again 6 bucks for a bowl of fries with no house sauces or aiolis which is pretty pathetic.  I don't think fries at Pommes Frites in NYC were this expensive and they had a myriad of inventive sauces.  

The overall impression I get from the place is just a good effort that misses the mark.  There are glaring holes missing and it's just disappointing that the effort to fix them isn't there.  You expect that with Izard helming the ship everything would be just right but it's not.  It's more a place to eat and be seen than a foodie paradise.  Unfortunately this place is more hype than substance but I respect what it's trying to do.  

Hit the photo booth at the end, it's a fun finish.

Very good food. I ordered the fish tostados. They were super tasty.
I would come back for sure.

Meh.

I do not see what all the fuss is about.

Nothing on the menu looked appetizing.

I got a soup and salad and then I hit the road Jack

Great breakfast spot! I would highly recommend making a reservation ahead of time as the wait can be lengthy. I have had multiple options from the menu and have never had a bad meal. Staff is always friendly and coffee is solid. Enjoy breakfast with a cozy booth!

After being rejected by Au Cheval , we had dinner at Little Goat . The Nachos were delicious especially the mash beans and the pork belly . We had the club sandwich, it was OK. The Ruben was excellent . The fries were a disappointment, too salty and the smoke flavor was too strong . The portions were huge , we ended up eating half of our plates . Our server was excellent and helpful .

Great first experience with one of Stephanie Izard's restaurants. The food was delicious, I have the shrimp and pork belly which was seasoned well and more than enough portion wise.

The restaurant is designed and decorated nicely with an open airy feeling and I liked the sky light ceiling. The staff was very attentive and the craft cocktails were yummy.
Great food, a bit warm at the place, but waiter listened and closed the door that cooled down the place.
