ANYHOW, My review stands between a 4 and a 5 star rating. I got the corn beef hash while in town for the day with my family. My family also ordered the cinnamon bun at the end to share which was delish. The group was kind of large and I can't remember what everyone got but we all enjoyed it. We sat outside with our 10 month old and our dog. The waiter was extremely efficient and nice. They brought water for my dog and we had 0 issues with them. I would come back if I lived in town.

Make a reservation so you don't have to wait! Note: you can't be seated without entire reservation party at the place normally. We were a big party and had a late comer so they let us slide.

They have a lot of vegetarian options - we got the paratha burrito and it was very flavorful and yummy. Would recommend it for sure but that's because i haven't tried any of the other dishes. I did have a bite of the veggie burger american style and it was rather bland. I'd stick with the paratha burrito or one of the more exciting veggie burger options.

Service was really good, our waitress was funny and offered good suggestions.

4.5 stars. I landed at Midway International and headed straight for this place. I needed my hometown fix of over the top culinary greatness and they did not disappoint.  The hostess - my server, Rebecca - the kitchen staff - all wonderful. I made a great choice for my first stop, this trip.
The coffee reminded me of the bold and soothing blends you normallly find in the Pacific Northwest (I had to buy a bag).
The chili is a one of a kind recipe, nontraditional and expertly prepared... deliciously surprising.
I couldn't order a sandwich, because I was on a no bread week - so I asked them to make me Rueben Fries and they did it for me! Perfect meal and great staff.
Thanks Rebecca and Little Goat Diner!

pics.caption: Their own coffee blend, by Dark Matter Coffee.
It's a no bread week for me, so I asked for Rueben Fries and they made the dish for me! Delicious. Try their house hot sauces too.

review.des:
I ordered their kimchi burger and it came out too raw, however the server replaced everything for me rightaway and no questions asked, very friendly, attentive staff, and very decent food.

crab dip was a little too salty for my taste, but overall a very pleasant experience! priced resonably for fulton market west loop area as well.

If you're planning to come in for brunch or lunch on a holiday, MAKE RESERVATIONS! Also, make sure you check if they're closing early or not because that's what happened to a lot of people. I had made reservations about a month in advance and we were seated pretty much right away. They were closing early for the Labor Day holiday, so a lot of disgruntled people got turned away at the door.

We split their Dark Chocolate Crisp Pancakes and a Goat Patty Melt. Both were phenomenal! I really liked both of them, but I think the pancakes were the clear favorite.

Our waitress was super nice and very upbeat. I would love to come back and try some of their other signature dishes - and the cinnamon bun, which was sold out by the time we went.

I've been here almost every week and have to say  today may have been an off day?? Came here for breakfast and the place wasn't even packed. Took 20 minutes for our food to be served and everything was underwhelming. Ordered the paratha burrito( dry and had wilted greens on top that looked like they were sitting under the warmer for an extended period of time) cauliflower bi bim bop (yolks were over cooked) and corned beef hash (very little corned beef that was overcooked and hash browns tasted as if it had been left over from the night before).  Didn't want to write a negative review but there should be more quality control from the kitchen before the food is delivered to the table.

Really artsy inside the restaurant. My gf wanted to go because was impressed with all the reviews. I had the banh mi burger I loved the idea but I didn't really enjoy it. My gf had biscuit and gravy & shrimp/grits which she enjoyed for the most part. The menu has a ton of uniques I will definitely be back when I go back to Chicago.

One word: crumpets. Omg. Yummy! Got the cinnamon bun as well, but we devoured it before I could get a pic. Everything was great. The ambiance is cute, service is great, and it just makes you feel good to be in there!

I throw down five stars occasionally, but if any restaurant deserves five stars it's this one.  Everything on the menu is an original and improved version of its original.  It is clear that an exceptional amount of time and effort went into each meal.

The cocktails were good. Braised beef los drowned was delicious. Chicken sandwich looked unappealing and tasted as it looked. I've been to Little Goat few times and have always been impressed. This time was lack luster.
On a side note, our waitress, Mikaela, was amazing. She made the meal.

Go on a weekday if you can! I love this place, but Fulton Market neighborhood becomes a madhouse during brunch on the weekends so it's hard to enjoy the wonderful details that make this Stephanie Izard establishment so fun.

Everything on the menu is huge. Come hungry. It is not your typical diner fare. The menu is fun and takes creative inspiration from different cultures. Try it all! Get a group and order the sticky bun. Plus, the bakery attached has amazing baked goods to take home for later on the way out.

On a Friday afternoon before New Years I went to try a burger place which is on the same street but they had a 4 hours wait time. I decided to check out nearby places and then I found this place( I've been told about this place but didn't knew where it was).
It was snowing outside, I got in and talked to the front desk if there was any wait time and yes there was an hour or so.
We've been told that the seats by the bar are first come first serve. so we went to the bar and surprisingly we got two chairs. Ordered drinks and food. I had ordered the everything goat burger. It was delicious but I couldn't finish it.

Truly spectacular. We scored a reservation for a late night on a random tuesday. Keep in mind their plates are meant to be shared (AKA, they're really small). Although it was very expensive (spent ~$250 per couple) it was worth the money. Because it was four of us we ended up ordering about 8 or 9 plates. You have to listen to the server when he/she recommends the green beans. They sound like whatever, but probably some of the tastiest I've had. I specifically enjoyed their hamachi crudo, duck tongues, pig face, and beef tongue.

I've been here a couple of times for brunch, and it's a very cute, very yummy lunch spot. Get the cinnamon buns, you won't regret it!

I'm taking off a star because we've had some cleanliness issues with the glasses, particularly, on the times that I've been there - old lipstick not being completely washed off, that kind of thing.

I love that making reservations here is super easy and doesn't require months notice in advance or hawking opentable. Breakfast is legit, prices are super affordable, staff is nice, outdoor seating is nice. I have historically always gotten the corned beef hash and invited more adventurous friends to join so I can pick off their plates. Never a mistake, everything that comes out of their kitchen is delish.

I LOVED LITTLE GOAT!!!! The atmosphere and vibe of the place was perfect. We made a reservation earlier in the day for 10 people and luckily got a table. Unfortunately, we still ended up having to wait 30 minutes past our reservation to get seated. But. The food and service more than made up for it. The place is really cute and spacious. The food was delicious. Breakfast all day-- which is one of my favorite things ever. Their burgers are great. French fries are great. The Caesar salad was one of the best I've ever had. Rail drinks were a little pricey, but I get it, it's New York. Bathrooms in the back through a door that's blended into the wall

Over-rated. Though dishes are creative, food was extremely heavy and greasy. Instead of adding flavor complexity with spices and fresh herb, this restaurant only knows how to use salt, chili, mayo, fat and more salt.  Over priced. Not impressed. Service is good.

I absolutely love the concept of a diner and love the creativity of the menu. This place tends to get a little packed so I suggest getting a reservation.
We sat outside which I also don't recommend, the service was a little slow but I think that's due to the foot traffic of this place, but the food is superb.
 I got the fish tostadas which were delicious- the fish was a little salty in my opinion but it comes with this slaw that has the perfect amount of acidity so I guess it kinda balanced out. We ordered the hash browns and nachos for the table which were both delicious.
 Overall good experience. Super chill spot, excited to go back and try more of the menu!

This place is absolutely incredible! The flavors of every dish that I had was fantastic. First time coming last night. I tried their special sesame sweet cream latte, very delish. Also tried the pork belly pancake, little piggy went to China, goat chili & pork belly fries with cheese sauce on the side. Everything was great. Highly recommend and reasonably prices. Our server was perfect, don't remember his name but great staff!

Meh, maybe I should have came for the Sunday Brunch and no right before a night out? I wanted to grab a quick dinner with a few friends before our evening of debauchery. Chef Izard's Little Goat was a definite "meh" for us. We had the biscuits and gravy and the Korean scallion pancake thing. Both were underwhelming in flavor. The biscuits were dry and the gravy lacked salty. The Scallion pancake was messy and lacked a sauce or something. I like the home-like feel to the place. Service was just alright but prices seemed a little high for an alright meal.

I am disappointed.

Little Goat can be best described as an upscale and innovative diner.  If you come for brunch, it's a good idea to make a reservation since this place is very popular on the weekends.  If you don't make a reservation, you can put your name on the list and they will text you when your table is ready.

This location includes both a seating area, and the bakery.  While waiting for a table, I headed to the bakery side and was tempted by all of the delicious sounding baked goods.  I opted just for basic iced coffee, and it was pretty good but a little on the expensive side at $5 for the 16oz.  

My friend and I were seated at the bar stool area and were fortunate to be able to see all of the meals coming out of the kitchen.  I think that being able to see all of the delicious options made picking a dish that much harder.  My friend and I shared a cinnamon roll, and it was delicious.  I decided to try the Okonomiyaki (Korean style pancake with small amounts of pork belly and a sauce over it) and was pleased with it.  A few months prior to my brunch visit, I came here at night for dessert and had the apple pie.  The apple pie tasted okay, but seemed to be missing something.  I would likely come back to this place again for brunch if I were in the area, but I don't have a strong desire to since there are other places in the area that I like a little better.

I highly recommend trying Little Goat Diner if you're in Chicago. We ordered the Crisp Shrimp Cocktail, Sloppy Goat, Pork Torta, The Fattoush, Okonomiyaki, and two Iced Dirty Chais. Our server advised us that this was a lot of food, but as hotel guests, we planned on having delicious leftovers in our room.

First, the sandwiches are HUGE. Like, bigger than my face huge, and served a la carte - not that you would need any more food with it. I'd recommend sharing a sandwich and ordering The Fattoush salad to share, so you can try more things. The Pork Torta and Sloppy Goat were both so generously piled with meat and toppings - and equally delicious and satisfying.

The Crisp Shrimp Cocktail was super original and served with lightly crispy noodles wrapped around the shrimp, on a piece of butter lettuce, with a horseradish-heavy cocktail sauce - meant to be eaten like a lettuce wrap (amazing!).

We didn't love the Okonomiyaki and I think it's because there seemed to be a lack of presence from the pork belly. I imagined that it would be chopped or in the scallion pancake, but I *think* it was shaved on top? Not sure. The Okonomiyaki also had a strong fish sauce/ shrimp paste taste to it, again not sure which one, but we didn't love it.

The Fattoush Salad may have been the best thing though. The ingredients in it are endless, and the chicken was amazing. It was huge, fresh, flavorful, and one made you feel great eating it.

Last but not least, get an Iced Dirty Chai - they don't disappoint!

pics.caption: Pork Torta - look at that height!
Pork Torta - seriously piled high with shredded pork, slaw, crunchy onions. Yum!
Crisp Shrimp Cocktail - meant to be eaten like a lettuce wrap, so good!

review.des:
Hmm I understand the hype and the long wait. Fortunately my friend made a reservation for us so we did not have to wait. When I entered the place was completely packed, then again it was 11am on a Saturday. The place can feel...compact? I guess they try to make the most out of their space and accommodate as many as possible.

Bull's Eye French Toast - Get it, get it now. French toast and syrup is not overly sweet. Strawberries balanced it well. The chicken is amazing. Personally I love that it's already chopped into pieces for me. Saves me time from cutting my food and I can go straight to digging into it. At first glance, it does not look like a lot of food. But halfway through you will see that it is certainly enough.

Literally the best brunch I have ever had in my life.

Was visiting from NYC and found this place on yelp with its raving reviews so I had to try it out.

Made reservations very easily on open table. Got seated right away. Ordered the bullseye French toast, this little piggy went to china, and then had brown. They were all so good. The bullseye French toast is sweet but loaded with crispy fried chicken and the toast is filled with a runny egg which was a pleasant surprise. The strawberries also add another sweet but fresh flavor to the dish. The French toast is huge so I recommend you share! Then the this little piggy went to china was very savory. I remember it being a little salty and oily but it was still really good. I probably wouldn't get it the next time

However the best thing I ate here was hands down the HASHBROWN. you HAVE to get it. It's like perfectly crispy yet moist and filled with cheese. Wow it was so good. You don't even need ketchup because it's seasoned well. If I can go back to Chicago, I will definitely be eating here like 3 meals a day.

pics.caption: Most delicious brunch I have ever had in my life

review.des: Knew we did not want a big meal, so we opted for Little Goat Diner.  Really cute interior and great interpretations of comfort food.  I had a shrimp, crispy pork belly and noodle dish that was a wonder of flavors.  My husband has probably had a Rubin sandwich in every city we have ever visited or lived.  This one was special. I think fresh sauerkraut or maybe just picked cabbage; much nicer than the overly sour commercial kind.  The bread richly buttered and I think grilled over wood.  Anyway.  Nice place for casual dinner.

Big fan of GatG, but just a little fan of Little Goat. After several past visits, the last one sealed the deal that the wait and service just wasn't worth the experience. My first visit was an evening one, a few months after their opening. My dining partner and I were underwhelmed with the food vs the hype.

My last visit for brunch was a mess. The wait took forever, with hemming and hawing and changing of the quoted wait time by the hostess stand. Once seated, service didn't get much better.

On the plus side the Bull's Eye French Toast (with fried chicken and eggs) was amazing. I wouldn't expect anything less from Stephanie Izard. But the overall experience wasn't for me.

What an incredible find. We found this gem on Yelp. With gluten free, dairy free and milkshake menus, there was something for everyone in our party.
The biscuits and gravy, dairy free chocolate milkshake and lemon cake were the highlights for us today. Not to mention delicious loose leaf tea that was brewed right st the table.  And we cannot forget our amazingly well informed and helpful waitress, Minty. The food came quickly and was very fresh.
Luckily we got a table outside on such a beautiful day.  This is a local must and a charming way to experience Chicago.

pics.caption: Yummy gluten and dairy free chocolate milkshake!

review.des: Ehhh...overpriced, overrated, over it. Edison bulbs in a dinner? No. Stop trying so hard. The service was good, and they have Cheerwine, so that's why it's three instead of two stars. The food was UN. DER. WHEL. MING. Skip it.

Me and my friend had Bull's eye french toast and Goat almighty burger. It was $16 and $20 which seems a bit over priced but you'll be convinced after checking out the portions of the menus. French toast was delicious having strawberries and well cooked crispy chicken on top w their special bbq maple syrup. But it was overly sweet that after a few bites I had to find spots that had no syrup on them.
We ordered goat almighty burger as it had a 'goat' in its name. It was special and enormous having all three sorts of meat which were beef, pork, and chicken. All the ingredients including fried onions, jalapeno, pickled cucumbers mixed well with the patties.
Won't recommend waiting a looong line but otherwise worth trying!

pics.caption: The eggs are in the middle. Well cooked!

review.des:
This is one of those places that leaves an impression and I thought it was all good.  The Diner serves breakfast, lunch and dinners all day long, that meant I had to make some serious choices, there was a lot of items that looked good.

I finally settled on the special, a homemade biscuit with pimento cheese, ham and eggs, my partner went for Okonomiyaki (a Japanese Pancake)  we started with Goat Chili Cheese fries and finished with Banana cream pie.  

Our waitress was very helpful with the menu and service was quick.   I am definitely looking forward to going back there again.

Really like the service, ambience and the food! My friend and I shared a bull's eye French toast and a side of hash brown.

The bull's eye French toast is a combination of sweet and savory ingredients: maple syrup, fresh strawberries, sunny side up egg within the French toast and fried chicken. Everything went so well with each other (except the strawberries were a little sour since they are not in season).
Went to Little Goat Diner again and was again super impressed! Wonderful spot for breakfast! Our favorites are the pancakes and the Bull's Eye french toast!

Came here for dinner yesterday and had the beet gazpacho and focaccia of the day. But before we got in, we had to wait for a little while because the place was pretty packed on a Friday evening.

The gazpacho had a good taste and a tiny hint of something spicy, along with a nice dollop of cream; however, it felt like a bowl was too much of the same flavor, I would've been ok with a cup of it.

The focaccia, though good, was unexpected (probably because I confused my Italian words and thought I was ordering bruschetta). It had different olives baked on top and was served warm with a slightly spicy & tangy sauce on the side. Overall pleased with the meal.
I was told this was the place to be for breakfast and they were absolutely correct. Just bring your big wallet though!

Super chill place for brunch and food any time of the day. Had their cauliflower bibimbap which was extremely healthy. I loved the cauliflower and all the toppings. Very good. Friend got the chicken and French toast. Chicken was good and the French toast was nice and fluffy and sweet. It had an interesting oniony flavor added to it for savoriness.
This place is worth the wait and cost. Those cinnamon buns are out of control.

The Little Goat is popular with the locals but I wasn't impressed. The service is great and the food comes out timely manner but the food was under-whelming. The "biscuits and gravy" is mushroom gravy and it had no flavor.  The corned beef hash was pretty good with lots of corned beef and onions.  My biggest frustration was that they make their own salsas in-house and they are terrible. Their version of spicy hot sauce was a weird reddish creamy goo. Ugh! I really wanted tobassco and they didn't have any - not even in the bar. (whaaat?!?!)  The BBQ sauce tasted like bad ketchup. Overall it was very "meh" so I won't go back. There are lots of other great places to have brunch in the city that I'll try going forward.   The bloody Mary's are $12 each.

They do sweet stuff well - desserts, pancakes, sticky buns, french toast, etc.  They looked good. Go for the sweets but lower your expectations on the savory.

I was definitely attracted to this place by the amount of attention it got when talking about restaurants to go to. Go there on a weekend in summer time to get some amazing diner food!

The food is extremely basic, and nothing special about it.

Yes, it's diner food, what do you expect?

I understand.

What i can say, there are better diner places around the city to go to, and much less expensive.

This place has amazing food and a cool vibe! The "This little piggy went to China" was one of my favorite things I've eaten. Bold flavors. My husband has the smoked corned beef hash and it was delicious!

pics.caption: This little piggy went to China

review.des:
I've been to the Little Goat several times and am always pleased! They have all-day breakfast, great cocktails and beers, fun Asian fusion, and good meats and veg options. For the meat-eaters, definitely try a goat dish on your first visit, like the sloppy joe. For the vegetarians, give the scrumptious crumpets a go.
This is where I bring people who've never been to West Loop before, and it's a pretty fail-safe crowd pleaser.

This place is AMAZING.

The food and service were completely on point. We ordered the nachos, pierogies, a couple beers, and wine. The pierogies were perfectly made and the consistency was very similar to the ones I had in Europe. Nachos consisted of homemade chips and a ton of toppings.

Beer selection was pretty nice and our server was just stellar.

A must visit if you're in the area.

Little Goat features 5 star dishes (i.e. Bulls Eye French Toast, Goat Almighty & Los Drowned) and 2 star dishes (i.e. Boo Boo Baise & Crisp Shrimp Cocktail). The shakes sound better than they taste and aren't worth the $8. The fries are solid, but not worth $7. Service can range from shoddy to stellar. The host booth also lacks consistency.

It's best to make a reservation because Stephanie Izard is as popular as Brendan Sodikoff, but wait times aren't usually too crazy. Loyal foodies often flock to Little Goat as they stall out the 2 hour Au Cheval or Girl & the Goat waiting list.

With arguably the best restaurant strip in Chicago, Little Goat is OK, but there are definitely much better options within a 3 block radius. LG ranks last among the Izard growing empire.

pics.caption: GOAT CHILI - sour cream, cheddar & pizza poofs
BULL'S EYE FRENCH TOAST - over-easy eggs, crispy chicken, sweet onion brioche, fresh strawberries & bbq maple syrup

review.des:
We had the best sandwiches we've ever had at Little Goat Diner.  The service was fantastic, too.  Plus the place just looks groovy.  All their items are a la carte, however.  If a side was included with the sandwich or had their fries not cost an additional $6 (for just enough fries that would normally come with 1 sandwich elsewhere), then I would have given them a 5th star. A tad picky? Yes.  But 4 stars is nothin' to sneeze about.

The Hubs and I shared 2 sammies, the Los Drowned (braised beef with havarti cheese, grilled onions, avocado and probably something else...it was EXCELLENT!), and their special Grilled Cheese (also DEE-LISH, tasted like an amazing grilled cheese & tomato soup all in one).  We shared an order of their fries which are smoked fries...they were tasty but to me they tasted exactly like those TGIFridays Potato Skins Potato Chips.  Still good but for the amount you get I don't think they were worth $6.  Now, did we NEED more fries? No..we were plenty full so at least they saved us from ourselves. ;)

I also tried The Grass is Greener cocktail made with gin and various other ingredients that was entirely too fabulous all mixed together.  I could have easily enjoyed a few of those but since walking to the L was in order next I stuck with just 1 cocktail.

Our server, Mikaela, was great.  Fun, speedy and very helpful with any questions or suggestions with the menu.  We popped in at 5 p.m. on a Saturday and were able to be seated right away as well.  Bonus!

Ive been to Girl and Goat before so I wasn't really sure what to expect. I had made reservations on Open Table and it was nice that they gave you the option of standard seating vs at the bar. The diner was really cute and I noticed the little details on the plates as well as the napkins on the table. I had the okonomiyaki and my brother had the Goat Almighty. Both were really good (my brother had me try a little bit of his). I've never had okonomiyaki before but I saw a video of Chef Izard preparing it so I was definitely curious after that. It was a savory pancake and it was light and fluffy. It was topped with an egg, fried tempura batter sprinkles and sauce. The burger had 4 layers of meat. It had 1 thick beef patty on the bottom then 2 layers of the braised beef and topped with the pork. I tried both meats and they really complemented each other even though their flavors were so contrasting. The smoked fries were also very addicting considering I don't like fries! For dessert, I ordered the One Twisted Sundae and my brother got the Coffee root beer float. The Sundae had salted caramel ice cream on top of a brownie and mixed in with candied pretzels. It was really good but also very sweet. My brother just devoured his Rootbeer float so I'm guessing he enjoyed it as well!  It was a great spot to stop in for a late lunch. I'm curious to try the dinner menu which I think is available starting at 5 pm.

Amazing highly recommend their bulls eye French toast. There was a poached egg in the middle of their toast!! And the fried chicken and strawberries were killer on top.

Their classic sundae was delicious as well. The chocolate syrup was like brownie syrup. It was grainy but in the same way that brownie batter is. I'm a sucker for sweet stuff though.

pics.caption: Bull's Eye French Toast absolutely godlike.

review.des: Probably the worst restaurant in Chicago Food sucks I don't understand how it has so many good reviews no free refills they fill up your drink with ice but the water has no ice in it strange!

I heard about little goat from a few friends who came to visit Chicago during marathon weekend. The initial plan was to go to Girl in the goat however there were no reservations available!! I'm not mad though because Little goat was superb. The only reason I docked a star were the unpleasant bees that frequented my table...not 1 or 2 but 4 bees around me and my party and hovering over our food. The servers were really nice about it in letting us know that they're harmless unless you instigate bees by swapping or trying to shoo them away. This really didn't help us with our experience however the weather was beautiful. Request to sit inside if you can't deal with those flying critters.

Alright now onto the goods... the food!!! Everything was spectacular.

1) Okonomiyaki
- Ohhh so good!! Especially that runny egg on top. Perfection

2) Biscuits and gravy
I'm really picky about my biscuits but this place got it right. The biscuit is soooooo moist and the perfect amount of butteriness. MmmmMmmmMmmm!! Ohhh the gravy to top it off, very flavorful and not too salty! This is a great choice to get that brunch craving filled.

3) Fat club:
Oh this guy is a fatty alright! So much cold cuts but oh so good. I had a hard time figuring out how to take my first bite out of this bad boy. This one dish can fill anyone up.

4) Mac and cheese:
I loveeeee Mac and cheese!! This Mac and cheese is just plain goooooooooooood. Get it. You won't regret it.

5) Fish tostada:
The fish was cooked perfectly; so soft and tender but fried to perfection with a little cripsiness. Everything complemented so well together however it does get to be messy.

6) Hot crab dip
Ho ho ho! Man was this goood. We were eyeing this cheesy fella and I'm so glad we got it. REAL crab meat guys!! Not that imitation crap! REAL crustacean! They even gave us extra crackers because obviously we needed more immediately.

We also wanted to try the fried pickles and onion rings however they ran out. :( definitely on my bucket list!! Little goat, I'll be back for you next time.

Petite chèvre...pas mal !

Came here for dinner with my friend who's in town. We both stewed over the drinks and food menus for 20 minutes. Ultimately, he copied me (!) and we both got the "This Little Piggy went to China," which is a sesame cheddar biscuit with sunny side eggs, Szechuan pork sausage, chili garlic chive sauce, and strawberries. Sounds weird but it works. We also split a side of pork belly home fries, which was totally unnecessary because we were so full from little piggy.

I think this place is better suited for breakfast or brunch. That said, eating breakfast for dinner is one of the adult joys in life. #adulting

Absolutely love LG! I am a big fan of their brunch menu! Everything is fantastic! Service is always great. One think I love is their separate Gluten Free Menu which really helps me feel less awkward about bringing up my allergy. I'm all about their sandwiches on the Masa chips!  And what is brunch without a cocktail... or three!

Always consistently fabulous. If you haven't been, you're living under a rock.

I LOVE Little Goat. It has been one of my favorite places in Chicago for a while and is my yearly birthday tradition because it's so fun. If you like strong flavors and salt, then this place is for you. If you don't...then I'm not sure what kind of food you would like.

Favs: Machos Nachos, Pork belly pancake, crumpets and chorizo (no longer on the menu), veggie quesadilla

There are enough reviews on the nachos and pork belly pancake, but the crumpets and quesadilla don't get enough attention! The crumpets come with some kind of citrus fruit, chorizo, and is topped with syrup! It sounds strange, but is the perfect sweet and salty and acidic combo. I wish they would bring it back. Veggie quesadilla is so creative and is perfect if you love goat cheese. I don't like vegetarian options so I never get veggie things, but this was delicious.

Mehs: Bulls eye French toast, Okonomiyaki, biscuits and gravy, fish tostada

Bulls eye French toast is VERY overrated. There is nothing special about it. Even the chicken on the toast is meh. The toast has wayyy too much egg so it feels like you're eating bread and omelet rather than French toast.
Okonomiyaki is too similar to the pork belly pancake for me to understand why they have this separate item - it isn't as good as the pork belly pancake.
Biscuits and gravy has way too much cumin. It tastes like Indian food...but not in a good way. It just wasn't my style. Biscuits and gravy is my go to at any breakfast place, so I've had many biscuits and gravy dishes, and this one just isn't my favorite.
Not sure why so many people like the fish tostada. It's very bland and nothing special.

The only frustrating thing about this place is they keep changing the breakfast section of the menu. A lot of things I like just aren't there anymore. But the $5 Photo Booth makes up for it, I would say, and still makes this one of my favorite places!

Unless you've made a reservation for this place, expect to wait at least 45 minutes during normal daytime hours. Definitely the most traditional fare of Chef Izard's three restaurants, I would say it's worth coming to at least once. Most of the menu items that I've had have been pretty ordinary, but a few of the fun ones to try are:
- the tonkatsu sandwich: a fun play on traditional japanese comfort food and it's very tasty and filling
- tempura mashed potatos: a pretty unique take on mash and the outside crispiness makes it really nice to eat
- hash browns: one of my friends orders this every time he eats here. The trick is to order them well done and to put a poached egg on top!

Oh, Little Goat you get a two thumbs up. Came by around 11 on a Thursday to avoid the lunch rush. Started off with a Bloody Mary. One of the best I've had in a while. Had that full pickled flavor with a hint of smokiness. The kimchi and miso truly made it one of a kind.

The menu had plenty of breakfast items to choose from as well as sandwiches and burgers. Lots of Asian inspired flavors and creative spins on classic dishes. It was most certainly a tough decision. But I ended up ordering the little goat went to China and my bf ordered the bull's eye french toast.

I was actually a bit iffy about my decision at first since I've never really been a fan of biscuits but this flaky cheddar biscuit completely changed my mind. It paired really well with the Szechuan pork sausage and sunny side up egg. Kudos to our waitress for this savory recommendation. However, the french toast was on the sweeter side. Came with fried chicken and strawberries. Totally reminded me of chicken waffles but with a twist. Overall, both dishes were really good and can't wait to come back to try the other options.

pics.caption: This little piggy went to China

review.des:
There were 5 of us for dinner on a Thursday night, 6:15pm reservation. Super cute spot & super busy!
2 of us got The Fat Club that was amazing! I was only able to eat half which was a bummer...
Another person in my party had the Bull's Eye French Toast - holy wow, you need to google it so you can see what it actually looks like (forgot to get a pic). Another had the veggie burger, she said she really liked it and the other had blueberry pancakes and said they were excellent! I wanted to get dessert but we were all too full. The reason I gave this place 3 stars is because although I had a 6:15pm reservation we weren't seated until close to 7pm. Someone in my party had to go up to the hostess stand to ask about our server as we didn't even get any water. And even after asking it took a while. The food did come out pretty quick, but our drink order took a long time. And we had to ask for the hostess for our bill. While the food was great, the service could us some improvements.

Why can I only give 5 stars???!!???  This place is soooo unbelievably amazing!!!  The line is ALWAYS Out the door which is great for me because I usually come alone and can sit at the counter.  The service is great even with people hanging off the rafters. Everytime I come to Chicago I make time for a visit. The food is just phenomenal. You can tell Chef Izard trains her people well!!!

Delicious brunch! We started with sharing the giant cinnamon roll. Wow that was incredible, and huge! I'm not usually an icing person but it was perfectly sweet. I got the Spanish omelette and he had the omelette of the day which was like a kimchi style omelette with mint, cilantro, onion etc. Mine was so good- the masa chips on top were new for me and really tied it all together. His was so unique but really enjoyable. The crispy onion straws mixed with the mint were so good! Overall the portions were large and we were deliciously stuffed when we left. The vibe of the restaurant was fun and it had a really pretty open ceiling that let the natural light in. Great place for a weekend brunch!

Little Goat is always a good brunch option. Made a reservation for brunch a few weeks ago and they had our table ready as soon as we arrived. Split one of their Ooey Gooey Cinnabuns - obviously delicious. For my main, I ordered the Smoked Corned Beef Hash with poached eggs - amazing! My friend ordered the Bi Bim Bop Breakfast Bowl and loved it. Great atmosphere, great staff and great food.

First of all, I want to mention how happy I was with the atmosphere of this restaurant. Most restaurants blast the air conditioning even when it's not needed. The temperature was cool and pleasant, not frigid. The place was busy when we arrived, but we were seated right away. The staff works hard to keep things moving along. Our food arrived quickly (within about 10 minutes) and was very tasty. I ordered the veggie burger and the patty had nice, big chunks of vegetables in it.

There is one thing that really bothered me about our visit. After I ordered my burger, our server asked me if I'd like fries with it. I said sure and the fries arrived with my burger in a small bowl. But when we received the bill, we noticed that we had been charged $6 for the fries alone. This seemed deceptive on the server's part because the way she phrased it - "Do you want fries with that?" - implied that it was included with my meal. I felt like I had been intentionally misled into paying $6 for a small amount (about a cup and a half's worth) of plain fries that just tasted okay. We still tipped and we did not complain about it (we're both pretty non-confrontational), but I still think this needs to be mentioned. If your server offers you a side item, make sure you're aware that it costs about $6 extra.

I ate here twice in 10 days while in Chicago. Once for lunch and once for breakfast. Wow! What a fun place to eat. The food and service are excellent. Sit at the bar if you can so that you can appreciate how hard the kitchen is working and get to see all the dishes as they head out to the lucky people. Get a cinnamon roll - seriously special. And the Pork Belly Pancake. The play on chicken and waffles fell short for me - I wanted more chicken and less sweet. And I ate every last bite.

Just popping in as review number 3,174 is not going to count for much but I had to make my statement that this is one of the best places to eat in the West Loop.

Chef Stephanie Izard has created a formula that produces fast unique delicious food consistently and the atmosphere is fun and eclectic.

I love coming here and there are enough vegan options to give me plenty of choice. The vege quesadilla is my "go to" choice but there are many others including the cheesy hash browns.

Every time we go to Chicago, LGD is always a planned stop. It's on open table and yelp reservations to help avoid the long wait - as there is usual a wait to be seat given the popularity of the diner. We have been here for both brunch as well as lunch and have never been disappointed by any of our food choices. Their food is American with some Asian fusion embedded in some of the plates. Definitely a good choice if you have time to sit and eat - not a good quick dine option. Always good service when we've been. Attached is their bakery which we always buy to go for the road. Freshly baked on site.

Omg. This place is amazing. I went here for the first time with coworkers and we were all very impressed. I ordered the fish tostadas and we had the onion rings and fried pickles for the table. The tostadas were huge and delicious. The fish was absolutely delicious. I'm definitely not a picky, eater but I don't like a lot of random things on my food. This tostada was covered in random things, but apparently every last food item on it was needed because the flavor was amazing.

The fried pickles and the onion rings were literally the best I have ever had. I don't know what it is in that batter, but they were so so good. You could honestly order the fried pickles and onion rings as a meal, the portion was that large.

I also ordered a drink but I can't remember the name. It has a strawberry in it along with some pepper flakes. This was very good as well.

Overall I loved this place and cannot wait to go back and try more of this great food!!

pics.caption: Fish tostadas! Very good and huge. I ate about half and was super full.
Amazing drink. I cant remember the name.

review.des: We went there for dinner during the weekdays so it was pretty empty. However, the food was amazing. I tried a breakfast paratha (basically an omelette surrounded by flaky soft warm bread) and it superseded my expectations. It was a good combination of American with Asian flare. The brussel sprouts were surprisingly good and the service was speedy. I would come back.

Went here for Brunch with a couple of friends. I liked this place but I didn't think it was anything special. They've got your normal standard American fare as well as some Asian fusion dishes that I didn't think were great. In a city with so many great options for food, I didn't find anything special in this place.

Overall, just a pretty average place.

Unassuming diner but delivers such a wonderful experience for first time visitors and tourists alike. Servers are amazing and the food is high quality and so good! Parents were skeptical at first but ended up loving it!

Definitely make a reservation. We sat outside on a Monday holiday afternoon. The service was great. I didn't try any of the fancier drink options but enjoyed a glass of wine. The food here is outstanding. I highly recommend the Little Piggy goes to China. It is seriously unlike anything I've ever ordered before - such a unique, incredibllu delicious breakfast/brunch option.

pics.caption: Little piggy went to China. The Best!!!
French toast with strawberries and chicken

review.des: Amazing food that doesn't break the bank. I haven't been to Girl and the Goat yet but I have a feeling I would like this place better. I came here for brunch with some friends and it was super easy to make a reservation online. The interior is really clean/modern looking and provides a nice ambience. There is even outdoor seating. For the food I tried the fish tacos which were amazing. Everything about it was unique from the chickpeas to the slaw to the tortilla shells. But it worked really well and was delicious without tasting heavy or greasy. I also tried the summer shrimp salad which I would get again. It was very light and refreshing and fresh, but definitely still filling.  I would love to come back here!

Anything chef touches turns to pure gold, and his diner is no exception. After being floored by the delicious menu at Girl and the Goat yesterday, I had to get back to the west loop and try this place. As expected, it was phenomenal.

Order literally anything and prepared to fall in love.

My bf had been to this place before and didn't have the greatest experience with his friends. But I decided to give it a shot, so he agreed to go again. Maybe he just ordered the wrong dishes, right?

So, we went. The service was super quick and attentive. We were seated immediately and ordered soon after. Of course, we went with the goat almighty burger and got a side of fried pickles and onion rings. I was pretty excited bc this burger seemed to be the big thing here (literally). Food took a while to get to our table, but once we got it we started digging in.

Sad to say, I was sorely disappointed as my bf got his "I told you so" moment. The burger was pretty subpar, lacking juicy flavor. I felt like I was just eating chunks of fat between two buns with a tiny bit of burger patty in between. The fried pickles and onion rings tasted like fried vinegar. This was the first restaurant that we did not finish our meal or plan to take leftovers home. (And that's saying something because we usually devour our meals.)

I left half full, with stumped expectations, and a bad aftertaste in my mouth. And we still paid the price for it all. Will not be returning to Little Goat, probably ever. Nothing against the people or staff there, because service was great, but the food just sucks.

pics.caption: Goat Almighty burger.  Had a side of fried pickles and onion rings with it. Probably would not get again.

review.des:
Came here with some friends on their recommendation as it's one of their favorite places.

The ambiance is nice, but also casual enough that you could wear sweats and not feel out of place. It was quite busy for a Wednesday evening and it was also loud, making it somewhat difficult to hear each other over the loud table.

Service was efficient and prompt. I had a sweet tooth so I got the dark chocolate chip crunch pancakes. They were excellent, some of the best pancakes I've ever had. Really hit the spot. Portion sizes here are huge, so expect to leave with leftovers.

Both of my companions meals looked divine as well. One weird thing: one of the waitresses refilling water glasses kept coming up to our table and interrupting our conversation to ask if we wanted more water. Not a big deal but a little awkward. I think most places they just refill without asking.

Overall a nice place to try breakfast-all-day.

Came here on a Monday morning. Made a reservation but probably didn't need it, either way we were sat immediately.

Started with coffee. Order the pork belly fries to split, oh man. So worth it!

I got the omelette of the day. Really good. Had a cheesy sauce, green beans, and crispy onions. Very happy with it.

My friend got the parathas burrito, so good and original. Definitely get this if you come here.

Lastly split the Choco taco and cherrwine for dessert (had a conversation over the weekend regarding what cherrwine is, so had to try it as it was on the menu. Really sweet, not a huge soda fan but it was good).

But the Choco taco. Only disappointment is it is more of a sundae with chocolate covered tortilla chips placed in it. But wow was it good. Really just wanted the same thing as a 7/11 Choco taco but with better, fresher ingredients. However this was delicious and a great dessert. Perfect size for 2 people to split.

I've loved my meals at Girl & the Goat, but it's a tough table to score--so have been meaning to check Little Goat out for a while!
Came for a late breakfast/brunch on a weekday around 10:30 and had no wait. The dining area is light and airy and has fun retro touches.
The breakfast options looked the most fun and interesting so we shared several: This little piggy goes to China, the okonomikayi, and the bulls-eye French toast, plus a side of the corn elotes.
The only thing we didn't finish was the this little piggy. The French toast was awesomely decadent (gone before even a photo was taken!), the okonomiyaki was light and savory, and the corn was a nice vegetable-ish touch. I wanted to like the this little piggy (kind of a sausage and egg biscuit with a Szechuan riff) but the combination of the Szechuan seasoning and sweetness and strawberries just didn't work for me.
Service was good, coffee was good and plentiful, and overall a very comfortable place to pig out for breakfast! Would definitely return (with a very empty stomach!) to try some of their other offerings.

pics.caption: This Little Piggy Went to China

review.des: 5 stars for a 5 star diner. Extensive menu with a ton of great options. I went for the Reuben, which is the best sandwich that exists. The Little Goat Reuben swaps out sauerkraut for kimchi which is a huge power move. Amazing food and they have Hamm's on tap.

The serving is very tiny for the price you pay. We ordered the This Little Pig Went to China dish and it was only one biscuit for $14. The service we had for our first time there was awful. Tried to sub my pork sausage for something else and the waiter was a jerk about it saying that it can never be done with no further explanations. Would NEVER come back to this overhyped place.
That they serve Chandon champagne in a cool but casual joint on Randolph is enough reason to eat here. Open Table option made it better!

On a Friday around 11AM, this place was PACKED. I was dining alone and sat at the counter, the typical spot at a diner for a loner. The food was delicious, the service was superb, and the drinks were wonderful. My server was so pleasant and offered great suggestions. I would love to go here again and I could take a bath in the BBQ Maple Syrup!

This Little Piggy Went to China: Just wow. This dish is amazing. I would recommend anyone come to Little Goat Diner just to try this dish. It's a great breakfast dish with amazing Asian flavors. Highly recommend.

Bulls-eye French Toast: From the description you think that it would be a weird combination of french toast with fried chicken, but Little Goat Diner makes it work! The brioche is an onion brioche which gives it a slight savory taste to match the chicken. The syrup has a slight bbq taste to compliment the chicken as well. The strawberries add a nice tangy twist to the dish. Might sound weird, but I thought it tasted great.

pics.caption: This Little Piggy Went to China
This Little Piggy Went to China

review.des:
I've been to Little Goat Diner twice now, and neither meal has disappointed.
The first time was for brunch and I can safely say their brunch menu is extensive and creative. I really had a hard time choosing what to eat.
The second time I went for dinner and debated between a burger, the scallion pancake sandwich, and the grilled cheese. Convinced by my server and reviews I've read, I got the grilled cheese. I'm not exactly a grilled cheese fanatic, but I appreciate a good grilled cheese. This was a very good grilled cheese. The bacon Gouda bread was incredible and the filling of apple-tomato was the filling I didn't know I wanted in a grilled cheese. I'm not sure if I can go back to regular grilled cheeses now that I've had one with bacon Gouda bread.
All in all, a very solid choice for dinner. I'd probably come back to try some of the other sandwiches or the other breakfast items. Their breakfast menu looked amazing. I'd recommend this place, especially for its creative and interesting menu. There's something for everyone. With West Loop, restaurants can really come and go, but Little Goat has been around for a while and I think it's become a staple in the neighborhood.

The selection at this place is so unique and interesting. There are combinations of very traditional dishes in unexpected ways. I had a Japanese pancake with pork belly and fried fish flakes. It was very delicious. They even have their own in house beer. I would def recommend coming when in Chicago.

pics.caption: Japanese pancake with pro belly and fried fish flakes

review.des:
Loved the updated dinner look!  Went early so  no wait!  The menu is very unique so if you aren't adventurous this isn't the place for you. I got "little pig goes to China"  It was delicious. A corn muffin with fresh sausage over easy eggs & an Asian sauce with green onions. Super umami!
We stopped at the bakery on our way out & picked up scones to go. Mexican chocolate. They were wonderful. Soft, buttery & really tasty.
It was fun & unique.

pics.caption: Booths with parquet wood on walls

review.des: I've heard so many things about this place that I had to go try it out! Definitely make a reservation here cuz it can get pretty crowded. The vibe of the restaurant is very 1960s - vinyl booths, steel tables, bright and colorful, vibrant images on the walls. The menu is pretty typical diner food with some interesting ethnic twists that I wasn't sure how to feel about. I ordered their popular bullseye French toast, and my friends ordered the chili and the American burger, as well as the One Twisted Sundae. Breakfast is available all day which is amazing! The French toast was a very interesting blend of savory and sweet and it was really filling! The sundae was great and I heard that the burger was very solid. Overall loved the vibe of the restaurant and the food, would definitely come back!

This place isn't as good as it used to be. I wasn't a big fan of where I was seated. I requested a booth and that request was only half granted. I was sat in the very back room and it wasn't an actual booth.

The food is pretty mediocre. I ordered the All American burger. I feel like they changed the way they prepare this. I thought the bun tasted stale and the burger patty wasn't fresh tasting.

Not sure what has changed but I was more of a fan of this place when it first opened.
If you would like to try different unexpected breakfast, you should go to little goat diner. The environment their and the food is perfect. It a good place to get new experience unexpected food.

Pickles and onions, tasty, greasy, could have used one more dipping sauce. So far the service has been slightly inattentive and unenthusiastic. I wanted to love This Little Piggy Went to China and I did enjoy the flavor.  The strawberries added another dimension. The biscuit was tough though and the the dish over all was greasy. Still, I loved the coffee and I am willing to try again. Someone suggested I get the fish tacos...wish I had....Wahwah.

Little Goat is a high-end diner that always seems to be busy. I had high expectations, and they were completely met.

They have a separate vegan menu and a variety of vegetarian options on the regular menu. I ordered the Vegan Bi Bim Bap, and it was amazing. The flavors all came together really well, and the dish was super healthy. I would highly recommend this dish for vegans, vegetarians, or anyone who wants to have a healthy yet delicious meal.

After being out all day in Chicago, and waiting for a 9:30 Nowait spot at Au Cheval we came to Little Goat Diner to kill time and perk up with some espresso. Yes, it was dinner time but we were already like 3 hours deep into our wait so there was no turning back.

We sat at the bar near the bakery and got a couple of espressos. The coffee was solid but nothing incredible. The real treat was watching the bakers work their magic in the open kitchen and of course, oogling at everyone else's food.

Now, I can't say much cause I didn't eat it...but Little Goat has some crazy dishes. I saw one table order the biggest burger I've ever seen. It was seriously stacked like a food tall. Just from how fun everything looked I'd totally come back for a meal.

If you're looking for something really different, definitely check out the little goat.   We came in seeking out a little more standard fare and didn't realize how many unique and interesting ingredients were going to be offered. I ordered the corned beef hash which was tasty & my boyfriend ordered the Spanish omelette (which came with pickled habanero peppers that totally knocked my boyfriends socks off- in a good way!) the home fries were delish with a drunken goat cheese on top which was such a treat. We loved the decor and the waitress was very nice & helpful. I'm sure we will be back to try out the lunch menu next time we visit Chicago :)

We were anxious to get this place after all the hype. The food did not disappoint, however the service was abominable! It was a Friday afternoon around 2pm. We waited to be greeted by our server for at least 10 minutes. Waited another 10 minutes for water.  We were a party of 5 with pretty simple drink orders, ice tea, Diet Coke and a glass of wine. The drinks came AFTER the food which took 30 minutes to arrive at our table. I had to ask a second time for the glass of wine. Left this place with a "bad taste in my mouth"......other restaurants with far superior service in Chicago....visit them instead.
Good ambiance & fun!  Our waitress was very nice and quick. Favorite part was the option of a dairy free, gluten free and vegan menu!

This place is fun! I've had their absurdly giant multi meat burger that's still under $20 and their patty melt. They mix a pleasantly low key diner atmosphere and vibes with the high quality and creative cuisine we've come to expect from the West Loop. They tend to take an existing classic and add some twist that makes you appreciate it in a whole new way. I love fries far too much, and their Pork Belly Home Fries are unbelievable. Turns out adding pickled peppers. cilantro, and a fish sauce vinaigrette was just what fried potatoes needed!
Able to handle a larger group (I ate here with 10 once). Excellent, prompt service.

Place is freakin amazing!! Had the Ruben which was the best I've ever had. The guys in the kitchen were 100mph. Talk about hard workers...  I admire them all.

The service?? Fucking amazing!!! Exceeded expectations, thru the roof.

Cool Fact:  This place is allergy conscious which I learned when the waitress asked about allergies. While I was surprised when asked, I have one so this was super cool. Wish I remembered her name. She was great!

Keep up the great work!!

10/10 would recommend.

Came to the diner for breakfast around 9 am on a Thursday. My friend and I had no trouble getting a seat. We were seated promptly in a booth and soon greeted by our waitress. She was very nice and gave us just the right amount of space.
I ordered 'This Little Piggy Went to China' and wasn't completely blown away but it did satisfy my breakfast craving. I really liked the sesame cheddar biscuit- it was buttery on the inside and had a great crisp/ crunchy shell. There was a sausage patty with two sunny side up eggs on top and it was topped with a chili garlic chive sauce. My problem with the dish was that there was too much sauce on it. It was a little bit overwhelming, to be honest. Otherwise I did enjoy my breakfast. I also had an americano for breakfast and it was a nice big cup but I didn't finish. The waitress was thoughtful enough to ask me if I wanted to take the rest to go. I thanked her and took the rest with me on my walk to the french market. Overall, I did enjoy my dish and would be willing to come back, however, I did think it was a bit expensive considering it wasn't the most unique in flavor or size.

Came here on Saturday, we had made reservations months ago to have my family come in and celebrate my birthday here for brunch. We arrived exactly at 12:15pm for our reservation, and were told they were waiting for our table to finish eating, and that it would be 10-15 minute wait. 20 minutes go by, we check on the status of our reservation, and the girl working the host stand didn't have anything more to tell me. 45 minutes go by and at this point we are starving, and aggravated. Finally we get seating almost an hour later. At that point- I don't care how great your food is, if your customers have to wait an hour for their reservation, that is a huge problem. Either: A) don't accept reservations or B) make sure you have a maximum amount of time set for table reservations. There's no reason why we had to wait over an hour when we had taken the time to be prepared and made these reservations months ago.

The food: it was great. I would be giving this place 5 stars if it was based solely on the flavor, selection, and quality of the items offered. I decided on the Fat Elvis Waffles, and they were fantastic. Our group also got the PQM bacon (nothing really special or unique for a $6 side of bacon), hash browns, and the Pork Belly Home Fries. The home fries were very good, the aoli it came with complimented it very well. Although, there were only about 3 small cubed pieces of pork belly for the dish, which was not enough. I wanted to try the cinnamon roll, but they were unfortunately out.

Besides the terrible reservation set-up they have, the food is great, and our waiter was attentive (although we were 100% sure he was stoned out of his mind:)). Overall, I'm not sure if I would make another trip back to Little Goat, but if you can snag a table on time, I'd say try it.

pics.caption: Pork Pork Belly Home Fries - $7.00 - not enough pork, but very good

review.des:
I was really looking forward to dining here after reading all of the wonderful reviews, but was sadly disappointed by the quality of the food here. We came here since the wait time for Au Cheval was so long and the wait time here wasn't too bad at all. I put my name in and only had to wait for around 45 minutes for a table on a Monday night. We ended up getting a table outside since we didn't have a reservation for a table inside which was fine. Our waiter quickly came to get our drink order and went over the menu with us. They pride themselves on their breakfast/brunch items which is served all day.

We ordered the Smoked Corn Beef Hash and This Little Piggy Went to China. The Smoked Corn Beef Hash comes in a bowl with hashbrowns on the bottom, corn beef, and a bed of eggs on top of that. I was not impressed with my meal at all. It was very dry and the eggs were way overcooked. The only thing I did like were my hashbrowns. It was shredded very finely and had a crispy texture to it. My husband did not like his dish, "This Little Piggy Went to China," at all. It has a biscuit that has a Szechuan sausage inside of it. It was covered with a chili sauce and fresh strawberries as well. It's creative in theory but was not enjoyable. We liked our hash browns and smoked fries the best. My friend ordered a Jerk Chicken sandwich instead of the breakfast/brunch options and he said he thoroughly enjoyed it more than what he had in the past. The server also made a mistake and brought out fries for him instead of the hash browns he ordered with his dish.

I like their creativity and playfulness with their food, however, I was not thoroughly satisfied with what we ordered at all. I would not plan on visiting this restaurant again in the future. The food was overly priced and it could have been something we made at home for half of the cost. And worst of all, I got pooped on my head by a bird while dining outside! Ugh!

Service 4/5
Food 2/5

pics.caption: This little piggy went to china

review.des:
I had been here on a previous occasion, it was a quick lunch & the food was great. I went back yesterday around 1pm(Sunday), we were told the waiting time was 30-45 min. We didn't mind waiting, but it became frustrating when we saw people that got there after us get seated, several groups and pairs. After a while we realized it wasn't just the people that had previous reservations. We asked the hostess how much longer we had to wait and miraculously we got seated right away... This was after we clearly specified we were okay with seating anywhere, minutes later we clearly heard one of the hostess tell a woman there was room in the bar.
Once we ordered our food, it was terrible, we had two burgers, and both were a disappointment. The only good thing was the latte and vanilla shake... what a shame. Never coming again.

pics.caption: Only good thing. Service is terrible, especially the hostess stand.

review.des:
Brought my brother here from out of town. I have lived in the west loop for over 5 years, and hadn't visited this place until just recently. I was pleasantly surprised. They mix a very casual atmosphere with GREAT food options.
I will definitely be back to try a few more dishes a few more times.

Amazing food! This was my first time at the restaurant - after having been to girl and the goat, I was excited to try out little goat. The entire restaurant has a cute diner feel with a great vibe. The service was great, as well. My favorite part was the food - the drowned sandwich was divine and I adore the fact that they have chocolate milk. It was the first time I've had chocolate milk since I was 12, and it was glorious. Overall, cute restaurant and delicious food. I can't wait to go back!

pics.caption: Gluten free los drowned. So delicious!
Los drowned sandwich on corn tortillas! Divine!

review.des: A fun diner in a fun neighborhood. My wife and I enjoy hanging out here and trying their interesting renditions on classic American diner food. The chickpea salad is one of my tops as well as the shrimp and grits. My dad loves the veggie burger. Truth be told there's nothing on the menu here that's "bad" - it's all super solid, well executed and pretty darn delicious. They always got something for m everyone. Also, it appears that they've expanded their pastry menu within the last year or so, that's a plus!!

Our food, drinks & service (our waiter was Ben) were all great when we went for a birthday dinner on 5/19/18.
Will definitely be returning.

Another winner on our Chicago restaurant checklist. Considering I found Little Goat Diner thanks to the Goop Guide to Chicago, of course I expected it to 1. be cool and 2. offer some unique, health-conscious food options.

We made a reservation for an early dinner and were seated immediately. The vibe of the menu and the restaurant itself is "modern diner." I loved the retro details and quirky dishes like the cake of the day- Funfetti.

My friend I went with is vegan, and after struggling to find decent vegan options at several other restaurants, we were thrilled that Little Goat had a full vegan menu. Just ask for it! She ordered a delicious chickpea salad, recommended by our waitress.

I ordered the Veggie Burger, American style, which I immediately deemed "the best veggie burger of my life." The house made patty was filled with fresh vegetables, (mushrooms, broccoli, etc.)

Sadly, we didn't have room for dessert, but I look forward to visiting again someday soon! Darling diner is also attached to a bakery, coffee shop and rooftop bar. Go check them out!

Today Little Goat came up in my Yelp "write a review" suggestions list, and I was like, "What?  How have I not reviewed Little Goat?  I've eaten here 87 times!"

Little Goat is so good.  We live in the neighborhood, and it's our go-to.  For breakfast, for lunch, for dinner, for late nite.  It's where we take out-of-town guests, and it's where we end up with our friends that have also been there a million times.  It's comfort food, it's reliable, it's comfy, and although you're in a super relaxed diner...it's incredible 5-star food.  You can get a patty melt or some nachos...or you can opt for special with seasonal ingredients that will blow your mind (I had ramps here last year for the five minutes they were in season, and it was one of the best breakfast dishes I had all year).  Have a cup of coffee or a beer...or get a cocktail with peppercorns that will make your taste buds go, "Whoa!"

The service can be a little hit or miss, but it's mostly a hit.  Jessica is amazing, and whenever she's working, we try to make sure we end up in her area.  (Jessica, you're so great!)  When Jessica's not around...I feel like smaller tables sometimes get ignored at the expense of larger groups, at least in my experience.

But basically you can't go wrong here.  I see people whining on Yelp about long lines, but you're in Chicago and it's popular: that's life, friends.  Make a reservation or go at off times.  I've hardly ever had to wait for a table when I plan at least 30 minutes in advance.

Finally: the price is right.  My husband's go-to is the pork tonkatsu.  It's $14 for a sandwich the size of your face.  You won't leave hungry, and it won't break the bank!
Goat chili stew, chicken/waffles and ....one of best desserts I might ever had- pretzel ice cream with caramelized pretzels on home made brownie

I love this place.

It is cool without being hipster- ish. Sorry hipsters I think you just have too much time on your hands.  

But this place is a type of authentic cool. Great food and genuine excellent caring service. All with a sense of grace and a casual "Joi de vivre"  that all makes me a super fan.

I bring all guests from out of town here for brunch if I can.

! Skip to the bottom for a summarization !

This place absolutely overwhelmed almost all my senses, and in a good way.

My boyfriends mom told us to stop by here while we were out with my cousins, heard from both parties that this place was good. 45 minute wait but that didn't really steer us away especially me since I was gawking at everything in the building. Loving that retro theme and all the employees has their own sense of style and I was LIVING for it!

WAITING FOR A TABLE?
they have a bar and a coffee spot where you can grab a drink while you wait.

NEED A SOUVENIR OR SOME MERCH ?
They also have a little souvenir/gift wall. Their little goat logo on their souvenirs items are adorable enough to gift for anyone.

When we finally sat down, we were all set on what we wanted to order. While you wait, definitely snag a menu and choose what you want especially if you have been waiting for awhile for a table.

SERVICE:
Service was awesome, attentive and water refills came through promptly.

SALAD ?!
I was on a carb binge since we landed in Chicago so I went to alternate route and got a salad. Goat'O-Goat'O, interesting name with an explosion of flavors in every bite. Veggies, shrimp, and a tamarind peanut dressing. The smell of the dressing was pungent and I was curious at first but after you drizzle that baby on top of everything... LORD HAVE MERCY. I need this recipe! The serving was gigantic ($14), I couldn't finish all of it. Definitely a staple to come back for.

OVERALL/SUMMARY:
- if you're waiting in line, grab a drink or coffee on the other side of their restaurant.
- if you're waiting for a table, for 30+ minutes, snag a menu so you can decide what you want.
- bathroom is to the left once you walk in. The door blends in with the wall, love that idea.
- prices were inexpensive for the amount of food you get.
service was awesome!
- this place is definitely a spot to try out if you're in the area.
I stopped by Little Goat diner before out way to the UC. We tried alot of thing! everything on the menu was very tasty and well priced. I will definitely be back.

This is just another mediocre restaurant coasting on the celebrity of its owner. I live in the neighborhood and have been to Little Goat maybe a dozen times over the past few years. Tonight was my most recent visit and will likely be my last. The restaurant was FREEZING, we were rushed to order (despite the restaurant being half full) and the food was not that good. I've never had a meal at Little Goat that I thought was better than average. If you care at all about what you are eating, there are a 20 places within walking distance that are better than Little Goat. The only reason to go here is that kids love this place. When my kid starts paying for dinner, we can come back.

Although I've never been a fan of the restaurant, I used to stop by the LG coffee bar with some frequency. Little Goat makes great coffee and the people working the coffee bar are incredibly friendly. The coffee bar was always awkwardly designed, but a recent remodel turned it into a logistical disaster. There's no natural place to stand out of the way of other customers while you wait for your coffee. It's not worth the hassle.

Had mix emotions on this place, wanted to like it , heard a lot of good stuff about these place. It was our anniversary,wanted to
To be special , we order appetizers onion rings and fried pickles tempura stile and crab dip , the onion rings and pickle was really greasy, the crab was more like a soup, had no textured at all, for main course my husband order the chicken pot pie and I order the cheesy grits and the fried chicken, his pot pie was delicious, my grits were cold and salty, the chicken was undercook, I informed the waitress about the under cook chicken and she informed me that it wasn't under cooked and that it was the brine the chef used to marinate the chicken on, so I showed her the bloody inside of my chicken and told her that it had nothing to do with the brine.

Luckily I have only been here at "off" times where the service and atmosphere is not rushed or hectic. The food is spot on for detail and flavor. Very well thought out menu offerings with excellent execution and presentation!

Smoked Pork and Toffee Crunch and the cake of the day is all I have to say. Another one of Stephanie Izard's amazing joint! Breakfast fare are of course delicious with a twist of creativity - not your usual brekkie spot. Come by and have yourself a truly good morning!

What a food experience!!! Oh my. Tonight went to little goat with a private group. We used the private room upstairs with the open kitchen and terrace. The atmosphere is so quaint and cozy - we loved it! But nothing could have prepared us for the culinary journey we were about to embark on. We tasted flavors pairings we could never have imagined. Tarragon butter, scallops, tuna, goat empanadas, salted caramel NY strip, sole with Mediterranean yogurt, all topped off with chocolate pavlova for dessert. Every bite was an explosion of flavor. My review can't do it justice, you'll have to try for yourself. You won't be sorry! Yum!

The best.  I'm shocked it's taken me 8 years to write a review but this place is the best chill spot to grab a bite in the city imo.  Really solid comfort food with a unique twist to each dish.  

I'm not a seafood nut, but the fish tostadas are off the hook.  Shakes, breakfast items and burgers are also excellent.

Came here for lunch on a weekday, and had a short 5-10 minute wait for our party of 3. Service was fast and friendly. We were feeling brunchy, so I got the paratha burrito (indian flatbread with sunny side up eggs inside, a salad mix on top, and a delicious sauce on the side. My sister got the bulls eye french toast which was phenomenal! I loved loved loved how the chicken was good. It was the perfect texture, and the breading on the outside was nice and crispy, with a sweet flavor to it. I also go the chocolate malt milkshake which was seriously  delicious and topped with fresh whipped cream. I would definitely come here again to explore some more menu options.

Get reservations and skip the line, this place is popular and for good reason. Styled like a diner, this food by far surpasses typical greasy spoon fare. The coffee is outstanding, rivaling any fancy coffee shop without the condescension. The menu is so original and creative; they blend genres of food masterfully.

I had the "Everything is Everything Crumpets," with lox, fried egg salad, tzatziki cream cheese, and pickles. The crumpets were like a cross between little biscuits and pancakes. The pickled onions were clearly made in house, so delicious. It's a big serving, so I couldn't even finish it all, but I tried!

My husband had the "This Little Piggy Went to China" dish. I have never thought of sesame oil and strawberries as being complementary, and now I can't get it out of my head. The Szechuan pork sausage was out of this world, and it was also a giant serving.

If you get a chance to come here, don't pass it up! It's definitely a special place.

OMG!  Do not pass up the crab dip appetizer!  It is the kind of dish you'll wish you had ordered for the main course as well.  Delicious doesn't even begin to describe it. It's a melty, creamy, savory, mouthwatering, crabtastic experience that delivers the type of overwhelming joy I can only compare to the first time I went all the way... with someone else... It was so satisfying, yet it was finished much too quickly.

I followed it up with the Bhan Mi Burger with a side of Asian-inspired broccoli. I was expecting the burger to be the star of the main course, but to my surprise, it was completely overshadowed by the broccoli. Chalk it up as a win for vegetarians. If all vegetables were this sumptuous, I would forever swear off my meat-eating ways.

It would get five stars, but the burger (delicious in its own right) was completely overshadowed by the appetizer and side item. Next time, I'll skip the burger and give more of their sides a try.

Due to the 3 hour wait at Au Cheval down the street, it brought us to Little Goat Diner which did not disappoint.

I started with a mimosa while waiting but recognized everyone around me drinking a bloody Mary.  Once I was seated, I had another look at the drink menu and the bloody mary with kimchi sounded fantastic so I decided to give it a try.  This would be on the top of my list for best bloody mary in Chicago.  I just started drinking bloody mary's less than a year ago so I've only gotten to try a handful of places.

For my meal I decided to go with This little piggy went to China.  A cheddar biscuit with sunnyside egg, pork sausage, chili sauce and blueberries.  This may sound like an interesting mix but surprisingly went very well together.  I would definitely get this dish again.

Service was great, super cute breakfast/brunch spot in the West Loop!
