This little piggy went to China

review.des:
I realize that some people probably feel that 5*s on a Top Chef restaurant is purely bias but let me assure you this rating is well deserved.

I highly recommend using Open Table to make your reservation with ease as there is a substantial turnout even during weekday lunch; though it's more than worth the wait.

This Art Deco diner meets Midwest Mom & Pop is done right. As they say it's all in the details, this place hits the nail on the head. Clean lines & neutral colors accented by kitschy yet bold signs & furniture like a scene from a good movie.

The menu may be a bit of a risk taking for people who prefer mild, classic & simple flavors but it tastes like absolute heaven. I am not one of those people and I promptly followed the waiter's suggestion to try "The Little Pig Went to China" which then became one of the best breakfast sandwiches I've ever eaten. A cheddar biscuit filled with sausage & PERFECTLY cooked sunny side up eggs bathing in a sea of a sesame/soy sauce of sorts, accented with yellow grape tomatoes... I honestly have never been so surprised by a breakfast dish and cannot wait to go back.

To top it all off, as if the fresh bakery & legitimate espresso station weren't enough, there is a photo booth that takes credit cards & cash, 2 minutes of your time & pops out  a color AND B+W photo strip. Yes. This place is totally bucket list worthy; if it's not on yours yet I suggest you pencil it in!

Love every single thing about this place! The atmosphere is very open and bright with quaint and unique decor. It took me almost half an hour to choose a meal because the entire menu looked amazing! The hash browns are to die for, alone with "this little piggy went to china". Great service too, especially being so busy on a Sunday! Can't wait to go back!

I've had Little Goat diner on my "To Try" list fo' evaaa, and just finally made it there with my +1.  Good choice on his part!

I ordered the Chopchae Burger and we shared the Aged Fries.

The fries came en masse but were kind of "meh" as far as flavor. They were the shoestring variety, but were very short and stumpy. ?! I've never seen such skinny little  1" fries. Is that a thing?

I ordered the Chopchae Burger because I thought I was getting a burger with a Korean twist (i.e. with chopchae ON it), BUT it turns out that it was a burger - sans bun - on top of noodles and with an egg.  It was GOOD - just not exactly what I was picturing: the menu description didn't mention there was no bun.  I had also requested my burger medium, but it came closer to rare.  Not wanting to have to flag down our pretty-absent and flippant server to have it re-fired, I just went with it.

My +1 ordered the Grilled Cheese and said it was the most lackluster sammy he'd ever had, and he's eaten (and enjoyed) Little Goat before.

I love diners and my Chopchae "Burger" WAS good... but the rest - including the service - was mediocre. Still, I'd try Little Goat again and give them a shot to redeem themselves, because I totally want to love them like everyone else seems to!

Brunch is probably my favorite meal of the day. When I'm traveling I'm always trying to find the best brunch places. There are so many in the Chicago area and Little Goat diner does not disappoint! This place was packed!! Fortunately they take reservations. I ordered this little piggy went to China and boy was it packed with flavor. We also got a cinnamon roll, who knew simple cinnamon roll can be soooo good. It was moist and had the right amount of sweetness. Service was fairly fast. Can't wait to return to Little Goat!

pics.caption: Cinnamon roll with the right amount of sweetness
This little piggy went to China

review.des: I have been here twice and I've gotten different things here. The first time I ordered the los drowned and the crumpets. The crumpets were delicious but the los drowned was not my cup of tea. It was a bit too messy and soggy but that's my fault. I was disappointed to learn that fries do NOT come with the sandwiches which was surprising cause the prices are pretty high for a diner. The fries were absolutely forgettable and not worth it in my opinion. The second time I went I got a pulled pork sandwich which was ok. The service was quite sloth-like and it took forever to get our food. They also completely forgot about the milkshake I ordered and the waiter was noticeably annoyed when she saw that the food runners still hadn't brought it out. I feel like I just ordered wrong and have bad luck haha but Idk, my personal experiences weren't great. but that's just me. I do really like the interior of the restaurant and the color scheme. They do have some tasty dishes.
Best dessert - pretzel ice cream sundae - beyond words!  Also very tasty chicken/ waffles

I got the best piece of toast ($3.00) I've ever had. My girlfriend made fun of me for having a random Toast craving but she also agreed that this Stephanie Izard toast was the best toast we've both ever had.

10/10.

(The rest of the food was good too. I wasn't a huge fan of the Bulleyes French Toast as it was super heavy and coma inducing but the regular piece of toast made up for everything).

pics.caption: Parathas Burrito - heavenly. Forgot it didn't have meat!

review.des: One of my favorite places to go to with my friends! They have an amazing selection of foods with great drinks. I would highly recommend this place if you are looking for a luxurious and good time in the city.
Goat chili is the only thing worth getting here - tho 2nd time i went it was too salty. The wait here is long and not worth it. The service was average.

I came to little goat for Sunday brunch without a reservation..risky I know! The wait was almost 2 hours BUT we walked into the bakery/bar area which is open seating and were lucky enough to snag a table! There's only 4 or 5 small tables in this area so it's a little tight but we were starving and so glad we didn't have to wait! I would definitely recommend making a reservation in advance but even a 2 hour wait would be totally worth it.
I had the razzle chai latte which was beautifully spicy and large and this little piggy went to china. The dish was awesome. The combo of strawberries and chili blended together surprisingly well and I would definitely order it again. My vegetarian boyfriend had the veggie patty melt and fries and was very satisfied. It's great to finally find a brunch place that has a couple different options for eggless vegetarians. Can't wait to go back!

pics.caption: Door to the bakery/bar with open seating!
This little piggy went to china

review.des:
Another wonderful restaurant from Stephanie Izard. Just like the Girl & the Goat, a lot of the breakfast menu items incorporate Asian flavors and popular Asian dishes. There's also a bakery attached to the restaurant that offers coffee and baked goods - worth checking out during your wait. I tried the chocolate croissant and the goat latte. The chocolate croissant is surprisingly good - it was nicely flakey and not dense like other croissants you get from coffee shops. The goat latte is not for me though; the goat milk has that prominent 'gaminess' you get from goat cheese that I did not like.

For breakfast, I got This Little Piggy Went to China which is a dish made up of sesame cheddar biscuit, szechuan pork sausage (more of a patty than sausage IMO), sunny side up eggs, and a chili garlic sauce. The dish is as good as it sounds. I just love how Little Goat Diner takes your standard, popular American breakfast items and make it a completely different yet cohesive dish by interweaving Asian flavors. All my friends were satisfied with their dishes as well. Another restaurant where I don't think you can go wrong. Best part is that the prices are competitive with other brunch places, so you don't have to worry about putting a dent in your wallet.

3.5 stars rounded down because food was way too salty

At first glance, the menu seems like an Asian fusion restaurant with a creative spin. I had difficulty deciding what to get because everything looked good.. but I was definitely surprised by a few things.

Here are the key takeaways:
- Portion sizes varied a lot so within our large party, we ended up sharing. The chocolate chip pancakes and Bull's Eye french toast items were huge, little piggy went to china was average, and the okonomiyaki was tiny.. A well-run restaurant would not have inconsistencies with the portion sizes if they are priced relatively similar
- Salty salty salty. My little piggy went to china was REALLY salty. Brussel sprouts were good but still pretty salty. Some other dishes were fine though so maybe it's just one chef who has a heavy hand
- The sides were good - we got the Not Chinese broccoli, brussel sprouts (my fav), and mac and cheese.
- The fried pickles & onion rings were interesting. It was covered in a light-tempura-like batter, not the typical doughy deep fry, making it crunchier than expected. Sauces were - yes you know it - SALTY.

There needs to be more oversight in the kitchen on what is being served to the customers. And I guess the expectation here is that since this is still a diner, the quantity of food is valued over the quality of food (or maybe it's just me). Well if that's the case, I'll probably go stick with the more well-known sister restaurant across the street for a tastier meal.

pics.caption: Little piggy went to China - flavors were good but SO salty I struggled to finish

review.des:
Not bad as a diner. Using so much details and add ons for brunch class food is awesome. Bull's eye i would give 9/10 points, having an onsen egg inside the french toast gives extra texture in the mouth. With extra chicken stripe on top makes the dish very fulfilling. Shrimp and grits 8/10 points. I really like how they gave extra flavor to the fluffy texture of the grits by dropping a potion of goat milk inside. But the dish became over complicated with pistachios and lettuce. I guess the Big Bang intention came to a fail. Chicken fingers 8/10. Its rare to find restaurants to use marinated and well beaten chicken breast as chicken strips. Its very tender and flavored. But the batter seems a little too simple, would be much crunchier if battered and fried a couple more times. Goat milk latte is a must try if u like goat milk.
I would recommend this diner if theres no need to wait.

pics.caption: No wait needed if go in the afternoon
Goat milk latte, must try if goat milk lover

review.des: I went here for lunch today and waited about 30 minutes for a table to be ready. Upon receiving the text that a table was ready, the hostess required us to wait an additional 10 minutes until the table was actually ready. When I was finally seated, I waited at my table for another 15 minutes. During this time, no one from the waitstaff approached our table and we decided to leave... Though I'm sure the food is great!

The food here is incredibly unique and equally excellent!  Remember, I rarely give out 5 stars. So 4 starts is still exceptional.  

I've been here several times and everything including their burgers, to their sausage and gravy, to their pies and everything else is just incredible. I usually give more detailed reviews than this, and if I didn't like it, I would, but just this once, trust me, you won't get a bad meal here. You just won't. I've brought friends from Rome, my boss from South Carolina, and my picky parents and everyone has had an excellent experience.  

I should mention that no matter what time of day, what day, or time of year, it's always busy, but you'd never know it from the service.  This is rare.  Every single visit has had exceptional service. That is a rarity unto itself.  

This is a "must" experience as any architecture tour is for a Chicago visitor.

Service was great

Coffee is worth coming back for

Biscuits & Gravy was off the charts good

Bullseye French Toast was very interesting to say the least with some flavorful twists that will excite your taste buds!

Overall I would give this awesome restaurant a 4.5 star review & I never

Been here three times, keep trying because it's good bad-for-you food. Only 3 stars because 2 of the 3 times I've been the hostess stand has just "lost" our name. What is that about?? Make sure you check with them if you've been waiting a while because that host stand has not figured their shit out.

Incredible food and super friendly staff. I got the goat chilli and "This little piggy went to China." The goat chilli is a must (can imagine it's especially great during the winter) and the "this little piggy.." dish was unique and absolutely delicious. Also tried the cinnabun which was super gooey (lived up to its name) and great if you're craving something sweet and the mac n cheese which was super cheesy and worth checking out. Portions are pretty big so expect to leave full.

Ordered a  nightly special, not on the menu, that our server told me about without asking the price.  Man that was a big mistake.  Everything else was good but I felt uncomfortable after leaving and will never return.  To offer a nightly special that is so much more expensive than anything else on the menu without disclosing the price left a bad taste in my mouth.

I've had only good experiences at Little Goat. I always order the goat chili and milkshakes- so good! Also, somewhat unexpectedly I've ended up getting the scallop special in both of my last two visits and boy were they delicious!  Would also recommend the Mac n cheese and seasonal gazpachos for starters / sides. It's much easier to a reservation here compared to Girl & the Goat and Duck Duck Goat as well which is always a plus as well!

Homemade everything.  Bread with bacon baked into it.  Wow, wow, wow!  We had a veggie quesadilla and a grilled cheese that was one of the most hearty sandwiches I've ever eaten.  Rebecca was our very kind, accommodating, knowledgeable, and professional server.  I could eat here all day every day.....and weigh 500 pounds, but it might jus be worth it!

A personal favorite in the West Loop. Little Goat never ceases to amaze me with their quirky twists on American diner classics. Kimchi rueban, sloppy GOAT....even their grilled cheese has guanciale on it! Everything I've tried here has been outstanding and fresh. They're great for brunch, lunch and dinner too! Though there might be a wait, trust me it's worth it! They have one of the best rooftop patios in the city, so wait the extra time for the full outdoor experience!

Keep em' coming Stephanie, Chicago loves ya!

Really good food. Great service and super cute, clean, and trendy environment.

I would give 5 stars but $10 for a weak mimosa is excessive. Also, the waiter told us the fries would be large enough to share between 3-4 people but it really seemed like one decent serving for maybe 1-2 people.

We had intended to come here for dinner, but our impromptu stop at Au Cheval spoiled our appetites, though not our moods.. we had a delightful time at Little Goat.

Eileen L.'s REFVIEW for Little Goat Diner

RELEVANT INFO
* Cutest interactive website evarrr
* Bar @ Little Goat Bakery is a good place to visit while waiting for your table
* Reservations (via OpenTable) recommended: our dinner was at 9:15PM, and the restaurant was still full, and new parties were constantly trickling in
* Texted when our table was ready, and the Host congratulated us on our 5 year when we checked in! :D
* Huge menu! Will have to try new things next time when this place isn't a second dinner spot :)
* Open until midnight Fridays and Saturdays
* Purse hooks at every table!
* Single restroom stalls are a major buzzkill!

EXPECTATIONS GOING IN
* I couldn't get reservations at The Girl & The Goat, so Little Goat will do

FOOD
* Side Caesar Salad ($7) + chicken ($4): kale tossed in a light, tasty Caesar dressing, with tender white-meat chicken
* Chicken & French Toast ($16): I love having a classic brunch dish during dinner; french toast was buttery, light and with great texture (slightly crunchy, thick, yet airy), the chicken batter had a slight cayenne kick to it

VALUE
* Reasonably priced for a second dinner :)

IMPRESSION OVERALL
* Great service :)
* Little Goat treated us to a sundae for our 5 year anniversary.. a nice touch indeed!

ENVIRONMENT / AMBIANCE
* Beautiful, clean, contemporary diner

WOW FACTOR
* The service was above and beyond

Who knew diner style food could be so amazing! Really do not judge by looks here, because you will be in for a pleasant surprise! The pot pie and burger are no ordinary versions at all and you will enjoy every bit of whatever you order. The prices do seem pretty steep for the food, but the taste explains why.

We ordered the Los Drowned Sandwich, Okonomiyaki, Shrimp Cocktail, and the Macho Nachos. Everything was delicious and high recommended!

The Los Drowned Sandwich was juicy, flavorful, crunchy, savory, creamy, and just amazing. It came with a side bowl of soup for dipping and just made every bite heavenly! The sauce did not drown out the meat flavor and every topping was a perfect match.

The Okonomiyaki was surprisingly good. Because you wouldn't think a mm American style diner place would do Japanese fare any justice, but we were completely wrong! The flavors and textures were perfect and we would have ordered another if we weren't already so full!

The Shrimp Cocktail was like a shrimp lettuce wrap with crunchy shrimp and the best marinara sauce ever! The sauce is chunkier and so perfectly tangy. The shrimp were wrapped in a strand of noodle and was so crunchy and flavorful.

The Macho Nachos were huge and perfect for sharing. The chips were thick and crunchy. The two types of cheese were melty and stringy. Every bite was sinfully good. The pulled pork was savory and juicy. The guacamole on top was creamy and seriously every bite left me wanting more.

pics.caption: Five of the best shrimp cocktail ever

review.des:
Little Goat Diner gets two thumbs up from this girl right here! I was in Chicago this past weekend and staying in the West Loop so waking up on Sunday morning, the boy and I decided to venture out for brunch.  We decided on the Little Goat Diner and started on our wonderful food adventure. We walked in and there was a huge crowd already waiting, we were quoted a wait time of 30 minutes but the lines were moving quickly.  I think we waited somewhere between 15-20 minutes total.  

We were greeted in a reasonable amount of time and our server was great!  We ordered the Bull's eye french toast, pork belly home fries, and the tonkatsu.  Oh! Also the mulled wine!  You have the get the mulled wine!!  The bull's eye french toast was delicious with the chunks of chicken in the middle soaking up all that goodness.  The pork belly homes fries were also delicious I just wished it had a little bit more pork belly in it or perhaps chopped up the two big pieces we did have into small pieces to just evenly distribute it.  My tonkatsu was good - the sauce was a bit off for me, maybe a little too sweet?  But it was thinned out nicely and the panko covering was nice and crunchy.

We were in and out in about an hour.  The service was quick and our server was super friendly.  The restaurant is a nice open area with plenty of tables, a little diner counter area, and there's a hidden door to the bathrooms!

pics.caption: Bull's eye French toast and Pork Belly home fries...YUUUUUUUUUUUUMMY GOODNESS!

review.des: Go early.. expect a wait. It's worth it! Birdseye French toasts is amazing! Great coffee

You definitely want to make a reservation on the weekends! This place gets packed and for good reason. The food is very good. We came for brunch and enjoyed a couple different dishes. We started off with a very stiff greyhound that was helpful in getting the days started.

Food is creative and delicious. The shrimp and cheesy grits were very good. BF had the omelette of the day with a mushroom mole and it was very good, if not a little rich. Also had the biscuits and gravy that was excellent.

Service was great. Loved the ambiance and decor of the place. I would come back.

Since I didn't care enough to plan ahead and get our group a reservation at Girl & the Goat, we ate at Stephanie Izard's other restaurant, Little Goat Diner, instead. Reservations for Little Goat were available same-day on OpenTable. Our dining experience here was A-OK. Given the hype, I was expecting better.

This is a neat, stylish diner with a bakery attached. One thing I think that's cool about its design is the hidden entrance to the restrooms. The door blends in with the wall like the entrance to some secret lair in a movie. I do like the playfulness about this place from the cartoon graphics on the menu to little touches like actually printing the words "Blue Plate" on the blue plate special plates.

We visited for dinner where the menu consisted of American breakfast foods, breads, sandwiches, soups, salads, burgers, dinner entrees, and apps/sides. Desserts included pies, cakes, shakes, and sundaes and drinks included bottled sodas like Cheerwine, spicy ginger ale, and Mexican Coke. They also have a coffee menu. Expect to spend at least $20-25 per person.

It's American food, but I wouldn't consider it traditional as many of the dishes have creative twists or takes. Here's what we tried:

* Reuben ($13) - smoked corned beef, kimchi, kraut, havarti, special sauce, Spence rye
* Korean Burger ($14) - kimchi, bacon, egg, chi mayo, sweet roll
* Shrimp & Pork Belly ($21) - summer squash, "shrimpy" noodles
* Blue Plate Special ($23) - Alaskan sockeye salmon, corn miso puree, squash, shiitake, pea tips, sun gold cherry chimichurri

I love good kimchi and Little Goat's version is actually decent. However, I'm not sure I liked it in the Reuben. The spicy and sour flavors of the kimchi just didn't jive with the traditional Reuben for me. The buttered and toasted bread and the quality of the corned beef was good. The sandwich was a little heavy and salty, but overall, not bad in my opinion.

The Korean burger was monstrous and a sight to behold (great presentation). It was difficult and messy to eat because of how big the burger was. All of the ingredients were piled on high. I thought the beef patty was delicious and generally, this was a fine burger. Smoky, savory, and satisfying.

Since I'm allergic to shrimp, I delicately ate my way around the shrimp and pork belly salad. All of the veggies were fresh. This was a simple, light, and refreshing salad. Definitely healthy. The blue plate special for the night was also fresh and healthy. The sockeye salmon was rich in flavor and the vegetable medley worked well together. On the downside, it wasn't filling, but at least I know I was eating smart. I'd order it again.

Service was excellent. The staff is friendly, attentive, and courteous. Our orders came out in a reasonable amount of time.

In the end, I think this place is probably better for breakfast, lunch, or brunch than it is for dinner. Regardless, it's still probably worth checking out.

Korean Burger. Kimchi, bacon, egg, chi mayo, sweet roll. $14.

review.des: I am obsessed with Little Goat. I can't believe I haven't left a review yet. Every time we go we sit at the bar (open seating--grab a drink (start with a bloody mary) while you wait and be cutthroat and you will get a seat). Cinnamon buns and pork belly home fries are my go to starters (pork belly home fries are like meat croutons they're so good!) Amazing bougie brunch, but not too bougie, know what i mean? Great bartenders, food, and atmosphere. And they have goat milk as an alternative milk option, what more could you want?

pics.caption: pork belly home fries and asian-y broccoli

review.des:
First impressions - your senses are completely overwhelmed when you walk in. This diner is beautiful, and everything smells amazing. The Goat Patty Melt was on point (cheesy + secret sauce + bread and butter pickles). The smoked fries were 5/5 amazing and like nothing I have ever had before. The fried pickles and onion rings were so well seasoned and basically tempura fried - super light and crispy - and came with an awesome ranch and a curry mustard for dipping which was delish.

Oh, and the Goat Latte (goat caramel, goat milk, chilli pepper) is the perfect thing to kick start your metabolism after stuffing your face.

I must return to try more of the things...*make a reservation - this place gets busy around 8:30 pm!

This diner was a recommendation from a friend. First, make reservations. The restaurant is in a busy neighborhood outside downtown. Parking is tough.
Food was excellent; adequate servings, bold flavors and interesting ingredients. The fried shrimp in lettuce wraps were delicious apps but priced at $15.
Sloppy goat is served in a soft bun and crowded with a delicious mix of ground goat and slaw. The Reuben is better than average and adds kimchi as a bonus
For no-meat types try the veggie gemelli- crazy good! Decent craft beer selection and their iced tea is genuine
Lemon soaked cake was as big as my head and the sundae is served in a medieval sized goblet.
Yes this place is worth the trip.

Came here on a Sunday and boy was it packed! Be prepared to wait an hour or so but it is well worth the wait! I got the Los Drowned which is like a roast beef sandwich but with braised beef. They kick it up a notch with pickled peppers and onions which in my opinion made the sandwich as great as it was. Let's also not forget to mention the bread! It was still so crisp and crunchy even after it was doused in au jus! Definitely a must try!

Let me just get this over with and say, I was a little disappointed. Not because the place is disappointing, but more so because my expectations were probably just too high. This was my first time dining in this part of Chicago so it was nice to see all the people dressed up for Italian, Indian, Chinese, and good ole' American dinners. This place is on the Chicago list of "rooftop food destinations" and we weren't able to be seated up there. So that was a bummer. Second, the whole place just felt crammed. Not like I was rubbing shoulders with anyone, but we got this reservation a week in advance and we were seated in a small 2-person table at the end of a divider wall. But let's talk about the actual food  

Fried Pickles & Onion Rings (5/5)
--- Okay, what? $9 put down and I'm expecting just a few shriveled pieces of each with some generic sauce. Wrong. So wrong. We had to take half of this awesome appetizer home. The pieces were huge, the portion was huge, and the sauces were, how you say ... Bone Apple Tea.

Chicken Pot Pie (5/5)
--- N/A

Goat Almighty
--- I don't know where to begin. And that's exactly how you'll feel when the server drops this on your table. This is one of those classic burgers that literally stand 12 inches tall because there's just so many random things within. What I could remember was two huge buns, a goat patty, another meat, chicken, fried onion rings, mini onion rings, and some other stuff. It was big, and I definitely had it for lunch the next day.

Mac & Cheese, a side of (3/5)
--- Here's where the problem lies. I've always said the Mac & Cheese orrrr Mashed Potatoes could either make or break a meal. This one didn't break it, mainly because I didn't even finish it all. Fortunately the burger was just so extreme that the Mac & Cheese was almost irrelevant. But I never forget. It was white cheddar cheese with some crispy breading on top? I'm not really sure but it wasn't great.

Summary:
I'll probably come back if I can get into a private event on the roof. Unfortunately, the chicken pot pie was almost as expensive as the burger and it was only the size of one of the buns. On top of that, or waitress never asked how the food was and only stopped by to fill our waters. Obviously, that's all you really need, but I had a better conversation with the guy who brought out my leaning tower of goat meat.

A large group of us met here for breakfast expecting an awesome meal.  Sadly, our visit missed the mark.  There were about 10 of us dining, and only one person liked their food.  Not sure what was going on - perhaps we visited on an off day or someone new was in the kitchen - but we left very unimpressed despite an amazing sounding menu.

First of all, the highlight was the mocha cappuccino.  It was perfectly sweet just the way I like it!  But then everything went downhill...

Hubby got the Okonomiyaki, which was a Japanese pancake topped with pork belly.  Flavors didn't marry the way they should have and the dish was really too salty.  I chose the Shrimp and Cheesy Grits, which I thought tasted just fine although the shrimp was cut in a way where they curled up like ruffles when cooked and was a little creepy.  But that's just my weird hangup, lol ..

One girl got the corned beef and said it was absolutely flavorless.  Another was not a fan of the pancakes, which is such a bizarre thing to screw up.  I tasted my friend's Little Piggy Went to China and it was awful - the taste left in my mouth about gave me anxiety, which I'm assuming came from the chili garlic chive sauce.  Cinnamon rolls and side of potatoes turned out to be the best of the bunch.

We ate dinner at the Little Goat's sister property across the street (Girl & the Goat), and I honestly have no idea how these two places can be related.  I really hope our experience was a one-time deal.  Yelp reviews are pretty good, so I'm thinking so.

It's rare that I keep clicking yes at a Yelp check-in.  Trendy, yes.  Hipster, yes.  Classy, um yep.  All of the above.  Not to mention BUSY!!!

My note on a perfect brunch:  Start with a spicy Bloody Mary and wait happily for their fantastic Shrimp & Cheesy Grits.  If shrimp or grits aren't your thing, adventure into what is otherwise known as "Yum" and formally called Okonomiyaki.  If I told you what it was, it wouldn't be an adventure and it is one well worth taking!

We are in town just for a wedding and tried to go to a brunch in Chicago. This place definitely does not disappoint! All the breakfast options sound delicious and cleverly named! You can't go wrong with a "The Little Piggy Went to China" or "Fat Elvis Waffles." We both ordered the little piggy and it was DELICIOUS! The flavors are very complex and work well together. If you are into it, check out the kimchi bloody mary :)
Probably the best breakfast spot in the west loop. I'm a big fan of the biscuits and gravy.
Amazing food, crazy fun service, went Sunday,going back Wednesday!! Want to try the whole menu!!!

I just ate the Chop Chae with a veggie patty, and it was one of the best meals I've ever eaten! Highly recommend. Also had the Blackstrap Coffee cocktail, and it was delicious as well. Got a table for 2 immediately, and the server was very sweet.

We had originally traveled next door to Au Cheval for lunch, but quickly learned their online hours were incorrect as we found them closed. Starving and drenched in sweat from walking multiple blocks in the summer heat, Little Goat caught our eye so we decided to take a chance.

I'd heard of its big sister Girl & The Goat (though hadn't been), but wasn't too familiar with this place. I also didn't realize reservations were so hard to come by as we simply walked in and were seated 10 minutes later. Granted, it was late afternoon on a weekday so not exactly a prime hour like brunch.

Our booth was comfortable and the decor both modern and casual, yet there was a large glass window in the ceiling of the main dining room that just radiated heat. We felt like we never fully cooled off sitting underneath it, though I bet it's a cool feature in the wintertime.

The first thing I noticed was that they serve breakfast all day, so immediately they get a star for that in my book. I also enjoyed their attention to detail throughout the restaurant. Their cute logo can be found on everything from the menu, to the glasses, to the napkin holders, and even on the plates.

Having a separate bakery next door, there was no shortage of treats on the menu as well. Seasonal pies, cake of the day, also sundaes and some devilish sounding shakes. Particularly the horchata milkshake.

We had dessert plans for later so we stayed on the savory path. My husband getting the patty melt with goat of course, and myself the grilled cheese with guanciale and smoked tomato. Our lovely waitress told us one order of fries is easily shared and she was correct. They were a bit thin for my taste and reminded me a lot of the ones from In n Out. I would have preferred them to remain in the fryer a few minutes longer too, but at least they were fresh.

The sandwiches however were excellent. Crispy yet buttery soft bread, quality ingredients with tons of flavor, and heavenly melted cheese. The only complaint being from my husband who hoped the goat would've had a more distinct taste. He said that had he not known, he would have simply thought it was beef.

Next time I would love to try a breakfast plate like perhaps the sourdough pancakes, Fat Elvis waffle, crumpets with chorizo maple syrup, or their ooey gooey cinnabun.

pics.caption: Patty melt with a goat patty
Draft brew in a cute glass

review.des: We arrived at 7PM on a Wednesday and miraculously did not have to wait for a table. We were immediately taken by the charming ambiance and interior design of the restaurant. After extensive deliberation, we ordered the goat chili cheese fries, okonomiyaki, and pork belly pancake. The food was delicious and the Asian food elements satisfied my Asian food cravings in the best diner-style way. The dishes were all very well rounded and blended the different savory, sweet, sour flavors together beautifully.

So yummy!! Came here on a whim while in the city and was blown away! I had the goat latte and this little piggy went to china for breakfast and loved most. Would really recommend the this little piggy because it had the best sausage and biscuit i've had. Don't be scared of the goat milk in the goat latte- it was one of the best lattes i've ever had. Hope to be returning soon!

The Little Goat has an extensive brunch menu with several vegetarian options or at least, dishes that can be made veggie.  They have the standard breakfast/brunch dishes that one expects and also some unique dishes (parathas burrito, tempura mashed potatoes!?).
We liked the classic diner decor (it may even be a diner from years ago and just redone?), and the place was super busy, which was a good sign.  They don't seat you unless your whole party is there, and we had a 10:30am reservation, and although all of us were there by 10:40, we had to wait another 10 minutes for a table.

I got the veggie quesadilla, hold the smoked blueberries.   Smoked anything tastes like meat and definitely not what I want.  It was good, but the cheese wasn't as melted as it should have been, and was a tad too oily.  It came with eggplant inside, and radishes on top.  Some bites of eggplant didn't taste fully cooked.  I also had a side of the cheesy hash browns.  They were good, but after the 4th bite, I had had enough.  

My friend had the corned beef and hash which got a thumbs up, and my boyfriend had the Spanish omelette, which was not at all a true Spanish omelette.  This was more a pile of potatoes and scrambled eggs squished together and had tortilla chips on top!!  Although it's often called a tortilla española, it is NOT supposed to come with tortilla or tortilla chips!  Aye aye aye.  And no, it wasn't a "play on words"...

Overall, by no means was it UNenjoyable, but it also wasn't really enjoyable, aside from the company.  It isn't somewhere I'd go again, or highly recommend.  Although, maybe is be willing to give the lunch menu a go?

I had very high expectations for Little Goat, being a Stephanie Izard restaurant. Unfortunately, it did not live up to the expectations. My boyfriend and I ordered the This Little Piggy Went to China and the Los Drowned. The Los Drowned was very good- not great. Nothing very memorable. This $14 sandwich came with no sides. The This Little Piggy Went to China was bad. This dish was very confused. There were too many flavors happening that did not complement each other. The Sichuan in the dish was overpowering and ruined the dish, leaving a numbing feeling on my tongue. The blackberries in the dish did not go with the other flavor combinations at all. Additionally, our service was terrible. One dish came out five minutes before the other dish, so my dish was a little cold by the time my boyfriend's came out. Also, I ordered a coffee and drank it in several minutes, but was never offered a refill, nor could I find our server to ask for a refill. For a $4 coffee, that's a little ridiculous.

Overall, I would not recommend this restaurant. The service was terrible and the food was 50/50. It's expensive and there are much better restaurants in West Town.

LOVE the fusion thing going on here!

I'm especially drawn to the kimchi pancake thing -- spicy, crunchy, and full of probiotics.

The burrito made with paratha? Sounds implausible, maybe, but it a) truly works, and b) is maybe even one of the best dishes on this restaurant's menu. (Yup. You have to believe me.)

This place can be hard to get into sans a reservation -- be forewarned. (But, hey, kiddo -- isn't that a really GOOD indicator of what you can expect?)

We got a reservation for early in the morning so we did not have to wait long. We got a booth seat next to the window so off to a good start.
I ordered the bulls eye french toast, it was a good combination of sweet and savory. Although i tried some of the dishes my friends ordered and liked the other more savory ones a little better. We also shared a fries for the table.
It feels like towards the end, our waitress kept coming back and rushing for us to finish whereas we wanted a nice girls out brunch. Overall a good experience.
The Ruben sandwich is so delicious that I cannot forget for my whole life!!! But need to wait for the seats because of the dining crowd

Been here a couple of times, and I'm just not that into Little Goat. I think it's overpriced and the dishes are underdeveloped. It doesn't quite scratch my itch for greasy diner food, nor does it satisfy a craving for an excellent restaurant meal. Meh.

Updated review, 3 stars to 4 stars
We came here after our failed lunch at Roisters and they saved the day with:

Los Drowned
Cake of the Day: Yellow cake with blueberries and vanilla buttercream

pics.caption: Cake of the Day: Yellow cake with blueberries and vanilla buttercream... yummo!!!

review.des:
Pros
-takes walk ins
-distinct flavored food
-menu has different options
-friendly staff
-great service
-brown sugar on the table :) I didn't have to ask for it!
-short wait for food
-reasonable prized
-fresh squeezed orange juice

One of my new favorites! The menu here is at lower price point than other restaurants in the West Loop, and getting a reservation on Open Table is no biggie. Come hungry, because they have large portions of comfort food.

We ordered the crab dip appetizer, dark chocolate chip pancakes, The Little Piggy Went to China, and a side of pork belly home fries. Everything was so good but we couldn't finish it! But the leftovers were equally amazing for breakfast.

They have a lot of options on the menu, and it took some time to decide what we wanted. I advise doing some research on the menu :)

Not to mention, service was really quick. Our waitress was very patient and consistently checked on us since we were so indecisive and took forever to order. Will definitely be coming back!

Update- came back on a Saturday morning with reservations... they were 45 mins late on our reservation. Hostesses were not attentive at all and it took me awhile for me to check in. Taking off 1 star.
Cute restaurant but this place gave me food poisoning. I ordered the Spanish omelette which wasn't even that great. I had a flight to NYC that night so you can imagine how that went.

We were visiting Chicago from out of state and we ate here 3 out of the 4 days that we were in town. All for the Okonomiyake. That thing is damn good! The pancake is perfectly moist! We ordered 1 to share for the first 2 times, but each had to get our own the third time. The goat chili was a good compliment to the dish. It's way easier to get reservations here. We never got a chance to eat across the street at the Girl and the Goat. It was a blessing though because I thoroughly enjoyed each meal that I had here.

I am not an american breakfast kind of girl but hearing a lot of raves from my friends, I thought I might give this place a try. This place was packed on a sunday morning and the wait was 20 minutes. I thought to myself "wow, this place is packed and people are willing to wait this long to eat here then the food must be fantastic." Oh boy, was I WRONG. I ordered the chocolate chip pancakes and a side of hash browns. The pancakes were too sweet  and my hash browns were burnt. On top of bad food, food was expensive. This place disappoint me more than my grades disappoint my mom.

Great place -new diverse flavors all in one menu. The chili cheese fries were out of this world and  he parathas burrito was a great new twist to the breakfast burrito. First you must use a fork and knife and second the Indian flavors really is the cherry on top.

pics.caption: Chili cheese fries and parathas burrito

review.des:
I'm a huge fan of Little Goat and the Little Goat cafe. I've never had to wait more than 15 minutes for a table, and it's the kind of place that you go to when you're not really sure what you want.

You can usually skip a wait if you opt to sit at the bar, but either way - great vibes all around. If you're not feeling the vibe, walk over next door to their cafe (you can order the same menu at the bar!) and enjoy the cafe experience.

The Loco Moco is delicioussss as are the sandwiches (the Los Drowned!!!) and salads. Easily a 2 meal kind of place, unless you're overly committed to finishing your plate.

Take public transit or Divvy over - parking is kind of a pain.

pics.caption: Coffee and oatmeal to start the day.

review.des: Came here with my friends for brunch. If you notice, this street loves their goat themes. They're all separate entities. The portions at the Goat Diner are pretty huge. They do use a lot of goat cheese/milk/products. Wait wasn't too long. The place is huge. Delicious food!
Very interesting flavors for breakfast. I really enjoyed my cauliflower rice dish with fried egg and pickled veggies. Coffee is plenty and staff very friendly!

Little Goat is one of my favorite places to take guests for a weekend brunch meal. Although a reservation is almost always a must and we tend to wait a few minutes despite the reservation booking, the food is worth it. There is an enormous variety on the menu. One of my favorites is the cauliflower bibimbap bowl. Definitely make a trip to Little Goat!

This had been on my restaurant bucket list and did not disappoint. We had reservations on a Saturday evening but still had to wait about 10 minutes for a table. This place stays PACKED! Service remained pretty good the entire time though. I insisted we order either a 3rd meal or an appetizer so that I could sample more of the menu. We started with their pork nachos- a HUGE portion of sweet pork and savory toppings. Messy, cheesy, and fantastic. They even traveled home pretty well. I ate the left overs 2 more times before finally giving up and throwing away the rest.

For my meal, I got the Bull's Eye French Toast- fried chicken, french toast, and a hidden egg in the middle. It had strawberries and syrup too. It had so much going on but it all went together SOOOO well. I took some of that home too, but definitely ate all the good parts at the restaurant.

I ordered their manhattan for my drink. It was a weird combo with the food, but they definitely make a good, stiff drink!

I didn't find the prices to be too over the top, and to leave with leftovers made me extremely happy! This place is a gem! Can't wait to go back....

pics.caption: This little piggy went to China

review.des: The sandwich I had was unbelievable. If you are just looking for a quick bite this is such a sweet little diner. The wait staff is very kind and attentive. I'd give extra stars if I could. I was impressed that we were able to get a table and were seated right away without a reservation.

Everything was delicious. I had The French toast and we split the hash browns. A must have is the cinnamon role. It's incredible. Parking is a challenge. But if you get here early enough you can find something on the street.

Everything was great from the service to the food to the atmosphere. Definitely make a utilize their website and make a reservation in advance. My favorite was the pork belly pancake. Also you'll want to make sure to save room for dessert!

This is a wonderful place to grab a wifi and delish bite to eat. I have been here now three times and I've never been disappointed with my choices. For breakfast, I would recommend the bull's eye French toast. Eggs, crispy chicken, BBQ maple syrup and strawberries. For something filling but lighter, try the chickpea, a huge salad that comes with falafel (even if not listed on the menu). Affordable, tasty place to bring family and friends with minimal wait time!
Casual atmosphere that has a modern diner flair. Service was prompt and friendly. Food was good but nothing great. I got the half chicken with tangy slaw. A bit overpriced.

A little disappointed considering the high expectations for this place.
I ordered the grilled cheese, which is a classic in my books and hardly something you can mess up. However, it came with olives inside - and I hate olives! And it's definitely not mentioned on the menu that there's onions in the grilled cheese.
Just not what I had in mind and hoped for.
The fried chicken on the other hand was tasty and really juicy.

Tokyo pro tip: head to the goat first thing in the morning and grab a tonkatsu sammich. Take it home, cut each half in half and all the crust off. Mash it in a tupperware container that is slightly too small. Let it rest in the fridge while you are at work.

After work call your spouse and tell them not to wait up. Proceed to the bar--with co-workers or by yourself--and order cheap draft beer.

"Kanpai!"

Slam the lager like Bad Santa. Order another round. Slow your stride after the first beer but still keep up a slightly uncomfortable pace. This should continue for some time until it's clear you've overstayed your watering hole welcome. Is someone in your party sleeping face down on the table? Deep-chest hiccups? Are other patrons taking notice of your slurring babble? Good, it's time.

Leave your cash, head to the door, slam your body shoulder-first into the side that is locked. Raise your hand apologetically, spew  "Arigatou gozaimasu!" go out the unlocked side.

Stumble home...

Hungry aren't you? Thirsty too? Of course you  are, you slob.

Once home head to the fridge for a night cap. Man, what's that creeping out of the recycling bin? Close in, squint, then you'll see it...it's a to-go box. A to-go box with a freak-ish miniature pony on it. (it's a flipping goat)

Regardless, that's when it will happen, your sammich memory will return. Fridge door open, light on, there it is-- the most perfect Japanese-style-deep-fried-pork-chop-reuben you've ever seen, anywhere.

And it's huge.

Jackpot.

I had been to Girl and the Goat but not here and was excited to try it. I went on a Saturday around 5 o'clock without a reservation. It was very busy and there was a line of people waiting but I was by myself and was able to get a seat at the counter right away. My server was Shane; she had only been working there for a month but did a great job and was very knowledgeable. After some consultation with Shane, I got the bahn mi burger and was blown away by it. It had so many delicious flavors. For my side, I was deciding between the squash and the broccoli. I was hesitant to get the broccoli because the only dish I didn't care for at Girl and the Goat was the broccoli dish. Shane convinced me that the broccoli dish at the diner was very flavorful and I'm glad I ordered it because she was right. The only disappointment I had was the lack of interesting non-alcoholic drinks. Their cocktail menu was extensive but I did not see any mocktails. Otherwise, I had a wonderful visit and was impressed by the service and the food.

WOW!!!  Great service in an atmosphere with great food!!!!!!!  Triple threat.  

We went on a Sunday around 8:30-9am.  We had a reservation for 11:30am but they got us in within 15 minutes.  The hosts were great and had an awesome energy-which is so rare amoungst hosts I feel.

The server, I didn't get his name (tall/skinny), was also very kind.

We had the Bullseye and the Yum!  We also got a side of mac and sausage.  Everything was 4-5 stars.  I wouldn't hesitate to return or recommend the place.  I get why the Exec Chef is so well like...the food is on point!
Yum! Always a wait, but worth it. Classics with a twist. I usually stick with breakfast fare - pancakes, hash, biscuits- all delicious. Quick, friendly service too once you get seated.

Really good, really busy, and pretty pricey. This is the kind of spot you visit rarely and wish you could go to more. Everything is too delicious anyway. Also the parking situation is inconvenient as hell. Definitely treat yourself every once in a while. Especially after some hard drinking. The grease will set you free.
Ordered okonomiyaki this time, great flavor, just like what I had in Japanese restaurant, get an offer of free Brussels spouts, nice presentation, thanks!
Amazing lunch. I really think the crab and heirloom special today was the best salad I have ever had. Creative and delicious. The mint tequila cocktail was also perfectly spicy!

Second time here, and I always leave feeling so underwhelmed. Food seems overpriced for the quality, and it feels like the staff are doing you a favor to serve you. This time we got served undercooked food, most likely won't be going back.

We came on a weeknight. Party of 3. Waited for an hour to and hour and half to be seated. Our server was friendly and made a lot of good suggestions for us.

We ordered biscuits and gravy, pork belly pancake, goat pattie melt, and the chicken pot pie. The biscuits and gravy was thick and had generous amounts of meat in the gravy. The pork belly pancake was flavorful and sweet. The chicken pot pie was dry and too salty. It was not very large and was rather pricey. My favorite dish was the pattie melt. The goat burger was meaty and was not too gamey. The burger was so juicy.

Overall, good experience.

Two of my friends and I were excited to try Little Goat Diner in Chicago while we were in town for a girls trip! We were all from out of town and weren't able to get reservations at Girl and the Goat since it was restaurant week in February. So instead we opted to go to breakfast at Little Goat Diner on a Monday morning.

It was delicious. The menu had so many great breakfast staples (omelettes, waffles, pancakes) but also sprinkled in lots of intriguing flavors and dishes (like creole crab crumpets).

The atmosphere was a beautiful blend of modern while paying homage to the retro diner feel. I can't imagine a more gorgeous/aesthetically pleasing diner. So so so well done.

The bakery portion to The Little Goat has some great options for taking on the go (homemade poptarts, cupcakes, etc.).

The most memorable part - Stephanie Izard was sitting in the booth next to ours! I am a huge top chef fan so I recognized her immediately. It made my whole trip!

I'm no...... food expert.... but I'd like to think I know when something tastes fantastic. And everything I ate here the other day -- parathas burrito, vegetarian home fries (not listed on menu, but waitress-recommended) and veggie japchae were incredible. I felt like every type of taste bud on my tongue was being stimulated; the food was just that well-balanced. Each dish was deliciously savory, and each ingredient gave just the right amount of simplicity AND complexity to create a well-rounded, well-thought out dish. The flavors are just incredible. Wish I could think of another way to explain this but wow -- everything was just SO yummy.

I feel like I give out a lot of 5 stars, and sometimes it's because I find the ambiance or the service or the aesthetic of the restaurant I'm reviewing to be particularly good and/or charming as well as the food. But this place deserves every one of my 5 stars for just the food alone. It's just an added bonus that the interior and the service are just as lovely as well.

We had breakfast here on a family trip. Everyone loved their choice. The cinnamon rolls were warm, deliciously gooey ands completely scrumptious mess! I got the blueberry pancakes were wonderful. The portions are really large and made it easy for us all to share with each other. We found it very family friendly. The 2 year old in our party could have watched the baker window for hours. It kept him pleasantly occupied and quiet while we waited for our food. Great pick!

I went to the little goat for a quick bite. The cocktail I got was pretty good. I forget the name, but it was a bourbon based cocktail with blueberry jam and mint. It was very good.

The goat patty melt was great. It was perfectly cooked (still pink) and the bread was perfectly toasted.

The smoked fries were not as crispy as I'd like and were quite salty.

Overall, it was a good experience!

Finally got a chance to try Little Goat Diner after hearing great things about the restaurant! We went on a Thursday afternoon around 12:15. We had a reservation but still had to wait a little bit as it was super busy with the lunch crowd. I ordered the Dark Chocolate Chip Crunch Pancakes and they were so good! I ended up only being able to eat half of the plate and took home the other half. The guy next to us ordered the Bull Eye's French Toast and my friend and I agreed that we had to try it next time because we most definitely will be coming back!

We had an early  dinner there last night before going to the theater. We were 6 people and sat at a big booth next to the window. The hostess was very nice and sat us right away. Our waiter was very attentive. We started with crab dip and bread sticks. We had chicken pie, fish tostadas, all American hamburger, patty burger and the goat hamburger. Everybody enjoyed their dinners. The food was delicious. The kids drunk chocolate milkshake and they enjoyed them very much. We'll be back!

The Little Goat is listed as a diner on Yelp, but as a NJ native, I'm gonna say this place looks like a diner, but it ain't much of a diner. It's more gourmet than your usual greasy spoon diner, and the prices reflect it. Service was friendly, but it felt like our food took forever to come out. As an appetizer, my group ordered the crab dip, which was served with not enough Ritz crackers. The waitress soon offered us more, but really they could have just included more.

I ordered the Goat Almighty with a side of the hash browns at the suggestion of our waitress. The Goat Almighty was a hefty goat burger with braised beef and BBQ pulled pork along with jalapenos, cheddar, onion rings, and salsa verde. It's pricey at $20, but very tasty. The hash browns were shredded and cooked on the griddle with cheese, which should have tasted amazing, but ended up tasting burnt. I didn't finish them.

Not much of a diner, but a decent place to grab a bite.

***Vegetarian Review***

PRO TIP - there's a vegan menu.

Ok, so I come here incredibly infrequently due to underwhelming experiences but this last visit was pretty good.  The Banh mi style burger is good.  It is pretty hard to eat as the patti falls apart as you eat it.  Overall, it's not really a Banh mi sandwich, but if you like vinegar, you'll like this.

Experience as a whole, a bit expensive for the quality. but its nice to sit on a patio.

Of Stephanie Izard's 3 popular spots in West Loop, this is by far the easiest to book a reservation at. We were promptly seated at our reservation time on a Sunday. The service was good, although not amazing, which is what I expected at a more casual diner.

I had the Almighty Goat burger, which is huge. No, really, it's humongous. As in you can't actually eat it like a burger because it won't fit in your mouth. It's delicious and will be more than enough to make you bloated, but you'll have to eat it with a fork and knife.

My fiance had the Kimchi goat burger which she loved. I didn't taste it myself since I was busy with the Almighty Goat burger but she said it was very good.

The other 2 at our table had the fish tostadas and Manicotti. Both were good. The fish tostadas was more food than expected. I did have a small taste of the fish and it was quite good.

Overall, it's not as good as Girl and the Goat but that's to be expected and it's a good casual diner place that gives generous portions of good food at a reasonable price.
One of my favorites for su day brunch. Make sure to make a reservation or you will wait a long time. I recommend getting an additional table pancake to share with your fellow diners.

I have been here several times & have never been let down. This weekend I took an out of town friend there for brunch. The wait was reasonable & the hostesses did a great job managing all the guests. Once seated, our server came right away & thoroughly explained the menu and specials. Our food came out quickly & was beyond expectation! I not only give this restaurant my highest recommendation, but I'm already planning my next visit.

Omg this place was so delicious!! One of many stops on our day adventure, we decided to break for lunch and stop in. All of us got a variety of dishes but I got the shrimp salad that had apples, red peppers, blueberries, tortilla bits and so much flavor. Every bite had a great combination of citrus flavor, shrimp and crunch. The salad mix of arugula and spinach provided a nice bitter counter balance and nothing was wilted or spoiled.

The service was delightful with our server offering wine suggestions and joking with our party. Each of my friends dishes were just as flavorful and some had a more savory twist. If you want to eat great food and enjoy all the little goat decals then this is your place. The wide windows will give you lots of Vitamin D. You can't go wrong!

I have long been a bit skeptical of the Stephanie Izzard empire as I find Girl & the Goat very salty and overhyped, so I was surprised at how much I truly liked Little Goat Diner. I came here for a work lunch with a client. He ordered the chicken and waffles which as heavy on the egg and seemed to like it. I ordered the fatty club, which was just so delicious. It was one of the better clubs I have had in my life. I bill myself as a club sandwich aficionado as I have spent quite a lot of time overseas. And while I am a very open minded eater, I sometimes just crave a club sandwich. Little Goat did not let me down.

I would recommend a reservation as it was really busy for lunch. Service was good and they kept filling up my water glass, which is how I judge an establishment.

Delicious. We had been recommended to come here by some friends who visited Chicago last week. It did not disappoint.

I ordered the Mac and cheese per a recommendation and it was delicious. I'm always disappointed when ordered Mac and cheese at restaurants, buy this was by far the best I've had. Not too cheesy, but rich enough to satisfy. My mom had the goat o goat o salad. It was also really good. I had some of that as well. Really good flavor overall. Just Asian enough for my liking.

We were pretty full but had the French Silk pie for dessert. Scrumptious. It was bigger than expected, so definitely shareable. My mom isn't the biggest chocolate fan, but she loved it.

Little Goat is a fun dining option that we often taking visiting friends and family to. Make a reservation online, though know that you might still have to wait for a table after you show up on a weekend for brunch (last time we were there we didn't get seated until 20 minutes after we arrived... and this was even after showing up on time for our reservation). Also, it gets loud in the restaurant during peak times. These two cons aside, I have been here for lunch and dinner numerous times. I am a gluten free diner and have dined here with individuals with other dietary restrictions including dairy and garlic allergies, and the waitstaff does a great job of checking and modifying dishes to make sure they are appropriate for our group. Last time I was there, I got the omelette, which was heavenly! The cheese was melted so perfectly on the inside.  My husband is a big eater and has been disappointed in the portion size of some plates in the past, so check with your server if you are exceptionally hungry. Most entrees don't come with sides, so you will need to order sides in addition to the main plates. The sides are usually a sharing size. They also have outdoor seating!

We brunched here over the weekend,  I had "This little piggy went to China" and my boyfriend ordered the Schnitzel Sandwich.  We ordered an additional hash brown and yogurt parfait.  The Schnitzel Sandwich was pretty tasty.  However, the little piggy who went to china likely came home with a tummy-ache.  There were so many overwhelming flavors in this dish! I don't know if it was my delicate palate, but I was left confused between the sesame cheddar biscuit, the egg yolk, the chili garlic sauce on the plate, the mustard aioli on the biscuit and the pork sausage. Sooo many flavors and none of them played nicely together on my tongue.  I took two bites, but couldn't bring myself to finish the monstrosity.  I ate the side of hash browns, which needed salt and left behind a bitter after-taste (perhaps it was the oil?).  I truly enjoyed the Yogurt parfait, it was simple and positively delicious (served with home made granola and fresh berry jam). I also had a latte from the cafe next door and it was simply divine.... so where does this leave us?  I think I would've enjoyed the food had I ordered a simple sandwich or sweet treat like pancakes.  Everything looked positively delicious, so I'm not sure where things went wrong.

The wait staff was very friendly and accommodating.  I really appreciated all that they did to make the meal enjoyable.  It was just a fail for me.
Great brunch food. Got the famous little piggy went to China and little goat latte, both lived up to the expectations

Came here for the first time since they opened and still just as good as I remembered. The menu is VERY extensive and really could suit anyone's palette. It was still very busy and crowded on a Wednesday night, but we had a solid meal. Service was great and the food was awesome. We got the Machos Nachos to start and OMG. Definitely the best dish we got. I ordered the Caesar Salad and it was just okay. Not the most unique dish I've ever ordered from there, but I was in the mood for it. Next time you go in, ask to sample a few of their beers. All of their beers are on tap, so they'll let you try them before you order!

Hash browns - Shredded and so good! Crispy all around and had cheese in it. I've never had better hash browns and I don't think I will ever have better.

Goat chili - I hate beans so obviously I am biased when I say I wasn't impressed, but my boyfriend loves chili and he still wasn't impressed. I think it was a little too sour. It was topped with lettuce (maybe) and sour cream. The one good thing I have to say about it is that there was a lot of meat in it.

Bloody Mary - Ketel one vodka and some type of kimchi infused whatever. This was good, but I've had better. The kimchi made this a little more sour than I would have liked and it was not spicy at all.

In a Pickle - this was a tequila cocktail. My bf said it just tasted like tequila with a lot of lime.

Bulls eye French toast - I hate to be the only one to dog on this, but I did not enjoy this as much as I thought I would. The French toast was soaked in the BBQ maple syrup so it was soggy and the only soggy thing I like is French fries from McDonald's. The chicken was fried nicely and the egg in the brioche was cooked perfectly.

Bi bim bop - cauliflower rice, fancy bacon (what the waitress called it), a fried egg, asome other stuff. I thought this was way too sour. There were bean sprouts, pickled purple cabbage, and mushrooms in it as well. I also didn't think there was enough bacon in it to say it had bacon in it on the menu.

My first two choices were sold out, so... maybe I would have been more impressed with Little Goat if I had gotten that. Such a shame because I absolutely love Girl and the Goat.

pics.caption: Hash browns are the best I've ever had.

review.des:
I've been to this place only a few times (about 3). I've made reservations each time. I was seated 30 minutes after my reservation each time.

Very poorly organized staff that work at this restaurant. They buy you an appetizer after each time they seat you 30 minutes late.

I'll never make a reservation here ever again when I have friends visiting town.

My expectations were probably too high, but I wasn't overly thrilled with the food here. Came here for bunch and were told the wait was 20 minutes, but they called us after a few minutes and we were seated at the community table in the dining area.

I ordered the 'This Little Piggy Went to China" which had a sesame cheddar biscuit with sunny side up eggs, szechuan pork sausage, chili garlic chive sauce and blackberries. The "szechuan" should've given it away for me. The flavor is very similar to spicy wontons. Also had the tempura mashed potatoes, which was interesting and not bad.

My cousin had the loco moco and said that it was kinda dry and that there should've been more gravy on it.

Went to The Little Goat for a spontaneous date night with my wife and was very surprised by the experience! The atmosphere is very casual with a modern dinner style feel.  The music was not so load that is hindered conversation.  The food was delicious!  We had the paratha burrito, macho nachos (without meat) and the tempura mashed potatoes. The tempura potatoes is a mush try! The nachos are a meal of its own; don't be fooled by the fact that it is listed as an accompaniment.  The parathas came with a delicious sauce, eggs, fresh greens and red kidney beans. We did not try their famous burgers however we will return to try the burgers and mushroom pasta.  Finally, the meal was very reasonably priced so if you are looking for delicious food at a reasonable price than look no further!

Very nice meal. Atmosphere was great for a group, but not as appealing for a couple.

The blend of flavors will surprise you, but don't be scared to try something different...it will not disappoint!!!

A family friendly spot, great for breakfast and lunch. We had a variety of things off the menu and everything was awesome. Only downsides are the long wait times and higher prices for certain items like the $6 bacon which was thin and chewy and just not that good.

Awesome. Just awesome. Not a huge wait; possible to get in without a reservation, unlike all the other "goat-branded" places. Creative, homey food. Good service. Can come here for a casual work breakfast with colleagues or take family out.

The food here has always been very delicious. And, you don't have to wait! Service is always very nice and friendly. I also recommend trying the dessert. The desserts here are some of the best you can get in Chicago.

We have walked by this place a few times, finally just stopping in because I was tired of flipping through Yelp photos. No reservation, but they take your name and text you when you're up. Great. The few benches outside made the 25 minute wait not too bad. The staff was amazing and we selected 3 different plates to share, the omelette of the day,  the bull's eye french toaat

Had breakfast here the other day. Absolutely loved the vibe, sat at a cozy little two top against the wall. Ordered nachos... yes, breakfast was at 11:30. Always on the hunt for some really worth it nachos and these were fantastic! My friend ordered the hash browns which had the perfect, little amount of cheese and this little pig went to China. I had some of all and it was deliciousness! He had to stop me from ordering a bann mi burger as well because my eyes were waaayyy bigger than my stomach. Coffee was excellent, service was excellent. Cannot wait to return... and to visit the Girl and the goat as well!

The Little Goat Diner is a good place to go to if you are really craving breakfast for dinner. They do have other options. You could get a burgers, steak, nachos, etc. But if I were you! Have the breakfast

My friend Courtney brought me here because of their vegan menu that she loves. I am the opposite and this place offers the best of both worlds. The open diner feel was really nice, but there was something about it that made it feel more classy, I couldn't put my finger on it. The staff was attentive and they all had their own unique sense of style. I ordered the Goat burger which is goat burger, braised beef, bbq pork, pickled jalapenos, salsa verde, onion rings and cheddar. OMG. It was so much food, but it was so good, it just didn't need the tostada added to it. I didn't care if it was supposed to soak up all the juices from everything above, the burger was already the messiest thing ever. Lol. I would totally order it again. I also split an order of smoked fries with my friend. I left there stuffed. I'd totally come back here to try the rest of their menu!
We absolutely love this place. Came here for breakfast on my birthday. We had the spanish omelette & biscuits and gravy. The food is amazing, ambiance is great!

While visiting Chicago, we decided to take the advice from family to try out the place. We arrived for brunch and was told it would be a 30-45 minutes wait for my boyfriend and I. We were okay waiting. We waited over an hour and during this time we kept seeing plenty of people who arrived after us get seated. When we finally spoke to the hostess, she asked if we were okay getting sat at the bar. At this point we were tired of waiting and just hungry so we agreed. Once we were sat in the corner, we waited an additional 30 minutes before we were even acknowledged or even given water by any of the staff. I was ready to walk away but my boyfriend insisted on waiting. Once we finally had our order in, our food arrived in about 10 minutes. We sat there watching all the food runners who were obviously doing an amazing job. I was just extremely disappointed and displeased with the staff and service. The menu items were also so random.  Masa chips, Paratha burrito? It was not worth the wait or our time.

The Girl and the Goat has been on my list of restaurants to check out ever since I started my current job a few years ago, which allows me to be in Chicago at least once a month. A combination of the timing of my trips and no reservations available has been the major roadblock in me not dining at the Girl and the Goat yet. Fast forward to a few years later, and I managed to stumble upon Stephanie Izard's Little Goat Diner.

I went on a Saturday for a late brunch, and did not have to wait for a table. I managed to grab a seat by the counter by the expo station facing the kitchen and I knew I would be in for a treat. I studied the menu on my commute into the city and knew I would be ordering the Shrimp and Cheesy Grits. The server mentioned it was a "good choice" and very "American," to which I responded that I'm actually from Canada, which we both shared a little chuckle at.

The brunch crowd was slowly dying down (it was 3PM, after all) so it didn't take long for my food to come. In front of me was a beautiful plate of cheesy grits in a pool of garlic butter sauce, topped with at least a dozen shrimp, and some brussels sprouts and pistachio. I have had shrimp and grits in New Orleans, and dare I say it, but this was much better than the one I had in the South! The was just enough grits, as opposed to an entire plate full of grits and the sauce was so buttery, that I wish I had a biscuit to soak up all that excess sauce with.

Overall, a satisfying and filling meal. If this is the quality of the food that is served here, I look forward to trying other items on the menu!

pics.caption: Shrimp and Cheesy Grits ($16): rock shrimp, braided pistachio, grumpy goat grits

review.des:
Unique and delicious
I highly recommend the okonomiyaki for brunch!
Make a reservation ahead of time- this is a happening place!

Little Goat Diner is one of those places you pass and you think, "must be good to have that many people waiting in line." You know what?  It's true.  It's really good.  It wasn't the best meal of my life, but their menu is creative and yet still approachable for people who aren't super adventurous (read: me).  We (party of two) visited around 12:30 pm on a Sunday afternoon.  After being told it would be an hour AND forty-five minutes to be seated (first available, not outside), we set off to discover new parts of West Loop.  Somehow, only twenty minutes went by before I received a text letting me know our two spots at the counter were available.

Side note: I really like that restaurants text me instead of giving me one of those weird buzzers that only work so far away.  If you're gonna make me wait, let me choose where I go.  Right?  So, +1 for that and +1 for letting me reply that we're on our way back (so I know they don't give our seats away).  Woo, technology!

After pouring over the menu, I finally settled upon Bull's Eye French Toast.  Admittedly, I'm new to the whole non-scrambled egg life.  I'm dipping my toe into the gooey pool.  So far, so good.  So, out comes my almost inch thick onion brioche bread with a soft, gooey egg baked in the middle of each slice.  Note: the bread isn't super high on the onion flavor, think of it more like well-seasoned.  The fried chicken on top was fantastic and just the right amount.  The strawberries were an unexpected addition, but I liked them on there to balance out the savory items.  The syrup (BBQ maple) wasn't overpowering or even really like BBQ at all.  It all just worked very well together.

I thought I was hungry, but I was beyond stuffed with just my meal.  Wowza!  My fella ordered this interesting Asian dish that had crunchies and some spicy mayo drizzled over it.  Naturally, I can't find it on the online menu today.  He liked it, and the side of bacon from nearby Publican Quality Meats.  The mimosas were a bit small for the $10 price tag, but I think it comes with the territory.  

The service was good, especially considering how loud and crazy busy they were.  Pretty fascinating to see a kitchen work and flow from the seats at the counter.  

Suggestions from what I saw: the Fat Elvis looked awesome if you're sharing with two other people.  The cinnamon rolls were ooey, gooey and looked amazing.  The shakes came in the old school diner glasses and one was even dairy free!  Next time I visit I'll have to try a burger and order a shake!  The side of fries are HUGE, so be sure to order with the intention of sharing.  

Overall: two thumbs up for a fun atmosphere and a creative menu.

Is there anything better than waffles (check), bananas (check), peanut butter (check), and bacon maple syrup (check)? No, there isn't. Especially when its a Sunday morning after a long Saturday night.

The rest of the menu is just as interesting. A top choice for any casual weekend breakfast.

I took my brother here for lunch and it was excellent. I got the patty melt, but I have to say I enjoyed the fries a lot more (hence the four stars). I would love to try it again and it's great for a casual lunch or dinner with friends or family.

Little goat is not your normal diner.  With breakfast eats like; breakfast spaghetti and clams. Kimchee-bacon-eggs and pancakes asian style, little piggy went to china.. The fusions were just odd but the curiosity of flavors will temp you.

I had the okinomayaki with pork, I asked for light mayo on top since they wouldnt put it on the side.  My husband had the all american hamburger.  Nothing was speaking to him. I also ordered, fries, onion rings/fried pickles.  I liked my dish a lot, yes taste just like any other okinomayaki but the way they cooked this thing was outstanding. I love the way the edges and underside were crispy.  Had sliced pork and benito shavings on top. The sauce too was not overpowering.  I really suggest to request for light sauce. My husbands hamburger was as he said 'just a burger', he also said it was soggy.

Now the fried stuff, onion rings and pickles were really oily.  You can taste it at first bite. The fries were salty and cold. We also ordered a dessert, a cake that had caramel, peanut butter, butter cream and... I dont recall what it was called but if the cake itself was not so dry, I think it would of been awesome. But each bite we needed to put a dollop of icing or whipped cream to help with the dryness.   The service was good, very attentive.  Overall if Im in Chicago fairly soon, I would give it another try.  They could of just been off that night.

pics.caption: Okinomiyaki with pork. Soo good! I asked them to go easy on the mayo.

review.des: You absolutely cannot go wrong here. I have been for breakfast, lunch, and dinner, and it's a go-to spot for a good meal! It's also a great spot to bring out-of-town guests: something that seems a little funky but isn't crazy expensive.

This place was awesome! The wait was like an hour and half on a Sunday morning but it was well worth it.
I got the okonomiyaki, which is basically a savory pancake with pork belly, a poached egg and other sauces (make sure to ask your waitress). First bite? Heaven. About half way through though, I started losing steam as it was so rich. It was a good taste of a new dish though.
For the table, we split goat chili cheese fries which were mind blowing. We also got the pork belly homefries, which were a little less impressive. I wasn't expecting the meat pieces to be in chunks.
I also got a mimosa but found it to be overpriced for the size. My friend's Bloody Mary, however, was delicious.
As there were a lot of amazing options, I definitely want to come back.
Good and flavorful eats.  Great wait staff. Very busy and extremely loud. It's hard to have a conversation. It's a good place for quality, casual food.

Little Goat confused me.  I don't know if they were so overrated, that I gave them 2 stars, or is this really a 2 star establishment?  I visited the restaurant Memorial Day weekend with a 30 minute wait.  Not too shabby.  We walked around "Restaurant Row" until we received the anticipated text message.  We made our way back to the restaurant and were seated.

We started off with a barista lemonade tea (which was on the "specials" menu) as well as a cappuccino.  The tea tasted like crystal light mixed with robitussin and the cappicinno was so cold, I confused it with a frapp.  So far, no good.

Next, our goat chili cheese fries came to the table.  The goat chili was flabbergasting!  It was hearty, meaty, but not too heavy--it reminded me of coney sauce.  The fries were covered in a blanket of white queso that resembled country gravy.  This was indeed a MISS.  The queso had a corn starchy flavor that was very unsettling.  The taste was tear-jerking and by this time, I started to get annoyed.
