Soon after, the entrees came to the table: This Little Piggy Went to CHINA and the infamous BullsEye French Toast.  This Little Piggy Went To China came with a biscuit, eggs, pork sausage, and a chili garlic chive sauce.  Asian cuisine is my all-time favorite so I imagined that this dish would have the most rockin' party in my mouth.  Yeahhhhhh, right.  The idea was there but, the implementation was a no-go. Wayyyyy too much sesame oil... on EVERYTHING.  That's all you tasted. The BullsEye was good.  It certainly wasn't great.  The French toast was a little dry for my liking, and the crispy chicken was crispy cold.  Left half of it on the plate.  

Service? So-so.  Décor? Nothing striking.  I was ready to knock everything off of the table when we received our damn $60 check. Obviously people like this place--I'm assuming I just went on a bad day.

pics.caption: Goat Chili Cheese Fries. Any way I can order these without the BC powder and water? Oh I mean the white cheese queso?
This Little Piggy Went to China--more like the 2 Cup Sesame Oil Special.

review.des:
Little Goat has been on my list of places to try for a long time now. In my first visit it was good. We probably over-ordered the amount of food.

First the macho nachos looked tempting. One thing I was disappointed about was their beans aren't vegetarian. Miss... The nachos without beans were quite generously topped with all sorts of goodies. Really a huge portion and I think that ruined my appetite. Lastly, I wanted to mention that the chips they use aren't the types I like. They were like the oily thick types.

So the veggie quesadilla was the other thing I had. They were good. Again very rich. The tortilla was done very well and crispy. I seemed like it was smothered in butter. It was really good, but probably not good for ya.  I was stuffed by the time I ate just half of it.

Anyway, then I tasted the Banh Mi style burger with the veggie burger substitute. It was ok. I think the other/"normal" burgers would've been a better choice.

Overall, I loved the menu and options they had.

The breakfast options on the menu were also awesome. Good variety. I think next time I'll keep my appetite more open and try other items as well.

I'm a big burger guy. I'm not saying one place has a supreme burger that is better than them all, but here the patty melt is king.

More than that the bread is made in house you can choose between three different patties (beef, goat, veggie)

There is actually enough cheese to call it a patty melt, the pickles are also made in house and are scrumptious, then to top it off big pieces of caramelized onion tie it together.

Grab a beer and call it a day.

I wasn't able to get a reservation at Girl and a Goat so I decided to try out Chef Stephanie Izard's other restaurant, Little Goat Diner. It definitely did not disappoint.

The first thing the server told me was that everything on the menu was available. That's wonderful news for anyone that loves breakfast items anytime of the day! That person isn't me however, but good to know :) I was torn between the Korean Burger or Shrimp & Pork Belly Noodles based on reviews I read. The server recommended the Korean Burger so that's what I went with. I avoid ordering anything spicy whenever I can but.... it was my first trip (of many I hope) to Chicago and I rarely eat goat meat... so I was sold.

The burger was delicious, a little on the spicy side but I managed. Sometimes it's worth all the sweat and discomfort! I also ordered the sweet corn elotes on the side. At first I was hesitant because of the cayenne butter but figured I was all in at this point with the spice level. No problems there because I almost ate the whole side dish before I even touched my burger.

I managed to save a little room for dessert and was glad I ordered the french silk pie. AMAZING!

I also tried the Moscow Goat since it had grapefruit in it. A nice twist on the Moscow Mule.

So I do love the food here but the service has been repeatedly disappointing. Today is the third week in a row when I have been there after the breakfast rush and need to ask for service. Normally I have to grab someone else who is not my server to refill my drink or get the check. There are always multiple people working. I find that they are busy amongst chatting with other workers. Disappointed with how much I love the food. I do not think it compares to the service I receive at any of Izard's other locations.

COST:
Varies (This review is for Little Goat/Goat Catering Group event they catered)

Ever since I heard of Stephanie Izzard and her genius, I've always wanted to "punch my card" and visit all of the places she owns. I've been to Girl & The Goat twice and while I've enjoyed coffee at Little Goat, I haven't had the chance to physically eat at the diner.

This review is mostly for their catering group, and I'd like to imagine their bombtastic food is also served in some shape or form at the diner. I've provided pics of each one, so you have a template of what to get in house.

Here's a few of the things they served: turkey sliders, chips with different dipping sauces (pictured is pimento), potato salad (the BEST I've had), flatbread and the super amazing tuna tostada type dish!

I personally adored how their goat logo is very well represented in their dish cards and what not. The service is outstanding and you can definitely tell Steph's magic touch in each dish. Now off I go to try Duck Duck Goat at some point and hit the trifecta!

I'd come back to Little Goat as everything which I saw coming out of the kitchen made me second guess my order. Our meal was on the heavy side, which given the very warm day wasn't the best pairing. However, on a cold winter night, this would really hit the spot. Welcoming atmosphere, easy to grab a seat, friendly staff and a diverse crowd dining around us. Food was great, too. My Rueben had wonderfully crispy pastrami and the kimchee was a creative twist. The onion rings were made with pickled onions which really set them apart from any that I'd had before. Best of all was the price. Two drinks, two meals and an appetizer for less than $70.

Food had great potential but was lacking in flavor and substance. I had the kale salad which was decent but pretty dry. My husband had the fish tostadas, which he loved except he said there was only a couple bites that had fish. For the price there should have been more. It was a little frustrating they texted our table was ready and after walking back to the restaurant it still took another 15 min to get seated. Service was good overall.

Truthfully I don't get the hype of this place. The nachos are out of this world but everything else is like ehh. I've never been for brunch only for dinner, so maybe that's what I'm missing. Don't plan on going back anytime soon.
Little Goat Diner has pretty good food. It's one of the better restaurants in the West Loop. They have an interesting and unique menu.

This place was ok. We came here for dinner and found that they are mainly a breakfast place. We got the patty melt which was nothing special, sadly. My sandwich was the fat club and that was tasty, but the mac & cheese was very plain. The staff was really helpful and the food came quickly. Very much a diner, but these little sandwiches were overpriced and came out with no sides. Much better food elsewhere in Chicago.
The is one of my favorite spots! Their food tastes amazing. It's like a Korean twist on American dishes. They book up fast though and the wait can be long

I came here for a late lunch on a Friday and there was no wait. My friend and I shared two dishes.

Fish Tostadas - crisp whitefish, shallot aioli, chickpeas, onion salad and harissa vinaigrette
SO delicious! The tostada and fish were crispy. The chickpeas and salad added great texture and all the flavors were well-balanced. It was a little messy and difficult to eat, but I would definitely order this again.

Pork Belly Pancake - scallion pancake, house hoisin, bok choy salad, ginger maple dressing
There was so much salad on top, I couldn't find the pork belly at first. Definitely a good dish to share. I loved all the Asian flavors.

Cold Brew Coffee  
I was a little sad when I found out they switched roasters from Stumptown to Dark Matter, but I'm glad Little Goat is supporting a local coffee roaster. The coffee was excellent and not bitter at all.

Another solid meal at Little Goat!

pics.caption: FISH TOSTADAS - crisp whitefish, shallot aioli, chickpeas onion salad & harissa vinaigrette
PORK BELLY PANCAKE - scallion pancake, house hoisin, bok choy salad & ginger maple dressing
THIS LITTLE PIGGY WENT TO CHINA - sesame cheddar biscuit, sunny eggs, szechuan pork sausage, chili garlic chive sauce & blackberries

review.des: I came here for Mothers Day with my family. It was 10 of us. I loved the menu!!! So many choice that we couldn't decide. So we ordered a bunch of items and shared. Everything was good in its own right. The best thing was the pork belly pancakes. So good!!! I highly recommend trying this restaurant

pics.caption: Grilled Cheese and Tomato Apple Soup

review.des:
I only like a few things from here: ooey gooey cinnabun, parathas burrito, and the shrimp sandwich. Things that I've tried and that I don't care for: little piggy went to china, breakfast tasty thing, biscuits and gravy, los drowned, fish tostadas, tempura mashed potatoes, springy shrimp & pork belly.

I come here pretty much only for an early morning breakfast or to pick up a cinnabun. I've given up on their lunch and dinner.

Little Goat is a crowd pleaser. We always take all of our out of town guests here as there is something for everyone since they take typical diner food and put a culinary twist on it. You usually have to wait for a table but they typically get you in pretty quick and you can enjoy a cocktail while you wait.

The Reuben and the veggie quesadilla are two of my favorite dishes. My husband would be upset if I didn't mention the patty melt, as this is his go to. I have to admit, it is so juicy and flavorful. Portion size is big and I often leave feeling overly full. We have yet to order the goat burger, which is monstrous,  but I plan to someday try and tackle it in a shared venture with someone else.

Service has always been on par here. Very friendly and attentive wait staff. Also love the old diner style booths and atmosphere.

If you want classic diner fare in a room that screams edgy cool, then Little Goat Diner is the biz.
Waffles, fried chicken, the juiciest burger, and comfort mug of coffee. Love this place.

I've visited twice now.

My first experience: amazing waiter, horrible food. I had the fish and chips(which they removed) and goat chili fries. Both were not so delicious. The waiter did offer to remove the fries from my bill, which I found thoughtful and later tipped him as much.

My second experience: good food, poor service. I had the grand burger(at least a foot tall) and the soup of the day, broccoli cheddar. The burger was awesome and the soup was tasty. Service forgot to bring the lemons I had asked for (twice), but otherwise my meal was pretty satisfactory. I had my unfinished meal(the burger was huge!) packed to-go, but my server instead dumped the contents. This happened near closing time, so take this with a grain of salt.

Overall,
Price: overpriced
Food: depends on the item. The menu isn't very flexible
Service: depends on the server
Thoughts: Probably my last time coming here..

pics.caption: Soup of the Day: broccoli cheddar!

review.des:
Great spot, especially for brunch. The cinnabun, shrimp and cheesy grits, and parathas burrito are all great.

Also wonderful to stop by the cafe and pick something up quickly if you don't have time to sit and eat.

Highly recommend!

So many options and they are all amazing! Izzard knocks it out of the park again. Crab dip, pork belly potatoes, fat Elvis waffles and more. To add to it, the coffee is spectacular. Great brunch with friends!

4.5 stars
First stop in Chicago! We had a late Friday bunch reservation with the place still buzzing full of happy customers. Our waitress, Joan, reminded me so much of Anna Kendrick; her smile lit up her whole face. She mentioned people have told her she resembles Julianne Moore. She stopped by our table at the right times asking if we needed anything else and made sure our glasses were full.

Big portions! Prices aren't bad either. Tempura mashed potatoes! By golly this was my favorite thing to eat here and it's a side dish! Crunchy fried exterior and those clumpy potatoes resembling a mashed banana texture ... accompanied by an Asian slaw underneath. Two long slabs of sweet fat Elvis waffles, nice and crisp except for the parts smothered in maple syrup, crumbled bacon pieces, whipped peanut butter made the dish! Nothing can beat fresh banana slices on waffles. Only $13. I tried a bite of the Went to China: biscuit topped with chorizo, a fried egg, and blackberry sauce-- the flavor mix was spot on. Omelette of the day was Spring Thing with lots of spinach, crisp French onions on top. Didn't get to try any but my friend left the plate clean.

So many restaurants with "goat" in their names in this area! I'd definitely recommend this place to newcomers. Staff is friendly, portions are bigger than expected, and it's a good way to become immersed in Chicago culture by people watching.

If I return one day, I'll get their notable bullseye French toast with strawberries & fried chicken pieces. Tempura mashed potatoes, I'll be back.

honestly have been wanting to go to this diner for months and was happily surprised to be taken here, and definitely not disappointed!! this is top ten sexiest meals by far, rich and engulfment french toast with strawberries and fried chicken, can't beat savory and sweet!!!!!!!!!! love it

Visited Little Goat because I heard of their dairy free options but I must say I wasn't too impressed.

Atmosphere- Solid, diner style/cozy. Good for groups as they have a few booths. It's also located in a great area (tons of spots, nice walk).
Service- I wasn't too impressed with the service. When the waitress first came to take our order I told her I couldn't have dairy and asked for suggestions, she said she'd come back to me. She came back a second time and I learned the dish I was looking at had dairy. She came back a third time with the dairy free menu- which I could have received the first time I mentioned I couldn't consume dairy (at the time I was not aware of the second menu). My friends all waited for me to get my food because it took so long for me to get my order in.
Food- I ended up going for the jerk chicken sandwich, which was decent. I don't think it merits a return on my part.

I've been here a number of times, whether it be just for drinks, brunch on a Sunday. Etc. This place is in the perfect area of West Loop. Very up and coming area, that has some of the best restaurants. Thoroughly enjoy the food. Especially prosciutto breakfast pizza mmmm!!! I think the only thing is they were slightly overpriced on the bottle service for mimosas. Whereas you can find bottomless options at many places similar to them around the city. That won't stop me from coming back here. Just a thought though.

Visiting Chicago, I knew we had to eat at one of the Goat restaurants. With a reservation, we chose to dine at Little Goat for breakfast. Given that it was a weekday, a reservation wasn't necessary; the restaurant was still 3/4 packed, speaking to its popularity. I'm sure part of it is due to its atmosphere. From walking to the Little Goat, you notice a huge goat spinning on top of the building. Then when you get inside, it reminds you of a cute diner from a movie scene.

I started with The Little Goat, which is a special latte made with goat milk. I've never had goat milk before, but chose to be adventurous due to the astonishing reviews that this drink had gotten on Yelp. Sadly, I can say I'm not a fan as it tasted like drinking straight up feta cheese - if you're a feta cheese fan, go for it! My friend had the latte, which was good, but nothing differentiating it from your standard latte.

For our entrees, we split the famous Bull's Eye French Toast and the smoked corned beef hash with eggs. The Bull's Eye French Toast was so good and our favorite as it had the perfect balance of savory and sweet. The sweet came from the syrup and the bread, while the savory came from crunchy pieces of fried chicken. I know, you're thinking "French toast with fried chicken? For breakfast? How does that work?" Just order it and you'll see! AND hidden inside the middle of each French toast is a perfectly poached egg! I was so excited when I cut into the middle and saw the yolk oozing out. Yum! The highlight of the smoked corned beef hash was the corned beef. The proportion of corned beef to hash browns was 1:1 and you get slices of corned beef, not speckles of it. Talk about a hearty breakfast! My only compliant is that the dish was a bit oily on the bottom and had a bit too much raw onions.

The portions at Little Goat are huge, so you can definitely order one entree and a side if you're not that hungry. Nonetheless, it definitely earned its celebrity rights and popularity.

pics.caption: Corn beef hash with sunny side eggs

review.des: They run out of chicken pot pies quickly, which I was disappointed about - really wanted to try. We could a variety of breakfast dishes and burgers. They were all okay, not that great. I wouldn't come back, a bit disappointed.
Love love love. Ambiance was great, clean and cute. Food was amazing! Great place to enjoy a good meal with friends!
Delicious, upscale diner food. Don't let diner fool you. This place is amazing. Everything on the menu is 10/10!

I really love this place! From the moment you walk in, you are charmed by the decorations. It's a dope new/old school diner adorned with an adorable goat. I'm a fan of Stephanie Izard's, so expectations were high for me. Stephanie delivered!

I ordered "this little piggy went to China," it was literally one of the best things I've ever eaten. I love to eat, and often explore interesting foods, but nothing has ever had the flavor profile that this meal had. The texture of the cheddar biscuit is perfect. It's crispy on the exterior, and soft and flavorful on the inside. The sausage is great too. It's tasty and a little sweet. The eggs were perfectly cooked, and the vinegar sauce that's swimming around the bowl is so dope. Oh! And the blackberries are a nice touch...not only are they a pretty garnish, but they're delicious and add a little bit of a tangy twist to the dish.

My hubby ordered the French toast with fried chicken. I tasted it and thought it was really good as well, but everyone at the table agreed my dish was the best, so try "this little piggy went to China." You will not regret this. It's amazing!

pics.caption: This Little Piggy went to China is one of the dopest meals I've ever had. Tons of really interesting flavors...

review.des:
Brilliant choice for out of town foodies with a child in tow. Not every dish was perfect, but for atmosphere, ambition, and execution this was a very special restaurant.

Dishes that were least successful:
--Hashbrowns: I am a hashbrowns lover and these were greasy and not worth eating

--elotes: The person who ordered them liked but I found them bland and interesting

--limeade: I'm a cocktail aficionado searching for new flavor profiles, and this was kind of boring. Tasted just like every non-alcoholic lime ade I have ever had and wasn't that strong. Disappointing.

medium:
--veggie quesadilla: I have mixed feelings about this dish because the texture was perfect. The tortillas were very good and they were griddled crisp. The chive sauce was also very nice. But the quesadilla had a strange nachoesque cheese inside. For people who don't actually like Mexican food this might be OK, but coming from San Diego this was weird and icky, and made me stop eating the quesadilla.

Highlights:
--sourdough pancakes: fluffy, delicious and perfect
--kids hamburger: my child ate this up very fast, though I didn't think that the fries were anything special
--watermelon gazpacho: fresh and nice
--chickpea salad: Justly  celebrated. And the chickpea fritters in it were fresh and interesting, not falafels but more like chickpea hush puppies

--desserts were really spectacular. We got the cherry pie which was the pie of the day, and though the cherry filling was quite sweet, the crust was out of this world. I was very impressed. Then we got the French silk pie, which was phenomenal. Delicious chocolate, fantastic crust, and nice mixture of textures with some crunchy chocolate crumble.

Overall, we were very impressed with this place and would absolutely recommend it to foodie families and to out-of-towners wanting to try something delicious in Chicago

One of my favorite restaurants in Chicago! I also love their sister restaurant across the street Girl and the Goat. Service was great and they even have a bakery connected to it. I had the fish tostadas - I loved the pickled vegetables on it. I wish I would have ordered a shake. They looked fabulous!

Made reservations and got there on time. I saw some people who got seated before we did and arrived after us when they didn't have reservations so that was not so cool. Any way after about fifteen minutes we got seated and our server greeted us and offer us drinks while we decided on the food. The food was good and dessert was awesome. The place it self looks nice. Might come back

Great brunch spot with tons of options. Be ready for a long wait over the weekend if you plan on going here for brunch. I know they have great burgers and sandwiches, I've only been here for brunch and always left satisfied.

I have literally never had a bad meal here. Want breakfast? You got it. Craving a burger? They've got you covered. Hankering for dessert? No problem! This place has got something for everybody. I can't recommend this place enough!

Amazing, affordable brunch spot in Chicago and definitely worth a visit. Little Goat is a diner by the same chefs as Girl and the Goat.

My boyfriend and I walked here after hearing the wait at Au Cheval was an hour plus long and were so glad we walked into Little Goat with no wait.

FOOD:
- Korean Burger ($14), 5/5 stars.
- Tempura Mashed Potatoes ($6), 5/5 stars. Sounds weird, but worth a try.
- Bull's Eye French Toast ($16) per the recommendation of Yelp, 4/5 stars. I got tired of it after just a few bites. Didn't like the strawberries on it.

Great portions for the price. Excited to try Girl and the Goat now.

One of my goto brunch places and came for dinner for the first time.

I'll have to write two different reviews for this one.

Brunch experience:
Amazing. I've had fat Elvis waffles, French toast, shrimp and grits, and other menus items I can't remember of and they were all delicious. The classic American dining atmosphere goes well with the food.

Dinner experience:
Eh. Limited dinner menu availability, ran out of lot of things. Not the best. It was the only place without 1+hour wait in west loop and it shows.

To make it a fair review, this place is a diner. So you should set a different expectation for dinner.

My rating is based on the brunch experience. You gotta check it out.

Been coming here for quite some time now, but I wanted to write a review on the exceptional service I received today! Came here for brunch and sat outside in the beautiful weather. We were seated immediately by such a kind hostess. Our waitress was very upbeat and nice and was on top of everything. The food was delicious as per usual. At the end of our meal, my sister scraped away at a part of her burrito. Nestled in it was a huge moth. We figured it fell from the trees above and scraped it out of her food. Immediately the bus boy tending to the tables outside noticed everything and came over to ask if everything was okay with her food. He quickly apologized and took the plate with the bug away. The manager also came out and apologized and offered to remake the burrito, on them. We told him we understood we were sitting outside so it was no worries. He offered to give my sister another iced coffee on the house. Right before we left, he gave us a cookie for my niece and nephew as well. The service is exceptional! We weren't going to say anything, but it was so nice to have them swoop into action and take responsibility even though the bug probably fell in from the trees. The entire team here works well together, and every employee knows how to go above and beyond for the customer! Give that bus boy a raise; he was on top of every single detail the entirety of our time here.
Will, of course, be back soon!

Stopped by for brunch with another couple. We were really happy with the menu options. The kitchen was very accommodating of my wife's dietary restrictions. The cocktails were well balanced and the beer selections was impressive. We sat outside and the service was fast. Would definitely go back.

I am biased because I "heart" Top Chef! This place is fantastic, the Mac n'cheese is delicious. My sister strangely ordered the baked beans, but again awesome! The Tonkatsu, a breaded pork cutlet on white bread (hmm) with Asian BBQ, mayo and cabbage slaw. For me, if something is breaded it doesn't need bread, the cabbage was, I really liked whatever it was marinated in and wish I had had more of that and less mayo/white bread. As for dessert, I tried the smoked pork and toffee milkshake. It was good, I didn't get much pork beyond a salty aftertaste but I like a toffee milk milkshake anytime.

The sides were delicious but the sandwich, well I'm sure there are more interesting things to try on the menu.

Overall- great atmosphere, wonderful staff, food is hit-or-miss depending on what you order.
I've been back several times. Nearly tried everything. My experience only gets better. Bring yourself. Bring your friends. Bring everyone. The menu has something for all and it will not disappoint.

If you want a fun and unique experience in Chicago, have an affinity for breakfast food, and don't have the energy to try to get into Girl & the Goat, this is the place to go to.

This is the kind of place you go to with a group of 10 adventurous friends and order the most "off-beat" things on the menu. I went with 1 gluten free, vegetarian cousin. But, we still ordered three ginormous dishes and gorged ourselves.

Pork Belly Pancake: OMG YUM. I love scallion pancakes. And, I love pork belly. So heavy, but just so delicious. This is the kind of dish you come to Little Goat for.

Dark Chocolate Chip Crunch Pancakes: My cousin got these Gluten Free (which is not listed as an option on the menu, but they can do it, so make sure you ask!), and they were so chocolately, and so satisfying. She said they were the best Gluten Free pancakes she had ever had.

Machos Nachos: GIANT place of nachos. So, so, so, so good.

Do not recommend: Goat Milk Cappuccino. I thought, let's be adventurous. I've had goat's milk before and absolutely hated it. Not sure why I thought this was a good idea. But, just don't do it. Trust me.

I definitely look forward to coming back here again and trying more things!
This place is amazing!!! We ordered this little piggy went to China and the Spanish omelet and grits. So good! Definitely make reservations or it will be a long wait.

Out of this world fried chicken....need I say more? When you're looking something more casual on Randolph, this a great place to enjoy a laid-back meal. With only two weeks of summer before my teaching schedules starts full-swing, my friend and I came down to the West Loop with no particular destination in mind. Parking is definitely more successful toward Madison and we lucked out. Our stroll around the neighborhood brought us to deciding between De Cero and The Little Goat Diner. After skimming the menu and spotting the reuben sandwich, we didn't even think twice. My friend ordered the Reuben, a grapefruit mimosa, and smoked fries, while I ordered a cider and the fried chicken. Wowza. The Reuben was scrumptious with the perfect balance of oozing cheese, toasted rye, and kimchi in place of sauerkraut (close cousin with a little more hear) to cut through the richness of the sandwich. My fried chicken included a breast, drumstick, and wing. I have no idea how long they let the chicken sit in what I'm guessing buttermilk with tabasco, but this chicken was fall off the bone, moist with this amazing crunch on the outside. The only thing left was bones. It did come with a slaw on the side, that I didn't care too much for (the flavor was on the blander side) but it had these delicious fried onions on top, which I picked off. I will be back for my fried chicken fix!

Nice place in the neighborhood. I usually come here to grab the oatmeal and a latte to go. The oatmeal definitely stands out as a little different to try (pricey but good). Make sure to ask if they have any oatmeal left (if you get there anytime after 9am) as they tend to run out quick.

I also tried their turkey sandwitch to go. Also an interesting concept with tomatoes, jam, and blueberries. Again, something fun to try, but necessarily something I would order on a regular basis.
Amazing. Had the French toast and struggled to finish half it was so large - absolutely delicious!! Highly recommend.

Combining diner classics with top chef flair, this diner is one of my favorite places to go for breakfast or dinner! The French toast and fried chicken is amazing, and don't miss the goat chili burger which you should share with someone you love. Go, but make a reservation if you want a seat on the weekend.
Loved breakfast so much that we came back for lunch.  Worth the wait but recommend that you have a reservation.

Came here for an early weeknight dinner and didn't have to wait long for a table of two.  I ordered the pork torta which was juicy and had a nice citrus kick.  It also was gigantic, could've served two.  My friend had the pot pie which was delicious and homey.  We were both too full for dessert.  I was recently informed they have little tartlets/pies at the in house bakery which I will definitely try next time!

I did not know what to expect as we went in here just for hunger and was I blown out of my mind! I didn't realize they were affiliated with Girt and The Goat and the "diner" twist was good. The entrees and deserts were delicious, I will be back!!! I suggest make a reservation to get in there as they do get packed, the food explains why ;)

I'm honestly EMBARRASSED at how often I've been to Little Goat. This is my go-to spot to bring friends and family who are visiting from out of town and my favorite restaurant in Chicago as a college student looking for a decent meal with a reasonable price attached to it. I've even skipped a morning lecture to meet a friend here for brunch once. I have a Little Goat Photobooth strip on my wall. Once, when I was drunk, I made a 9pm reservation for a table of one on my birthday. Months before my actual birthday.

Food: In my trips here I've tried "This Little Piggy Went to China," the Bi Bim Bop Breakfast Bowl, the Shrimp Salad (from their summer menu I believe), the Chickpea Salad, the Bahn Mi style burger, their nachos, their broccoli, their Reuben, the "Goat Almighty," and their Smoked Pork & Toffee Crunch Shake. I particularly love their broccoli and Chickpea salad. I've never been disappointed with the flavors and quality of food, with my only complaint being that the salads and the breakfast bowls have, on occasion, been overdressed/overseasoned. Stephanie Izard is a genius at integrating and balancing flavors; you seriously can't go wrong with anything on the menu.

Service/Atmosphere: The Little Goat decor takes quintessential American diner items and decor and gives them a serious upgrade. While still casual, the place is clean, modern, and full of natural lighting during the day. During the summer they also have outdoor seating. The service here is consistently top-notch: fast, attentive, and very friendly. As a bonus, they also have a gluten-free menu and do their best to accommodate food allergies or restrictions.

The only difficulty is that if you plan on going during the weekend for brunch or dinner, you will almost definitely need a reservation. Luckily, that process is an easy one if you can afford to schedule advance. Otherwise, weekday meals are pretty doable.

Definitely make a trip to Little Goat, you won't be disappointed. I'll probably see you there.

The Little Goat Diner isn't your typical diner with regular burgers and fries, and milkshakes! We got goat burgers, lamb ribs, and a very yummy and creamy crab dip with ritz crackers.

The ambiance was awesome. It was a bit dim with glass ceiling which made it intimate it enough, yet it was loud as a typical diner lol. So, I enjoyed the "QT" with the boyfriend here.

He liked his goat burger, however, said that there was nothing special about it and the burger was a bit salty. I had the lamb ribs and it was good. It fell right off the bone as I was hoping for. I am not too big on lamb (they didn't have the duck I wanted anymore!), but the vegetables and strawberries served with this dish married the flavors altogether very well.

Service was great and it ran so smooth! Our waitress was very sweet and hip. She knew the menu very well and helped us make our decisions on food.

Although tempted, we did not try the dessert of the day, "Cheez It," but everything on their menu looks and sounded great! The next time we are in Chicago, we do hope to get a reservation for the actual Girl and the Goat restaurant, but if we cannot, we wouldn't mind dining here again.
I went here for brunch. The bibimbop is fantastic! Especially for people who don't want something too heavy during the warmer months.

Get the everything crumpets! Such a different dish and it was delicious, but I stress the crumpets are amazing! I don't even know if England can get them as good as they tasted right in the west loop area of Chicago! Atmosphere was also pretty fool and the service was good overall.  Definitely a good place to visit!

When I first moved to Chicago this was my go to diner for brunch. I liked the unique dishes and most that I tried were pretty tasty (the Elvis french toast, and Spanish omelet were my favs). But the more I came over time and tried other dishes for lunch/dinner, the more I realized that my go to spot was actually kinda mediocre. I'll be sticking to my fav brunch items if I ever come here again.

Wow.  Just awesome.  Hostess was actually friendly which is a rarity on Randolph

Server was super upbeat.  He seemed to really enjoy himself.  We had the crab dip. The goat chili.  The beef cheek stroganoff and the sloppy goat.

Everything was awesome including the homemade cake and ice cream at the end

Thank you little goat.  Awesome time

This place is to die for!! Definitely one of my favorite places in the whole city. My boyfriend and I are huge fans of Stephanie Izard and this restaurant is maybe my favorite of her three Chicago restaurants. It can get super busy and a little crowded but it's so worth it. The atmosphere is incredible and the food is even better. I wish I could give it 6 stars.

You get what you pay for. The service is prompt and very very friendly. This small spin off restaurant of Girl and the Goat holds up to its reputation. The portions are more than generous, and for a price that you can't beat in the city. I left there with a great feeling and a happy stomach.

A friend brought me here: a simple out-of-towner from a little city called Los Angeles.

Luckily reservations were made ahead of time for breakfast.

I braved the storm and the windchill to get here and I never looked back.

The french toast with chicken and strawberries was amazing. I hate coffee but I drank their brew black. And I HATE drinking coffee straight black (I'm gonna drop a "No homo" here in case that line sounded "off")

The waiter was nice and the place has a nice welcoming atmosphere.

Of course some of you reading this might not believe someone from Los Angeles since Chicago seems to be the capital of fatty food central..... but honestly..... this place is magical.

If you're from Chicago and HAVEN'T tried this place... then shame on you.

Awesome service on a weekday morning. The staff was super friendly and flexible with our reservation when we were running late. They got our order, food, and checks in a timely but not rushed manner. We were in and out in 30 minutes!

The guy and I ordered the Little Piggy went to China, which was a biscuit with Chinese sausage, egg, and a tangy sauce. Everything about it was delicious. I'll be coming back if I ever end up in Chicago again!

pics.caption: Little piggy went to China. Sooooo delicious!

review.des:
So so yummy! A great brunch place in the West Loop. I recommend getting there on the early side on the weekends, because there is a wait. We got the cinnamon bun, which tasted good but I honestly don't think is worth it. It's not the best cinnamon bun I've ever had.
The bull eyes French toast and the smoked corned beef hash were delicious. So so good!! I think the corned beef hash was my favorite. By far the most flavorful corned beef hash I have ever had. The French toast is really good, the sweet syrup and strawberries taste really great with the crunchy chicken finger. It is not greasy, and very yummy.

pics.caption: Close up of the French toast- delish!
Our brunch! Smoked corned beef hash (front), and bulleye French toast (back)
Cinnamon bun- tasty but not the best ever

review.des: Solid food. A bit overpriced for what it is but that's the neighborhood. It's a good place to experience any of the "goats" in a casual way.

pics.caption: This little This Little Piggy Went To China

review.des:
It's more a 3.5, but I can't quite round it up to 4. Came on a Sunday afternoon, was asked to wait for 45 minutes wait, we wondered off to whole foods couple of blocks away. It's nice to be texted once our table was ready.  

Macho nachos: nice crispy large but soft nachos. Salty, savory, sweet bites. Gigantic plate, pickled onion, sliced jalapeño gives it a balanced flavor. Super delish!

Pork belly scallion pancake: a tadddd but too salty, but workable, you have to eat everything together. The slaw on top was quite refreshing. I recommend it.

Smoked beef and hashed brown: wonderfully flavored hash, goes well with the beef. It was not mind blowing, but a classic.

Kimchi goat burger: the patty is super salty! The bread, egg helps a little. But the kimchi is also really salty! Quite a downer.

pics.caption: Macho nachos, sooooo good. The chips was amazing
Korean burger goat patty. Super salty, the patty and the kimchi was too salty.
Pork belly pancake, yummy, tho just a slight bit salty.

review.des: AMAZING. Come here and you will not be disappointed. Great service / menu  / tastiness. Been here many times, will continue to eat here. Thank you.

Being quite a fan of chef Izard I was disappointed about our meal at Little Goat. Don't get me wrong - the food is not bad by any means, and the dishes brought me a very comfortable feeling. But that's the problem, nothing we tried were great or special or memorable. It's like some good dishes that a good home cook can pull off. If Little Goat was a little place in my neighborhood where I can stop by anytime, sure I would visit it again. But having to wait 1.5 hours to be seated in a very packed restaurant in an area with a lot of other great choices, I don't think I feel the need to come back.

Mind. Blown.
All of their dishes are very unique and it makes it very hard to choose one! I ended up getting a breakfast dish called This Little Piggy Went To China, and holy flavor bomb! So much happening in this and it is absolutely amazing. If you like more bold, adventurous flavors, this is for you. Our waiter, who was also wonderful, recommended this dish, and that is exactly the reason I like to ask staff their personal favorites.
The whole atmosphere of the place has a great vibe with its diner-style bar stools and classy decor. Will definitely be back many times to try more things on the menu.

We gave this place two tries. The first try was by choice, to celebrate a birthday. I had a veggie burger and my fiancé had the Goat All Mighty. My veggie burger was mushy and his meat was dry and disappointing. Both of us agreed we would never order those meals again.
Fast forward a year, we were out last night celebrating a cousins birthday and he chose Little Goat for dinner. I had the veggie quesadilla and my fiancé chose 2 different meals, both of which were already out (a total or five or six items were already out), and he ended up with the short ribs. Well my quesadilla was just ok. I've had better. He enjoyed his short ribs, but today he is vomiting and on the toilet. This guys never ever gets sick. He felt sick shortly after the meal so I know it's from the food. We planned a 3 day wknd to enjoy our time off, and he is now sick and in bed.
This is a disappointment as we are both fans of Girl and the Goat and Duck Duck Goat. I'm shocked at how well this place is rated. My cousin had the All American burger and said it was alright. My other cousin had a sandwich that he said was basically an Italian beef that you can get anywhere. Do yourself a favor and eat at one of the many other places near Randolph.
I love this place. Lots of seating, great service, family friendly and great food. Make sure you are ready for fusion dinner food because that's what you will enjoy here.

I've been to Girl and the Goat and yes, it's fantastic BUT Little Goat is where it's at! The food is always amazing and they have unique offerings that you won't find at other restaurants.

The overall vibe of the place is casual and fun with a bit of class. I call it a fancy diner.

I would give a 5 star review but the service is hit or miss whenever I go. Last time I was there, I had a server who didn't even say "hi".. then she brought the wrong drinks and didn't come back to check on us until it was time to drop the check.

We went here when we couldn't get into girl and the goat, but we weren't disappointed. It has an almost upscale diner vibe with nice lighting. I had the fat Elvis waffles and my boyfriend had some tasty sandwich au jus. My waffles were light and crispy with bacon bits, banana and a peanutbutter butter. Salty and sweet.

This would be a great place for a date or taking visiting family

The crowd at the front should tell you more then you need to know, but it moves quickly and the wait staff were absolutely lovely. And the food would be worth the wait even if it wasn't fast.

Quick polite service in a busy restaurant, it wasn't cramped and everything arrived hot. Don't miss the cinnamon bun or the French toast. The menu will make you plan your second trip before you even order because you'll want to try everything.

Outstanding and exciting food, we will absolutely be back, as well as to the sister restaurants!

This Little Goat made its way all across the street from the Girl that it was with, and decided to open up shop to give us folks a chance to dine at one of the best diners out here in Chitown.

Breakfast. Lunch. BRUNCH?! Oh, and dinner too. There is no shortage of meal times for the hungry seeker looking to enjoy some great dining outside of the elusive restaurant across the street. My friends and I had a 5 minute wait for a Sunday evening meal around 18:00. We took on the Pokemon Go gym that occupies the space, and before you know it, we were seated.

The menu was vast! There were so many breakfast items everywhere that it took forever for us to decide. I ended up going for "This Little Piggy Went to China," and it sure did. Sure, it wasn't a goat, but Szechuan pork sausage and chili garlic sauce gave every bite its own kick. Topped with a fried egg and served with a sesame cheddar biscuit, it was made for me!

The service here was not bad either. While a friend was waiting for his food, they offered him a round of fries just so he can munch on something while the rest of us dove into our meals. Thanks buddy!

Awesome food, great casual dining experience, and friendly service. I'll be back Little Goat. Don't stray too far now!

Little Goat is a great place! They have amazing coffee and they food is always solid! They have a fab vegan menu (you have to ask for it - but it does exist) and a great standard one as well.  I've been there on multiple times and never have a bad meal.  They are always busy so do be prepared for a faster service (they need to turn tables quick sometimes) but they are always welcoming and will answer all your questions.  I enjoy eating at the bar to be able to watch the action but the booths and communal table are also great! The bakery bar is fun and has some great to go items when you're on the run.

One of my favorite weekend brunch spots, Little Goat Diner is a perfect place to have a laid back meal. The menu is extremely creative (one would expect nothing less from Stephanie Izard) and I like that equal attention is given to both brunch and lunch.
It's relatively easy to get a reservation here, which I always appreciate. However, if you do need to wait, you can grab a drink and/or a pastry from the bakery and bar at the back of the restaurant.
My favorite thing on the menu is the Parathas Burritto. It's pretty filling and you might not have to eat again that day but so darn good. I could use the chili pepper sauce on anything and everything. If you're into waffles you can't miss the Fat Elvis Waffles. Pretty much as decadent as they sound. On the lunch side, the Fish Tostadas are a lighter option but get the Reuben if you want to go big or go home.
Put Little Goat on your "best brunches" list and get breakkie fix.

Great vibe, great service, and the food was delish!! The breadsticks are more like loaves of bread lol! The crab dip is divine, and if you get the AH-mazing grilled cheese sandwich, be sure to get the tomato soup to go with it. I don't even like tomato soup and I ate every drop!

Stephanie Izard is brilliant. She's a Top Chef Winner (Season 4), was announced as Food & Wine magazine's "Best New Chef" (in 2011), and now runs three successful and highly acclaimed restaurants in Chicago's West Loop neighborhood. The original, Girl & The Goat, was awarded 'Best New Restaurant' by Saveur magazine. And Duck Duck Goat, a Chinese-inspired restaurant has also become a Chicago favorite. **Be sure to make reservations for those places as they book up weeks in advance. Or they also take walk-ins, so feel free to take a chance!

If you're like me, and it's too late, and you're in Chicago and you didn't plan your meals at all then you should definitely pop into Little Goat Diner. The idea behind Little Goat Diner was to allow the growing bakery program from Girl & The Goat to flourish and offer patrons seeking a taste of Izard an easier and more accessible option.

We showed up for breakfast, we were in town for Lollapalooza- a popular music festival, and really only had breakfast and lunch to explore Chicago's food scene since we'd be at the festival during dinnertime. Knowing I didn't have a shot at Izard's other restaurants, I happily took the opportunity to head to Little Goat Diner for breakfast.

From the moment we showed up I was in love, the layout of the space is just delightful, bright and airy. It's refreshing to be inside, and the atmosphere puts you in a good mood. The team at Little Goat Diner was so welcoming too, answering all of our questions about what to eat on the menu. And I'm glad we asked, and I'm glad we listened.

The menu offers very traditional breakfast items from pancakes to eggs, and also puts a little spin on it by incorporating Izard's whimsy into the dishes. We started off with some coffee, I opted for the Barista's Special. It was essentially a S'mores latte, topped with a nice heap of marshmallow fluff. It tasted just like a S'more and was a delicious way to begin the meal.

We then were suggested to try the Blueberry Pancakes and were told we were able to order a single pancake. So we had one of those, and then a cinnamon roll. The pancake was served with a crumble on top and a buttermilk butter. The buttermilk butter is as dangerous as it sounds, but you will definitely want to spread it on top.

The honest to goodness star of the meal was the "This little piggy went to China". It starts with a sesame cheddar biscuit, szechuan pork sausage topped with chili garlic, chive sauce and blackberries topped with a sunny egg. It was sweet, spicy, filling, sweet, spicy, delicious! It was all we talked about after we ate there, and now looking at the pictures I am having some withdrawls. This restuarnt is so good!

There are a bunch of other delicious breakfast, lunch, and dinner menu items. There's a full bar, full coffee bar, and not to forget that they serve breakfast all day. It's a perfect place to begin or end your day, and this will definitely be on my list of places to visit when I come back to Chicago!

The food and service were both 5 star worthy. We had The Fish Tostada,Tempura mashed potatoes (simply the best thing we ate) Mac and cheese excellent and the Crispy Creole Chicken and I would recommend trying many dishes and passing around .

We were looking for a family friendly place in the city after the marathon to indulge, and Little Goat did not disappoint! The food was excellent. I had the Reuben, my mother had Los Drowned and my boys easily shared chicken tenders. We also had a side Very Lil Caesar, and it was delicious across the board. The meal - including iced tea and coke was barely $55 - well-priced for the city. Also the staff was attentive, and our waitress, Camille, was totally on top of it. We'll definitely come back!

Great food location and service. Goat patty melt home fries fried pickles and onion rings and the best Cabernet Sauvignon I have ever tasted ... You will leave with food large  portions on every dish.. make a reservation this place is very busy..

Having never been to any of the "goats", I was excited to give this place a try for brunch. From the beginning, this place is great: the interior is classy, but the menu is almost childlike (in a good way) with the little cartoons. Our waitress was friendly and took great care of us.

My bullseye French toast was incredible. The sweet syrup and strawberries somehow worked perfectly with the more heavy components of egg and chicken. However, my friend ordered this little piggy went to China, and I think I actually preferred her food-talk about bursting with flavor.
Also ordered hash browns for the table. Weren't my favorite ever, but definitely good-they were stringier than most, but packed on the bottom which still gave them good crunch.

This place definitely leaves me wanting to head over to girl and the goat and give it a shot. I'll be back!

Good food and great service,  the perfect combination.  Service was fast even though the diner was happening with every table full.  

Our server was delightful, patient and helpful.  

The food was fantastic; even the toast was great.  

Great call for brunch.

I placed an order for a sandwich and the waiter never brought it out. I understand that it was a little  busy but it was still early in the night and not totally overwhelming. He remembered all of our drink orders and brought out the apps but forgot about my entree. I asked for ONE item of food and I don't think it's too much to ask to remember to complete this order. How a server can completely forget is beyond me as THAT IS THEIR JOB to remember the  order and bring the food out to the customer. It's a shame because I've heard good reviews about this place and the server was nice but I don't think I will be returning.

My boyfriend and I ordered the little piggy goes to china and okinomiyaki. The little piggy goes to china was a wonderful savory dish.  I highly recommend this dish. The okinomiyaki was edible but not amazing.

I'd say this is the best diner food on the planet. Right off the bat, Little Goat takes reservations, a HUGE win because this is a popular spot. Great staff as well, always a good attitude and conversation.

To the food. You will leave stuffed, big portions and they don't skimp on the fats. It's a diner, so I wouldn't have it any other way.

If you want to impress your friends and server, get The Goat Almighty. This burger is a mountain of four different meats, a few types of onions and sauced to high hell. Absolutely delicious. Even though there are so many different types of meat and flavors, nothing goes unnoticed or gets lost in the mix.

Be aware, this thing is absolutely huge and I believe I'm the only person to ever finish this beast, this monster, this Goat Almighty.

Came here recently. Got the grilled cheese and the halibut special and the tomato soup. Also got the raspberry desert. It was all excellent. And the servers were all very pleasant. Even though a bit loud inside, it was a quite relaxing place. I was very impressed overall with it. Would love to go back again.

Little goat diner!!! This place has some of the most unique menu items I've ever seen. We went for brunch and got the breakfast burrito. Not much of a burrito, but amazing nonetheless with really delicious and unique flavors and ingredients. Our waiter was really knowledgeable and patient with my questions. The fries were okay, I would choose the hash browns next time. We also got the glass noodles with a veggie patty and that was really good. Overall, a terrific meal and overall great experience

Diner with a twist! Amongst the many restaurants in this area you may find yourself with a picky eater who says "I don't know", take them here!  It has everything you want and it is done very well! I'm still working my way through the menu and tempted on a few favorites from before.

Best burger! We are outside on a perfect summer evening. Husband had Reuben. Both couldn't have been better. Fries - shoestring (my favorite) and clearly real handcut potatoes. Server was friendly, explained specialties, and helped us make just the right choices.

TL;DNR -- too salty, wasn't worth the wait, a lot of better places to eat in fulton market.

mannn, I waited 1h & 45m for this?

things we ordered:
* this little piggy went to china
* bull's eye french toast
* pork belly pancake
* goat chili
* goat chili cheese fries

first off, every dish we was really, salty.

* this little piggy went to china
-- it was good the first few bites, but it became overwhelmingly salty. the dish itself had too much going on, especially with the addition of the gooseberries. i didn't finish it & didn't care to take it home.

* bull's eye french toast
-- probably the best of the dishes we had & i was really surprised. it was more sweet than savory. the brioche did not taste like onion nor did the syrup taste like bbq. it just tastes like a brioche bread with an egg in the middle (like eggs in a basket) topped with chicken, syrup, & strawberries.

* pork belly pancake
-- the ginger & bok choy salad was refreshing against the salty pork belly & crispy pancakes. but i found this dish to be really salty as well

* goat chili cheese fries
-- the fries were golden & topped with the goat chili & smothered with cheese. the dish was also pretty good, but again heavy on the salt.

* goat chili
-- it's literally chili, but with goat. not terrible, but not awesome.

overall, we spent about $66. i don't think i'd come back if there was a wait. there's honestly so many other places to eat in fulton market. the diner's cute and clean though.

pics.caption: this little piggy went to china

review.des:
Came here late on a Saturday night for a late night snack and it did not disappoint. We were seated right away and our server was nice and welcoming. Place looked nice and modern- definitely not your usual Denny's or IHOP.

Ordered chicken tenders with a side of corn and chicken quesadillas. DELICIOUS. The best was the buttered corn with cilantro in my opinion, I couldn't get over how good it was. Chicken tenders were deep fried to perfection and came out warm and crisp. Quesadillas looked bomb but I did not try them.

I definitely recommend this place! Would like to try other items in their menu! Check it out!

This place would've been a 5 star if it wasn't for the service. My server at the counter looked like she didn't want to be there. When I asked what she recommends, she said everything...

I had the pig from china dish and it was delicious. Very flavorful and worth the trip out. Would definitely recommend any first timers in Chicago to check it out!

pics.caption: This Little Piggy Went to China!

review.des: Amazing!  The server was fun and attentive, very knowledgeable about the menu. The food was delicious and quick. I highly recommend the crumpets. My Australian husband was skeptical and then blown away! Consider making a reservation by we got in right away while others had to wait quite some time. Such a fun atmosphere.

I definitely left feeling like I need to give this place another shot, but the first time experience was lack-luster! I went for a birthday lunch with colleagues; service at the front door felt very rushed, and we were crammed at a smaller table for a large group. The restaurant is buzzing with activity, and it has such a cool upscale diner feel to it, but it made conversation pretty difficult.

I'm a big fan of Stephanie Izard, but I was so disappointed in my meal! I got the pork belly pancake, which was not great. It's a pretty tiny dish....the scallion pancake was really tough, and difficult to cut (seemed to be over-cooked). The pork was a little too sweet for my taste, and was also very tough. It tasted like it was something that had been left sitting under a heat lamp too long. Table mates mostly got salads, and they didn't seem to think they were anything spectacular.

The menu is very creative and quite extensive, so I certainly want to give it another chance! Bummer the first impression wasn't spectacular.

The experience at this recreated diner was beyond disappointing.  Elevated comfort food? More like uninspired, inhospitable, tired, unworthy. We had a reservation for an early time, lots of empty booths but we were seated at a tiny two top. (booths still empty when we left. Server came right away with initial service items, greeting etc. this was the last hint of attention we got. Took order, someone else brought food, resentful refill of drink, no check in to see if we liked the sad food. No comment as they cleared the half eaten plates. Unimpressed.

If you like a little bit of ethnic flare to your diner food and like being adventurous, you'll love Little Goat Diner! I've been meaning to eat here for awhile, and the diner did not disappoint. I love how Little Goat serves a variety of food, especially brunch food... the best meal of the day.

The portions are pretty big, but I think you can't really go wrong with anything on the menu. I am a huge fan of the tasty asian thing (literally the name) and the french toast. I've been eyeing the Elvis Waffles, so I'll try that next time. The cheez-it ice cream dessert sounds super strange though. Cinnamon roll was just okay... not steaming warm with a melty glaze on top. Also, beware the cold brew is pretty sour.

Overall, a very filling meal... If you live in Chicago, I suggest coming a few time with friends to try everything on the menu! It's a diner version (and more affordable version) of Girl and the Goat.

Originally we didn't plan to come here for dinner but we did anyways and super glad we did! The other place we were suppose to be at had a 2 hour wait so we came here in hopes to get our food sooner otherwise we would be hangry.

For a table the wait was 45 minutes but we saw three spots available at the bar so we sat there right away.

We still kept the other reservation so we only ordered Los Drowned, Loco Moco, and goat chili cheese fries to share. The food was really good and our waitress was on top of everything. Having breakfast for dinner was great, especially since I didn't get lunch haha.

I took the bus to get here but from what I saw parking looks like a pain.

Definitely a treat. I had this pig went to China town and the bf had the waffle and chicken. My food was burst of different flavors. I don't normally get Asian influence food at a non-Asian restaurant but this just blew my mind. The fusion is oh so right.

Once again.... Hype overshadows poor quality.  I'm not sure why this chicks restaurants are so highly rated. I've had better food cooked by Sue and Bob in rural Kentucky. And I didn't have to take out a second mortgage. $9 for Mac n chz???  Good? Average. Sloppy joe...Manwich. nachos were the only thing worth the money. Did you see my picture of our pie???  Crap. Thank God Izard won a cooking show. Without her celeb status I don't think she could keep her food places open.

pics.caption: This was $16 worth of pie to go from LGD.  Really??? This is the crap I open up when I get home ready to enjoy a great piece of pie??

review.des: Love. Love. Love. I had heard this place was great for kids and it was! We took my son here for his 2nd birthday and the service and food were impeccable.  Our server seated my in laws and my son's godparents while we were on the way. We had reservations too - very easy to make. It was on a Sunday but still packed. Love the casual feel but everyone there looked like they were to have fun. They have valet but we took a spot through a lot close by. When we arrived they had a high chair ready for us and water was already on the table. Our server greeted us promptly and got in our drink orders. When he came back with our drinks, we ordered the entrees. I got a chocolate malt shake (duh, amazing - and so much whipped cream, how it should be!), and the mushroom ragout. My son got a side of Mac and cheese, my husband got the Reuben sandwich, my mother in law got the chicken pot pie. I don't remember what everyone else got though - but I know for sure there wasn't much left! At the end the server got us a little ice cream sundae for my son to sing happy birthday, which totally made his day. Pricing wasn't terrible - the food was delicious and my son was happy. I would definitely come here again, especially so I can try out the cocktails next time! What I super appreciated was our server's patience and quickness - my son was having a temper tantrum and he got him some goat stickers, made sure he was happy (as well as the rest of our table). He's the one that really made it worth our while to come here, and I've been really looking forward to visiting this place, so thanks to that server who made my son's birthday so great!

This was such a cool place to try as our last restaurant in Chicago! It's very cute looking inside, with a very modern diner feel. The menu had a lot of classics that had the little goat twist: I had the shrimp and cheesy grits that had pistachios and tomatoes, my friend had the little goat latte that had goat's milk in it, and we all shared the cheez-it sundae (very unique and tasty)! In the back, they have a bar and a cafe and an are that has their merch like t-shirts and signature spices, which I thought was very cool. If you're visiting Chicago, definitely give this place a try, and make a reservation like we did so you don't have to wait in line.
Great Bloody Marys, but food is only OK. Disappointing for a place with such a good reputation.

Best brunch in Chicago.  Had the biscuits and gravy and it was great. Sat at the bar which saved us the headache of waiting 30 minutes to eat. Highly recommend for anyone visiting or living in Chicago.

We had a gift card to use and had a great time, it was gift the migrant workers night off evening, and you could hear the stress in the servers voice when explaining they were struggling with a small staff on, we didn't mind. There was a few thing I would've tried if that hadn't been out of product, but my chicken was good. There was a man that was screaming at people on the way in and out(which was not the establishments fault)and it was so busy we couldn't sit at the Small 6 seater bar, this wasn't a bad thing for the restaurant, but soured the eve a bit for us. All in all would recommend a night here.

Literally the best brunch food I've had. PLEASE OPEN ONE IN New York!!!! the only reason I would come back to visit Chicago is to come here. Their food is absolutely amazing, it's SO unique and so freaking delicious.

Came back here for the 3rd time for a quick birthday dinner. We decided to try out their new savory asian pancakes. First, the scallion pancake was just ok, nothing too exciting. It's very similar to the pork belly pancake they had back then, but just without the pork belly. It was just sour veggies on top of a pancake. I think they could've done better with this menu.

Then, the okonomiyaki - Japanese savory pancake which was delicious!! The bonito flakes and the sauces on top are the key of this pancake. Highly recommended!

Lastly, the vegan bahn mi burger - the patty was filling and delicious, and I think they made them out of potatoes. It had a texture of a creamy mashed potato inside which we really enjoyed about this vegan burger. Unfortunately, it seems like they didn't put a lot of effort on the "bahn mi" part. It lacked flavor, and I didn't really get the flavor of a Vietnamese sandwich. It's like they just added to veggies just for the presentation or for the look of a bahn mi sandwich. I think they should add more tangy/sweetness to the burger. Other than that, the burger was great!

The Bullseye French Toast is a must eat! It is the perfect blend of sweet and savory- the french toast is ooey gooey and eggy (YUM) and the fried chicken was perfectly cooked! Little Piggy Went to China had a really good cheddar biscuit but the the chili sauce was too overpowering- i ended up picking it off my food.
The Cheezit sundae sounded weird but was probably one of the best desserts I've ever had! The strawberry gelato totally worked with the savory gelato!
Stopped in for a coffee- I ended up ordering a cappuccino and my husband had a hot chocolate. Both were very good, and the staff was friendly.

Love that Little Goat has twists on breakfast food that are yummy, creative, and not too gimmicky. The paratha tacos are amazing, as is little piggy. Good drinks, but the breakfast food is the real star here.

Came for breakfast and left very full and content. I had the shrimp and grits and don't think I've ever finished an entree faster. The grits were as cheesy as advertised and the sauce was delicious. It didn't feel heavy or too rich and was one of the best bowls of shrimp and grits I've ever had. My husband had the everything is everything crumpets which was equally delicious. The dish was an imaginative play on bagels and lox and succeeded with each of its components. A win all around!

I love this restaurant! First time coming here and the food was spectacular! The decor was great and are server was A+!
Had the grilled cheese and tomato soup and the Coco Taco sundae! To die for! Will be back!

Very casual, laid back diner. I'm a big fan of this place for multiple reasons. When it came to getting reservations, it was fairly easy and quick through Open Table. If you don't book ahead and depending on the day, you'll have to wait 30-45 minutes. Saturday and Sunday brunch crowd is obviously more busy.

I went with my family and we tried a variety of the dishes - all really good. This is a great kid friendly restaurant and I was really surprised as to how much they go out of their way for the little ones. From providing coloring menus to the wait staff engaging with them. I live in the neighborhood and have been back multiple times - always bringing people either in or out of town that have never been there before. Despite all the upscale restaurants in the area, it's nice to have a no non-sense option for food.

Long wait, but worth it. Really cool atmosphere and decor, and super friendly staff!

The menu is familiar-ish, with some really unique twists. And the food is delicious! Highly recommend the pancakes. Mmmmmmmm.

Gave this place a try twice and they just kept disappointing. This review is the honest facts that happened to me both times I've been to this diner.

First time here:
Made reservations for my husband and I and was seated right away. However, it took 10 minutes to get water and another 5 for the waitress to introduce herself, this is not an exaggeration, just facts. Another 10 minutes for my waitress to come back with our drink order and finally take our food order.  She asked me what I wanted in a rushed way and when I was done, she grabbed my menu and my husband's, didn't say a word, and walked away....COMPLETELY FORGETTING TO TAKE MY HUSBAND'S ORDER. We had to wave her down 5 minutes later to order and for this she apologized so we let that go. So by the time we put in our full order, we had been sitting in the restaurant for 30 Minutes. The only reason I stayed and did not leave mid dinner was the fact that people raved about the food...This I concur,  is true. Food was delicious, innovative,  and very unique.  I had the pork belly fries with the grilled cheese and it was the BEST thing I've ever eaten in a while.  The only reason I even wanted to give this place a second chance was for their glorious food...which leads me to my second chance visit.

Second visit:
Made reservation for a bunch of my girlfriends for brunch. Looking forward to see if my experience will be better this time around. We were given water right away,  greeted within 5 minutes by the waiter, he was attentive so, I was quite optimistic. I ordered the "little piggy went to china" breakfast that according to the menu has sunny side up eggs...which can really be made over easy, over medium etc, I wasn't asked by the server. My food arrives and though smelled delicious, my egg whites were still CLEAR. Granted I wish they were more specific as to how cooked this sunny side up egg would be, but the fact that I'm pregnant and cannot eat uncooked eggs was really bothering me. So I asked the waiter if there's anyway I can have the eggs more cooked and this is what he says:
"Ok so, First of all the chef would not change how your egg is made because it's very insulting to him. Also it would be unsanitary to bring this to the kitchen since it touched your table."
Which are all very valid points but what's insulting is how this was his initial response. So I suggesed if he can just bring me a more well done egg to the table and for this he agreed right away. So why the fuss when that could've just been suggested by him to begin with? I don't expect every waiter to empathize with their pregnant customers, but not insulting the chef's ego cause I wanted my egg more well done for the safety of my unborn child was a bigger priority for him in this case. He could've just easily solved my dilemma by suggesting bringing a more cooked egg to the table, but he found it necessary to mouth off to a paying customer.

I really, really wanted to like this place and even went back a second time to give it a chance. But man, for the caliber of food they serve, the waitstaff needs some serious training. I was a server and busgirl for 5 years and these guys weren't even meeting the bare minimum expectations of what a server should be in a reputable place. I understand it's a casual "diner" and not a 5 star restaurant, but they really have to retrain their staff if they want to keep repeat customers coming. What a shame. The 2 stars are SOLELY for the food and nothing else.
We absolutely love going here. The food is amazing! Out of town guests always enjoy when we take them here!
Great for a quick stop for a cafe and bakery snack or make a reservation for the unique spin on brunch menu.  Definitely the sister restaurant to girl and the goat and easier to get into.

This place is hopping! If you come by yourself or with just one other person without reservations, you may want to sit at the bar. It's first come first serve, in both the coffee shop bar and the diner bar.

Service is excellent, although it did take a little bit for the waiter to notice me at the bar. He had other tables, but once he is there, he is sure you get your food as quickly as they can. Also, the host/ hostess doesn't always provide a drink / cocktail menu so make sure you ask for it!

Food. I ordered the duck breast. It was melt in your mouth delicious! Not too heavy or overly fatty either. I cleaned my plate. Dessert. I went with the lemon pie tart. It hit the spot. Not too sweet, a little tart but definitely a great lemon dessert. The crust was amazingly crumbly too! Drink. I got the Eastwoods ride which was the perfect amount of sweet and ginger and alcohol! Haha! Loved it!

Overall, a great place to try out for some delicious food! It can be a bit pricey for the diner atmosphere though.

pics.caption: Lemon pie tart - hits the spot if you like lemon desserts $8
Duck breast is delicious! And not too fatty. $25

review.des: I love this place! I've been a few times and everytime has been a hit. I took a friend who doesnt really care where he eats and he was blown away at how good a simple patty melt can be. he said "your just going to order avocado toast?" and what showed up was homeade bread covered in avocado and all kinds of other goodness. Wasn't "just" avocado toast. She has quite a few vegan options, make sure to ask for a menu, including a shake, I believe, but im always too full to indugle in the sweets.

One of my favorite restaurants in Chicago. Several unique takes on classics and overall really good food. Great variety to accommodate everyone in your group (and whatever meal you're craving) -- they even have a special gluten-free menu (just ask for it). They also have happy hour deals.

I recommend the Machos Nachos to share. Be warned, the Goat Almighty is huge!
Really cool spot. Very laid back atmosphere and great food and service. Being little sister to girl and the goat I didn't expect any less. You must try the sloppy goat! You won't be disappointed!

Saturday evening after the Cirque circus. 7:00 pm Total chaos to park. BTW $16 valet only.

We made it 5 minutes late and hostess gave our party of six reservation a problem? With being late by 5 minutes? Really? It was a total mess in traffic.
I would Not recommend prime dining on Saturday night at 7pm. Go around 5pm or 8:30 pm! Also, prepare yourself for people who bring in babies! OMG! I raised 4 children and would not dream of bringing children into this restaurant after 6pm! It was noisy.

We waited 15 minutes!  I saw two six seating booths empty! I told my daughter I was willing to bet we would be seated in one of those booths.
I was correct! That hostess was there acting like nothing was available and then, did us the favor? of seating us in a booth that was sitting empty for 15 minutes, when we could have been seated right away. I was totally disgusted but said nothing, since I was there with my adult kids.

Food is calorie /fat laden. I ordered the whitefish tortas, which were excellent and probably the healthiest item on the menu!. The grilled cheese sandwich, my pregnant daughter ordered,
was so greasy she ate only half and did not take it home. Too overdone with butter and, it was burnt. My son ordered the meat concoction that had a goat burger, lamb, roast beef topped with a toasted roll and a fried onion ring. Totally too much, if you are into meat gluttony! BTW, the meat in the Reuben is not corned beef! It's roast beef and definitely would Not order. What is a Reuben w/o corned beef?

The desserts, however, were spot on! The peach pie with whipped cream was shared with the table and was the best I have ever tasted with the shortbread pie crust. Very good! Also ordered was a special ice cream sundae  with chocolate crust and topped with a caramel popcorn!

Total experience.? Meh for the price. Meh for food. Meh for the Parking. No hassle and $16 Valet. Better than average for dessert. Would I dine there again? I do not think so unless it was for brunch.
Brunch items were interesting and are served all day!

First of all, the food was good and I have nothing to complain about there. The atmosphere and interior are very nice. Getting a table was a little hard and I did not feel like sitting at the bar area. Now that I think back at it, maybe would have been a better idea than getting a table.

The very low rating I have given this restaurant is because of the awfully rude, slow and unattentive staff. It is very unfortunate when Chicago restaurants that are popular and have good food, also have bad service because they know that people will still come in droves to eat.

As we were here for lunch, I did not want to spend 2 hours here. The hosts at the front were all very rude, and not just to me, but to all of the customers that came in. The server that we had only came over once. He took our order and disappeared. After a very long wait, the food was brought by a runner. The waiter never came back to check on us, offer us water, condiments or anything else. After a frustrating meal and a very long wait, we could not catch any servers that would give us the check. (Our server was really MIA by now). I had to walk over to the hostess and ask them to send someone with a check. They seemed very displeased that I did that and gave me attitude again. Finally, I was able to pay my bill and I vowed to never come back here again.

While the food here is good, the staff should be ashamed at the low level of service they provide at this establishment.

Had heard about the hype about this place for years and had seen it multiple times on Yelp so my sisters and I decided to give it a try. We got here at around 8am on a Saturday and we're seated immediately. The restaurant didn't start filling up until 9:30am. We were pleased to know that we could order anything off the menu no matter the time of day. We took advantage.

I had the patty melt sandwich. The meat was juicy and the cheese had a good combination going on. Gave this 4/5.

Sister number 1 had chicken and waffles, which were really good! She doesn't usually like egg with sweet things, but thoroughly enjoyed this combo. The only thing is that she had wished she asked for the syrup on the side since it was overly sweet.

Sister number 2 got the omelette of the day which was ham and cheese. This was the best looking ham and cheese omelette I had ever seen. The thing was huge, had a variety of delicious cheeses and the ham was well prepared. I wish I would've ordered this, but don't regret my patty melt at all.

Great food, but a bit of a wait to get service at our table. Still plan on coming back soon though.

I'm a fan of G&TG so I naturally had to come here for breakfast.

Bullseye french toast wins me over.

Best Breakfast in Chi-town.

I sat at the counter. Love the fast and friendly service.

I'll have to take pictures in the photo booth next time.

Not a fan.  It's WAY over-hyped, the food is good at best, and the crowd/noise level is just too much.  If you absolutely love brunch, then you might love this place, but if you hate waiting forever for a table for mediocre food, then avoid at all costs.

This is one of my very favorite places to eat in Chicago. I'm a big fan of all things from Stephanie Izard including her restaurants, events and following her on Top Chef.
