All the dishes her are winners in my mind from the pancakes to crumpets, to the corn beef has (my favorite) with homemade bread and hot coffee. I've hd other meals here but since they serve breakfast all day here I try to take advantage.

pics.caption: Corn beef hash with scrambled eggs

review.des:
I've been here twice -- once for brunch, which was amaaazing, and again for dinner...which left something to be desired. Between my friends and I, we've ordered the Little Piggy Went To China, the Kimchi-Stir-Fry-Pancake-Thing, the Pork Belly Okonomiyaki, the Tempura Mashed Potatoes, and the hash browns.

Little Piggy Went To China: I think they alter their menu seasonally, because I've ordered this on two separate occasions and I swear it was a different dish. First time I had it, it was absolutely delicious. I grew up with Chinese food and was really impressed how they worked pretty authentic Sichuan flavors into traditionally Western biscuit, eggs, sausage breakfast sandwich. Perfect egg. However, the second time I ordered this when I was back a couple months later, they had added strawberries to the sauce?? Kind of muddled up the perfect flavor they'd had before and made it weirdly sweet, which didn't go well with the Sichuan pepper sauce. ): didn't enjoy it as much.

Okonomiyaki was tasty...but a little bit too cakey vs. the crispy stuff I'm used to. Also, my friend and I couldn't find any pork belly in it. We were kind of disappointed and confused.

Absolutely loved the tempura mashed potatoes, though. Really interesting sauce and pickled vegetables brightened it up.

Kimchi-stir-fry-pancake-thing: tasty, but I don't think it's on the menu anymore ):

All in all, I was really excited to come back to this place after my first time eating here...but the second time, with the altered little piggy and the pork-belly-less okonomiyaki, I was kind of disappointed. Might come back again, but then again, might not.

Arrived on Saturday around 12-1230. Wait was an hour but it's worth it. It's in a fun area and they text you when you're table is ready so you can leave. Valet is worth it and easy. $14.00 and they accept credit. WIN!

Next door and connects is Little Goat Bakery and coffee bar. We grabbed some lattes and a couple open stools and drank and chatted for a few. There is some outside seating too.

We were seated in about 45 min even though they said an hour. Ordered onion rings and fried pickles before. The best pickles I've ever had. They onion rings tasted like they were marinated in mustard before breaded and fried & it was great.

I definitely wanted something with goat. Order the sloppy goat like a sloppy joe with rosemary slaw. Yep! This was delish!!!!!!! Didn't want it to end. Only comes with the sandwich but with the coffee and onion rings/pickles before it was plenty.

They don't have same day reservations but you can make them before. If you don't want to wait like we did, do that.

pics.caption: Nonfat Latte from Little Goat Bakery

review.des: Went to Little Goat Diner on a whim with my boyfriend this past Friday night and absolutely loved it!! We both have the same tastes, so we usually get two dishes and split them. This time we split the Bulls Eye French Toast and the Los Drowned "sammich" and loved them both!! I also got the caramel latte and could've probably had  another one by the time I finished it. 10/10 would recommend this place to a friend!!

Make reservations to avoid waiting in line. The food is delicious and large portions and still affordable.
It's a great place to support local. The tempura mashed potatoes are delicious! The staff is knowledgeable and very attentive.

The Little Goat is a great trendy diner in the West Loop. You'll get a higher end experience than you'd expect from any typical diner, but all of the comfort.

-Atmosphere is super cool. They have a rotating neon goat on the roof. It's updated retro inside with cool banquettes and a great counter.
-The place is often very crowded. We came on a Monday night and were told there was a wait for a table unless we wanted to sit at the counter. I found this to be a slightly dubious claim, but didn't feel like arguing. We ended up getting a seat by the bakery area where the seats are first come, first serve.
-It was a great atmosphere in the bakery area--we got to see all the bakers in the back baking breads and desserts as we waited.
-They had good draft beers and craft cocktails.
-Club sandwich was delicious.
-Patty melt was good--but the onions were too big and overpowering. It also kind of fell apart when you picked it up which I don't expect from a patty melt.
-Side of fries was tiny and outrageously priced at $7--really felt like they were ripping us off.
-Service was friendly if a little slow--there were several times we were trying to find our server.

Overall, it's great to have a place like this in your neighborhood.

I had my rehearsal dinner on the roof and it did not disappoint. I have had their brunch on several occasions, which has always been yummy. The dinner served at our event was divine. All our guests raved about the view and the service.

I recommend trying to go not at peak hours because the waits can be long.

When I envision a diner I see pancakes, omeletes, meat loaf, biscuits, buttery toast, BLT sandwiches, coffee, etc. Not here. Yes, there are breakfast and lunch items but not the basics. I want good comfort food at a reasonable price. Not here. The spicy chicken sandwich on brioche bun was lacking flavor. The bun was too soft and sweet to hold up the chicken breast. The garlic mash potatoes were okay but where was the garlic? The waffles had an ounce of syrup, I mean bacon syrup. Plus, I hate paying for someone's rent  - $14.00 for a chicken sandwich just because the restaurant is located downtown. Baaaaaad

Great food, cocktails, and service. The pork belly pancake and the fried pickles and onions were delicious, as was the pisco-based cocktail. During outside with the skyline in the background was lovely.

This place is a definite must! Reservations are recommended so you can be seated promptly. We had 10:30 am reservations, tons of people waiting to get in, we walk up, and we're sat right away! The menu changes for the season to keep things fresh!

The has browns are NOT your everyday hash browns. They alone are packed full of flavor and I can confidently say they are the best hash browns I've ever add! Ask for the chipotle hot sauce (it's a medium spice) and I drizzled it over the hash browns. All I can say is a classic OMG!! You will not be disappointed.  

I ordered the okonomiyaki which is a pancake with pork belly baked on top, poached egg on top, drizzled with a sauce of greatness and the flavor is like a breakfast, lunch, and dinner gut busy and made a baby that is the most delicious brunch item I've ever had!

Phenominal food! The apple tomato soup was refreshing and bursting with flavor. Mac N Cheese was second to none, creamy with a light crunch on top! The Chick Pea salad was also unique and the Harissa vinaigrette was tangy, slightly spicy deliciousness!!! Definitely a must try when in Chicago!!! Stephanie Izard does not disappoint.

Yummy!

I had a pretty delightful experience here the other night for dinner. I would describe the Little Goat as a diner with a modern twist and playful creations on diner food. Several dishes caught my eye such as the Bahn Mi Burger and the Fish Tostadas, but having to narrow it down to one I went for the Pork Belly Pancake sammich. Basically a large scallion pancake a slice of tender pork belly with hoisin sauce and topped with a bok choi salad. Rather than eat it like a sandwich / wrap, I went knife and fork on it down to the last bite. Super tasty! My only gripe was that only half the pancake was topped with that super tender and delicious pork belly :(  

I also got a chance to try a bite of the Not Chinese Broccoli and the Fried Chicken. The Not Chinese Broccoli reminded me of like a really mild szechuan vegetable dish, super light and delicious. The Fried Chicken also had some asian fusion going on as the breading did remind me of chicken tonkatsu. Super delicious as well!

'Til next time, cheers!

pics.caption: Pork belly pancake sammich... Just a tad skimpy on the pork belly in my opinion.

review.des:
Another winner from Chef Izard and one that completely surprised me.  When I read the words "diner", I was expecting heavy, plain and standard but well executed dishes.  Yes I was wrong! The environment is loud but vibrant ... It bustles with excitement.  The food is global twists on classics and definitely made well with some serious speed.  It helps to have the same attention warmth to the service we saw at the girl and the goat.  

So we ordered 2 sides and 2 main ... Not realizing the mains can feed a super hungry person or realistically 2 people!! So be warned ... Come with an appetite or with a lot of mouths!  Yes tuna melt looked like a salad at first ... It's like 2 meals in one.  A full sized salad AND the sandwich.  I was impressed with the the sandwich as it was perfectly crunchy from being nicely toasted and the filling was excellent.  Lots of tuna, very creamy and healthy dose of lemon to cut through the mayo.  The cheese added another tasty component to it.  My goato goato salad was meal sized with plentiful amount of shrimp and a great variety of vegetables.  Definitely one of the better salads I've had in Chicago.

The sides nearly stole the night... The tempura mash potato was so well done.  Creamy starchy interior was perfectly battered and fried to a greaseless crunch that was still crispy 10 minutes later.  Is it indulgent yes but whoever came up with this idea ... I love you.  The fish sauce pea greens was a nice Vietnamese influenced dish.  I really liked the sweet and pungent savory fish notes to the crunchy greens.  

Our ending to the night was a great lemon curd tart that coverted a lemon hater.  A thick buttery graham tart shell contained a creamy bright lemon curd that was lightly covered with a blueberry sauce.  Loved this!!

Lastly the service was phenomenal ... Water was always refilled the moment it got to half.  A friendly passing of the staff to make sure everything was good happened throughout the night but it never felt intrusive.  Just a gentle pulse to make sure everything was perfect.  I do admit the speed of service was incredibly fast.  I think we got the tuna melt I under 5 minutes.  

I'll definitely return!

pics.caption: That isn't a salad ... tuna melt which is the best one I've tried.  Also tempura mashed potato (!!) and greens with Vietnamese influence

review.des: I had heard great things about Little Goat Diner from a few people, so I put it on the list of restaurants to try on our last trip to Chicago. Reservations were made online, which is simple and gets you to a table quickly. We went for brunch on a Sunday morning, so there was a wait if one did not make reservations. Once we got to a table, we ordered an Ooey Gooey Cinnabun for the three of us to share, and OMG, it was heaven. Soft and chewy, with loads of cinnamon and copious amounts of cream cheese frosting. So yummy! I ordered a cold brew, which was strong and delicious. I also tried my fiancee's Bloody Mary, which was spicy and very unique, as it is made with kimchi. It was good, but a little unexpected-tasting. For a meal, I got This Little Piggy Went to China - cheddar biscuit, szechuan pork patty, chili-garlic-chive sauce and strawberries. The flavors work very well together, and the portion was huge. I also got bites of the Parathas Burrito - delicious, I'll get this next time - and the biscuits and gravy - good, but a lot of mushroom flavor. I love the decor here, which is an eclectic mix of shabby chic and retro diner vibes. Our server was polite, efficient, and made good recommendations. I highly recommend this place if you're in the area.

pics.caption: This Little Piggy Went to China

review.des:
Little goat.. little goat... are you the baby of Girl and the Goat or not???

Well, I wasn't cool enough to get into Girl and the Goat, so second best was brunch at Little Goat. We arrived early as we're old and wake up early. The wait was minimal at roughly 15 minutes for 5 people.

First off, my cappuccino was good. Figuring that I'm such a "foodie", I went out on the limb and ordered the breakfast spaghetti and clams even though it sounded disgusting... because... I really don't know what I was thinking?? Verdict appears that it really wasn't that appetizing, so my recommendation cannot be for this.

On the other hand, my fiance, the play it safe guy, got the shrimp and grits. Holy smokes! I'm not a true southern girl so I never understood the draw to grits (tastes like even shittier oatmeal), but these were flavored grits. The dish was bursting with flavor, so being the good girlfriend that I am, I pushed my dish aside and helped my fiance finish his. If I could tastefully lick the plate, I would've, but it was my 29th birthday weekend, so I was trying to keep it classy.

So, ultimately, my verdict is, eat this if you can, but please, don't sit out for a ridiculous 2 hour wait if that's what it comes down to. Hop along, plenty of better options down that same street.

A friend recommended this place for lunch on a recent visit to Chicago and I'm so glad he did. We made reservations for 9:30 on Saturday and it was already packed inside with people waiting. Our waiter was warm and friendly and explained the menu to us. Hubby ordered the fat Elvis and I got the apple pancakes. Both entrees were excellent. We also got yogurt and granola as a side and the yogurt was out of this world. It was so rich and creamy it tasted like ice cream. We had a lovely time here, definitely recommend and definitely items make a reservation.

I love places that put on a great breakfast / brunch. This place was AWESOME..!  Very busy on a Sunday morning... that's a good sign. Excellent coffee... special Goat Blend from Dark Matter coffee.  I had the Okonomiyaki, which was also AWESOME.  The whole staff was friendly & very invested in the operation. I'll be back for sure.
Had the bulls eye french toast and it definitely hit the mark! The restaurant is really cute too, with a bar, booths, family-style tables, and outdoor eating

pics.caption: French toast with fried chicken, strawberries, and (underneath it all) a sunnyside up egg!

review.des: Interesting melange of diner, bakery, bar and high-end restaurant. The bakery is excellent on its own... as is the bar. The wait for a table can be a while. And the food is American diner straight-forward. all in all excellent. I highly recommend the burgers and the chicken.

I try to stray from reviewing highly popular restaurants as I feel as though my review will get lost in the mix (unless it's a negative one because I had a bad experience and in that case I don't even hesitate to write). HOWEVER, this place is worth the hype. I walked here thinking this was Girl and the Goat and my tired eyes and hungry stomach just saw the little Goat on the top of the restaurant and assumed I had reached my destination. Because I was alone, I was immediately sat at the bar and given a menu that read "The Little Goat Diner" to which I said " Oh.". I had come this far and was already sat that I decided to stay, especially since after doing some research I knew this sister restaurant was just as good, and it was.

I ordered the Pork Belly Home fries and the The Little Piggy Goes to China (I'm totally making these names up from memory, so don't quote me on these dish names) and I was highly impressed. I'm always weary of Asian fusion places, but the cooks execute the mixture of flavors PERFECTY. To simply describe it, I was essentially having Asian comfort food.

The décor was very cute. A retrofitted 60s diner feel, with a bit of an upscale twist. What really brought me to write this review was the meeting that I caught with the GM and some of the employees. He was telling them that it was Lollapalooza weekend, so they should prepare for some rushes. BUT to always remember to be courteous and provide excellent service. He pointed out things such as "Always say excuse me. If a customer is coming, they have the right of way." "Always say thank you. This is extremely important.". Working in a restaurant myself, I tend to notice more than the typical customer and even prior to working in a restaurant, customer service is always an important factor in my experience. I have to applaud this manager for these callouts because it isn't something that other restaurants make a point to remember to do.

Thanks Little Goat Diner! The experience was great. If only I lived in Chicago, I'd be a regular.

After trying to reserve a table at the Girl & the Goat, we were recommended this diner alternative by the same owner. It had a lot of hype, but I can see why.

Although it was "diner" food, it had an upscale flair. I ordered the veggie quesadillas which came topped with radishes and a delicious chive yogurt dipping sauce. The presentation was well done, and the beer glasses even had adorable little goats on them!

I really wanted to LOVE this place, but I thought it was just ok. The pictures of the food look so amazing that my husband and I were so excited to try it out. I had the Spanish omelette, my husband had two eggs bacon and hash browns, and we ordered the Fat Elvis waffles. Everything was jut ok. The food was a little bit greasy, and the scrambled eggs were a little runny. The service was good, and our waitress was fast and attentive considering she was very busy. The Fat Elvis was the highlight for sure, but it was extremely sweet. I love sweet stuff and yet found them to be a little bit too sweet. My husband, unfortunately, had an eye lash in his eggs which was definitely not a good thing, but they were replaced for us quickly (no biggie). Maybe I had set my expectations to high. I imagined something different, but it's really greasy spoon breakfast and a higher price point.

I really couldn't finish my fries, there were THAT many (be warned!). My burger was also a behemoth, but I'm not complaining.

I really love the indoor modern diner vibes, but I chose to eat outside because of the lovely weather. Unfortunately, they didn't have an umbrella for the table to block the strong sun. It actually made the experience unpleasant.

The waitress also really didn't seem genuinely happy to work her job, so that upset me a little knowing I was bothering her every time I would need her.

I really enjoyed this place! Great atmosphere, never has the wait like Girl & the Goat, and has a menu that is filled with straight comfort food.

I had the biscuits and gravy and Bullseye french toast. The biscuits and gravy was exactly what I needed that Tuesday night at 11pm. My mama never made me biscuits and gravy as a kid, and now I'm pissed she didn't. The only thing I would say is that the biscuits were slightly drier than expected.

Now for the Bullseye french toast. The description is "eggs, crispy chicken, sweet onion brioche, bbq maple syrup". I couldn't even imagine what that would taste like. It just doesn't make sense. But, once I combined all those flavors in single bites I was enlightened. So strange, but soooooo good. And wait for that hidden egg IN the french toast. Next level.

When I've had a long day or when I need to eat and let the worries of life fade away in dreams of Bullseye french toast or when I just feel like it, find me at Little Goat.

pics.caption: Chicken French toast with bbq syrup. Surprised me!
Biscuits and gravy. Late night satisfaction.

review.des: I ate here once long ago.  Was looking forward to eating again.  They however can't follow there own posted hours and closed early even though half the tables had people in them. I won't go back ever again.

Little Goat Diner had both hit and miss.  The Bull's Eye French Toast was a hit.  I am not a big fan of sweet breakfast item in general, but the maple syrup on this dish wasn't overwhelming.  The chicken had nice exterior crunch.  The runny egg hidden inside was a nice touch.  Definitely one of the better French Toast dish I had in recent years.  

The okonomiyaki, on the other hand, was a miss.  Traditional okonomiyaki consists of many ingredients inside and on top.  The Little Goat version lacked many of these ingredients, which made it a lot less substantial. Not to mention it was on the dry side.  I think Little Goat Diner is a good breakfast and brunch spot, but the okonomiyaki won't be on my list next time.
Ehhh, crazy loud, average food.  I was expecting something special but was disappointed.  I've had better, I've certainly had worse. YMMV.

Fantastic AMAZING diner. Everything was so thoughtful, tasty, amazing combinations make the choice of what to eat tricky.
We shared a couple of different dishes .... they were SUBLIME.
The onion pancake with hoisin porkbelly and salad had incredible flavours. Thankyou Little Goat and especially to Anthony for making our lunch an unforgettable experience. EXCEPTIONAL service. YES I shall travel all the way from Australia
to come back!
K

pics.caption: Funky dining with a titch of elegance and fun

review.des:
First off, my friends and I were those people that showed up asking if they were still open when they were 10 minutes to closing.

Fortunately for us, they still sat us! The server was also very friendly, and she didn't seem to mind or give us any grief. We only went to help fill up a friend with some carbs so the morning after wasn't going to be so rough. Therefore, we got the biscuit and gravy, garlic bread, and mac and cheese.

My favorite item out of the three would have to be the garlic bread (which wasn't very garlic-y) because of that tomato puree they have for it. Oh my goodness, it was so good! I wasn't even that hungry but I wanted to eat more of the garlic bread because of that puree.

The mac and cheese seemed average...very back-to-basics. The biscuit and gravy were good but I don't think it was anything spectacular, however my friend was very happy with both of the items.

I'd want to come back to try the other things though.

pics.caption: Side of Mac and cheese, biscuit and gravy, and garlic bread. :)

review.des: I've been here for both dinner and brunch and it has always delivered on good quality food and is always worth it. It has been relatively easy to walk-in and not wait too long. Would highly recommend.

Little Goat Diner has a great vibe right when you step in. The decor is fun and so is the menu. I've ordered the Reuben with kimchi before and it's a great combination. The crab dip is also delicious and a generous serving. The Choco Taco dessert they were offering for a while might be the favorite thing I've ordered. The sour cream ice cream in it is amazing. The prices are reasonable considering the quality of ingredients.

Chicken and Waffles was the best thing we had and a lot of food. We also had the omelette of the day - I ate most of that because my husband didn't want to share his Chicken.
Server was super nice and helpful but the food took a while to come.
I walked out of there feeling like a needed a nap. I don't think there is anything light on the menu, but what we did have was great.
Cute, casual spot that's worth a try if you're in the area. The wait is not too bad and prices are decent. The food is diner food with some twists. I would certainly return.

Ahh Little Goat Diner. When I first went to eat there, I took my friend who lives in Chicago. We had such a great experience. Note make reservations. The ambience is open and just positive. Waiters are great. Prompt and food was delicious. My friend is vegetarian and he LOVED this place. You can't go wrong with their specialty coffees. Now when we visit Chicago, my friend always want to go there for breakfast. Been there three times now every time we visit Chicago.
Good food. I had the okonomiyaki which was good but it wasn't what I was in the mood for. The flavors were very unorthodox.

We obviously couldn't get enough of Chef Stephanie's food, so much so that we went to the Little Goat for brunch the following day after having dinner at Girl and the Goat across the street the night before. Again, an establishment where there is always a wait but not as outrageous as its sister restaurant. The way to go around this if you don't have a reservation would be to check out their bar to see if there are open spots. The entire menu is available for ordering there, and lucky for us, we were able to snag seats within 10 minutes. Not bad, yeah?

We had a cup of GOAT CHILI ($6) which was hearty and scrumptious without that heavy feel. It wasn't gamey at all, in fact, it's the goat meat flavor that carried this one through. Their BISCUITS and GRAVY ($6/sm) on the other hand was one big giant flaky and buttery biscuit smothered with gravy cooked with pork sausage and mushrooms. Drooling yet? I asked for more gravy on the side and the bartender gladly gave me a full cup. Don't judge me, it was that good!

For my main entree, I got the BULL'S EYE FRENCH TOAST ($16) topped with crispy chicken pieces and fresh strawberry slices, then drizzled with bbq maple syrup. It was a lovely plate but the magic happened when I cut open my sweet onion brioche -  a glorious yellow yolk oozed out! Little did I know a beautifully cooked egg was going to surprise me in the middle of all that. So rad!  

I switched plates with my husband halfway through my meal to have some of his SHRIMP and GRITS ($16). This Southern fare is always delightful to have but by throwing in some braised pistachios and using grumpy goat grits made Chef Stephanie's twist on this extra brilliant.

Service was top-notch across the board. We came back the next morning to grab coffee while waiting for a table at the nearby Au Cheval. With a slight setback on our order, I saw how well they were able to fix the issue with a positive attitude. This Top Chef winner won for a damn good reason and it shows in her restaurants.

Brunch this time - you definitely want to make a reservation if you can because that wait got real long after we got our sidewalk table at 10:15AM. Well-made drinks and Asian-inspired food. Filling but not heavy. Friend was pleasantly buzzed after her Bloody Mary and very happy with the okonomiyaki. The pancake came out a wee bit smaller than I was expecting but it was full of good ingredients and drizzled with yummy mayo. I drank the Little Goat Latte (could have been creamier) and maybe a pisco-based tequila sunrise-like drink with soda in lieu of juice? It was delightful but I don't see it on the bar menu online anymore. I also had the chop chae burger set with a goat patty and mmmm I love goat. Patty was less tender than a lamb burger but I liked it that way and they got the mince loose enough to retain juice but not be bad chewy. Glass noodles were cooked just right and it was a wonderfully aromatic dish.

pics.caption: Delicious drink that I can't find in the menu online anymore

review.des:
With my friends from California here for a weekend, I wanted to make sure they got a good taste of all the great food that Chicago has to offer. Thus Little Goat Diner made it onto our itinerary filled with some of the more iconic Chicago eats since Girl and the Goat had so much hype but it was difficult to get my large group a reservation there.

We had a reservation for 2:15 pm for a late lunch and overall service was pretty good. We ordered the goat chili cheese fries and the macho nachos as appetizers, both of which were delicious and very satisfying. I love that the place has a diner feel but reinvents the dishes to make everything a little more interesting. The chili was made with goat (of course) and had a nice subtly different taste to it.  The nachos were even better, with unique masa-based chips and delicious toppings. Unfortunately, that's where the highlights for us stopped as the entrees paled in comparison. Part of the reason was that the "snacks" we ordered were very heavy and also came in very large portions which probably took away from the entrees a bit. But even so, none of us were really impressed with the entrees we ordered (Bull's Eye French Toast, Fish Tostada, Okonomiyaki, etc.) That's not to say anything was bad at all -- just underwhelming. Maybe my expectations were too high, but I probably wouldn't recommend this place if you're only interested in it for the hype. I can't say it's not worth a try because you might like it better than I did, but I have to say it wouldn't make the top of my list for places to try in West Loop.

Not impressed . The food was good, service was nice, the restaurant decorations along with the coffee counter was excellent, and the restaurant's location was perfect... But still not impressed. I couldn't get past the ala carte menu style. In most brunch restaurants in the city such as yolk, most entrees come with your choice of hash browns or potatoes and pancakes/ toast/ English muffin. At this restaurant however you purchase everything separately. It seems like a cute concept & it allows one to try multiple dishes similar to a tapas restaurant however I think the idea just does not translate well to a restaurant that focuses on breakfast.

I ordered an omelet, pancakes, and hashbrown separately. When my food arrived, I was surprised and shocked by how small the portions were.
Additionally, I ordered the housecoffee and was beyond annoyed when I realized that you pay per cup. What is that all about???

At the end of my breakfast when I received my bill I was shocked to see that my tiny ala carte breakfast would end up costing me twice as much then it would have if I had gone somewhere else... Not to mention the fact that I left still hungry!

What is this whole restaurant all about?!?
Great food! Nachos are amazing. Service is great.  Food is reasonably priced for a hipster area.

Such a cute atmosphere. The dinner menu has everything you'd want and the drink menu has even more! It's such a shame the service was mediocre  compared to the food. The male bartender  was constantly working but the female bartender only paid attention to the regular customers and ignored the rest of us. I'm not sure if this was the way they usually divided the workload but was a little off putting.

Awesome amazing delicious. The neighborhood is so hopping with innovative yummy restaurants and bars.

Lunch - food was delicious we ended up ordering to share and still couldn't finish it!

I think little goat is way better than girl and the goat down the street. I know it's the same owner but the food here is bigger, better and less expensive and all those things play a role in my rating. The Ruben sandwich is awesome!
Overpriced, Overhyped diner.  Everything here is so pricey, food is good, but comparing to other places is not good enough for those price tags.

Great spot. And what a great staff. Food was amazing. Had the bulls eye French toast, biscuit and gravy, and the corn beef hash. Also got to try the buffalo dip as well. All had great taste but my favorite must say is the bulls eye. The bulls eye had a egg in the middle! Banging.
Amazing restaraunt, bar and coffee parlor all in one. One of the best restaurants in Chicago. Highly recommended! I can not explain how good the food is

I love this diner! The food was so tasty, the atmosphere was hip and chic, and if you want to skip the wait, you can choose bar seating. It was quite crowded the weekend I decided to go, and even though I made a reservation, I was still given bar seating. I ordered the chicken and waffles dish and it is easily one of the best restaurants to serve the pairing. You wont regret it!

My brother and sister-in-law took my fam here for dinner as a Xmas gift.  Deeelightful.

It has a nice diner vibe without all of the chaos a diner might have.  The decour is simple but consistent.  We very much enjoyed the photo booth and button vending machine while we were waiting for our table to be readied.

I started with the soup of the day, which was a butternut squash.  It was fantastic.  My mom had a taste and said it might be the best soup she's ever hard.  For my meal, I had a steak sandwich (I cannot remember the cutsie name).  I liked it a lot but not 5-stars a lot.  Something about one of the textures in it was strange and there were a lot of flavors, which was a bit overwhelming.  Honestly though, the soup was 5-stars on its own, so I am landing on 4 stars with a lot of plans to go back and try new things.  Everyone else's meal looked great, and it's so reasonably priced for food of that calibur.

Also, the coffee shop attached was really cute and I'd love to stop there and pick up some this-little-goat-went-to spices and sammich bread.

As someone new to Chicago, I feel like I hit the jackpot finding this place and can't wait to introduce it to my friends.  For food, I ordered the "This little piggy went to China" - every bite contained new and unexpected flavor explosions in the best way possible.  My friend ordered the biscuits and gravy, which usually I find to be heavy and bland but here was rich in flavor as well.  Our waitress, Gillian, was friendly and courteous, and we especially appreciated that she made sure to tell us that although she had a 25+ table just sitting down, she would not forget about us.  As a brunch spot, this place goes above and beyond.

This place is hoppin'! Even with a reservation, which I would highly recommend making, you will likely have to wait to be seated. The food is gourmet diner food- decadent and artery-clogging and oh-so-delicious. My friend and I each got a cocktail, both of which were well-prepared, and split two menu items- the Bull's Eye French Toast and the GARGANTUAN Goat Almighty burger. Both were fantastic. The french toast/fried egg/fried chicken combo was a hit. And that burger- goat burger patty, braised beef brisket, and pulled pork, topped with giant onion rings- wow! It was insane in the best way! Though I did start getting the meat sweats halfway though, ha! I wish we had even a tiny bit of room for something sweet, as their shakes looked amazing. Next time!

pics.caption: Goat Almighty burger- goat patty, braised beef brisket, pulled pork, topped with cheese, onion rings, and pickled peppers
Bull's Eye French Toast- with runny egg in the middle, topped with fried chicken, strawberries, and BBQ maple syrup

review.des: Lovely breakfast and wonderful service! We walked from the Hyatt Regency on Wacker (kind of a hike) and took in a lot of sights on the way.  3 Sisters Farm Oatmeal was delicious!

I would say 3.5 stars overall. This is definitely the type of place you would take a group or your friends for brunch. Came here around 2 P.M. on a Sunday and the place was packed (but no wait). The menu is pretty interesting and creative, a mixture of Asian-fusion as well as traditional American favorites. Tried the Okonomoyaki, a burger, has browns and a bit of a milkshake. Everything was tasty (though very unhealthy). Portions of some items are huge (e.g. some of the sandwiches and the special goat burger), but others were just modest. Hash browns were a good size, crispy and hot, but super greasy. The Asian-fusion foods did, in fact, taste Asian, and I enjoyed the meal. The burger was on grilled bread (rather than a bun) and was smothered in butter and cheese (a win for me), but it's disappointing that it doesn't come with anything else. The milkshake was decent. The one reason why I would say 3.5 stars is that the prices seem to be extremely steep for the items we ordered. $8 for a milkshake and $14 for a regular sized burger with nothing else is more than I would expect for a casual brunch.

Overall, food is good, prices are a little high, but if you don't mind paying them, I'd stop by.
Awesome customer service, cool atmosphere, and a great time. The little goat has it all.

pics.caption: Great atmosphere. Skylights are my bag, baby

review.des: Went for lunch after seeing Little Goat on the list of child friendly restaurants - AMAZING. My friend had a young child with her who got a little fussy at one point but the server never once seemed annoyed and was very patient with us, which we are so appreciative of.  So not only was the service awesome, but the food was amazing too. Will definitely be back!

It lived up to the hype. Didn't realize Girl & the Goat was closed on Sunday mornings, so we went across the street to Little Goat Diner and were lucky enough to be able to sit almost immediately at the bar. I got the "parathas burrito" and my friend got the "this little piggy went to China". Both were literally amazing. I was surprised by the look of the parathas burrito (for obvious reasons, was expecting a burrito) but it was perfect and not too heavy either. Would highly recommend!! We also started off our meal with a nice crab dip appetizer that was truly aces.

pics.caption: This Little Piggy Went To China

review.des: Cute little spot in the West Loop but I would suggest reservations- even for lunch! We sat outside on the sidewalk patio which wasn't overwhelmingly loud. I had a scone which was fantastic and very reasonably priced and an iced latte that was more expensive than what I desired. I also had the yogurt and granola which was very sweet but the granola was fantastic! I didn't have adventurous food choices but overall thought it was yummy! Will go back.

Excellent service, excellent food quality and food options (vegetarian and meat eaters), but expecting a table as a walk-in is impossible so be patient but it's worth the wait.
Happy dining.

The atmosphere here was fantastic with food and drink to match. I had the Jerk Chicken Sandwich and a Sazerac, both of which were absolutely wonderful. Everything here is alacarte, so the bill adds up quickly. However, given I'm from Minneapolis where seemingly everything is cheaper, the prices seemed fair for the quality of the food.

Also, we ended up sitting inside, but the street-level patio looked really nice.

In sum, I highly recommend going here. The food is great, the atmosphere is really fun with great music, and the drinks are delicious!

Ummmm I barely need to write this because the consensus has consensed~ Little Goat is top notch brunching. Allow me to order for you:

THIS LITTLE PIGGY WENT TO CHINA - $13.00
sesame cheddar biscuit. sunny eggs. szechuan pork sausage. chili garlic chive sauce. gooseberries

*Only Bongo Room can compete, but I think this is the best brunch item of mi vidaaaaaaaaa! My friend (who is a svelte 6'4" and can eat for three) got a bowl of fries (fine, kind of shoe string style), a pulled pork bbq sandwich (YES. Not v brunchy in my book, but SO GOOD), and a Fat Elvis (too sweet for me to want a whole one, but great for mooching).

*With Love from Peru cocktail was delightful.

*Twenty minute wait (showed up Sunday around noon, so not bad!) and chilled in the bakery area with a coffee and a cookie. Very cute decor, kind of like a high-end Dove's vibe, and classic foods that they made their own and elevated to perfection. It's like the best version of your everyday favorites.

pics.caption: Cool bakery area to chill in if you're waiting (or eat in if you prefer!).

review.des:
I settled on the Bulls Eye French Toast after my server recommended it. I had read good reviews of this dish, so I went for it. I wasn't as impressed as others seemed to be. I think the bread part was delicious. Yum. Egg cooked in each slice. But strawberries AND fried chicken?  I wasn't such a fan of the combination of those two.
Nice staff, decent restaurant space, music was a little loud, but overall positive experience, but unsure if I'll go out of my way to go again.

I went on a family brunch outing to the Little Goat Diner during a short trip to Chicago. My girlfriend and I had visited Girl & the Goat the night before and both agreed that the Little Goat was a much better dining experience. We shared the Pork Belly Pancake and Fish Tostadas. Both the dishes were very good but my favorite was the Fish Tostadas. My mom stated that the blueberry pancakes were below average and they didn't seem to look the greatest. All in all it was a good meal and I would go back to try out some of the interesting dishes on the menu.

Amazing food! Had the veggie quesadilla. Best quesadilla I've ever had.  The parathas burrito was really good as well. All the flavors complimented each other really well. Hash browns were nothing special but still crispy cheesy and delicious.  Great for vegetarians.

Little Goat Diner offers an extensive menu of unique twists on American diner classics. Based off whatever looked most intriguing from its Yelp album, This Little Piggy Went to China piqued my curiosity. Boy oh boy, was I sent down memory lane the experiences of eating street food in Northern China. They nailed the chili garlic chive flavor on an otherwise western biscuit and sausage breakfast sandwich. Another classic with notes of Asian flavors was their reuben sammich paired with kimchi. Quite interesting. Will come back with my cousins for a larger tasting of their eclectic foods.

pics.caption: This Little Pig Went to China + Rueben

review.des: Best brunch is the city, but also great for any meal! Menu is a little big so stay somewhat close to home. Love the parathas burrito and the veggie burger. Def worth it, expect a wait and get a bloody mary, one of the best in the city.

I could not have been more disappointed with the service today at Little Goat Diner. I'm a vegetarian  and I keep Kosher, yet was brought an omelet with tons of ham tucked inside--even though the omelet was supposed to be completely vegetarian. In fact, I even had a lengthy conversation with the waiter about how I was a vegetarian.

I sent the omelet back--but there was very, very little remorse from the staff at all levels, including the manager who I spoke with. I didn't have time to stay for a new omelet, and I'm incredibly disappointed with the staff. They took it off the bill--but that was it.

Especially given that matters like this may involve RELIGIOUS beliefs (as opposed to someone just having a wrong ingredient in an order), I would expect much more from Little Goat Diner. I don't plan to come back to it -- or affiliated establishments -- any time soon.

So if you come to Chicago every blue moon and that ridiculously hard table at Girl & the Goat is hard to come by...meet it's hot sister.....Little Goat Diner....HAYYYYYY!

After glowing reviews from numerous friends, we had to come try this place out for brunch. So food wise, what should you order??? EVERYTHING.

We came in with a small group of us. I secured reservations since I knew there might be a mad rush for this place. We were seated within 10 min of arrival. Scooped a booth next to the window with a place to hang out jackets - love it!

For food we ordered: the parathas burrito (not really a burrito..more like a naan flat bread, but go with it), biscuits and gravy, omelette, this little piggy went to china ( laugh all you want - it's damn good.), and the hot crab dip. I have to say the "This Little Piggy Went to China" really knocked it out of this world! The not so amazing part was the crab dip...too fishy tasting for my taste-buds and didn't blow my socks off like I was hoping for.

Heads up - the don't offer to change the way the eggs are cooked, learned that after trying to alter the sunny side up stuff.

The service was friendly and did a great job looking after us given the huge rush. I was really glad we came and the food was definitely worth it!!

This place is overrated. All the build up and talk had me interested. Just an average restaurant tbh. Food  is good not great. It's basically one of those fancy spots to show off on social media, "Look at me , I'm so cool" haha ..

Every meal I've ever had here is AMAZING. Most recently I had the corn beef hash. It's one of the more traditional items on the menu but it was packed with great flavor and was a pretty hefty portion. The service here is outstanding but the wait can be long-even with a reservation we waited about 15 minutes past our reserved time-  so it may not be the best for big groups.
I've been here a few times and the food is good and the service is excellent. Usually there isn't too much of a wait, but if you know you're going ahead of time, try making a reservation
I love the food here! Great diner feel with healthy options while still having amazing food. I would come here all the time if I could!

Amazing, inspiring, lovely, delicious.  So much attention to detail, beautiful decor, fun & fresh vibe.  I love all of Stephanie's restaurants, and I'm so glad we went.  Brunch was delicious, great tasting comfort food.

Verdict? Unimpressed.

The service was fantastic and hence the two stars but other than that, I have nothing nice to say about Little Goat.  Should I blame my expectations? Maybe! If people talk a place up so much and you wait 1 plus hour to be seated then yes my food better be kick ass. The coffee was awful, unreasonably strong and completely undrinkable. The food was so salty I couldn't even touch the potatoes. I had the corned beef hash and my husband had a Spanish omelette or something like it. His was semi okay but mine was awful. They had slapped slices of corned beef in my plate with crappy salty potatoes. They did get my eggs right but then again if you mess that up you shouldn't be in business. I am not so sure I plan on returning.

My favorite meal this past weekend in Chicago. I had This Little Piggy Went to China and it was delicious. I love all the unique menu choices. Brought a group here and everyone really enjoyed it. A fun and eclectic place, I highly recommend checking it out!

Came here on a Monday afternoon. I did not know what to expect. I only knew I wanted something different from the ordinary and boy did I get it. I ordered the Bahn Mi Beef burger with Pork Belly fries. Deeeeeeeelllllllliiccciiioouusssss!!!! My friend ordered the fish tostadas and broccoli. Everything was great!! I recommend coming here if you're in a mood for something different.

I'd like to like this restaurant, but I just can't. I've been here on four occasions, and each time I have left disappointed. I don't know where they get their beans, but the coffee always tastes stale. The lattes have no depth of flavor and are more cream than coffee. "This Little Piggy Went to China," a dish consisting of a sesame cheddar biscuit, eggs, szechuan pork sausage, chili garlic chive sauce, and gooseberries, is the biggest disappointment of all. The dish is ridiculously salty and the overuse of the chili garlic chive sauce borders on offensive. The sourdough pancakes are lack-luster. The service and ambiance is great, but who cares when the food is subpar.
This place has an awesome diner aesthetic with a new age twist on the food. The menu is what I see on the food network channel and have always wanted to try. Highly recommend but get a reservation!
A fantastic establishment with a warm ambiance, great service, and quality food. If you're looking for a place to eat on a cold, snowy night, I highly recommend you visit Little Goat.

We came here on a Thursday night - very busy. We had to wait in the bar for a bit before getting seated. I had a vodka water which cost $11.15; in my opinion, that's steep for a shot of vodka and water.

We got seated the night began. The waiter was great. Service was quick. We ordered 2 sandwiches and a burrito. We all agreed the food was just okay. I would probably not come here again. The fries were good.. so there's that.

All in all, I wouldn't recommend as there are many other great places around.

We had a reservation and so were seated promptly upon arrival by the very friendly hostess. I was quite excited to see such a large vegetarian/vegan menu as I am usually provided with 2-3 mediocre options. The waitress was quite helpful in recommending a few options, and I went with the veggie burger done banh mi style. Although far too greasy for me, grease is expected from a diner and the sandwich was still delicious. I don't know the name of what my friend ordered, but his dairy free chocolate shake was fantastic. Overall, great service, ambiance, and food. I would highly recommend.
Cute little place by Stephanie Izard.  Fun diner for a casual meal.  Drinks are great too.

Ate okonomiyako. Yummy. Very eggy. Tried the French toast which was delicious - not quite sweet and had a salty taste to it. Very unique. The Cinnabon we thought would be warm and soft, but it was cold and a bit dried up.. so not as fresh as we would like. The goat marketing is awesome. Just love seeing the goat figure everywhere. My friend ended up getting one of their beanies.

pics.caption: This little piggy went to China. Get this.

review.des: Lively atmosphere.  Terrific food.  Prices are reasonable. And I love that they have different menus for your dietary preferences.  5 thumbs up!

I finally made it to Little Goat! So, I coincidentally happen to be in Chicago during World Series madness. It's Wednesday night, Game 7, and the city is buzzing with sports-fueled tension. This is exciting and all i.e. curse, blah blah, etc. but what is even more exciting is that the most popular and difficult to access restaurants (with no TVs) are unbelievably empty. Little Goat, Au Cheval, heck probably even The Girl & The Goat had tables a plenty--my three foodie compatriots and I strolled right on in to the first.

Little Goat definitely achieves an elevated diner feel, with squishy bench seats but modern bare bulb lighting. The 90's pop music brought me back and got my head bobbing. Everything, including glasses, plates, and paper utensil wraps, was customized with the Little Goat logo which not only ups the brand but makes the customer feel like they are going through a whole experience. Three of us shared the crab dip and and goat chili cheese fries appetizers. The crab dip has little filler and comes with good ol' Ritz crackers, which might portray kitchen laziness but are at the same time comforting. The dip was a bit salty for my taste. The fries are thin and best eaten with a fork due to chunky chili topping. For my entree, I ordered the This Little Piggy Went To China, which consists of a cheddar biscuit with sausage and sunny side up eggs surrounded by gooseberry sauce. I had never had gooseberries before, and they tasted like sweeter tomatoes. As much as I wanted to love my dinner, I didn't for the simple reason that the tart sauce overpowered all of the actual food it enveloped. The portions are large and very filling, though. Honestly, I would rate Little Goat three stars if it weren't for the fun breakfast-for-dinner options and the restaurant's overall fun vibe. However, I would totally come back to try other dishes as well as their shakes.

pics.caption: This Little Piggy Went To China

review.des: Amazing place. We did have reservations and still waited some time. I ordered the everything Lox. So good. The everything crumpets were out of this world. I didn't care too much for the side of the egg salad. My friend ordered the French toast with the chicken. He loved it but he didn't know the eggs were sunny side up. He did not love that part. Overall good place and service was good.

Came here with a group of friends on a weekend. It can get busy! The food is worth the wait.

Before I get to the food, I first have to mention the restaurant itself. It's like an upscale diner. Not too pretentious though, it feels homey in here. We sat at a booth next to a window. Loved having the sun streaming in during a lunch time meal.

I had the fish tacos. Crispy fried fish with a light slaw. The fish had a light crispy coating of fried goodness. No greasy feeling at all!

I also went to the bar and bread section of the restaurant. I got one of their yummy cupcakes to go. This is a great place for lunch! And then for dinner go to Girl and the Goat right across the street. That just might make it a perfect day in Chicago!

Trying something a little different with a spin on things this is where it's at. Definitely have to be in the mood for change when reading the menu. My final decision was a apple tomato relish with bacon grill cheese on a sour dough bread, cheese grits (Gouda goat cheese and one other cheese) and cherry wine soda. It was ok yet will return to try something different at least 1 more time. Customer service was fair went during lunch nice crowd indoor and outdoor. All age ranges was present and looks like throughout diner everyone had something different. Bottom line if your down and want to try something different with a touch of cost 13.00 for sandwich only and $4.00 for sides cool yet I've had better and sure you have too. Dessert shop in diner... I tried a butterscotch oatmeal cookie yummy will stop in for 1 of those and coffee and skip lunch.

The veggie burger was probably the best I've ever had. One kid had a burger with cheese, he liked it. The other kid had the fish tostadas. Huge portion. The only downfall was the long wait. And not sure what was going on with the hostesses, but quite a few parties ended up in front of us. Seems they need a better system for that. They had a lot of open seats, but surely the kitchen could've handled it. Worth the visit for the food and super cute atmosphere. While you're waiting, grab a drink in the bar.

My coworkers have all been here and they said I've got to try it.  I looked at the menu and it's almost all breakfast food and it was dinner time.  I was skeptical but wow the food is delicious.  I definitely don't mind breakfast food any time of day if it tastes like this.  We shared a Fat Elvis Waffles amongst the 5 of us and I had the Bulls Eye French Toast.  It tastes so good it felt like I was sinning with a guilty pleasure.  The service was great. The place was well decorated, simple but sweet.  The prices were ok for the area.  I'll definitely be back.

This was my first time dining in one of the Stephanie Izard franchises, and I wasn't disappointed. Located in the West Loop, this holds down the corner across from Bar Siena. I recommend making a reservation, and possibly dining early. We made ours for 530pm on a Saturday(blue plate anyone?) but it actually made perfect sense...the place was plenty busy already anyway, and as we dined, the throng of expectant diners waiting near the door just grew and grew and grew. Made our early dining time seem like a super smart idea! Of course, I can't take the credit for eating at 530. My usual dinner time is about 9pm, so...all credit goes to the lady.

For appetizers, we ordered drinks. I got the Old Fashioned, made with George Dickel 8 year Bourbon, and she got the Cherry Smoke Bomb, a mezcal based drink. Tell me if you've heard this story before. Man drinks 375ml of Mezcal, proceeds to play a horrible game of Classic Concentration while being filmed, and then goes on a drunken rant about Half Price Books' buy-back policy. Same man also splits a bottle of mezcal with a girl he picked up at the bar, and after drinking her half of the bottle she begins wailing the lyrics to a Shiny Toy Guns song, and crying while said man drunkenly stares in disbelief.

Yeah, that man was me. Me and mezcal have a storied history. We don't play well together. And yet, this Cherry Smoke Bomb deal was actually pretty good, making me rethink our relationship. Like maybe me and mezcal aren't meant to be monogamous. No, we probably need a little polyamory in our lives. Anyway....it was pretty good for something I expected to taste and smell like bad decisions. The Old Fashioned was good as well. Bourbon, sugar, and orange bitters, well balanced and tasty.

On to the food. Dining partner is a pescetarian, so not wanting to shut the sharing door on her, I ordered the gemelli with mushroom ragout, she got the spiced sautéed shrimp, and we split a bowl of the Brussels sprouts. Wasn't disappointed about my pasta choice being meatless. In fact, I actually wanted breakfast food for dinner, but we both thought it might be a little strange to have with our cocktails, so I opted against it. The mushrooms have just enough umami to make the pasta kind of meaty on its own, and as it turns out, she loves mushrooms too! The overall profile of that dish made it so I didn't miss the meat, and that's a great feat to accomplish. Her dish was pretty good as well, although I didn't really taste the Kim chee in the dish as described on the menu. Brussels sprouts - don't let the fish sauce discourage you! It had almonds and a fish sauce vinaigrette, topped with crispy onions that look like Durkees but taste like homemade. So good. Like a warm salad. Not sure if warm salad is really your speed or not, but the dish worked well. I mean, we were scraping the bowl. So there's that.

We were seated at the counter and my eyes would start to blur if I stared ahead at the half wall that separates the kitchen from the dining area. Don't be like me. Being seated right next to each other at the counter was good for us however, as it is a bit loud in the restaurant just due to the number of people all having conversations at once. After dinner and pre-drink drinks, we were ready to hit the bars.

Little Goat Diner is the perfect launching pad for a night out in the West Loop!

Celebrity chef owned, one of the best restaurants recognized in the country - I knew I had to check out one of the "Goats" before leaving Chicago.

The menu has plenty of options for every imaginable craving. Usually I  opt for savory main but gave in to one of the most popular dishes - Bull's eyes French toast. My husband saw Loco Moco on the menu and instantly knew he had to give it a try.

My French toasts - thick cut toasts with fried egg at the center. It was the most disappointing meal of my Chicago visit. The BBQ chili syrup tasted like store bought duck sauce. The fried chicken pieces appeared as a thrown on afterthought. Though crispy, they were flavorless. The toasts themselves were undercooked - the centers were still soggy. So much regrets on one plate.

Goat Burger Loco Moco - my husband was disappointed to see a dish which appeared closer to "fried rice". What makes things worse were - the rice was lukewarm and under seasoned; the patty was stiff and dry. The regrets just didn't stop.  

Filled with disappointments and regrets - we had no room for desserts. Overall - perhaps we ordered the wrong items but won't be returning to see if that's the case.

Wonderful dinner to sit and try new foods prepared unlike most. Have to visit and try for yourself.
Nice staff, good little bar with terrific selection of beer and full bar. Wonderful bakery which must be checked out. Take home or have there,
A casual gem with extra flair. The food has a classic feel but comes with a twist that your palette wouldn't expect. One of my most recommended spots

Great service, very organized crew, super fast!

I got a Sloppy Goat (just like a Sloppy Joe), and apple cream soup. Both were pretty decent. Although I found my Sloppy Goat a little salty, maybe that's just the way they are? They have so many other breakfast items on the menu that I really wanted to try, definitely will visit Little Goat again next time.

I really wanted this to be a great experience but it wasn't. Cold, loud, crowded, zero parking and expensive valet. There were 7 in our party and not one person loved their dish. Disappointed. Moving on.

Love this place. I've only gone for breakfast and lunch but the service is always great and the food is to die for! I love how it's set up as a diner so it feels very casual but it also has modern touches that make it more upscale.

Why wait until morning when you can have brunch as a late night dinner? This classy yet casual diner has fantastic food and service. Comfortable booths, wooden tables, cute table wear, creative wallpaper, and a unique chandelier.
I came here around 9 pm on a randon weeknight and was surpised to see that the place was still packed. We didn't have the foresight to make a reservation, but only had to wait 10-15 minutes for a table. Once seated, the wait staff was extremely attentive and helpful. The menu had plenty of brunch items, as well as sandwiches, soups and salads, a handful of which seemed to be asian-fushion. I ordered the apple-tomato soup, which warmed me up after traveling through the wind and rain. The soup had two unique flavors which actually worked well together: creamy tomato, with a sweet aftertaste. I often hesitate to order salads at restaurants because of the chance I might be paying for overpriced lettuce, but this place is definitely worth it! For only $7, i got a substantial caesar salad packed with fresh ingredients: romaine kale, radish, bell peppers, and beets. Once I told our server that I wasn't a fan of anchovy, he was able to modify the order so there wasn't any anchovies in the salad or dressing. The hash browns in my bf's meal were stringy and delicious. Next time I'll be ordering something more greasy and/or sweet :)
This place rocks!

Went for breakfast on Sunday and enjoyed ourselves. We made a reservation for 8am, and good thing, since it was pretty busy. I don't normally care for breakfast places where everything is a la carte though. I got the seasonal omelet (ham and cheese) and enjoyed it. My husband got the biscuits and gravy and he liked the gravy a lot; the biscuit was a little dry. The cinnamon roll was good, but a tad dry as well. It was a good meal for sure, but I don't think I would go out of my way to return.

Little Goat is just across the street from Girl And the Goat and looks like it's the same owner.

Sis and I came here on an early Monday morning and we were still half awake.  Amanda's energy and enthusiasm helped wake us up and here's what we ordered:

DARK CHOCOLATE CHIP CRUNCH PANCAKES - $12
With Chocolate Malt Butter.
This was a mistake. I don't even like dark chocolate. The pile of 3 large pancakes had chunks of dark chocolate chips and malt balls, which made it slightly crunchy. The pancakes were dry though, but too sweet for me to want to add syrup. I will not add butter because that's just more dark chocolate that I already don't like. Maybe someone who loves dark chocolate would dislike it less than me.  This was a mistake for us.

BULL'S EYE FRENCH TOAST - $16
Eggs. Crispy Chicken. Sweet Onion Brioche. BBQ Maple Syrup.
There's also lots of sliced strawberries.  Okay now doesn't all that sound good?! Now it would have if it wasn't all mashed up together.  So here we have a thick cut of brioche that is French toast but I also has an egg in it like Eggy in a Basket.  Sounds good right? However since everything in this dish is drenched in Maple Syrup (didn't really taste any BBQ flavor), the egg tasted like weird solid custard.  Nope. The pieces of crispy chicken (white meat) was good but it was just so drowned in syrup that it made it overly sweet and not crunchy any longer. I was only able to have a few bites and had to call it quites. This dish was overkill.

MAC N CHEESE - $7
This was my favorite thing pit of the rest.  It doesn't look cheesy or creamy but it really is because the thin sauce oozed to the bottom.  The pasta was soft just as I liked and I enjoyed it very much.  This simple dish was my favorite.  Sometimes I guess it's ok to keep things simple.

I think I loved EVERYTHING about Little Goat except for the food I ordered.  I loved the branding, the atmosphere, the restaurant decor, the stellar staff, the bakery shop next door...everything else but the food. Perhaps I need to come back and order something else.  Oh and I thought it was so cute to have a free button machine right in front! Gosh I love the branding of Little Goat!

One of my favorite places for brunch or lunch. Their fish tacos are delicious. I've also tried many other entrees and they never disappoint. You may have to wait a while during busy times. Bar is first come first serve. Service is always pretty good

I must have ordered the wrong thing??? Right? I sure hope so.

Little Goat did nothing for me and I REALLY, REALLY like Girl and the Goat.

We arrived around linner time, having not had breakfast and knowing we'd have an early dinner but definitely needed something to eat since we'd flown into town that morning on the first flight and it was now almost 3P and we hadn't had a chance to have anything to eat yet.

We arrived and were told two seats were available at the counter, of course we took them! Since we were super hungry and waiting 30 min for a table just didn't make sense.

I ordered the Bull's Eye French Toast and too my surprise it was covered in strawberries. Yuck! I don't care much for strawberries so as soon as this dish was set down in front of me I was totally bummed. I scooted these off and around and only had a few bites of them, but the French toast was just way to soggy for me. The only semi tolerable part of this dish was the chicken.

My boyfriend ordered the corned beef hash and eggs, which I tried a bite of and did not care for either.

If I return I'm definitely going pancakes or sandwich or all together skipping and trying Au Cheval on the corner.

I probably don't need to add to the raves here - but can't help it. Seriously everything on the menu is delicious!! I am obsessed with their chickpea salad - sooo good! Try to head there during off hours if possible though because the wait can be nuts during peak! Totally worth it though if you have time to kill.

Great vibe and ambience, and the food/flavors are so unique! My only complaint is that they used to have a fried pickle sandwich with tzatziki that was absolutely incredible, and it's now off the menu. Bring it back, please!

What more is there to add that hasn't been mentioned in the other 2,000+ reviews?

Patty Melt - They do a fine job. Patty was cooked just as ordered and the caramelized onions pushed the melt over the top.

All American Burger - You're getting what you asked for. A solid All American Burger.

Smoked Pork and Toffee Milkshake - My friend lives and dies by this shake so I had to try it. It's actually really good with a not too overbearing smoky pork flavor and mixed with a healthy amount of little bits of toffee to balance it out. Recommend spooning the milkshake as the toffee bits will clog the straw.

Smoked fries - eh...I could pass on them. Thin cut fries that weren't anything special.

Excellent service, clean and lively environment, and not too loud.

pics.caption: All American burger,  smoked pork and toffee shake, biscuits and gravy.

review.des:
Ok... This place doesn't need my 5 star review... They already have over 2000 Reviews but I can't help myself and sing their praises!! I had a Blue Plate Special of their version of Pigs in a Blanket (A Hot Dog wrapped in a pancake with fried eggs on top with a BBQ Maple Syrup).

Crazy Combination but OMG SOOOOO GOOOOD!!

And as important as the food is the service and everyone was incredible and friendly. My server was Amanda and she was just the perfect ray of Sunshine on a dreary Thursday Morning!!

I now understand the hype and will absolutely come back!! Can't believe I doubted this place.

pics.caption: Blue Plate Special. Hot Dog Wrapped in a Pancake with BBQ Maple Syrup. Don't doubt it... F'Amazing

review.des: This is one of my favorite restaurants in the world.  Consistently above the bar,  and constantly changing.  Innovative, flavorful,  and subtle when it needs to be. Cheap,  with solid cocktails. You can expect things to be delicious, yet different.  I tried This little piggy went to China and the pork belly pancake,  but I'd bet that the menu changes by the time you visit.  No matter,  check this place out.
Real good food, real good service. But let's talk about the playlist they were playing Valentine's Day evening... can someone please share the playlist?!! Real good place for a date!

Good burger, but hard to forget that practically next door is the best burger in America i.e. Au Cheval.  Was able to get a lunch table as a walk-in with only a 10 minute wait or so.  That was definitely a bonus.

Really nothing healthy on the menu so don't go if you are on a diet.  While the food was good I found the service to be a little rushed.  I also thought the price point was a little high for what is was (casual American with some ethnic/fusion twists).  Guess that's what comes with the territory for a celebrity chef joint.  

Awesome location so tons of fun stuff to do afterwards.

In the end it is just a diner so don't expect anything too much.  But if you are going for diner food there are probably similar quality options at half the price.  If you are going for the more upscale diner experience then go to Au Cheval instead (if you can get in)!

Pretty good place for brunch. My friend and I were visiting Chicago and heard this is another restaurant owned by top chef Stephanie Izard, and she's a fan of the show. Came close to 11am for breakfast/brunch on a weekday and we're lucky to get there when we did as the lunch crowd started piling in shortly after and a small line formed. Place is really nice and clean yet simple. Has a somewhat modern diner feel to it. Staff was friendly and met our needs just fine.

I got a mimosa to drink bc hell i'm in vacation but was quite disappointed in how small it was :/ We got an order of the tempura mashed potatoes which I thought were very interesting, but I didn't quite get the craze in it. I suppose it's different but otherwise it didn't leave any impression on me. For entrees I got the Little Piggy from China and my friend got the Chicken and French toast and those dishes were totally worth it!! The bread and the runny egg and eat of the little piggy with all the seasoning and sauces were suuuuper yummy and the chicken and French toast was HUGE!! Good portions of meat that was delicious with fresh strawberries and we were surprised to find an over easy egg in the middle of the French toast! I also ordered a side of home made sausage because ... idk, why not?! And it was also very good, thick and juicy!! So I definitely wasn't disappointed with our entrees and would recommend either of those dishes.

Their menu has changed as I was looking forward to trying other dishes that were no longer on the menu so be aware of a changing menu. Price wise I'll say it's fair. Not cheap but not overly overly priced I suppose. I probably wouldn't go here for lunch during work but as a nice treat for myself, I would. In an apparently growing/happening area of West Town, with multiple bars, restaurants and shops, Little Goat is worth checking out!

pics.caption: Mimosa so small... what a waste of my money.
Another view of Little Piggy went to China
Chicken and French Toast, a must!!

review.des:
For a place ranked this high it has consistently delivered lackluster food. This hipster haven draws huge crowds but that is probably a combination of a high yelp score and fantastic ambiance (hence the two star rating as opposed to 1)

This is my main problem with the diner: the food. The flavor combinations are an eager attempt to combine unique flavors and ideas but fall short most of the time. On my most recent visit I got the Bull's Eye French Toast. I could not taste the BBQ elements in the syrup they report, the chicken tasted like the Chinese food found in mall cafeterias, and I found an eggshell in my eggs.

This chef is supposed to be renowned and there was an eggshell in the eggs! For something so pricey on the menu, at least take a second to scoop out the eggshell. I've eaten at Waffle House a bunch of times and I have yet to discover an eggshell in my food--and Waffle House is infamous for their sloppiness.

It was overall a disappointing experience, and this was my second time here. Both times the flavor palate was real average and an ambitious misfire.

Decent outdoor, great for people watching. Good veggie burger, alley smoke was nice (it's a drink). They messed up and did a beef burger instead and it took a hell of a time for them to refire the right order. They comped it so that was good but damn, it took a long time. Would check it out again and just keep my fingers crossed they got it right on try one.
I love Little Goat Diner! There's normally a short wait but the service is great and the food is even better. The tonkatsu burger is huge and fulfills my large appetite.

I never make reservations, but can always find a quick seat at the counter.  LOVE this place!  It's fun, great service and tasty food!

I've tried the following here and all were delicious!  Bull's Eyes French toast, Fat Elvis Waffles, Bi Bim Bop, the tempura mashed potato and the macho nachos... washed down with an icy cold Cheerwine!  They carry Cheerwine - I am forever devoted to you, Steph!

It's a huge menu - I always have trouble deciding what to order,  it there's so much variety and I LOVE that I have choices.

Desserts are great... I usually walk over from Girl & the Goat and will have dessert here.  

I already mentioned the great service, but the wait staff does a really great job of being on top of your order, being knowledgeable about the menu to offer recommendations, having a fun conversation with you to add to the overall experience.

I fell in love with the Little Goat immediately after I seen that they carried Gum ball Head on tap. I decided this place was worth a try after checking out their menu and post-meal I can verify that.

I ordered the fish tostadas and man.... let me tell you. That was an amazing choice on my part. The food was delicious.. oh and the portion size was ginormous!

I recommend ubering if you live near the west loop. Parking is hard to find and valet costs $14 for 0-4 hours.

Make sure you make reservations ahead of time.

Amazing Brunch. I had the corn beef hash which was phenomenal and it serves two people. stuffed. Love the decor in the restaurant. Also had a Bloody Mary which was also very good and spicy! I would definitely recommend this Diner.

There are not enough compliments to describe this restaurant.

The setting is bright and happy.
The service is impeccable. It's quick, the servers know the menus and make recommendations based on feedback from the customers. The team helps one another so if, for instance, you drop your fork on the floor, whoever is passing by will get you a clean fork. In other words, it's a well-managed restaurant.
The food is consistent.  If you have something you like, you can go back for it over and over and it will be the same.  The choices are varied.  The flavors of each dish are carefully constructed.
It's a great restaurant that I return to over and over and always have a great meal and a fun experience.

I mean, how do you even start a review for a restaurant such as this? I'd long been a fan of Stephanie Izard after watching (and rooting for her to) win Top Chef many years ago and I'd heard of her amazing restaurants in Chicago. The time finally came for me to come to Stephanie's city and try, for the first time, her award winning food.

Being a party of 1 and only having time for one meal here, there was no way I could order everything I wanted to try. I ended up with the Los Drowned - a french dip-esque sandwich but elevated and FAR better. The Los Drowned come with braised beef (that basically melts in your mouth), havarti, avocado, pickled peppers & onions, and spicy mayo on a hoagie. I mean. Sound simple, but nononono - it was HEAVENLY. I've never had a sandwich so satisfying for my soul. It was life changing, really.

I opted to have some fries on the side which were perfectly seasoned with some kind of spicy ranch salt - super delicious - but I was so full from my sandwich that I didn't need too many fries.

Of course, being full, somehow, didn't stop me from ordering dessert...I mean...two desserts...heh. I ended up getting the french silk pie, which is basically the most perfect chocolate pudding in the most perfect crust, topped with crunchy chocolate somethings and served with a giant dollop of whipped cream on the side. I'm not even that big of a chocolate fan, but this. I could eat this every day. (Thank God I don't live there, so I actually cannot eat this every day).

My second dessert was really to appease my curiosity - the smoked pork and toffee crunch shake. OH DEAR LORD. The savoriness of bacon with the sweet crunch of toffee. It certainly wasn't a "light" milkshake (does that even exist??) but it was so amazingly delectable, my tastebuds went wild!

Biggest plus of this visit - I saw Stephanie Izard!! I'm a little sad I didn't get to say hi to her, but the waitress said that she was really busy getting ready for a big event. No worries - I'm satisfied with my celebrity chef sighting :)

There is one thing I know for sure - this will be my first stop next time I come to Chicago!!

pics.caption: Smoked pork and toffee crunch shake

review.des: Love. Attended an event upstairs.  All of the appetizers were amazing, goat empanadas, ahi, oysters. Then the dinner was even better. Cashew green beans, roasted cauliflower, sea bass and lamb ribs. If I had room I would have had seconds. The tiny strawberry shortcake was ok. Nice size but a more simple marinated strawberry without the unnecessary  carbs would have been better. Service was impeccable.

They have an awesome menu for gluten-free and vegan. The inside dining is absolutely perfect aesthetically, and the patio is great in the summer. It's worth the long wait! The food is always on point and plentifully portioned.
Just ridiculously good. Parathas. Pork belly. Tempura potatoes. Bloody. Habanero sauce. Service. Kids pancakes and eggs. All just perfect.

So. Much. Yes.

Every single thing I put in my mouth here was divine. There was a great mix of different kinds of foods for a brunch time meal- sweet and savory, lunch and breakfast... and supper.... and dessert! There was also some Asian fusion style dishes. Usually Asian fusion is questionable, sometimes even disgusting. But this was amazinggggg and truly done correctly with a perfect balance between Asian flavors (Vietnamese, Chinese, Japanese). We had the cinnamon roll to start- DO IT because it is perfect, gooey and dripping with a frosting that isn't too sweet, and the roll isn't dry inside and is so scrumptious. Then we had fried pickles and onion rings, which is a pregnant lady's dream. Amazing. Next up? Pork Belly Pancake- a nice scallion pancake with tender pork belly on top, a really great combo done very well. Also had a Fat Club sandwich - which was probably the best club sandwich I have had in a long time. Not too much bread (house made), with avocados and havarti- a perfect towering sandwich cut into four little squares of delectability! Everything was so good, we could have stayed for dinner!

To top it all off, service was AMAZING, our waitress (Minty) killed it and she brought great recommendations with her. I love servers who actually know their menu and can describe the dishes to a T.

Must Trys: EVERYTHING! Cinnamon bun, fat club sandwich

Yummilicious Factor: A++
staff very attentive to allergies and details. menu is amazing. wait is the only downfall, which just means everyone loves it.

My new favorite place!! I have nothing but great things to say about this place. I didn't make it to the place I wanted to go but that was a haven sent. I loved the food and the drinks everything was good. The star of my food choices had to the chili cheese goat fries yum I am still dreaming about these fries.

pics.caption: A great choice to have some bad credentials
