review.des: I found this place by accident and loved it! Great food. Great atmosphere. I was alone and enjoyed sitting at the bar.

Fantastic brunch, with a separate vegan menu! The vegan menu here has a great variety, including everything from interesting brunch items to burgers to dinner entrees and drinks. I got the vegan crumpets, which were fantastic. More along the lines of a beignet, served with gooseberries and maple syrup. So flavorful and delicious. The hash browns were also excellent, and a huge portion for the price.

My friend and I both ordered bloody Mary's, which our server informed me are not vegan by default, but can be made vegan upon request. They were amazing-very spicy and boozy! Great coffee too. The ambience is a bit hectic (they are busy for a reason!) but the quality of the food and service are truly memorable and worth the wait. Definitely my top choice for vegan brunch in Chicago.

Really a 3 1/2 but since we don't have half stars will give it 3. It was rare lunch date with the hubby we chose to meet here from our respective workplaces. Seated inside, I felt the service was kinda slow our server did mention it was busier than useual. I had the veggie sandwich and my husband had the goat burger. Their special seasonal cider which was lukewarm to cold at its best was not a good drink to order. Nothing very exciting on or off the menu to make me come back.

pics.caption: Caramel Apple cider .  Can skip this next time!

review.des: Lovely ambiance and our server was really kind and helpful. Barely waited as walk-ins and the food was so delicious. Got their well known French toast with chicken.

Oh. Wow.

Really unique twists on everyday breakfast foods. And the hype lives up to excellent food. I got the paratha burrito and it was delicious -- such a unique combination of flavors and textures.

They can make some things vegetarian on the regular menu and have a vegan menu as well. Definitely will be coming back.

One of the most creative and alluring menus I've ever encountered! Little goat is a very accessible version of its sister restaurant, the girl and the goat.
Ambiance- fun, hip, like an upscale diner.
Food- we tried 4 things: the Mac and cheese was deliciously creamy with crispy Parmesan and breadcrumbs on top, the fried pickles and onion rings were nice and light (tempura battered, and sweet pickles if you're curious) and served with mustard and ranch dipping sauces, the beef stew was just ok (underwhelming and too soupy, to be honest) and the paratha burrito was very flavorful (but got soggy at the end, because it was sitting on a bed of sauce)
Service- average, a bit slow at times, but the kitchen churned out our food so quickly that I can't complain!
Overall, it was an enjoyable dinner. We'll be back!

My friends and i came here for Sunday brunch and had a great experience. We made reservations and were seated within 5 minutes. I would recommend making reservations because the people that didn't definitely had a long wait. We ordered a mimosa carafe which was the perfect size for 4 people-we each got about 1.5-2 mimosas out of the carafe. I ordered the dark chocolate chip pancakes which were pretty good-i would give a 4/5. It would've been better if served with regular butter as opposed to the chocolate spread that they offer. The portion was pretty big-i was pretty hungry going into brunch and ate the whole thing but i was really full afterwards (i probably should've just ate part of it, oh well!). The atmosphere was casual and great for a mid day brunch with girlfriends. The service was pretty attentive. I would love to come back and try other items on the menu. My friends got the burger and the French toast and they loved their choices.

I LOVED the corned beef hash. It was amazing! Their hash browns are tiny round strings that are cooked perfectly crisp with onions in them. The corned beef was sliced perfectly, given out liberally and the perfect amount of salt to compliment the salt less hash browns without adding any. I ordered the eggs poached. It was heavenly. I had the pork and toffee milk shake and that was awesome!

The piggie thing did not agree with me. it reminded me of stomach bile and burned my throat and stomach like vomit when I ate it. I know that sounds so harsh, but it just really didn't sit well.

The elvis waffles were WAYYY overhyped online. They were good, but not great.

I know this is a critical review, but that's how I am about this kind of thing. I would go back for the corned beef hash. It was spectacular!

The extra star is for the service and ambiance. Our waitress was very sweet and cheery even early in the morning on a Friday. She wrapped up our to go lunches so we could eat them down at the air show practice without issue. Multiple members of the staff were available to grab us extra napkins, keep coffee topped off or just offer a friendly smile if eye contact was made.

The interior decor and spacious layout was very appreciated. Classy and tasteful. Open and clean. Very impressive.

We were visiting from California, a foodie friend had given us a list of restaurants to hit up. Little Goat was on the top of the list. Great atmosphere, def need reservations glad I made them. Somewhat Loud, hip dive-ish type place. Food is nothing short of spectacular. Everything sounded, looked and smelled. We loved our server Sarah great energy and genuine (she looked and spoke just like Emma Stone lol) I asked her what she liked and she was no help at all of course cause she confirmed that everything was amazing lol we went with the special Blue Plate salmon and my wife had pork belly with shrimp both on Sarah's recommendation. Absolutely delicious! Cooked to perfection! Will certainly be back again when we visit Chicago. Do yourself a favor and don't miss out!

pics.caption: Rad sky  light and RH chandelier at Little Goat

review.des: OMG so full!! Portion sizes are huge and the food is amazing. Definitely worth stopping by if you're in the area and worth the trip if you're not. It was pretty busy and Sean, our server, made sure we had everything we need as well as making awesome recommendations, despite how busy he was.

Love their food. I went their 3 time and every time I went to restaurant I'm not disappointed. They have a very good vegetarian option. Ask for their vegan menu the food is delicious. The restaurant decor is nice and comfortable. Their waiter is nice and friendly. I will definitely be back to restaurant again!!

Had the eggs and hash browns. My friend had the  French toast with chicken. Mine was good and simple. I only give 4 stars because they didn't have any chicken sausage or turkey sausage. But the hash browns were delicious. The French toast and the chicken were so good. Not sure if I would go back but it was good service.

I was super excited to come here for brunch last Sunday. The menu was a nice variety with creative items. I settled on the biscuits and gravy and home fries, while my friend got the Japanese pancake with pork belly. I was a bigger fan of her dish than mine, but loved my "little goat latte" which was made with goats milk. Service was good, but unfortunately our waitress disappeared at the end and we spent nearly 2 hours until we were able to cash out.

I honestly don't understand the fad about this place. Maybe I ordered the wrong things..first of all, I made a reservation 2 weeks in advance and I asked for a booth and the hostess said no. ALRIGHT THEN. I ordered the little goat latte... biggest mistake. That was the worst latte I've ever had and it had cumin??? Didn't like that at all. I then had sourdough pancakes and the hash browns. There was honestly nothing WOW about the pancakes or anything. It was okay and nothing special.

Parking, traffic, snow and ice... All of these are problems that will not keep me from going to the Little Goat Diner!

There are so many amazing sounding things on this menu, I could probably go every day for a month and not be bored.

While I never used to be a person who liked mixes of sweet and salty, the Bull's Eye French Toast dispelled that for me in one fell swoop. Eggs, crispy chicken, sweet onion brioche, and barbecue maple syrup all made for a fantastic combination.

The This Little Piggy Went to China was what my companion chose, and it couldn't have been better! I may actually have to get that the next time I'm there!

The tempura mashed potatoes and pork belly home fries were OK, but I think I would pass them up next time and try something else.

Definitely make a reservation, because even though we had one, we still ended up waiting a little bit. This place gets crazy crowded, and it's understandable as to why - the food is outstanding!
I really like this spot.  Came with wife  and daughter.    A little pricey for a diner but this is not really a diner.

Favorite lunch/brunch spot in the city. So many interesting menu options full of flavor!  The wait is never as long as they say when you show up on the weekends so that is always a nice surprise. We usually duck into Bar Siena and have a cocktail while we wait.

The cocktails here are different and yummy. My favorite dishes I've had are little piggy went to china as well as the fish tostadas. Full of flavor and so fresh always. It's nice to be able to share dishes just so you can try more things in one sitting.

This is a must try in West Loop!

As a huge fan of Girl and the Goat, Little Goat has been on my radar ever since it opened. It seemed like a more casual restaurant with a way broader menu that included breakfast stuff, sandwiches, tapas style snacks, and also heavier dishes. Little Goat was a place I wouldn't really plan ahead for and make reservations in advance like you have to for GaTG, which is probably why I haven't checked it out until now. Every time I would drop by to try to get a table there would be a huge wait, and with all the other great options on Randolph, it just never seemed worth it.

We were getting hungry late on a Friday night and took a stroll down to the West Loop to find some good late night eats. After finding out Grange Hall's kitchen was closed we just took a shot at Little Goat. Usually when passing by Little Goat I've come to just assume the wait is longer than I'm willing to deal with, but surprisingly we were seated immediately. I guess 11PM is a sweet spot.

Ambiance: The inside had that modern take on a classic dinner type of vibe. There were a bunch of booths and a lunch counter in front of the kitchen. Even the plates and condiments at the table reminded me of a diner-ish atmosphere.

Food: Since the menu was so big, there wasn't an obvious clear cut item to try that everyone was raving about. We just ended up ordering a bunch of stuff with a lot of meat in it haha.

Goat Almighty Burger - DAMN, is all I gotta say. All the signs of its enormity were there: it cost $20 and even the waiter flat out warned us that it was pretty big. Having some pretty large appetites though, we sort've just dismissed these clues. Let's just say we were pretty shocked when it was brought to our table. This monster of a burger had two skewers lodged in there just to keep it upright. It was just so tall that there was no other way to eat it besides fork and knifing the thing or eating the top and bottom halves separately.

Now I've had a full pound burger patty at other restaurants before but I think collectively all the meats in this thing outweighs it. The base was a goat burger patty with cheese on it. Ok, good start. Then throw on some braised beef. Then pile on a huge mound of pulled pork. And then just top it off with some jumbo onion rings. Just ridiculous. I can't even really pinpoint each ingredient individually. It was dark, I was drunk, and there was just a pile of meat in front of me. All I know is every bite of that sandwich was tender, juicy and delicious.

Sloppy Goat - It was good, but I probably wouldn't have been able to tell the difference if they swapped out the goat for beef. The slaw on top gave it a nice cooling flavor and a little bit of crunch. The bread was just great. Usually bread is just a silent component of a sandwich, but this roll really stood out in both texture and the way it meshed well with the other ingredients.

Fried Chicken - The chicken was actually really tasty. The skin/breading was very light and crunchy and did not at all have that greasy taste/texture. The meat was ultra juicy too. My only complaint is that it was a little on the small side. The breast seemed more like half the size of what you get at KFC/Popeyes. I wasn't the biggest fan of the coleslaw that was on the side, but it was topped with some delicious crunchy fried onions so it was ok.

Hash Browns - You can't go to a diner and not get any breakfast food, so I decided to throw these in there too. The potatoes were cut really thin and fried extra crispy, which is a plus for me. It didn't look very cheesy but that richness was felt with every bite (and the next morning too haha).

Overall, I enjoyed eating at Little Goat and would come back whenever the wait is reasonable. The food was solid all around, but it just didn't have that specialty item that really wowed me and has me specifically wanting to come back over and over again just to get it.
Great diner. Food was amazing. Highly recommend. Also located nearby breweries and other great spots

I've been wanting to go to The Girl and the Goat and cannot seem to get a reservation, Argh!  So, one Saturday morning, I was up and about in the city and decided to try my luck at Little Goat Diner.  I arrived ~8 or 8:30am and sat at the bar, no issues.  Since this was my first time here, I decided I had to try something different and special.  So, I ordered the Little Piggy Went to China and a Razzle Chai Latte.  The tea was thick and spicy, definitely not the type of chai latte you get at Starbucks, but it felt like an authentic spice mixture and I liked it for a treat.  The meal was very interesting...I don't even know how to describe it because it was such a perplexing mix of flavors.  The biscuit was like southern comfort yummy, the sausage had a nice Asian spice to it and the egg was cooked perfectly.  It had a thin spicy strawberry sauce on it which was very odd.  I kept eating it with each forkful and it intrigued, yet confused, my tastebuds.  Honestly, I'm glad I tried it, I didn't love it but I didn't necessarily dislike it, it was just a unique experience...I just don't know that I would order it again.  
That being said, it's clear Stephanie Izard is an extremely talented chef and I'm definitely interested in going back sometime to try some other stuff when I'm in the city.  Now, if only I can get that dang reso at The Girl and the Goat....

I've been wanting to come here for a while. I finally got a chance to come for dinner. I arrived around 5pm on Saturday and there was a table available immediately. The atmosphere is neat with an upscale cafe style appearance. It would be a good place to bring guests from out-of-town.

Service was good, but not excellent. The waiter was friendly and took our order quickly, but we didn't see him again until we had almost finished eating. Our food came within 15min of ordering.

The food was very good, but in my opinion, overpriced. I ordered the sloppy goat (a traditional sloppy joe with goat meat, slaw, and a homemade bun). It was $13 and fries were separate and cost another $6. The fries were not very crispy and a little salty for me.

You should expect to pay around $14 for sandwiches with no side item. Most breakfast items are $13-20.

It's a very unique restaurant with good food, but I think it's a little overrated. Given the fact that there are so many other good sandwich shops and breakfast places in town with better prices, I'm not sure if I will come back.

Stephanie Izard's a force in the Chicago culinary scene. Sure, she's the first female chef to win Top Chef. But more importantly, she's staked her culinary claim in the West Loop area of Chicago, which is certainly a dining hot spot. Chef Izard's got Girl and the Goat & Little Goat Diner amidst bastions such as Aviary & Next as well as Publican & Blackbird. And something's clearly going right in her kitchen, because both of her locations are regularly packed.

Case in point - I popped in for an early lunch during a week of conferencing in the city. And Little Goat was stuffed to the brim, whether diners were enjoying themselves al fresco or within. Little Goat is Chef Izard's upscale, yet unpretentious, diner. It features a wide gamut of classics with some culinary twists, many of which were Asian-inspired. I pulled up a seat at the counter, which offered a decent view of the kitchen at work.

Smoked Pork & Toffee Crunch Shake [$7]

I had to start off with this shake, considering my entire dining experience this trip was essentially a gustatory gamut of carnivorous delights. The foundation of smokiness was quite intense, but the sweet and salty elements of the toffee crunch helped to create some balance. There were small chunks of pork interspersed throughout the shake, which was tasty overall, but more gimmick for me than a must-order.

Pork Belly Pancake [$13]
Scallion pancake, house hoisin, bok choy salad, ginger maple dressing

On the other hand, you'd be hard pressed not to find me ordering this must-have dish. I appreciated that the Asian flavors weren't overtly in your face, but I found myself wondering how I wasn't indulging in an elevated Peking duck meal, supplanted with a crisp and hefty portion of pork belly. The gluttonous chew from the scallion pancake was on point and provided a nice textural contrast with the crisp bok choy slaw. The slaw which had just enough acidity to balance out the pork belly which was hidden beneath.

Well-crisped on the outside, it yielded to a trembling and unctuous cut of belly that was absolutely delicious. The ginger maple dressing helped to provide some sweet spice to counter the savory elements, while the fried wonton strips provided additional texture for each bite.  

Mac n Cheese [$7]
Camembert, cheddar

It's a safe bet that I'll always try the mac n cheese. This iteration featured sharp cheddar melded with creamy Camembert. The well-seasoned marriage lent itself to a creaminess that clung to the al dente shells, topped with crisp and buttery bread crumbs. Nothing wrong here.

Overall, I was impressed with Chef Izard's upscale diner. The menu is large, but considering the long hours it's open and the impressive crowds it pulls in, there's plenty to satiate a wide variety of appetites. The pork belly pancake is certainly a winner and has me salivating for my next trip back to Chicago. Girl & the Goat is now a must for me.

pics.caption: Hefty slab of pork belly underneath the bok choy slaw

review.des: I loved Little Goat Diner. The ambiance is bright/airy. The service is fast. The food is great. I was celebrating my birthday, and they treated me to a delicious cinnamon roll! I had the omelette of the day and it was huge. I tasted a bit of the apple pancakes, which were incredible. If I lived in Chicago I would come here all the time and try the whole menu.

Everybody seems to eat breakfast here but we stopped for dinner. The beef stew had deep flavor and the meat was very tender. The Korean burger was also outstanding with kimchi, bacon and an egg.
The menu had lots of items we'll be back for. Thank goodness for valet parking in an impossible neighborhood to park.

We were searching for a new breakfast spot and had not checked out Little Goat yet.  What a pair!  The atmosphere is upscale retro diner.  We split a smattering of entrées because so many sounded so good.  We went with This Little Piggy went to China - which had a great combination of savory and sweet flavors; the OKONOMIYAKI (which street did this food come from??) that was out of this world; the Bulls Eye French Toast (brioche French Toast meets egg in the hole delicious); the Bi Bim Bop (my vegetarian loved minus the bacon); the sourdough pancakes (teen boy devoured but tasted like ordinary pancakes to me) and a side of the park belly home fries (awesome).  What a great combination.  Everyone said - we have our new breakfast place!

One of the best diner places to go.
I love all the food that I ordered. (5-6dishes). Authentic food !!

Would originally give 5 stars but the last visit was incredibly disappointing. Service was very slow and was recommended the Bull's Eye French Toast. Husband LOVES the blueberry pancakes--they're awesome! The French Toast, however, was "disgusting" to quote my husband. It had a very odd day-old-Chinese-food sweet & sour aftertaste to it that was completely unwelcome. Don't get me wrong, I love Chinese/fusion food, but if I wanted that for breakfast, I would've ordered the Okonomiyaki or the Little Piggy dish. I just wanted French toast and it came heavy with that odd aftertaste.

The fat club is okay. The mac and cheese seemed quite flavorless/bland, goat sliders were meh. The smoked corned beef hash is excellent, as was their omelet at a prior visit.

tl;dr: only getting pancakes/hash/omelettes from now on.

Decent food! Always packed though so if you are hungry try a place at the bar! Service is extremely fast but the hash I had was mediocre at best. It was my first time there! So I am definitely coming in again and might even change my opinion about it!
The avocado toast here is insanely delicious. I dream about it. So flavorful, citrus-y, herby. And vegan! They have a separate vegan menu. Plus they're open all day. I love it here.

I had brunch here last Thursday to celebrate my birthday. The food was rich and the service was okay. We ordered the pork belly pancake, Rueben sandwich, fried pickles and onion rings, and the chocolate malt shake. The sandwich and pork belly pancake were good and we loved the shake. We didn't really like the fried pickles and onion rings.

As for the service, it was fairly solid up until the part when the server didn't check back with us soon enough. My water was empty and my mother's was near empty by the time the server came back around. It was hard to eat the rich food when there's nothing to wash it down.

Overall the experience was good and the prices were fair. Maybe I'll stop in again when I'm in town.

Consistently terrible customer service. Every server we have had is slow, inattentive, and gives major attitude. It doesn't matter if the food is good, Stephanie Izard really needs to shape a better environment in her restaurants. Clearly you can see that the experience made such a bad impression that it outranked anything else.

A great place for brunch or just getting a small bite to eat. I have been therefor brunch and the Fat Elvis Waffles are to die for. Most recently we went there for a quick lunch and as always the food was great. We had the Pork Porta sandwich and the Goat Chili soup. The sandwich was great and very tasty and the soup was also really good. We were there around 4 pm on a Monday and there wasn't any wait, but by the time we were leaving around 5 the place was starting to get really crowded for the happy hour specials. I would 100% recommend this place and plan to visit real soon.

pics.caption: Pork Porta sandwich and Goat Chili soup

review.des: Little Goat Diner is a spot that can appeal to many different tastes. I personally think it's a bit overrated. That being said, the prices are reasonable and not bad considering it's located in the heart of the West Loop. I've gotten several things from breakfast food to dinner items and overall have not been impressed.

If you don't want to wait months to eat at girl and the goat, little goat is the same chef but with more diner friendly foods.

Good spot for brunch or lunch / dinner.

No reservations so get ready to wait on weekends.
Great atmosphere. The tables in the bar side is more quiet compared to the front tables as not many people go to the back to have dinner. Food was delicious, and drinks were great! Very good place.

Made reservations for 2 on a Monday evening and was seated promptly. We got the Hot Crab Dip, Chicken Pot Pie, Scallops, and Lemon Buttermilk Cake. Everything was phenomenal. The first dunk of the ritz bitz crackers into the smothering hot crab dip was everything we wanted and more. Our server came by with another cup of crackers and brought more upon request. It was so creamy, cheesy and had so much CRAB! The Chicken Pot Pie and Scallops were both perfectly cooked and had great presentation. The Lemon Buttermilk Cake on their special menu...was to die for. It was the perfect blend of lemon, butter, and whipped cream. The house whipped cream was fluffy and light. Every crumb of the cake was gone when we finished.
The food here is always amazing and flavorful! I loved the crab dip and veggie enchiladas I got here last time. Beautiful outdoor seating as well!

Absolutely brilliant place all around.

Service was friendly, the ambiance/decor was beautiful and cozy, and the food was amazing.

Everything tasted fresh and you could tell that effort was put into every aspect of the dish.

My friend got the Fat Elvis Waffles and I got This Little Piggy Went to China.

Coming from Southwest China, I actually have a pretty good handle on what Szechuan food is supposed to taste like, and Little Goat hit the nail on the head with this one. Coupled with the biscuits and the sunny side egg, this dish was interesting and complex both taste-wise and texture-wise. The strawberries kind of threw me off though. I didn't really understand their purpose but I ate them anyway and tried not to question their existence.

I had some of the Fat Elvis Waffles too and they were delicious. Very rich and flavorful, but I'm not huge on sweets so it was not my first choice.

Little Goat is a diner-lovers dream come true!  Work friends brought me here for lunch yesterday and wow... just wow!  The atmosphere is bright and warm. The server was so friendly and welcoming. The menu was full of so many tempting delights. And since we were celebrating the completion of a project, we started with a craft cocktail. I had the Lapsang Peach Blossom - a sweet and boozy bourbon delight! We shared the warm crab dip with Ritz crackers - heaven!  And each of us tried a different lunch entrée.  I had the kale-chickpea salad - a very hearty and satisfying explosion of flavor, texture and color. It was amazing.  And then.... oh then..... we shared the Banana crème pie and it was quite simply the best thing ever. The crust was thick sugared graham cracker. The filling was decadent bananas in banana cream, topped with inches of fluffy whipped cream.  Have I already used the word heaven? Well, heaven it is. The menu promises so many more delights. I eagerly await the chance to escape here again soon!

If you want some amazing brunch food, check this place out.
I give this place a 4.5 stars because it was truly a very delicious meal.

I had the - This Little Piggy Went to China - $14.00
Sesame cheddar biscuit. Sunny eggs. Szechuan pork sausage. Chili garlic chive sauce. blackberries
The chili sauce was delicious and really made the sausage even better. the eggs were a delicious mess and the biscuit was crispy/fluffy/perfect. the blackberries i thought was genius! added a great sweet and tart element to the dish. The only downside i thought was that the dish overall was a little bit too salty. (not inedible, but definitely makes you drink water or wish you had some other dish to eat it with)

i will definitely be back when i'm in chicago and i hope to try the many other items on the menu.

great food!
highly recommended

This place is amazing. Got a booth for 5 people on a Saturday and we got seated right away as soon everyone arrived. We go a bunch of things off of the menu. They have a chickpea fritters salad which is kinda like the chickpea fritters at girl and the goat

So, the food here is delicious. We found this place from Yelp reviews and word of mouth. We went on a Sunday at prime time and were told it was a 40 minute wait- long story short- 50 minutes later, they seated people that came after us, before us. When we brought this to their attention, they seated us immediately, sent us their cinnamon bun, and comped our entire meal. THAT is what I call customer service. When you make a mistake (which was understandable but frustrating, you make up for it. Because of that, we would go back. The food was delicious. GET THE HASH BROWNS with cheese. Best hash browns I've ever had. The coffee is delicious too. Everything we had was amazing- but those hash browns.....get them!

Littel Goat is my second favorite Izard restaurant but its style and quality make it an easy 5 star joint! Like Girl & the Goat and Duck Duck Goat, Izard masterfully works in unique ingredients that will simply "Wow" you. A diner in name and ethos this is, but there is nothing plain and simple about it. Come for the giant goat burger and return for the amazing milkshakes:)

It's a diner, but kicked up a notch and a half. There is something resembling most of your diner favorites on the menu, but it will cost more, and be... elevated. You'll also see things nothing like what you'd see in a normal diner. I've been here a few times and always tried something different, and I've never been disappointed. Some faves are the Los Drowned (very messy, and watch out for some pieces of fat), the BBQ Pork and Tonkatsu. The sandwiches are generally large, but word of warning: they are a la carte. The smoked fries are pricey at $7, but they are enough for at least two people. In true diner fashion, you can order breakfast all day.

They take reservations, and I suggest you make them. It gets pretty busy here, for good reason!

This place was excellent!  Casual, lower costs mixed with unique dishes.  My brother had a Bahn Mi burger, and I had a braised beef style sandwich with excellent toppings.  The apps are also great... Fried pickles and onions are highly recommended due to their perfect clean batter and nice big slices.  Good selection of drinks as well, and bar in the back if you don't want to wait to be seated. Situated close to other attractions in the area.

So very cool place, make a reservation if you want to have lunch. I had a Rueben, would have done something different if I went there again after seeing what others were eating but it was good.  They Club sandwich looked amazing and the chicken salad was what I should have gotten. We got some pork belly fries, these were amazing, low carb diet out the door.
Very Good BBQ and corn bread was the Booomb!!! Friendly staff thanks for serving my family!

Only got takeout here, but the restaurant itself is beautiful. I love the upscale diner feel of this place. Got the pork belly pancakes and they were delicious! I also like that the other side of the restaurant has a bar and coffee shop if you want to grab a quick drink or browse some of their pastries.

One of the best brunches I've ever had.

// LOCATION // West Loop by Au Cheval and by the same chefs as Girl and the Goat.

// SERVICE // Great. The waitress was super chill, but was very prompt and helpful

// WAIT // Nonexistent on a Wednesday morning

// FOOD //
    + Orange Juice: Freshly squeezed, pulp-y and memorable enough to write about
    + Bull's Eye French Toast: Soft, fluffy french toast with tender chunks of fried chicken. Great if you love the salty/sweet combo
    + Smoked corned beef hash with eggs: Eggs any way you like it with savory corned beef and crunchy hash. It is an American breakfast done right.

If you cannot get seated at Girl and the Goat, Little Goat is definitely worth a try.

pics.caption: Smoked corned beef hash with eggs

review.des: Another overpriced overrated restaurant in Chicago. I tried several items including the cinnamon roll and french toast. If it were just a regular diner I would say its fine for what it is. For how much they charge! Not impressed!
Just wow. Everything about this Diner is astounding. The food, the drinks, the mood, the music, the lighting, and overall a great time. Go for breakfast, lunch, or dinner. You won't regret it.

The food is great for breakfast, a cute coffee shop next door to bide your time in while you wait. Parking can be a pain but does not effect my review. I wish they a bit more savory choices but I would recommend the bullseye French toast. There is communal seating as well so be sure to specify you preference.

Little Goat is an upscale American diner that serves breakfast all day.  However, this is not a gimmick.  This is a truly great restaurant that serves up elevated breakfast dishes in a cool setting with several great touches that remind you the old great American diners.

My Overall Rating - 4 1/2 Stars (Atmosphere, Service, Food, Return)

Atmosphere - You see the words Diner on its windows, but the Little Goat feels like a nice upscale restaurant.  But what you'll find is they've woven the diner theme all throughout the restaurant.  Look around and you'll see classic round barstools, tables with metal trim, plenty of booth space, and plenty of coffee cups.  It's a great concept that fits the breakfast all day theme perfectly.  1 Star.

Service - Our server was friendly & attentive, and was great tending to our needs.  But the restaurant was packed on a Wednesday night, and we had to flag him down a few times.  Service was delayed, but this is really due to how busy they were.  When available, our server was sure to get our orders in and did a great job following up.  Bonus, he made a few great recommendations from the huge menu that turned out to be table pleasers.  1/2 Star.

Food - Breakfast is the most important meal of the day, and if it's your favorite it can be ordered all day!  We started with the nachos - but we had no idea what we were getting into.  We received a huge platter of homemade chips topped with pulled pork, beans, cheese, avocado, and plenty of other healthy toppings.  If you order this, make sure you have at least 4 people in your family to share.  But I was here for breakfast, so of course I order the Bullseye French Toast.  This French toast dish comes topped with fried chicken, egg, and of course BBQ Maple Syrup.  Sweet/Salty/Soft/Crunchy/Yes/Delicious.  And since we're eating at a diner, of course we order the Betterfinger sundae.  All you need to know is it comes with chocolate covered cheez-its.  Bottom line, not only did Little Goat's food surprise me, but the menu & dishes were whimsical and delicious.  2 Stars.

Will I Return? - Yes.  I'm a sucker for diners.  Throw in one that serves creative breakfast all day and crazy desserts - no doubt I'll return to the great Little Goat.  Just beware they do get busy, but when you're the best at what you do people will come.  1 Star.

My Yelp Rating Scale (Sum of all parts):
1 Star - Atmosphere - Is it a cool dive?  Perhaps an upscale place?  No matter the type, atmosphere plays a big part and I'll give a star if I like it or thinks it has great charm.
1 Star - Service - You can have a great meal with bad service.  But that's also what can make a five star joint drop to four.  It's important to the dining experience that service is great and on point.
2 Stars - Food - I'll award up to two stars for the food, since this is the main reason we dine out.  Sometimes the extra star is given for value, but it's really all about the food.
1 Star - Will I come back? - If I know for a fact I'll return, I'll give this a star. A place has to make an impression for me to return.

Each Category can be given up to 1 star except food (2 stars) because I consider all these categories important to the overall dining experience.  I will sum them up to provide my final Yelp score.

The food was actually more of a 3.5 star and normally would round up, but rounded down due to service...

Here's the service rant so skip this (rather long) paragraph if you just care about the food.... Came in for brunch, had a little wait so grabbed coffee next door at little goat bread and was seated shortly after... During this time, the coffee lid had popped off twice spilling really hot coffee so when we sat down I asked for a mug that I could pour my coffee into.  The waiter grabs my cup and walks off with it and reappears several minutes later with two coffee mugs with black coffee (note my friend didn't order coffee and I really just wanted the full cup of coffee I had just bought in a mug).  He sets the mugs in front of us and walks off.... So several minutes later when he walks by again I ask for milk and sugar and he's like fine but there's sugar right in front of you and before I can clarify that I wanted the fake stuff he walked away again.  Came back again several minutes later with the milk and I asked him for the truvia which took another few minutes to grab a couple packets of sugar... Rinse and repeat this several minute long fiasco for a second time with coffee refills, during which time he told me he heard me ask for milk (even though he walked by several times and never bothered to drop it off). Basically I had cold coffee with breakfast with a side of major attitude, and messing with coffee in the morning is like messing with alcohol during happy hour, it's just not done.  If he hadn't been so dismissive and a little nicer I probably would have given him a pass since I've been on the other side of the counter and understand the breakfast rush, but he seriously put a damper on my Saturday morning.

Moving on to the food, had a really good omelette of the day with eggplant and scallions (and I don't even like  omelettes...) Topped with fried onions that were a surprisingly yummy contrast in texture.  Would have been nice to know that it doesn't come with anything (i.e. toast) but wasn't about to wait another 10 min for the waiter to walk by again to order some...

Overall, food was good (not surprising as I really like most of Izard's places), but waiter sucked... Will say the hostesses were nice enough and the reason the stars stayed at 3 and not lower...

pics.caption: Omelette of the day with eggplant caponata, scallions and herbed cream cheese

review.des: Man this place is great! I'm eating "this little piggy went to China" weird name but great food.

We were excited to try out Little Goat Diner after a enjoying a great meal at the Girl and the Goat. We waited for 30 minutes on a Sunday night for an indoor seating - it is possible to make reservations, although it's not a long wait. I may have expected too much from the Little Goat, expecting it to be more of a twist on diner food. But I felt like the food I had there was very much like diner food and not much more :( We had the fries with cheese and goat chili ($12) and the "Patty Melt" with the veggie patty ($14). The fries and goat chili were good, but it didn't blow my mind. Then, the patty melt was so anti-climatic, it was literally a sandwich with a piece of cheese, the veggie burger patty and some onions inside. The veggie burger didn't taste anything special and the whole "Patty Melt" felt like something I could have slapped together at home in 3 minutes.

Our server was really sweet, but the overall food was a disappointment. I have heard though that their brunch is good so maybe I will come back to try that - hopefully that doesn't disappoint.

pics.caption: Cheesy fries with goat chili on the side (12$)

review.des: Little Goat has been on my list to try since moving to Chicago. I was expecting to be wow'ed and I just wasn't as impressed as I thought or hoped I would be! When you walk in, it's definitely a diner feel, but a bit nicer. We had 9pm reservations, but they didn't have any tables ready, so we headed to the back where the bakery/bar/coffee bar were located to grab a drink.   The bartender was a bit snotty in my opinion - corrected me twice in the name of the drink... I ordered the "1.21 Gigawatts" and apparently it's really important to him that you include the numbers when ordering. Either way, I thought the drink was OK - kind of on the overly sweet side. We were seating about 15-20 mins later at a booth. One person in our group brought some wine bottles - there's a 25 dollar corking fee and our waitress was awesome and only charged it once for two bottles - super nice. I ordered the patty melt with the veggie burger and it was tasty, just greasy and it wasn't anything super special. We also got onion rings and fried pickles for the table - when I picked one up, it was literally dripping in oil - not that appetizing for me. Overall, I wasn't really impressed and likely won't be back any time soon.

The menu was incredibly creative and we were seated relatively quickly without a reservation. However, all members of my party were a little disappointed with what we got. While GOOD, it was missing the little "something-something" that the menu implied. We may have just all gotten the wrong thing, but it was a little bit of a let down (especially considering the cost!)

It's supposed to be diner food kicked up a few notches. Way better than that. Delicious! The staff is nice and friendly too. Our waiter, Carl, gave good suggestions. We were glad we ordered what he suggested. So good!

pics.caption: Shrimp and goat cheese grits. Added a poached egg on top, biscuit on the side. Delicious!

review.des:
Cute place, funny menu, and delicious food - no complaints. Probably need a reservation.
It looks like they might have a rotating cocktail menu, but HIGHLY recommend the crayon grenade, so good.

Little Goat Diner is an interesting place with interesting food. I came here for breakfast. However, you don't have to come during breakfast to try their breakfast food. They serve breakfast all day. So wake up late and wander in at around 3 PM to eat their breakfast.

They have some creative dishes for their breakfast. One of the ones that intrigued me was the "This Little Piggy Went to China." It's basically a biscuit, eggs, and sausage with Sichuan flavoring.

I tried it and it was great. I loved the chili garlic chive sauce. It was nice and spicy. The biscuit, eggs, and sausages were done well too.

The Fat Elvis Waffles is a great option if you want something more traditional. The bacon maple syrup was decadent and good. How can you go wrong with bacon and maple syrup?

For lunch, I tried their Reuben. I liked it with the kimchi. Being Korean, I love adding kimchi to salty meats like Corned Beef. I think it's better than using sauerkraut. The bread and meat were excellent as well.

The Chickpea salad was good. It was a salad. But it looked like they added some falafels in it, along with fresh chickpeas. I thought that was a nice touch. I don't know if they were falafels, but it looked and tasted like one. And they are made with chickpeas, so why not?

Overall, this is a solid diner in Chicago. If you want some great breakfast food, try this place.

Honestly, wtf? I've been here twice & both times I've left with a tummy ache, bitterness & regret. 1. Bloody Mary is awful & aggressive, flavors are down right gross. 2. Chicken & waffles are so DRY & bland, with no flavor or creative seasoning/ sauce nothing to help it. It was like eating sand with flavorless chicken skin & bone. 3. I ordered a classic breakfast: eggs, bacon, sausage, toast.. I ate a plate of pure drenched grease with no seasoning or "creativity" for the price I paid. Even the bacon was just whatever which tastes way better served at publican even though it's supposed to be the same. The entire menu is screaming "I'm trying too hard" with more attention with adding random ingredients to dishes as opposed to caring about FLAVOR!
Honestly, you're paying for the name of a chef, polite staff & a nice atmosphere.. NOT THE FOOD.

Great service and food!
Was visiting Chicago and decided to check it out. The hashbrowns were the best. Enjoyed our brunch there

Really hard to go wrong with Little Goat. Came for breakfast and the Bullseye French Toast hits the spot. Perfect combination of sweet and savory with toast, eggs, chicken, and syrup. The biscuit and gravy is also worth trying. Crispy biscuit and meaty gravy.

Little Goat continues to set the bar

Came here for brunch, and it was amazing. I had a spicy bloody mary, hash browns, the broccoli, and the breakfast burrito thing on naan. The hash browns weren't super special, but tasted good. The "not Chinese broccoli" was amazing. The burrito was SO GOOD too-- it wasn't like a breakfast burrito at all-- it was like a yummy salad on naan. I'll definitely come back. Good vegetarian options.

This place is super cute. The staff seems friendly and greets everyone with a smile. Which is super nice because I came here alone. And Sarah was great. She answered my questions and was very sweet.

I got a drink - the fernet about it.  It's delicious and STRONG. Well for the money, $12, it better be. It has a good flavor and I recommend it if you're stopping in. Maybe not the best thing for me at three in the afternoon, but eh, sue me.

My parathas burrito is fantastic!! It's so delicious I wish I could have one vey day. There are maybe a few too many peppers for my taste, but they give a good kick. He salad on top is spicy, but a good spicy, not a 'I wanna cry spicy'. Nice large portion. You'd be hard pressed to leave hungry if you manage to finish this dish. I loved the Indian bread. The whole thing was delicious. But it needed more guacamole. There was just a tiny dollop underneath the salad. It would have been nice to have more.
Simply Amazing. Huge fan of the duck fried rice. It's a unique taste  that you won't get anywhere else in the city.
This place is so cute and quaint!! Check out the little goat bar & barista that is attached next door!!

Great place for everyone, including families/kids. The food is always good, some of our favorites:  Fat Elvis Waffles, Fish Tostadas, Smoke Fries, Vegan Home Fries (TONS of vegan options!) and the French Dip.

If you're from out of town, do not miss this spot!  There's usually a wait, but they move people through quickly.  Espresso drinks are awesome, hit the coffee bar while you wait.

Shout out to Sophie, barista extraordinaire, and servers Minty and Becca. We are always taken good care of at the Goat!

Wanted to come here after the excellent experience at girl and the goat

Honey I'm back 2/5 Way too strong and not sweet enough

Shrimp and grit 4/5 the portion is small and a bit on the Watery side but they were really generous on the amount of shrimp. Overall I really like it. Just wish that it's more filling.

Brussels sprout 5/5 crunchy and delicious I can finish the whole plate by myself

Smoke pork toffee shake 5/5 it's very pricy for a Starbucks grande size shake to be $8 but it's so so so good~ you don't really taste the pork at all. It's not salty and tastes more like a toffee shake

Staff 5/5 excellent recommendation, very fast in bringing food, taking check,...everything... best crew I have encountered for the week I stayed at Chicago

This restaurant will be on my list everytime I come to Chicago:)

AMAZING! Girl & the goat's chef just does everything and does it so deliciously. Make sure you make reservations even on a weekday during the day. My favorites - "this little piggy went to china" and any of their burgers...a must go in chicago!

pics.caption: This little piggy went to china! Sichuan province to be exact :P

review.des: Had the corned beef hash and a cup of coffee. Yea Mon ! I'll be back here for sure, the CBH was really good, coffee also damn good.  Several friends have advised me to try other menu items.

Made reservations with friends in advance to try this place I had heard great things about. Had a little trouble deciding between the Bahn Mi burger and the fish tostadas, but I hadn't had tostadas since before I was in the womb, so I decided right as I placed my order. The taste was pretty good, a little bit heavy to my surprise, but the flavor was quite unique: there was a nice balance of tang, richness and crispness from the cilantro. Will be back to try the Bahn Mi burger!

Very pretty dining room and very hospitable staff. But the food was very disappointing. Going in with no expectations, the food was nothing to smile about. I had a bite of the Reuben, scallion pancake pork belly, goat chili, crumpets, crab dip and more. Everything was very salty.
The tastiest aspect was the salad on top of the pancake.
I admire the effort and creativity. But the food just wasn't good.

pics.caption: Crab dip, chili, Reuben. Everything was over salted. Fun place but not very tasty.

review.des:
I can't tell you what the food was like or how quickly I was seated because I left before I could get to the hosts arrival.
The reason. I parked outside...three spaces easily. The parking valet asked for my keys and $16. I pointed out that you don't need a valet parking when your car is 10ft from the door. His belligerent look and facial tics convinced me this was going nowhere. I left and I won't be back. Robbery from a highly rated restaurant is never on my menu.

I couldn't get reservations to "Girl and the Goat" so I thought we would try this. I kept an open mind and found that for a diner it's an A+, Good food! But I guess I just couldn't tell what vibe they were trying to give. The food was priced according to the area but it was just the atmosphere... An upscale diner???

We ordered the nachos... It's made with bbq pork, I guess it's more of a preference... it was still good but I prefer beef or chicken. The Mac and Cheese was delicious! My husband ordered the patty melt. Very generous portions and made perfectly medium. The fries were crisp and seasoned well.  We also ordered the shrimp app as well. It really didn't do much for us... It was basically just presentation.

There were other options on the menu that we wanted to try but we will have to do it on our next visit. We will definitely be back.  Service was friendly and attentive.

pics.caption: Has a nice kick, made with BBQ pork.

review.des: The food was delicious and priced moderately.  The service was friendly and helpful. We waited for 20 mins. for our seats - on a weekend, which isn't bad.  We ordered Hot crab dip, brussels sprouts, Mushroom Ragout and fish tostadas. It's a casual place to have dinner with friends.  The atmosphere and decor is okay.., nothing unique or interesting, but not your greasy diner either.

Excellent sandwich and fries! To be honest, it was out of this world. Would definitely go back. The only reason it is not five stars is because I felt a little rushed, but that's okay because it was packed on a Saturday afternoon. Make sure to make a reservation so you don't have to wait.

Little Goat, a walk away from Girl and the Goat, is a little less fancy, but you can go here without making a reservation(huge plus)! The first thing I noticed is that the place the cutest inside! Someone once told me that Chicago restaurants have the best decor, and I do believe it. It reminds me of a diner, but a little more modern with dainty chandeliers and lights and adorable patterned wallpaper. The service here is especially great! Our server was very happy to be there for us as it was our first time.

Hot crab dip: one of my favorite foods the entire night! Hot crab dip encased by ritz crackers is the perfect little tasting for the entrees. I wish we had ordered more of these! We ate it so fast, it looks like we fought over it.

I had the hash and eggs: not too shabby, but I think I was already pretty full from the crab dip. I did like their house hot sauce to go along with it, but I don't think it was hot enough for me!

Special fish: my friend has this and she really liked how flavorful the fish was, but I think she mentioned she wish it came with a rice or pasta.

Fried chicken: my favorite entree! Fried to perfection with just the right amount of crunchy and salty.

Mashed potatoes and mac and cheese were pretty standard in my book.

Horchata smoothie: YES that's exactly what I wrote! Don't think about it, just order it - trust me!

A haiku:

8 AM - you'd think
you beat the crowd, but moms with
strollers win again

Chicago. Day 6. Breakfast diner.

Maple chorizo crumpets - 5/5
This little piggy went to china - 4/5
Bullseye french toast - 4/5

Overall, this place is awesome. "As good as it gets."

So happy you're able to make reservations on Open Table! Makes the whole process go so nice and quick. Our service was amazing and attentive. I had the bulls eye French toast. And it was the perfect combo between sweet and savory. Will be back for sure!

Went tonight to get lattes. Worst service I have ever had. The way the barista was looking while we were asking was just not cool. Then she didn't close the lid of the latte off. So when I went to grab my coffee it spilled every where. Another waiter comes and sees the mess I'm cleaning with my husband and friend and doesn't even take a second to ask if everything is ok or if we need help. I asked the barista to get a napkin and cup to because my latte is all spilled and she didn't even acknowledge it. She just gave me an empty cup and walked away. From what I had left in my latte it wasn't even good. I will definitely never ever come back here after this service. Horrible

I thought I took a pic of the incredible shrimp and grits but I must have eaten it too fast.  Seriously fantastic.  Lots of fresh shrimp, mouth watering sauce, and cream grits.  Excellent portion.  The little goat latte was innovative with masala and caramel.  The hash-browns were the best I've had, chopped finely like little noodles.  Don't think twice about dining here.  Open table takes reservations!
Really fun and unique atmosphere. The Almighty Goat burger was incredible, although hard to finish in one sitting!

This is place is awesome, stopped by for brunch with the family. The batter for the chicken tenders...man oh man are those chicken tenders so good! The braised beef (los drowned) was what I ordered and I'm coming back for more. Wife had the sloppy goat and it was just okay, but we enjoyed our visit.

Repeat customer here for sure.

Awesome food for both breakfast and dinner. Great diner feel and not too long of a wait usually. "Classy diner" i think would be my best description.

Some of our favorites when we go include the Sloppy Goat, Los Drowned Sandwich, Bullseye French Toast, and the Coffee is great too!

Haven't been up on the roof before, but that looks really cool too

We made a special trip to the west loop for lunch at Little Goat Diner, and it was so worth it! It was crowded and loud inside, so we were happy to get a table outside.  I had the parathas burrito which was unusual and tasty- two fried eggs were tucked into the delicious Indian flat bread.  The bread was thin and sort of grilled so the outside was crispy. It's topped with some greens, red beans, and a just a hint of spicy sauce. I loved it. I also tasted the shrimp and grits which were great - delicate and deep in flavor, it was really well executed. We had the pork belly home fries which was good and a chocolate malt shake which was also good. The portion sizes are hearty, so the fries and shake were a bit over the top. I totally recommend this place for friendly service and yummy food!
The wait was a little long, but we luckily were able to grab two seats at the bar. The bartender was so knowledgeable and the service was awesome. The food was fantastic- definitely recommend!

pics.caption: Everything is Everything Crumpets- unique and delicious take on bagel and lox!

review.des: This place did not disappoint. I shared a Los Drowned and the Tonkatsu. They were both good but the Los Drowned was my favorite by far. The beef on it is crazy tender and the break is so soft the sandwich pretty much melts in your mouth. We got the corn side, which was delicious, and the pork belly home fries. I'd recommend both!

Came here for brunch last weekend with my in-laws and it did not disappoint. Menu has a lot of interesting twists on it with ingredient combinations that I would have never thought to put together. Since we didn't know where to start we asked for recommendations and were not led astray.

I got the "This little piggy went to China" and was blown away with how flavorful it was. Somehow a cheddar biscuit, sausage, a sunny side up egg, strawberries, and an savory Asian sauce complimented each other perfectly. Our party also enjoyed the Bull's eye French toast and the Parathas burrito. We grabbed and donut at the attached bakery/cafe and will definitely be back.
Can't wait to try out Girl and the goat and Duck duck Goat! Stephanie Izard is a culinary wizard!

Overall, I was really disappointed with Little Goat Diner. We came here after learning that both Girl & The Goat and Au Cheval had 2+ hour waits, and we were starving. Unfortunately, even our hunger could not disguise the quality of the food. :(

+ Chocolate Goat Milk - I was really excited for this because I love goat products, but this tasted like chocolate cow milk. I felt very silly paying so much for what basically tastes like normal chocolate milk.

+ Crab Dip - The dip wasn't bad flavor-wise (arguably the best thing we got here) but even though the dish was hot, the dip inside was still cold. It was definitely full of crabmeat and was tasty, but it would've been exponentially better if it had been warm. The crackers on the side were basically Ritz crackers - very uniform and buttery. The waitress kindly offered us a second batch of crackers when she noticed that we were low, but the second batch was all super crumbly and fragile; they all broke immediately when we tried to dip them.

+ All-American Burger - Their special sauce tastes remarkably like McDonald's special sauce. The resemblance to a Big Mac flavor-wise was utterly uncanny. It tastes good, but that was really strange ... unless they mean to imply that McDonald's represents "All-American"?

+ Shrimp, Pork Belly, Zucchini and Shrimpy Noodles - Aside from the tender, tasty pork belly, this was unpalatable. I was shocked by this horrible rendition of an Asian-inspired dish (would not have gotten it if it had said that on the menu) - the noodles and veggies were drowning in ginger and soy sauce. The shrimp was overcooked and the veggies were ruined by the overpowering sauce.

The crab dip was very filling, which was a good thing because I really could not make myself eat the shrimp/pork belly disaster that I got. I probably should've stuck with something goat, so I guess that's my fault. Service was very slow.

On the plus side, there is a Pokemon Gym here; I battled it and raised it several levels while waiting for our food.

After trying The Girl & the Goat on my last trip to Chicago, I was very eager to try Little Goat, mostly because it was a little bit more focused on diner comfort food, and also didn't require long waits or reservations months in advance.

Little Goat has the feel of a modern diner, and it seems to attract both tourists and locals alike. The menu has all the diner offerings you could want: breakfast items, sandwiches, burgers, appetizers, and supper items. Yet, all of these dishes seem to be a twist on their respective classic versions. We ordered the goat patty melt, pork belly pancake, and the Korean goat burger. I wasn't pleased that the burgers didn't come with fries, but we ordered a side of the smoked fries, and they were great. The potatoes were cut just right, and the smokey flavor was pretty addicting. The patty melt was awesome, with just the right amount of goat to bread, and the pickles provided the sourness and crunchiness. The pork belly pancake was well-balanced with the vegetables and pork belly. The Korean goat burger came with an egg on top, which was super rich and delicious.

Our waiter was very friendly and helpful with recommendations, but seemed to forget about our table at times. Prices are fine, although again, I think the sandwiches/burgers should come with fries. Just a pet peeve of mine. I really would like to try the Goat Almighty, which is the colossal goat burger with BBQ pork, braised beef, and onion rings, and many other toppings. One of these days, I will bring the full power that is my appetite.

Overall, the creativity and the quality of food will keep me coming back to try all their offerings. For a casual, yet elevated meal in the Fulton Market area, you cannot go wrong with Little Goat.

pics.caption: This little piggy went to China. So good.

review.des:
I loved the decor and food here ! Our service was okay... not bad or particularly good. Server seemed kind of "over it" - but I really enjoyed my experience overall.

I had a veggie burger with a side of their famous hash brows. The veggie patty was really good! I didn't feel like I was "missing out" on meat.

The hash browns are awesome ! They are shredded into tiny strings and served crispy (not greasy) with white cheese on the inside ! So good.

And they have two really good house made hot sauces. I would go back

They have an interesting Asian twist on their menu. I didn't order anything with an Asian twist, but I ordered the corned beef hash. The corned beef was more of a pastrami, but the hash browns were really good!

Fair warning, my review is quite biased and I've only been here once. That one experience was not the typical patron's experience, as it was for a private event held upstairs. I was not responsible for the arrangements, so I can't even speak to whether this restaurant creates these menus for each event or what. I don't see any of the dishes I enjoyed in the pictures or the current menu. But... y'all. It's so worth it to call and ask.

When I lived in Chicago, I frequented G&tG as much as possible. Big fan who only got bigger after every visit. During a recent visit to Chicago, I was especially excited to have been invited to a private event held at this location. Let me describe some of the highlights so you can all be jealous:

The assortment of fresh baked breads, including an olive loaf and a parmesan crisp. These paired perfectly with the sriracha butter and the goat liver mousse. Other starter dishes included a PHENOMENAL tuna poke. I tried to restrict myself to one piece of bread, but... well. I couldn't.

A sea scallop served with a blueberry nuoc cham and all these other bits of delicious goodness. My dining companions and I all looked at each other after finishing the actual scallop and we lifted the bowls to our mouths and drank that sauce. Yes we did.

at this point of this chef tasting menu, I was so very thankful that I had had the foresight to wear stretchy clothes. THANK YOU MAXI DRESS.

A perfectly cooked salmon served family style (with a szechuan chile sauce, veggies, and a yogurt sauce) was divine. Had a crisp layer at the top but was perfectly flaky and tender inside. Bowls of a green curry roasted pork shank. I don't know where a shank comes from, but these were some big ol meaty bones that melted in my mouth. At no point was a knife needed. (There was def some parsley or cilantro in this dish, and I hate them both. But it was so good, I didn't care. I went back for seconds and thirds).  

We were treated to a shared plate of vanilla malt gelato, served with crunchy caramel popcorn and chocolate magic shell. Individual tiny mason jars of gelee with blueberries, topped with sour cream whip and crunchy meringue. These two desserts were a contrast in sweet and rich vs light and refreshing.

TL;DR: I had an atypical experience and food at this restaurant due to special event. Each dish blew my mind in the complex flavor combinations that left me wanting more. Service was friendly, non-intrusive, and impeccable. GO GET YOU SOME GOAT.

pro tip: upstairs dining room/event room has a GORGEOUS rooftop.

We wanted to avoid typical diner food so this was a cool change up with a slightly Asian twist on some of the traditional brunch items! We shared goat chili and tempura mashed potatoes - the goat chili was great, although I didn't think the mashed potatoes were THAT interesting (it's fried mashed potatoes. Of course it'll taste good).

I got the Los Drowned (I think) sandwich which was basically beef brisket, havarti, avocado and lots of other yummy ingredients in a hoagie - plus a dipping sauce. The sandwich was great and we were absolutely stuffed by the end. Slightly on the pricey side but really yummy food!

Let me first start off by saying the portion sizes are unbelievable.  Considering the quality you're getting, the dishes are worth two meals and you will probably be taking home leftovers.  This restaurant is part of the "goat" group so you know the meal is gonna be good.  They offer the breakfast menu all day so no worries about missing out on a brunch.

We ordered the jerk chicken and sloppy goat sandwiches, both huge and delicious.  But just sitting at the bar area we could see various dishes coming out of the open kitchen like the mound of salads, various Asian dishes, and exceptionally tasty-looking mac and cheese.

If you can't get into Goat & Girl, and just want to experience some of the chef's dishes at a reasonable price right next door, give this place a try.  I would surely bring out-of-towners here for a nice, filling brunch.

I was in Chicago for a friend's wedding and was able to carve out some time to explore one of my favorite cities in America. I've been a fan of Stephanie Izard ever since she appeared on Season 4 of Top Chef in 2008 where she went on to win it all. During this trip, I was determined to eat at either Girl and the Goat or Little Goat, which were conveniently right across the street from each other. My friends and I couldn't get a table at Girl and the Goat so we opted for Little Goat. This cool, laid-back diner was buzzing with the sounds like a classic 50's diner. (I'm only imagining since I wasn't born in the 50's.) The menu was an interesting fusion of diner food with lots of Asian influences like Kimchee Bacon & Eggs, Parathas Burrito, Chinese Chicken Sandwich and a Bahn Mi Style Burger.

At the time, I was on a strict eating regiment so my options were narrowed pretty quickly. I ended up getting a faux noodle dish - Tofu Noodles with Spring Peas, Peanuts and Chilies in a Blueberry Szechuan Sauce. I've eaten of these ingredients at some point in my ongoing culinary quest around the country, but I've never eaten them all together in one flavor exploding bowl. The tofu noodles were incredible to the point that I forgot that they were made of tofu. The spring peas and and peanuts added great textural contrast. The Blueberry Szechuan Sauce brought everything together in a fantastically tangy and spicy way. The creativity and balance was executed perfectly. I would challenge any tofu-haters to try it. It completely changed my perspective on tofu and I'd imagine it would change many others' too.

Overall, the food is great with a sense of creativity that's unique to Stephanie Izard. The service was fast and pleasant. My friends enjoyed themselves too. Everything was a perfect from start to finish. Based on this visit, I hope to make time for Girl and the Goat during my next visit to Chi town.

pics.caption: Tofu Noodles with Spring Peas, Peanuts and Chilies in a Blueberry Szechuan Sauce

review.des:
Since it's nearly next to impossible to drop into The Goat and the Girl, my Chicago neighbors took us to Little Goat so that I could try the tasty offerings of Janes Beard award winning chef Stephanie Izard.

The space has a lovely open air feel with outdoor seating that lines the sidewalk.  We sat next to a huge window in a spacious booth offering plenty of opportunity to people watch.  The seats were a bit worn and torn in some places but it is a diner.

It's difficult to choose your meal as everything sounds delicious and in an incarnation you're familiar with but better.  So you've had French toast but bit garlic brioche French toast!  I ordered that with crispy chicken and strawberries.  My friends ordered a juicy cheeseburger and the tastiest fries I've had in a while.  We also ordered fried pickles.  Way to indulge!

All worth it though.  If Chicago didn't have so many restaurants, I. would absolutely go back.  Service is decent and prices are on the high side of reasonable.  Expect to spend around $30 for breakfast if you want apps or a cocktail.

pics.caption: The French Toast and Crispy Chicken.

review.des:
Wow.

Like, I knew Little Goat Diner was going to be good. The fact that the food is good should not surprise anyone with a yelp! account at this point. It shouldn't...

and yet, my first bite of that Reuben.

Let's revisit this in a sec.

Little Goat Diner is, as you already know, the diner-themed spin-off of Girl and the Goat (a supposedly at-least-equally amazing restaurant across the street that I have not tried but at which it is notoriously hard to get a reservation). One thing I wish I'd known ahead of time is how impossible it was going to be to park nearby -- it's not a problem we generally have in Indianapolis. Just go into your experience at Little Goat Diner or anywhere nearby knowing that you will either be walking a little like I did or paying for a valet. Did I have a reservation? No, I walked in alone and was kindly seated at the bar immediately. There seemed to be a couple of empty tables as well. It was a Tuesday night, but what I'm trying to say is that you should be able to get in here, unlike at Little Goat's big sister restaurant.

Anyway, despite my singleton status that night, I was treated with nothing but kindness from every person on the staff I dealt with and I hope I tipped them well enough to let them know how much I appreciated that. Once seated, I pored over the menu. It's huge, guys, and everything on it sounds delicious. The struggle is real but my waiter was there for me. I let him know a couple of the things I was considering and he steered me towards the Reuben since they make the corned beef in-house and I'm a big fan of kimchi too. I threw on a side of the brussels sprouts too, for a vegetable.

Wow. Again.

That sammy was slammin. The sprouts were great too. I polished them both off embarrassingly quick but not a single waiter pointed it out (none of the classic "guess you really liked that sandwich, huh?"). The worst part for me was that I was there alone so I didn't get to try anyone else's food. If the guy next to me hadn't followed my lead and ordered the Reuben, I probably would have asked him for at least a bite. Second worst part is that I'm constantly suggesting going to Little Goat Diner before remembering that it's in Chicago and I am not.

How much did I like it? I went next door to the Little Goat Bakery/Bar and bought a souvenir onesie for my daughter. Not sure I know how to give better praise than that.

Absolutely delicious food and cocktail. I don't know why I did not try it before. We ordered fish tostadas and hot crab dip and 2 cocktails. The portion size is good and the service is quick even on a busy Saturday night.

I have to say, the quaint and hip interior of this place has taken diners to a whole new level. There's also a fun little photo booth to make use of while you wait to be seated! The wait wasn't bad, especially since we did not call in for a reservation, we were seated fairly quickly.

In terms of food, we started off with the goat chili which was absolutely delicious! Perfect for a cold winter day! My boyfriend ordered the patty melt which came with caramelized onions, a thin beef patty, cheese and a special sauce on two slices of toast. Definitely a worth while grilled cheese burger. I went with the los drowned, which is one of their top sellers. It's basically a sandwich with braised beef which I was not a fan of. The meet itself was too chewy.

Overall, I enjoyed the ambience of the place. Definitely would like to try their breakfast one day!

The food is good but I think it's a little bit overhyped; there's always a wait. Randolph st is home to so many great restaurants, this would not be my first choice. Great for lunch with coworkers but I wouldn't go out of my way specifically for this restaurant.

I have now dined here four times: once when it opened back in 2013 and then three times this year alone. Also always for breakfast. Little Goat Diner is classic looking white diner with their hipster servers. I haven't had a bad meal here and have enjoyed the chicken & waffles, shrimp and cheesy grits as well as the french toast. I loved the chicken & waffles the best. Overall, if you're looking for a great breakfast spot with a wide variety of choices (I want to try the piggy went to China dish next), look no further.

Yuppie Diner Food.

Everything I tasted (because I'm a slob who steals things off everyone's plates) absolutely delicious. Diner food is hard to mess up, but the LGD brought some new flavors that were unexpected and very much welcomed.

I can rave and rave, but you really should just and experience it for yourself.

Au Cheval had 63 tables ahead of us on a Friday night at 9:40pm. So we headed down the street and saw that Little Goat had some tables available. Waitress was lackluster on service. Didn't really seem enthusiastic about the menu offerings or what we wanted to drink. On to the food:

- Breakfast spaghetti 'n clams 'n crab: I don't get this dish. It's like an egg omelet...with pan-fried noodles and 3 clams...sitting in a salty clear broth. I did not see or taste any crab. Highly disappointed in this dish.
- Pork Belly Pancake: this was a very tasty dish. The scallion pancake was very similar to the Beijing style ones and the pork belly was tender and well seasoned (albeit skimpy in portion). The cabbage slaw on top was a nice crunch factor to tie everything together.
- Smoked fries: not worth the $6. Thin fries that were room temperature, nothing special, McDonald's trump these any day.
- Patty Melt: this was pretty good- the caramelized onions, pickles and gooey cheese all made it a messy tasty sandwich. But again, nothing special that will make me crave it and come back.
- Backyard BBQ cocktail- did not taste any alcohol and the flavors just did not work for me.

Overall, I have tried their brunch and now I've tried their dinner and it's just not that special for me to come back. Chicago has so many other places that would blow this place away.

It's been a while since we were last here. Sadly it's actually gotten worse.

The joint was maybe a quarter full, if that, and yet it still took over a half an hour for our food to land on our table after ordering.

We had an out of town visitor who was jonesing for the Fat Elvis....but they ran out of bananas, so no Fat Elvis.

Yeah, ish happens, not a tragedy.....but point I'm making is running out of a key ingredient for one of their signature dishes is just bad management - and that seems pretty par for the course these days. They seem terribly understaffed. The bathrooms were a disgusting mess (never an issue before). And 35 minutes to get our f'n food on a slow weekday. Really?

They're cutting corners and it shows.

Finally pulled myself away from Girl & the Goat to try the Little Goat Diner.  Very glad I did.  Had the Fish tostadas, the fish was lightly battered.  I do wish there had been more avocado.  Got an order of the Brussels sprouts in a fish sauce vinaigrette, with crispy onions, this had great flavor, but a little salty.  Would definitely return.

pics.caption: Brussels sprouts with fish sauce vinaigrette

review.des:
Really cool diner feel.  Was great for lunch.  Ordered a pork belly pancake type dish which was very unique and good.  The menu has lots of exotic things that I never tried before.

Service was excellent and food was overall good.  The chili was not bad - tasted fresh.

My biggest regret about Little Goat is that I didn't dine here for dinner. What a fool! Instead I stopped in here late after dinner one night for desert.

It was my own fault really, I was in Chicago for 36 hours & I had a 'To Eat List' as long as my arm, with little time to conquer it. I ran around this city like a crazy person; I ate Chicago Dogs, Deep Dish Pizza, Italian Beef... More Deep Dish. To say I felt gross is pretty much an understatement.

I eventually made it to Little Goat Diner at around 9pm, I walked here from Cloud Gate on a mission, being a huge fan of Chef Stephanie Izard from her season of Top Chef. What a gorgeous restaurant! High ceilings, clean lines & an open kitchen, it's simply stunning.

At 9pm it was heaving with groups of people. As we made our way to our booth in the back corner, I rubber-necked & marvelled at how delicious all the food looked. It's such an awful shame I wasn't hungry.

As a result my friend & I ordered sensibly opting for a S'more inspired desert to share & a Blueberry Pie Milkshake with crumbled pieces of pie throughout.

What we had was glorious, such beautiful & inspired comfort food. I'll absolutely be back next time I'm in town to give this place the attention it deserves. This place is one of the best.

The only thing I can say about this place is that it is very unique to try once if you're visiting from out of town, but if I was from Chicago or lived in the area, I honestly probably wouldn't frequent the place. Little Goat is essentially a diner with a menu not expected of a diner which is really cool and interesting, but at the end of the day, it's diner food: greasy, probably not the healthiest, but without the great prices of a regular diner.

If you're going to try something unique, go for the pork belly pancakes - very good and very different. The smoked pork and toffee shake was also great (tasted like a salted caramel shake).

The space feels like a slightly upscale diner but again, it's part of the experience. Overall, glad I tried it, experienced the hype, but probably won't be going again on my next visit to Chicago

I was really pumped to try something new and nothing was really jumping out at me from the menu, so I order the chicken and French toast. What did I eat? It had a bizzare mix of flavors that did not compliment each other. The egg was fried into the toast, which was cool, but I found a fairy large eggshell, quarter size, in my meal. Usually I would say something, but I barely finished my dish because I was put off by the flavor combo. The waitress was the best, super friendly, insightful, passionate about the menu and restaurant.

Great little diner but the Girl and the Goat folks. I had the El Diablo Agave drink for starters and it was amazing. The Bulls Eye French Toast was super delicious. It comes with chopped buttermilk fried chicken and egg inside the French toast and topped with strawberries and syrup. My coworker had the Reuben sandwich which was also tasty.  I must say that we had a fantastic bartender, Matthew, that was extremely helpful and made great drinks. Definitely try this place.

Little Goat Diner has my favorite turkey club sandwich in the city! Fries are perfect too!

Getting a table is a hassle once in a while, but that turkey sandwich is worth the wait!

The kitchen is like clock work and is a joy to watch if you're a service design nerd like me. Sit at the counter if this is the kind of thing that entertains you.

I had the blue plate special - scallop taco, slaw and baked beans. I expected two small tacos but the monsters that arrived were huge! Very tasty, perhaps a bit sweet for my palate but I was really impressed with how everything went together. Who would have thought baked beans would work?

Mimosas are fresh and served in a tumbler meaning you can get them down faster. Though at $10 each you might want to pace yourself.
