This is my new favorite spot on account of their gourmet nachos! They are freakin delicious in my humble opinion, like the best . Love their unique menu.

Make sure you go during off peak for walk-in (caught them on a weekday afternoon and didn't have to wait AS long), OR reserve a table in advance, brunch might take weeks, book it ahead of time!

A great little spot. I had the breakfast Bip bim bop and my wife had the Japanese pancake. Our friends had the party melt and fried chicken. The food was really good, as was the cocktails. Wait staff was very nice. I would very much recommend this place.

What a cute yummy place! We came here for dinner, where I had breakfast (the chicken 'n waffles), and then for breakfast, where I had dinner (goat loco moco). The waffles with strawberries was slightly overly sweet for me, but the chicken that went on top was so juicy and perfectly cooked! I love love loved the loco moco. The entire dish - with the greens, the rice, and the other stuff. The flavor profiles just meshed so well together. That ground goat meat patty was perfect! Ask for it medium-rare, not well done, and it will be so much better!
The service is also pleasing and friendly without being overbearing. They're just cool people. I love the décor and the feel of the place with its interesting wallpaper and details like baby goats inside the coffee mugs. Cute!
I also love that you don't have to wait insanely long or make rezzo's weeks in advance. That's def a plus.

Fun spot! Came here to have a couple drinks and really enjoyed my experience at the back bar. The bartender was very knowledgeable and made a mean cocktail (I got the pear one - don't remember the full name but it was goooood). She also recommended the fish torta dish which was an EXPLOSION of fun flavors. Recommend!

Little Goat never disappoints. Their staff is all up to speed on their unique menu offerings and their friendly and positive attitudes are infectious. The host stand was very friendly and helpful in letting us know that we were next to receive an outside table and that they would find us in the bar when it was ready.

I love that they have more seating in the bar now! A nice booth against the wall with high top tables and additional chairs. We ordered the smoked cherry bomb cocktail - awesome flavor combinations in this drink, love the mezcal and cherry syrup combo.

Then we headed outside for our food. To start, we had the fried pickles and onion. I love the curry mayo to dip.

For our entre, we split The Ratatouille Pierogi  and .. My HEART I loved these, great combination of flavors and the summer squash was cooked perfectly, not too firm not too soft. Perfect for my friend who is a vegetarian.

For dessert we had the miso banana split - which Izard debuted on her winning episode of Iron Chef Gauntlet.

Overall, Little Goat Diner is consistent with food and service and always have a creative new dish that I can't wait to try.
So good! Got the Beef Cheeks Stroganoff. Had leftovers were just as good as the first time I ate it!

Often when I am really hungover or have been stuck inside an elevator all day with a 80 year old woman and her humping yorky I dream of a meal so breakfastly profound you can not only finish it but leave with leftovers no one minds reheating. Enter Little Goat Diner and their laid back "I'm not here to impress you" diner attitude. I've gone 5 times and am just now remembering to review the place. Sometimes I wrestle with quantity over quality vice versa but not here. It is a perfect blend of both, kind of like if your grandma was a top chef and kept filling your plate every time you got even close to 2 slices of French toast left. Simple, elegant, and extravagant all rolled in to one like a pig in a blanket. Also great place for your 250 lb linebacker cousin who plays pro football and can eat a full grown horse in one sitting.

Quite possibly in my top 3 burgers of all time! Yes - quite the bold statement but this place just rocked at everything they did in what is ultimately an upmarket diner but is understandably very busy for a reason - and this burger really was amazing!

I just went for the standard American classic so who knows what level the unique ones like the kimchi one delivers at but this was towering over my plate like a skyscraper in downtown and was super packed with lovely salad and pickles, whilst the artisan baked bread roll encasing it was the real star of the show in taste and keeping the awesomeness all together.

I've never eaten a burger I couldn't finish (unless it tasted awful...) and I wasn't going to be beaten here although I think I did go a  bit too heavy on the tasty fries to begin with...be warned - everything is so filling!

Overall pure excellence and the whole menu looks fantastic - definitely I'll be back next time I visit Chi-town!

I love this place. My breakfast is always delicious when I come here and they have really creative items on the menu!. I tend to like a savory breakfast, but when I've come and also split pancakes with others they are SOOOO GOOD!!!

They used to have this asian breakfast thingie which was delicious. Sadly it's not on the menu anymore but I got the breakfast bibimbap and it did not disappoint! I loved the cauliflower "rice" which made this healthier. The eggs were perfectly cooked. And I highly recommend asking for the habanero hot sauce. It is very cravable!!

It's hard to get healthy breakfast options that aren't just omelettes or yogurt, so I really appreciated my dish that was creative, different, and still very healthy!

Love myself a diner - although this diner is more upscale than most. It has great food and is a lot easier to get into than the other goat establishments. Went for breakfast with a big group and we got a giant table which was nice. Food and service were great, go hungry as the portions are decently sized.

Hands down best pancakes ever! The sourdough pancakes were terrific and fluffy. House-made sausage was also great. As extra torture to my diet we order the pork belly home fries. I could not eat it all. Coffee was a little bitter but paired well with our meal. Service was somewhat slow to start but food came out timely and hot. My friend was not a fan of their corned beef and hash but it looked good.
One of my favorites for a quick bite.  I love the diner style atmosphere and I have never had a bad meal here.  I always recommend it to those who can't snag a reservation across the street.

First time going after a concert in the area.  It was a little late.

The waitress was a little rude, no patience and she got a little bit of attitude and it seemed like she was rushing us to finish and get out.  

Maybe because it was a little late, the food was not that great.  We both ordered a burger and I gotta say the best part of the burger were the fries.... that you get a la carte!

They were out of a couple of beers, which again, it was late and I understand.

Not impressed.  May or may not come back.
I love it. I get the Goat Almighty almost every time I dine here. Can never finish it in one sitting. They do some drinks but I come for the outstanding food.

LOVED the food and full flavor. The goat concept was super cute and well executed with the themed gift shop. Chicken pot pie had a unique flavor but was a bit dry. The fattoush salad was amazing, full of quinoa and chicken but vinaigrette really completed the salad.
If this is your first time trying Little Goat, "This little piggie went to china" is a hands down great first experience meal!

The food is just not good. . .I loved Girl and the Goat so I thought I might at least like this place as well, but nope.

I got the grilled cheese and it tasted like tomato soup with mystery meat inside two slices of soggy bread. WTF? Please don't take innovation so far that your creation resembles nothing like the original inspiration.

My friend got the french toast with fried chicken and strawberries, the Bulls Eye toast I believe. It was okay for a bite, but I really don't think anyone wants to have more than a few bites of this strange combination.

The chili goat fries were decent, but definitely overpriced for what they are.

Will not be back.

This place completely blew my mind!  A friend who lives nearby suggested we go to Little Goat for an early dinner, because honestly, I'm sick of Parlor all the time...and I'm super glad he made this suggestion.

We walked in around 5ish and noticed a few open tables and booths.  We opted for a booth, and our server was there almost immediately with menus.  After going over their offerings, I settled on the Sloppy Goat with a side of Not Chinese Broccoli, while my buddy got the Fish Tostadas with a side of Goat Chili Cheese Fries.

The fries came out first, so I picked at one from his order, and holy shit that chili was awesome!  It had huge chunks of beef, and their cheese sauce was more like a light and creamy bechemel  (sp?) as opposed to the standard yellow goop.  I'm not usually a fan of fried foods, but these were addictive.

My Sloppy Goat was phenominal!  Huge portions, the goat was ground and seasoned properly, the slaw was fresh, and the bread was the perfect consistency to hold it all together.  I also snagged a tostada from my friend's plate, and the fish along with all the toppings, was AWESOME!

I loved everything about this place.  And you would expect the bill to be much higher based on quality and quantity, but you would be surprised.  This is definitely a place I would visit again.

Solid three stars, but no more. 1.5 stars go to the manager, 0.5 star for the creative menu, 0.5 star for the taste, 0.5 to the setting, - 1 star for "ok"-food, - 10 stars to the hostesses.

We were there on a family trip and had made a previous reservation. We called to confirm the reservation, on a Thursday at 7:30 pm. Arrived at 7:20 pm, talked to the host, she confirmed it would be a tiny wait. To make a long story short, tiny wait ended up being 45 min (so no point in making a reservation). We were five people, so they told us we were going to be seated as soon as the bigger tables were free. One group with six people arrived AFTER us, had a reservation after ours, were sat BEFORE. Another five people group arrived later, was also sat BEFORE. Hostesses was rude and simply answered "we are sitting people as they show up". Just as I am about to get super hangry, I talk to the manager and repeat the same words the hostess mentioned...and surprise, another group of five that just arrived is seated before us.

I don't know it it was because we were obviously tourists and they preferred safe, and frequent customers (which would be a dumb, because we are often in Chicago) or just plain mistake. I just can say it was very annoying (plus imagine having your 86 year old grandma and teenage sister waiting for 45 min, after having walked all day).

1.5 stars to the manager who tried to compensate for her rude hostess. She personally took us to our (communal) table (oops, all other tables were taken...because oops, sorry, they sat three other parties before us. Oops, did I mention that again?) She offered appetizers and drinks on the house (which again, very nice, but mom/teenager/grandma don't are eager drinkers, they were just hungry). She recommended the nachos, which were very good, and we asked for the chicken fingers. By the time we got them however, it was already so late (around 8:45, 75 min after reservation) that we ate them and were not hungry anymore. Points also to the manager for asking an experienced and very attentive waitress to take care of us (we saw her talking to the waiter that was assigned to our neighbors and explain the situation). We appreciated her effort.

Husband got a burger, was ok, but nothing special. Sister got the pork-belly pancakes, were good, but also not extraordinary. I got the fish tacos, not good at all.

All in all, would be a nice place to go if you could just walk in and get a drink and dinner or if you had a hangover and wanted pancakes (then again, I don't know anybody who likes to wait in that condition). Not worth making a reservation or going all the way down there just for their food. If you are in the neighborhood try it out, but don't plan around it.

Reservations on Open Table were hard to come by, but our group of 4 arrived around 9:30 a.m. on a gorgeous Sunday and only waited a few minutes before our table outside on the patio was ready.  

Cocktails at 9:30 on a Sunday?  You bet!  My friends opted for a carafe of mimosas, but I was too enthusiastic about the cocktail list and ordered the "Backyard BBQ," which was refreshing, strong, and well made.  The cocktail list is much longer than what's on the Little Goat website (although that too is lengthy!)

The Bull's Eye French toast is amazing!  I completely forgot that this dish was served with egg, and was pleasantly surprised when I cut into the thick, fluffy onion brioche, and discovered the egg had been cooked inside the French toast.  The French toast was topped with crispy chicken and BBQ maple syrup.  The portions are perfect, I didn't leave feeling hungry OR overstuffed.

Little Goat is not for picky eaters.  My friend wanted a more plain dish than what was offered on the menu and asked for plain French Toast.  We thought the waitress was joking when she said, "the cook refuses to make that," but she was serious.  Another friend was able to order plain egg whites and a side of grits, so there is some room for simplicity, but not very much.  However, *I* came to Little Goat to eat the often raved-about food from the menu and loved it!

My friend ordered the dark chocolate chip pancakes instead, which looked delicious with the crunchy chocolate bits and chocolate butter on the side.  The cheesy grits looked good too.

I want to come back and try their milkshakes, dinner menu, and bakery items.  They appear to serve breakfast, lunch, and dinner all day.  If you're not sitting on the patio, the dining room is huge, lively, and a bit loud.  After brunch, I recommend hopping around some of the bars in the West Loop.  There is so much going on in "restaurant row" that you can easily spend the entire day here.

Love this place . I have been here about 4 or 5 times now . Tried something new each time and have really loved everything . Food is great! Space is very quite and nice cocktail selection
The breakfast burrito( can't remember the technical name ) is awesome !
The Tuna melt is also amazing .. I normally don't order tuna melts but this one has a cheese sauce on it . So good
The taco salad is also a great choice , it has the goat chili on it .
My friend got the pork tonkatsu sandwich (pictured) she really enjoyed it - it was gigantic!!! You could easily share it so that you could try more items . Seriously huge!
My only complaint has been service. Not super attentive or friendly . Our server was playing way more attention to the table of guys next to us then our table . Our drinks were always empty . We had to stop a random server to get water.  None the less it hasn't stopped me from returning
Definitely Make a reservation if you can . It gets very busy

pics.caption: Pork tonkatsu sandwich . Very large ! Definitely shareable

review.des:
In our venture to try all things under the Goat enterprise, we came here the morning before Girl & Goat. The diner is vastly lacking in comparison. The menu has some Asian-inspired twists, like okonomiyaki and kimchi in the reuben, but these were unfortunately all misses.

Interested in the fusion dishes, we ordered the Bull's Eye French Toast, This Little Piggy Went to China, and reuben. None of them did their compelling descriptions justice. You could only very barely taste the sweet onion in the brioche used for the french toast. The kimchi was nowhere near pungent enough in the reuben, which may also have been due to the absolute smothering of cheese. My personal disappointment was This Little Piggy Went to China, which featured the saltiest biscuit of my life and a bland McMuffin sausage patty. I was so excited for the promised szechuan and chili flavors, but all I tasted was salt.

The price tag was also a bit ridiculous for what we were getting. And while I appreciate the fresh take on traditional diner fare, I would have liked it much better if the food lived up to it. The two stars are for good service and clean restaurant.

Loved the coffee......

Stumbled across this cute diner place while waiting for a table at Au Cheval. Walked down the street looking for some coffee. Ordered an iced little goat minus the goat milk. I can honestly say, this was the best coffee I have ever had. Too bad I wasn't able to order any pastries or check out the food.

Next time Chicago......I will be back.

pics.caption: Ordered an Iced Little Goat Coffee. How cute is this! Enjoyed every last drop.

review.des: Food was very good. Air conditioning was almost non-existent. Hostess said A/C was having trouble that day. We were told by our waiter that they  had to close on Father's Day because of the heat so it wasn't just the day we were here. You expect A/C at a restaurant in Chicago during the summer.   If it's a hot day and you don't mind sweating while you eat - eat here. In addition  the noise level was 9.5 on a 10 Point scale.

I came here with a friend from out of town and we both loved this place. We had previously gone to Girl and the Goat and wanted to try out Little Goat Diner for brunch. Thankfully when we arrived on a weekday there was no line and plenty of seats. There were a lot of good options on the menu. The food was very good and savory. Our waiter was also very good. Overall a great experience!

Really this is a 4.5 review.  We had a very nice experience here for brunch/lunch. The place was slammed, but they got us seated fairly quickly.  

The food is basically elevated diner food, which was excellent.  The only drawback was that our server wasn't that great.  Just a little inattentive.  Although I just think she was a little overwhelmed by how busy it was.  

I would definitely make a trip back down here again.

The paratha with avocado salad is absolutely delicious. The paratha was amazing, perfectly cooked with an authentic taste, and this is coming from someone who is from the land of parathas. I was very skeptical about it trying it, but boy am I glad I did. The dish blew me away. The eggs and salad that came with it meshed perfectly in flavor. I've found my go-to healthy paratha fix!!
Service was excellent.
Overall a wonderful place for breakfast any time of the day or week.

This is a great place for brunch. My friends from out of town were visiting and found this place via Yelp. They have a very unique array of brunch foods. I ordered a clams and crab spaghetti omelette and one of my friends ordered the kim chi pancakes. My dish was excellent, and I would return again.

pics.caption: This little piggy went to China dish - sesame cheddar biscuit, sunny eggs, Szechuan pork sausage, chili garlic chive sauce, blackberries
Breakfast spaghetti n clams n crab dish

review.des:
Definitely a great choice for a fail safe brunch in Chicago. Large portions and a nice ambience. Definitely recommend getting a reservation. Me and my boyfriend came on a Saturday morning around 9:30am and there was already a bunch of people waiting outside.

As for the food, the menu has a good selection with traditional brunch comfort food but with a twist. I definitely appreciate the quirks and thought that went into creating these dishes. I must say I was expecting a lot more just because of the hype surrounding the place. I got the "this little piggy went to china" and I would definitely recommend!

Got the regular burger plus egg and bacon. It was good but nothing special...
French fries are smoked which tastes delicious at the beggining but when you reach half portion you just cannot eat it anymore.
That is a REALLY noisy place so if you plan to meet people for talking go somewhere else.
The waitress was really careful and nice.

Little Goat is a reliable spot on Randolph Street for good food, fantastic service, and a fun atmosphere.

The first thing you notice walking in is how cool the diner style dining room looks. It's almost always crowded and filled with the din of conversation and activity, which adds to the atmosphere.

I've been here several times, and I'm always impressed with how good the service is. Everyone is very friendly, professional, and seems to know the menu backwards and forwards. This is my favorite aspect of the restaurant, and it keeps me coming back.

The food can range from okay to great, so it's worth asking your server for advice. Having grown up eating a variety of Asian food, I am at once excited to see certain Asian cuisine and ingredients incorporated into the menu, yet mostly disappointed with the execution. Most everything else is quite tasty though. And I am a big fan of the Elvis Waffles.

At first glance the line/wait may be off putting, but to say it's worth it would be an understatement. They do take reservations so you can always plan ahead and avoid the wait. The food is a wide selection of combinations that you wouldn't think of. Surprisingly enough they work. From paratha burritos to a breakfast spaghetti that has clams.

The decor and ambience are on point. The skylight definitely brightens things up ;)

*Hint* the bathroom is IN the wallpaper.

If you don't mind waiting for a table and are hungry for a unique take on traditional diner fare, this is your spot. Many of her dishes offer an Asian spin and I've not had anything like it before. Portions are large, be ready for a much needed siesta after your meal

I wasn't as big of a fan of the meal I got the last time I was here- this little piggy went to china, I just didn't like the flavor combinations, but I have had some delicious meals here.  The crab dip is great and the chicken and waffles meal is a great brunch!

pics.caption: This little piggy went to china

review.des:
I came here for lunch a couple of weeks ago and very much enjoyed the meal. They do have a menu at the hostess stand with gluten free items marked. As other reviewers have noted they also have items which may contain gluten on this list so just make sure you're aware which is which and pick for your personal comfort level.

To start we split a hot crab dip which was amazingly rich and tasted very strongly of crab although I didnt notice a huge amount of actual crab chunks, this was served with some sort of tortilla chips instead of the ritz crackers.

I also ordered a lil caesar salad (served without croutons) which was amazing and a small side of the goat chili. My boyfriend ordered the tonkatsu sandwich and enjoyed it as well.

We did not have a reservation and were seated around 11:45am on a weekday with no issue. It did get a lot more crowded as it got later so I would try to come on the early side, at least for lunch, if you dont have a reservation.

Food probably deserves a 4 star but I find it incredibly frustrating that Little Goat will make you wait an extra 15-20 minutes after your reservation time. Food is good and interesting but nothing to write home about. I'd give it a very meh experience grade.

We went to the Goat Diner for a late business breakfast. The food was unique and quite tasty! I had the Bullseye French Toast which was the excellent...however I still regret not trying the Fat Elvis...next time!

The service was also excellent....I highly recommend giving it a try if you are in the area.

Give me nachos or give me death! Being from LA, i'm pretty serious about my nacho situation. Sometimes restaurants don't get the chip right! The chip is the most important fools! Its the foundation of the dish. MUST - GET - IT - RIGHT! Mr. Little Goat - Thank you for getting it right. Who knew? Pancakes here are delicious, milk shakes are great! They also give pretty good french fry as well. Can't go wrong with anything on this diner menu.  Amazing coffee too. I'll pretty much eat anything they make. There I said it.
Awesome!!! Great food and great service. Loved it! We tried different plates and even though we had our favorites, we were not disappointed with any of them. I would definifely go back!

Seriously the best experience I had dining in Chicago (which is my favorite food city!). I have many food restrictions and I was so looked after during a large dinner (where I would have been happy with a plate of grilled vegetables to spare the staff the trouble. My server Jillian brought dish after dish of everything I could eat and was so mindful of me in a sea of 40+ people that I was truly floored. Everything was so good and down to the Heath Ceramic plates, so very memorable!
I suggest the green beans which I was told by local members of the party are quite legend... and pretty much any veggie they serve... off the charts amazing!
Thank you Little Goat Diner!

My boyfriend and I went to Little Goat for a cocktail before our reservation at Roister. I've been dying to try Girl and the Goat, so I figured a cocktail at Little Goat would be right up my alley. Just popping into the bar, we were happy to see seats available. I ordered the Paloma and my boyfriend ordered an Old Fashioned. You can tell the place is very busy, and the employees seem a little overwhelmed. When we got our drinks I asked for a straw, as my cocktail wasn't evenly flavored throughout, the bartenders told me they didn't have straws in an attempt to go straw-less to be eco friendly and reduce plastic. I wouldn't have minded but I wanted the straw in order to stir my drink. My boyfriend ended up having to get up and get me my own straw from the coffee bar, leading to a dirty look from the bartender. Both bartenders did not make us feel welcome to the restaurant at all, and more of a hassle for asking for something as simple as a straw. We closed our tab quickly after as the whole encounter made us really uncomfortable, and as we left we both agreed we'd never even consider going back. The whole encounter was very disheartening as someone who was so looking forward to being there.

We were back in town so decided to check out one of our favorites of our old neighborhood. I ordered the pork belly pancake and brussel sprouts and the hubby ordered the skirt steak...and we were so pleased with our food that we ordered the apple pie and mac and cheese to go for late night cravings in our hotel room. Ambiance - awesome, food - extremely memorable, service - a little slow but friendly. Left as happy campers and thankful that Stephanie and her team are keeping up the quality even 5 years after opening.

I went with my friend a little bit ago and was blown away by the amazing food and service!! The food is a great fusion of all different cultures. I loved the twist they gave the Asian food in particular. This is one of my new favorite diners and I am planning on taking many more of my friends there!

ANYTHING YOU TRY ON THE MENU WILL BE A GOOD PICK.
But, we all have our favorites...
When the blueberry pancakes are in season, make sure to order 12.
The best sandwich ever is the los drowned. You gotta get that. The garlic mashed potatoes are HOLY MOLY DELICIOUS. Let's see.. any dessert on the menu will be great because dessert is dessert and is exceptional 100% of the time.

I can't say enough about this place besides that wait times can be long, so you gotta call ahead to make a reservation. There is a very fun photo booth in the lobby which makes watching everyone eat delicious food VERY SLOWLY a little less unbearable.
LOVE THIS PLACE - go often and everything is good.  If you are looking for a place to host a group, they have a great patio section and private room on their second floor that is really nice.
Definitely a good place for any meal, but in my experience, some of the staff was rude, but otherwise, the restaurant takes risks with their menu and does not come up short.

Great food, but both myself and my man felt very rushed throughout the entire meal. I understand they were busy but we had made reservations for a reason and expect to be serviced properly. The hostess tried to be polite but everything she said was so rushed and really made me want to leave because I felt like we were bothering her by sitting in her booth.

Let me just start by saying... this is good eating.  I met my brother for lunch, and we decided on this place because it is one of his favorites.

I loved the decor, as soon as we walked in.  It's a modern version of the classic 50's diner; light, airy and cheerful.  

We sat at a booth which was roomy and comfortable.  I had the Los Drowned, a succulent sandwich consisting of braised beef, avocado, harvati cheese, spicy mayo, pickled peppers & onions between a hoagie roll.  It was outstanding!

I forgot what my brother ordered, but it didn't last long anyway.  I looked up about 9 mins later and it was 1/4 of it left.  (He came from the gym and warned me that he was super hungry.)

We shared a salmon omelet that was so delicious, light and fragrant that I swore it was award winning.

The unbelievable thing is with this food was it was hearty without leaving me stuffed.  We actually had dessert.  The piece of chocolate silk pie I had was not only the perfect way to end this delightful diner experience, but it stole a piece of my heart!

This is not your dad's diner. Everything that seems traditional in title has some unique twist or addition that you'd never imagine. We started with the goat chili cheese fries which were so indulgent we were almost too full for our sandwiches! I had the grilled cheese which had a decent flavor but was too greasy to finish, unfortunately. Overall it was a cool place, kind of hipstery, but a little more expensive than somewhere I'd want to eat regularly.

We tried to make a reservation several days before Sunday; anything after 8am was full. Sunday is brunch day, also the restaurant convention was in town, that picks up the traffic I am sure. We walked there early and were told that the wait would be 45 minutes. We sat outside in the beautiful weather on a nice bench and watched the al fresco diners eat and saw some interesting food walk past us.

50 mins later, I got a text saying our table was ready. We went in and were to be seated at a communal diner style table. Since we were visiting our niece and wanted a real table for some conversation, we declined that seating. The hostess graciously put us back on the list and said we should not have gone on the "any available seating" list. You can sit at a table, outside table, a diner counter or the diner tables. Now we know. We went back outside for 15 minutes and the hostess came out to find us.

I had a Michelada to start, which tasted like a good simple Bloody Mary without the toothpicks of food in it. The server Minty was personable and knew the very large menu cold. She was able to help my niece decide on a brunchy dish leaning vegetarian, and chose the Goat'O Goat'O shrimp and veggie with peanut dressing salad. My wife chose the same. I chose the Sloppy Goat, a Joe with BBQ goat meat and a huge pile of slaw on a ethereal bun to die for.

We followed up with some excellent coffee and tried to avoid the amazing looking desserts flying around. We finished our visit with a stop at the bakery next door. The staff, the good food and fun vibe make this a place I hope to visit again next time we are in the City.

We went here on a Tuesday morning for breakfast around 10am with luck of no wait time! I've heard so much about this place so I just had to come and try what they had to offer...This little piggy went to China was our favorite! Too bad they ran out of the Ooey gooey cinnabun...Although I prefer French toast over waffles, I liked the Fat Elvis waffles vs the Little goat Bulls eye French toast(which seems overrated) My brother tried the Biscuits and gravy which goes well on the smoked fries! My brother ordered the Honey yogurt & house granola which he says was OK. Service was good and prompt! Prices were reasonable for portion! Noise level was average...

pics.caption: This little piggy went to China

review.des: Excellent diner! Very wonderful vibe! I had the Ruben sandwich it lived up to the expectation and the sauce was wonderful. The sourdough pancakes were a great dessert option as I thought that it was wonderful that they decided to compliment the pancakes with real maple syrup instead of the artificial corn syrup which many of the restaurants serve.

Over priced , over hyped and just average food.   I will never make an effort to just go there, maybe if am close by?    Despite having a reservation on two occasions , we still waited 45 minutes for our table and for the mediocre food.    I expect more from a Top Chef winner who I support at her other ventures.    You can do much better, but seems like the folks who frequent here just want to trendy and will pack it and not demand better food.

Tip: Order crumpets. Even if you believe only the Queen Mum and her festooned hat ilk are the only ones who enjoy them. If you have any tastebuds, you will too.

Griddled and served with butter and jam, the crumpet outshone both scones of the day (chocolate cherry pistachio and dried mango chocolate chip) and our entree (french toast and fried chicken with strawberries and syrup).

Everything as tasty as you would expect from a restaurant of this caliber and pedigree, but the crumpet is transcendent. Please add one to whatever you order.

Beautiful airy space and great service.

I'm wondering why oh why I'm giving a diner 5 stars...but I can't help myself! In the past month I've been here twice for the worlds best patty melt (aka morning after food) and the Choco Taco Sundae (for two!!). There are so many awesome menu items, but I'm sticking to the tried and true at this point. It hasn't failed! In spite of crowds, the wait is minimal and all the seating is good. Lots of booth seating. The only exception to that is having to wait or sit in the annexed bar. It's a bit snug and not cozy enough to stay long.

I'd been wanted to try out Little Goat for a while because I know it's a popular spot. The whole place is themed like a diner although the food is more upscale. We split brussel sprouts and 2 different sandwiches. Overall it was pretty good. The sandwiches were flavorful and brussel sprouts were amazing. It's a little overpriced for upscale diner food, but definitely worth checking out once.

Went here twice, once for breakfast and once for dinner and both times the entrees were to die for. Ordered the parathas burrito for breakfast and I wish I could eat that every day of my life. It was so incredibly flavorful and the textures of everything were just perfect. For dinner a friend and I shared the goat chili fries were meh (why I gave this place stars instead of 5) but holy moly the pork belly pancake was incredible. I will have dreams about that perfectly crisped scallion pancake and buttery melt in your mouth pork belly.

First stop on our Chicago food trip! I heard great things about the Goat restaurants (mostly Girl & the Goat) so I was excited to try this place. The wait was ~30-40 for 5 on a Saturday morning but there is plenty to see around the neighborhood.

Ambiance: Crowded with a mix of families and groups of friends. Very lively and busy diner-esque decor. Our waitress seemed frazzled and in a rush for us to order and head out.

Food: Very diverse menu centered mostly around Asian fusion.
Moscow Goat: refreshing and delicious!
This little piggy went to china: too salty for me. the flavors were great but the sauce coupled with the marinated meat was too much for my palate. However, not bad overall

We had had dinner at Alinea the night before for the start of my bachelorette weekend in Chicago and MI, to say we needed a little heavy breakfast is an understatement. Our table ordered:
-          Side of hash browns with cheese (for the table) - MAN these were good, kinda like frizzled phyllo dough
-          Side of mac and cheese for the table
-          I spilt the eggs in a hole with the fried chicken. I wish the chicken had been in bigger pieces - it was a little dry - but good
-          The Elvis waffle (with whipped peanut butter and a maple bacon syrup)
-          Corned beef hash- it is not chunks of corned beef but slices and that same great potato frizzle

We loved our server - but were seated by the bathrooms, (even when we had a reservation and a booth sat empty upfront they were "saving for someone")

I wanted it to be better. Still happy I went.

pics.caption: Side of hash browns with cheese...look average but was my favorite....the potatoes were frizzled....so good.
Corned beef hash...the beef is sliced not cubed.

review.des:
Been to Little Goat twice: once for dinner, once for breakfast. Both times were enjoyable.

The decor is nice. Very bright and airy, not overly hip or pretentious, which I found kind of refreshing.

Dinner would probably get 3.5 stars on its own. The service, if I remember correctly, was pretty helpful in steering us away from boring chicken fingers (don't even know why I was considering them) and towards the goat chili cheese fries. I'm picky about my chili cheese fries (and am an Edzo's loyalist) but these were fantastic. Lots of depth of flavor. The manicotti, on the other hand, was meh. I ordered it because of the interesting rhubarb sauce twist, but the rhubarb made the sauce too ketchupy.

Breakfast was probably 4.5 stars on its own. Coffee special was a blend of coffee and horchata. Yum! Sat at the bar and got a free cinnamon roll, which was, needless to say, pretty great. Hash browns were exactly to my liking: cut long and stringy using a spiral slicer, with just the right amount of crust. But I didn't even eat much of them, since I was too busy gorging myself on the This Piggy Went to China and the Bull's Eye French Toast. The former is an amalgam of biscuits, fried eggs, asian-spiced sausage, and some sort of sauce that was really zesty and tasty but a tad too salty when consumed in large quantities. The latter is a french toast made with sweet onion broche and served with barbecue maple syrup. It tasted weird at first, but was a real grower. By the time we finished it, I was enamored with it.

I was VERY impressed with Little Goat. My friends told me we were going to a diner and I was not very excited to hear it, but as soon as I saw the plates people were eating and read the menu, I knew we made the right choice. The balance of flavor was absolute perfection. Umami, sour and sweet, savory and starchy, everything. I have never tasted anything like it (southern and Chinese fusion). I highly recommend it and am dying to go back!

pics.caption: Chinese sausage with sunny side up egg on a scallion biscuit with chili soy and scallion sauce

review.des: I have no idea what is the hype with the place. I love other restaurants of the group, but this one.. you can get a better value eating elsewhere, it's always packed and the food is pretty standard.

Easily some of the best food I've had in a long time, very cute retro diner feel, and phenomenal service! That being said THIS IS NOT A TRADITIONAL AMERICAN DINER! If you come here looking for normal cuisine, it's not going to make you happy, but if you desire an adventure of sorts this place will have you coming back over and over again!
My 18 year old sister's review,
"Get the nachos, there is no way sex could be better than these nachos."

Had a chance to stop in here first to the bakery which is connected to the restaurant where there's a bar and a quick pick up spot for pastries/breads and sandwiches on weekdays. Good alternative if you don't want to wait but still want to get a taste. Bagels are awesome, on par with New York. Next visit was on a weekday morning when it wasn't busy at all. The staff was great, very hospitable and knowledgable of the menu. We ordered the "This Little Piggy went to China", "Asian Style Breakfast Thingy", and side of hash browns. The coffee and cappuccino were also enjoyed. I was really pleasantly surprised of how well the "East meets West" style breakfast fit so well together. I would never think to use kimchi or even soy sauce for breakfast unless it was dim sum. "This Little Piggy went to China" was my favorite but the Asian style break also had a tasty vinaigrette dipping sauce. There's definitely a lot to try on the menu.

-Smile when you order!

pics.caption: "Asian Style Breakfast Thingy", hash browns, and "This Little Piggy Went To China"

review.des: We came here for breakfast a few months ago, it was sooo amazing food was great. The place is busy lots going on, but servers were great. Everything we tried was delicious but our favorite had to be the cinnamon roll, it was one of the best I've ever had. Can't wait to go back!

I wish that Stephanie Izard would decide one day to open a chain of diners all around the Chicagoland area so that I can eat here whenever I want. Parking was a bit hard to come by, though there was valet parking service outside for $14.00. Our recent visit was around 11:30 AM and decided to pop into the diner for a bite. We ended up parking the car on Peoria street and paid for street parking. I hadn't expected the restaurant to be so full at 11:30 AM, but by 11:45 AM,  the restaurant had a line of people waiting. We were lucky we got in before the rush. I loved the open space of the diner, with a bar stool counter top for patrons to dine at. We were seated in a cozy corner by the kitchen. The staff from the people who greeted us from the front door, to the server that took our order, to the busser were all courteous and friendly. I had originally wanted breakfast food, but my girlfriend had raves about the Los Drowned sandwich. I was intrigued by braised beef on a hoagie and decided to go for it. It was messy, delicious, tender, explosion of flavor sandwich I had tasted in forever. The sandwich was a big portion, but I had cravings for fries as well. I was  skeptical at first when I saw that it was shoe string fries, but they were delicately fried to a crisp and seasoned well. It was a wonderful complimentary dish to the sandwich. I'd love to make more visits here and try other items on the menu.

I had a chance to stop by LG a second time, and I think it was even better than the first! We ordered a ton of items family-style, so it was great to try a few more

Crab dip (ref and GF)- 5*, love the masa chips that come with the GF option! Even better than the ritz with the original
Goat chili- 5*, fantastic. Love the little kick you get from the jalapeños on top
Fried pickles and onions-4*, great breading, but awkwardly large lumps of fried things that make it harder to share
Tempura mashed potatoes- 5*, obviously
PQM bacon- 3*, meh. It's no Au Cheval bacon, to be honest
Chocolate shake- 3.5*, really good, don't get me wrong, but nothing super special or different
Hash browns- 3.5*, love how stringy and crispy these are! But a little blah, could use more cheese!

The entire menu is delicious! I really enjoy the sophisticated take on an old school diner with consistently excellent food. My personal favorite is the Ruben. The only downfall with a place as popular as this one is the increased noise level- a huge pet peeve of mine.

During our trip in Chicago, we came here for breakfast. We got here pretty early, thank goodness we didn't have to wait.

I really liked the look and feel of this "diner". For some reason, the first thing I noticed was it looked super clean.  There was a photo booth  right next to the entrance and also in the back they had a bar and a little shop. It was pretty cute.

We got seated quickly since we were there early. They were able to accommodate a table for 6. All of us ordered from the "Cereal Killers" section of the menu. For some reason, I wanted to order something I usually don't, something they wouldn't have in San Diego. And then I saw it staring at me, "The little pig went to China". I was hesitant to order it since I was hungry and was already thinking if I didn't like it, I'd end up starving. Luckily my husband offered to share and/or trade food if needed lol.

So this section right here is dedicated to the Little Pig Went To China plate. It was definitely different. Not bad, not great, just different. This dish consisted of a sesame cheddar biscuit with Szechuan pork sausage, sunny side up eggs, chili garlic chive sauce poured all over and gooseberries. Definitely didn't taste like a typical breakfast dish. May possibly be better for lunch. The biscuit was good, the sausage was full of flavor, the sauce wasn't bad either. I just felt that it all didn't go together well. The gooseberries were nice and sweet too. Overall the dish has a very strong Asian influence to it. All the flavors were there and were actually good, just not together for me. Would I order it again? Probably not. It's more of a one time dish for me.

My husband ordered the Bulls Eye French Toast. The presentation to this was cute. You got two pieces of sweet onion brioche with the middle caved in each having an egg in it, then covered by some chicken and drenched in a BBQ maple syrup. The dish itself was tasty, however the chicken was somewhat dry.

Overall I found this diner interesting. I would love to come back and try other things on their menu. Hope to see you soon Little Goat Diner!

pics.caption: Beautiful presentation of the little pig went to china

review.des: We heard a lot about the main restaurant. So when we were in Chicago, we decided to go here instead since the reservations for the main was booked months in advance. This place is an Asian fused with American Diner classics. Wife got the Japchae and I got the Tonkatsu sandwich. Both had good intentions of wanting to be good. Japchae had good flavors but the cold and hot ingredients didn't mix well. The tonkatsu had the thinnest piece of meat ever. The sauce didn't go well either. Would recommend it if your palette was not diverse.
Wow! This is my 2nd go round and it gets gooder and gooder! Had breakfast for dinner -- A Little Taste of Asia, kimchi, egg, bacon & pancake! Yummy! The coffee is wonderful! A new favorite!

Wow - even among the wonderful restaurants in and beyond the West Loop, Little Goat Diner stands out.
I was in town to visit my daughter, and after a walk through the Art Institute, we made our way out beyond the expressway.
There was a 15 minute wait to be seated, so we strolled west along Randolph, and back east to the restaurant just in time to be paged via text message.
The conversation and chatter in the restaurant was palpable - great atmosphere.  The menu had some great stuff, including a Cuban sandwich blue-plate special that my daughter ordered, but I ordered the pork sandwich.  For some strange reason, I got the "blue plate" (it said so, right on the plate!), instead of her.  We exchanged samples of each other's sandwich fillings, all delicious.
We also ordered some grilled broccoli, which we thought we'd asked for in advance of our sandwiches, but it came with the sandwiches.  Not a problem, because it too was really tasty.
After our lunch, we walked back to the subway, and back home.

Really loved grabbing lunch at Little Goat!  The service was slow (granted, they are SUPER busy always) but they were really friendly.  The food was amazingly delicious.  We got nachos for the table (SO DELICIOUS, get these to share!), I ordered a patty melt (amazingly good - everything about it was to die for) and I ended the meal with a 'choco taco' which is like a deconstructed ice cream taco that users sour cream ice cream and will blow your mind with your uniquely amazing it is.  Just trust me and get it.

Highly recommend, but make a reservation!

My family and I are long time fans of Stephanie from Top Chef so we were excited to hear about her little brunch place. The line was pretty long and the restaurant was crowded but for good reason. The ambiance of the place is very friendly and cute.

I ordered the peanut butter butter and bacon waffles while my sister ordered the fried chicken French toast. The bacon was a little too greasy for my taste, but the waffles were great with the peanut butter. I'd probably definitely order this again. My sister likes the French toast but she was a little thrown off by the combination of the strawberries and chicken and the fact that the eggs were fried inside the bread. Nevertheless she loved it.

My friend ordered the pulled pork sandwich which she liked and my mom had the yogurt with granola. Love this place and would definitely go back if I ever got the chance.

pics.caption: Fried chicken French toast with strawberries!
Peanut butter butter and bacon waffles with maple syrup!

review.des: Great place to dine. Food is familiar with top quality and expert preparation. It is fun to eat such delicious food in such a casual environment. This is NOT your average diner! The extensive menu has something for everyone, including the vegetarian I was dining with. I would definitely recommend this spot in the west loop if you aren't looking for something super swanky.

LOVE this place! Everything on the menu is a creative take on a classic. Even the dishes that had flavor combinations I wasn't used to at all really blew me away. I got a salad there (off of the dinner menu) that was the best salad I've ever had!

The space has the classiest diner-inspired decorating I've ever seen, and definitely makes me feel okay about spending a little extra on more casual fare.

It does get very busy, so plan accordingly. There's a bar space in the back where you can hang out to wait for a table. It includes a little gift shop and a window that looks into the bakery!

Very cool experience that makes me excited to try the other Izard spots.

I got together with a former co-worker to celebrate my move to NYC today at Little Goat. This is the second time I've been to the restaurant in the past 2 weeks and each time we arrived a couple of minutes before our reservation but still had to wait to be seated. My assumption is because people wind up staying at their tables too long but who knows. Usually I always get a burger and they're phenomenal but I wanted to switch it up this time. I ordered THIS LITTLE PIGGY WENT TO CHINA. It was sooooo good. I will definitely order again and I'm upset I never got it before today. Service was good, a little slower than normal. It's midday on a Saturday so I get it. I will obviously be back again :)

Came here as a second choice to the two hour wait down the street for Sunday brunch. Waited an hour, food was awesome and staff was friendly and attentive. The place was packed and can accommodate large groups. Music was lively, and it's a great place for families with young children.

Located in Westloop, I came here for Brunch on a holiday with two of my girlfriends.

Without any reservations, wait time was about 30 minutes. They give you the option for a private table (usually a booth) or first table available. Family-dinerlike atmosphere.

Love that their dishes are infused with Asian cuisine. Three of us ordered a dish and shared with one another.

Pork belly pancakes ($13) - Scallion pancake house hoisin bok Choy salad ginger maple dressing. This was delicious. I would come back again and order this.

Parathas burrito ($13) Indians flatbread sunny side eggs, Avacado bean, salad. This was also delicious.

Bulls eye French toast ($16)  Eggs, crispy chicken, sweet onion ,brioche, bbq ,maple syrup

I want to come back here and try other things on the menu when I come back to Chicago!

I've been here twice and both times I've been a little unimpressed. I don't know if it's because Girl and the Goat is THAT good that this pales in comparison, but I've had mediocre service both times, and while the food is decent, it wasn't anything crazy.

The prices aren't absurd, luckily, but the diner feel + refined variations of traditional diner entrees kind of hit me as strange.

Luckily both times I've gone I've gotten to skip the wait. I think I'd come again but never if I had to wait in line...which, especially on weekends, can get a little crazy

PS I have to say, though, the choco taco = winning.

We went here because Au Cheval had a 2.5 hour wait. It was great! I got the club sandwich and my wife got a goat burger. Both were good. We really liked the crab cheese dip appetizer with the ritz crackers.

Our waiter was excellent. He had multiple tables and even one very large group of 8-10 people. He did a fantastic job attending to us and all the tables.

For the price, it was on the higher end for what you got but it was more of a trendy place. It might have been a little to hipster for me but my wife enjoyed it.

Out with friends for Sunday brunch we decided to try this place. We went at 1130 and there was already a 2hour wait, so make reservations or be prepared to wait. Once we were all seated, we ordered, and got our food fast. We had a great waitress who was very patient with our large party. I ordered a burger with cheese fries that were amazing!!! Another member of our party got fried mashed potatoes...it wasn't so good.
Overall we each had a good time and would come back, this time with a reservation.

So I have followed Little Goat Diner on Instagram for awhile now and I knew my next trip to Chicago would include a visit. OH. MY. WORD ... I am in love with this place. Make a reservation on Open Table to make sure you're one of the lucky ones who do t ha e to wait to enjoy this slice.  I chose my meal based on what I saw passing tables and it wasn't easy to decide. I ended up with Bulls Eye's French toast which was awesome and my daughter went with This Little Piggy Went To China. They were both amazing and out of this world. We shared an order of hash browns that had warm goat cheese in the middle. Who knew it would be that  fantastic! The coffee was even an A+. Our waitress Gillian was also phenomenal.  You can't go wrong here!

pics.caption: This Little Piggy Went To China

review.des:
Wow! The Los Drowned is definitely something I dream about still! The braised beef is perfect! So tender. So juicy.

The hoagie (bottom bun) is perfectly soaked with all the juices and spices and the pickled cabbages just balances out all the taste. You guys have to try this! We came on a rainy day and didn't have to wait at all.

1.5 hour wait but the food definitely didn't disappoint. I ordered the piggy went to China dish and at some point I thought about licking the plate.
My group and I shared some sides - Mac and cheese and the smoked fries. The sides were okay, it wasn't bad but nothing I would crave again.

pics.caption: Little piggy that went to China.  Blackberries were surprisingly good on it!

review.des:
We walked in on a rainy Saturday night and they were able to seat us within thirty minutes, which was great. We grabbed a drink at the bar while we waited. We ended up sitting at the countertops, which was pleasant and the service was attentive.

We had burgers and split the Mac n cheese. I had the kimchi burger which was delicious and pretty unique. The egg was a great touch. It was a little under for medium; it was pretty pink on the inside. My friend's burger was good as well, but her bun was so soggy it was impossible to pick the burger up. The Mac n cheese was delicious and was surprisingly light; it was definitely enough for the two of us to share.

After going to girl and the goat, I was very disappointed with Little Goat. My boyfriend and I came here for lunch on a whim when we were in the city. We loved Girl and the Goat and figured we would love this retro diner from the same owner. However, the service left more to be desired and the food wasn't anywhere near as good as Girl and the Goat. A little coffee area is conjoined with the diner. I didn't try the coffee, but it looked really cute and we decided to wait in that area.

Food: After about a 40 min wait, we were seated in the stools, which were very uncomfortable. We got the machos nachos, fish tostadas, and Bahn Mi Style burger. The best part of the meal was the machos nachos. It was packed with flavor. I loved the pickled peppers! It was a surprising sweet flavor mixed with delicious fatty and buttery pulled pork. The sauce was an added bonus. The rest of the food left more to be desired. The fish tostadas didn't have a lot of flavor and were hard to eat. I love fish tacos and adding chickpeas to the mix only sounds good. I wish the fish was flakey and had more flavor. The bahn mi style burger was pretty good. It was much better on paper than it was in my stomach. It is hard to pinpoint exactly what was wrong as I am not an executive chef, but it was just lacking something to put it over the top. A delicious sauce or some fresh veggies would have done wonders. Overall, it was ok.

Service: The service was pretty bad. We were sitting on the stools and watched the food pop out. However, it took 20 mins to have someone notice us. All the waitresses were so focused on their tables they forgot about us! Eventually we had to flag someone down to take our order and she passed us along to someone else. She was prompt enough getting our drinks, but the food took longer. Since we had the view, we saw our food sitting through the food window for a while. All she had to do was literally pick up the food turn around and place it in front of us. She must have decided since we weren't a table it wasn't worth her time.

Overall, I will probably give Little Goat another chance. I'll get the nachos again, but may try one of their fancier sandwiches or maybe a breakfast item. Either way, the next time I go, I will go with much lower expectations.

Amazing brunch experience after church. We had a short 20 min wait before our private table was ready. Jillian is so kind and has so much energy. I appreciate her patience in explaining some of the meals and helping me make a decision. I had the Bulls Eye French toast. Mostly because my friend couldn't stop raving about how good it was and I wasn't feeling super adventurous.

The French toast was pretty good. Flavorful with maple syrup, strawberries, and cooked well. I wasn't expecting the Bulls eye to be sunny side up eyes in the actual bread. It was interesting since I usually overlook my eggs. I will return for another meal in the future but probably won't order that again.

pics.caption: Not where I expected the egg to be

review.des:
This Little Pig Went to China - Way too salty, too much going on.  I tried to avoid the sauce as much as possible and the food was still oversalted and overseasoned.  The pepper in the dish was paralyzingly numb.  The food could have been served without any sauce and it would have been fine.

Okonomiyaki - Was expecting more pork belly to come with the dish.  Instead, it was served as thin slivers on top.  Not substantial enough.

Great spot to try while in Chicago if you couldn't get reservations for the Girl and Goat. This sister restaurant was perfect for brunch.
Easy to get to via the L train or Uber from River North.
One big thing to note- they have a gluten free menu (just ask) and were very accommodating to those with celiac disease.
This girl however went full gluten and got the this little piggy went to China!

pics.caption: Amazing Asian inspired biscuit and gravy "this little piggy went to China"

review.des: This joint IS NOT BLUE COLAR FRIENDLY.  My self and 2 associates arrived at 9:15 the place was empty. They had my name and asked us to wait while they cleared a table. THE PLACE WAS EMPTY. A couple walk in and are seated immediately then 2 girls walk in and again seated immediately. I informed my associates and we left  we went to Wishbone. Fantastic service there.

Oh Little Goat, I do love you so.  Please give me all of your crab dip all of the time!

I've been to Little Goat for brunch and I've also organized a private party.  Both experiences were great.  

Brunch was crowded, even early, but they take brunch reservations so if you're able to do a little pre-planning, you should be good.  We all enjoyed everything we tried.  I kind of forgot everything everyone else got because my eyes were on the prize.  The prize being the bullseye french toast.  Imagine my surprise when I cut into that baby, forgetting that egg was on the description.  A hidden egg inside my french toast and fried chicken!  Awesome.  The coffee is great and the bloody mary was fine by me.  

Fast forward to planning my work's holiday party.  That french toast was still on my mind, so I decided to blow some company money to satisfy my whims.  Working with the event staff was a breeze.  

We had the sweet kitchen space to ourselves and were greeted with smiles and snacks.  I wanted to scoop the crab dip into my purse for later.  I'm like a tacky grandma in that way.  We tried a ton of family style menu items, the highlight of which was the goat leg.  If you're doing an event there, it is well worth adding.  Everything we tried was great and the cocktails were also fabulous.  

Great food, friendly staff, a photobooth, and that patio will have me scheming more ways to plan another event here.

I did my research on restaurants in Chicago and chose Little Goat to celebrate my birthday as well as 6 month milestone of my first pregnancy. I had family members from out of town and various parts of the city come together to celebrate. Little Goats IRRESPONSIBLE policy turned a celebratory event into an unfortunate night that ruined a special evening for my family and I.

I did my due diligence and RSVP'd a table for 15 people two weeks in advance. I adhered to their rules for larger parties on the weekend and agreed to an 8pm dinner slot. When little goat called 30 minutes prior to our arrival to confirm number of guest I promptly responded 15 people.

We arrived at 7:45pm and was told the table was being prepared as the current customers were wrapping up and paying checks.
8pm, the time of our reservation, we are told the customers have paid and we are waiting for them leave.
8:20pm told the same, the customers have paid and we are waiting for them to leave, it's our policy that we cannot ask a table to leave even if there is an RSVP.

Which is irresponsible of management to do so. As a restaurant owner myself we make it clear to walk-ins if there is a large party we are prepping for. When calling around to other restaurants it was made clear to me that there was a time frame due to other RSVP's.  

8:48pm - the customers are still seated and squatting already having paid and are just chatting. we are seated in a desperate attempt by management in TWO separate booths. This offer was ridiculous- and defeats the purpose of a celebratory meal by separating and closing off the parties. At this point, feeling defeated and experiencing the intense hunger 6months of pregnancy brings - I obliged.

The night was ruined, fatigue, hunger, hormones and sadness had taken over my excitement of celebration and I ended up crying for most of the dinner service. My family did their best to be complaint free and passive on the mistreatment but it was clear they also were defeated.

I recognize the staff did what they could to get us a table quickly and it's unfortunate the staff is tied down to a IRRESPONSIBLE POLICY!

The staff apologized profusely, offered free apps, and after the party being split into two booths and myself speaking to the floor manager to discuss the debacle refunded our meal.

Though, it wasn't about the money or the apologies. The celebrations had been lost.  The people of my family took times from hectic schedules, to pause and take a moment to come together and share our lives together, and Little Goat's Policy and handle of the RSVP was a complete failure.

I started with the homemade Bloody Mary mix, different, but amazing. Luckily my daughter and I got a spot at the bar and didn't have to wait 20 mins. Friday afternoon. We shared 2 meals and I absolutely loved the corned beef hash. More like grilled corned beef over shoe stringed hash potatoes with eggs over easy. Delicious!!   Beef brisket sandwich was also fabulous. Ok, I liked it. Even though at first I didn't think I'd like the Asian influences in my brunch. The bakery and coffee bar is also good
This place is awesome! The korean burger was out of this world and I love their cinnamon rolls! You have to go multiple times so you can try all the goodness!

We went back and this time I had the spiced apple pancakes and my BF had the shrimp and cheese grits with two fried eggs on top. We also had the Dark Matter Coffee. Everything was very good and the waiter was friendly and approachable. The only complaint we had was that we had to sit at the counter, which is right near kitchen. It was very hot and we were both sweating which made it difficult to enjoy our food to the fullest extent. Hopefully next time there will be tables/booths available.

Huge, varied menu with delicious options including brunch served all day. Lots of interesting twists on classic brunch fare including pork belly pancakes and Cajun crab crumpets. I had the "Little Piggy Went to China" and it was a delicious - eggs, biscuit, Szechuan sausage, and a delicious sauce. Fiancée ordered the pork belly pancakes and they were perfectly balanced with the slaw/salad on top.

We also ordered a side of Brussel sprouts which were good enough to eat as an entree. Whole meal was $39 with tax (before tip).

Decor is hip and clean and the staff is friendly and offered lots of recommendations. Will definitely return and highly recommend.
It was ok   Food was good and so was the service   but it was really crowed and hard to enjoy the food
Also a nice discovery while visiting for a class.  Been a long time since I was there but I wanted to make sure folks knew of this great place.  I'll be back the next time I am in the city!

What is there to say that hasn't already been said in the 2K yelp reviews? Aside from the amazing food, the service was also outstanding! Our server took the time to chat with us about the menu and our trip to Chicago. We ordered the crab dip, shrimp & cheesey grits, and the corn beef hash. Granted we came from brunch on a Sunday so it is expected for the kitchen to be backed up. We finished both the crab dip and the shrimp & grits and waited a good 10 minutes before the corn beef hash came. It was definitely worth the wait!

Bright, sunny, and clean inside decor with a slight retro diner vibe with booth and counter seats.

As for food, the menu looked amazing. From breakfast eats to classic sandwiches, I loved how the menu offered the staple diner items but also infused it's own twist into the dishes. I got the goat-o goat-o which was the perfect summer salad. Light, crisp, and cool with a flavorful dressing that leaves you perfectly content and not overly weighed down by something too greasy.
little goat to go. is soooooooooo painful. completely disorganized. i've never waited 30 minutes for a latte, I couldn't image how bad it would be if it was actually busy.

Wow I must say this place got me nocked out with their vegan menu and the chooses, A+ guys! I really thought this place won't have a single vegan item on the menu, the service was amazing food chooses and how it came out were also incredible little over salted I had their vegan local burger, and the savory mushroom pancake.

TIP: reduce the sodium content, and start advertising vegan on Yelp as well because when I yelped vegan places this place did not show up.

Nothing amazing. Diner food. I had heard their sister restaurant Girl and the Goat was amazing but we couldn't get a table so wandered across the street here for dinner. My husband and I both started with the crab dip which was more cream cheese than crab. We then ordered sandwiches which were also underwhelming. Meh, don't think I would come back. Service was also extremely slow.

My oh my. What have I done.
My waiter. I hate him. He said it was worth trying.
I've ruined my life. I've eaten the greatest burger ever.

This place is amazing. The portions are gargantuan. My friends and I came here after a long day of work on a Monday and it was still packed. We originally tried to go to Goat on the Grill (same owner), but of course there was a 2 hour wait on a Monday night at 8 pm... So we headed over here to get some diner food. I was of course skeptical because there was no way diner food would live up to the insane amount of hype I was hearing from my friends. But man, this place is fantastic. Awe-inspiring. Think food buds exploding into a symphony in your mouth. Best yet, the drinks are fantastic and so is the coffee.

We ordered some smoked fries and nachos to start. Skip the fries, the nachos are humongous and taste so good. My friends got a bunch of other sandwiches, but the best by far was the Asian pork belly sandwich and this ridiculous Goat almighty burger. WARNING: If you order the burger, prepare to be full for the rest of your life. And maybe puke if you finish all of it that night.

Chicago has amazing food... if only you had good weather. I would live here.

pics.caption: All hail the Goat Almighty burger

review.des: Love this place.    Service amazing and I love the menu.  So much to look at and try.   If you can check out the roof top area.   Little goat a must
I mean, who doesn't love upscale diner food with cocktails?! Fun vibe with a photo booth. Breakfast all day. The sandwiches are pretty big.
Amazing. Worth the wait. Had the Rueben. Thought it would be huge and sloppy. I was so surprised that it was a normal human portion. It was delicious I licked the plate.

We wanted to like this restaurant so badly.  Great location, great decor, and friendly staff, but sadly it was the food that is getting the two star ratings.   My husband for the Reuben sandwich and I the braised beef sandwich (Los Dunk I think?) mine was supposed to be braised which to me means tender meat.  This was a poor piece of beef cut in big slices and reheated on the flat top, causing it to be so tough I couldn't but through any part of it and full of fat. It came with an awesome dipping sauce, but there was so much wetness from all the other stuff they put on the sandwich it was already falling apart before I picked it up.   Same for my husband, way too much sauce on his sandwich.  Total bill with tip $90 for two drinks, two crappy sandwiches, (no sides) and a kids meal and drink!

Stopped here on a Sunday for brunch. It was great! Portions are very generous so come hungry! The biscuits and hashbrowns were so good! They told us it would be an hour wait but we went straight back to the cafe/bar area and were seated immediately!

Little goat is one of my favorite places in the city! From their brunch menu to their nachos, I have yet to find something I haven't liked from here. Came here for brunch recently, I got the bulls eye French toast! Toast and chicken, how can I say no to that?! It was delicious! The chicken was crispy and tender, the syrup was sweet, and the egg mixed with toast was in replaceable. Will definitely be coming back for more!

Came in here for lunch on our trip. We sat at the bar by the kitchen. My husband ordered a burger. I ordered a mac and cheese along with Chilly. My husband's burger sat out for about 10 minutes before they brought it to him with my food. We asked if they could take it back and make another as it was cold and the girl that organizes all the food for the servers (wears glasses has dark brown hair and asian eyes) said yes. We were watching them for a bit and the burger was then brought back to my husband after about another 10 minutes and it was still cold. We are positive they didn't do anything at all to his burger so we are very disappointed with this restaurant. Nevertheless- for being a diner - it is pricey. Go get brunch some where else like the BombaBar.

Little Goat Diner gives you a true diner experience with gourmet food. I was totally blown away. When I arrived there was a huge crowd outside so I knew the waiting list was long. I didn't care, I was going to wait it out. Then when I told the hostess I was a lone diner, she informed if I didn't mind sitting at the counter, she could seat me immediately. Sometimes it pays to eat alone.

Once I was seated, the two girls to my left were finished and leaving. I quickly chatted them up for recommendations and they said I had to experience the Brussels Sprouts. I shared with them my recent love affair with Brussels Sprouts and how I hated them as a child. They both confessed the same thing, so I knew I had to try them.

I'm fan of Bloody Mary's, especially on a Sunday morning. However, I am also a big fan of a Moscow Mule. When I saw a Moscow Goat on their cocktail menu, I knew it was meant to be. Their Moscow Goat is Bombay Dry Gin, Ginger Beer and Grapefruit with lime garnish. Oh, so refreshing. If only we could start every morning with one of these.

I had every intention of having breakfast, since they serve it all day. However, since it was nearly 1 PM and the girls had recommended the sprouts, I had to change to my lunch plan. I was going to try their Ruben, I wanted to add a new entry to my list here on Yelp.  Then as I was talking to my hispster waiter, I had a sudden piffany. I'm at the Little Goat DIner, so I should eat goat. I selected the Kilgus Goat Burger as my sandwich. For those of you have not tried goat before, don't be scared, give it a try.

My burger was just as flavorful as any beef, lamb or bison burger. It was served on a Sesame Seed bun with the traditional burger garnishes. I had my pickle, onion, special sauce (what would a burger be without special sauce), lettuce and tomato.
There was no need for ketchup or mustard, this burger was a winner just the way it was served.

The Stir Fried Brussels Sprouts were a little too crunchy for me. and could have used a lttle more seasoning. Don't get me wrong, they were good, but my favorite sprouts are at The Pump Room.

I can not wait for my next trip to Chicago, I'll be back at the Little Goat Diner for breakfast. I've gotta try those biscuits and gravy.

Good but not great.  My Fat Club fell flat on flavor.  The Bull's Eye French Toast portion was much smaller than expected.  I was picturing a larger portion of more traditional fried chicken.  The nachos were the star of the afternoon.  The house made chips stayed crispy and the topping proportions were on point.

Last time we came for brunch there was a mega line. This time we wisened up, though, got there nice and early and we were seated right away. Score.
We started with the Asian style breakfast thingy-- really good, kinda like a savory pancake scramble.

For dessert, the dark chocolate pancakes. They were totally good but also pretty standard, nothing crazy out of this world like some of the other stuff on the menu.

Very good, makes me want to try the chefs other restaurants. Had the pancake wrapped goat meat hot dog. Was really tasty. Bloody Mary was spicy, kinda garlicky, it's "kimchee" spiced but doesn't have that fermented taste really. Definitely worth a try and a revisit to try what you didn't get the first time.

pics.caption: Breakfast special: goat hot dog wrapped with pancake, topped with over easy eggs, scallions, maple syrup. Delicious.

review.des: I thought this was good, not great. I had the grilled cheese which was very rich but tasty enough. I couldn't taste the bacon. The fried pickles and onions were not good. They were tempura battered which I didn't expect , I wish that had been in the description. They were very bland , incredibly flavorless. I should've sent them back. My husband liked his scallion pancake. My daughter's chocolate chip pancakes were no better then any others she's had. Our waiter was nice and I did have a good cocktail. I'm glad I tried it but I would not go out of my way to return.

First time in this place. Probably not as fancy as the others around the Fulton market area but still has nice casual atmosphere, good food and nice waiting area, aka the bar.
We did the burgers- Korean and Bahn Mi and both were good. But I've had better. The smoked fries as a side came out quick but not sure if I'll tag them as one of the best of its kind.

But I'll revisit once more for breakfast as the menu looks enticing

This place  seems to get the raved, but I wasn't really won over by it.

I get that the french toast is a favorite and everyone loves a diner, but a lot of it seemed over the top. They did have some simpler options for breakfast diners that might not want a fancy dish, things such as bagels and fruit cups. The entrees were great and a huge portion, but really no side was considerable or pushed by the wait staff. I like variety in my meal, so this wasn't something I was all that excited about. The food seemed very well prepared, but not something you would take home to reheat, if you know what I mean.

On my last visit, I had the pork torta. It is essentially cochinita pibil that they call "yucatan," which seemed only different in the sense of they didn't slow roast it quite the same. The waitress was totally unprepared to talk about what "yucatan" might have meant. I like it when we can have a little conversation about the taste of the dish and not just, "It's liked stewed shredded pork on a bun. Yucatan style." Hmm.

The restaurant itself is pretty cool. Cozy. Get a reservation if it's dinner time!

I'd definitely go again, but just wasn't my deal. I'm glad they call it a "diner" in name, so people know what to expect.

Little Goat is "little" inside, but definitely not small in flavors.

The more casual version of its older sister, Little Goat brings classic American diner food to the trendy scene with more gourmet offerings. Just don't forget--it's still diner food.

They have breakfast options all day, along with sandwiches, salads and burgers, just as you would expect. But my goodness me, that Goat burger is a sight to behold and a monster to eat (though I did attempt it). So many different meats and flavors and textures....your mom and pop diner sure ain't got no burger like this. If you're hungry and ready to eat, then you're ready for this.

The corn was alright, and the fries could be much better (along with the timeliness of service). They do have a full bar menu which is definitely something to keep in your back pocket.

If you're looking for a quick and tasty meal, this is your place. Otherwise, you may want to walk across the street for a more than casual experience.

I recently learned from a waitress that they use beef in the goat chili. They don't tell anyone. It doesn't say so on the menu. I don't eat beef and I was horrified to learn this; I have been eating there since they opened.

I was shocked!

We went there for dinner, 9PM, and when we looked at the menu it was mostly breakfast dishes.

I don't regret, I had one of the best burgers ever.
We ordered two glasses of wine served in short glasses, i found it awesome.

My wife ordered a nice vegetarian noodles which wa also great!

It is too complicated to get a reservation here, this is why I didn't give 5 stars.
