Five of us had breakfast at Little Goat Diner last weekend.  I was not overly excited about the food, the coffee or the service.  I ordered a veggie omelette and the omelette was greasy, flat (not fluffy like most omelettes) and the veggies were tasteless.  Toast needed to be ordered a la carte for an extra $3.  The brewed coffee and the lattes were lukewarm.  We said something to our server about the temp of the coffee and nothing changed with the next round of coffees.  We mentioned it again and no solution was offered.  Our server seemed nice, but was not engaged with us, friendly or warm/welcoming.  The whole experience was very mediocre.  I don't plan to return soon or recommend Little Goat Diner to friends.

Had birthday brunch! This has been added to my 'Must Have' list for my Chicago trips.  The wait was about 30min without a reservation on a Friday afternoon.  It was well worth the wait. I got the French toast, it had a over easy egg in the center with chopped fried chicken.  It was soooo good, however I would recommend getting the BBQ maple syrup on the side, its thin and caused the other slice to get soggy.  My best friend ordered the shrimp and grits, OMG, the best I've ever had.  Everything was fresh and full of flavor.  Going back before heading back to AZ!

I was disappointed in the quality of the food, given the reviews this restaurant gets.

THE GOOD
The atmosphere is cute and the outside tables look very relaxing.

THE MEH
We ordered takeout, so I don't expect fantastic presentation or extremely hot food, so I did not take points of for either of those. We order takeout from many diners, so I know what to expect.

We ordered:

Corn beef hash -- Interesting take on this dish, where the corn beef is not cubed, it is five inch slices of corn beef. In my opinion -- ick. And the hash browns were soggy, greasy, and at the same time al dente. I have never had al dente hash browns before...they were spiralized potatoes -- love the creativity-- but they were crunchy and not because they had been browned (which I would love). They were crunchy because they were slightly raw. To my taste, the only crunch I want in hash browns is on the outside of a fully cooked potato. This was a sloppy, unsightly mess. If I had been eating at the restaurant, I would have politely sent it back.

Cheese grits -- overall pretty good

Cinnamon roll -- looked delicious with all the icing on top, but dry on the inside and just not worth he calories. It looked like it was going to taste amazing, but was in fact pretty dull. Do not expect anything like an Ann Sathers roll because it's not even close.

Parking is also very scarce and valet is $14, so I have higher expectations. Not sure it's worth the hassle to park. I'd probably go to the Palace Grill next time.

pics.caption: Corn beef hash -- huge slices of corn beef with greasy underdone spiralized potatoes. A disappointment.

review.des: Felt like having a hearty breakfast today to fill the engine with good gas for running errands in this tropical weather we're experiencing in Chicago today. (10 degrees - insert palm tree).  Corned beef hash and eggs, poached.  (Sometimes I like to make the dish messy like a five year old and break the yolk to watch the ooze).  The hash browns in the mix were crispy and tasty, bits of smoked corned beef for flavor and one of the eggs was perfectly poached, the other was the Danny Devito of the pair. (Referencing the movie Twins). A very good portion though, just needed a wee bit more salt.

pics.caption: I had cinnamon roll envy, but I couldn't eat that then..... Until today #gladpassoverisover
Oatmeal with blueberry and fresh made honey yogurt

review.des: Always fantastic!  Get a reservation if you can (if not, stop into one of Fulton Market's bars for an hour or so wait for weekend brunch).  The drinks are good, the food is fantastic and the waitstaff is great.

Food was good. Service was good. Hostess station was a nightmare. Even with a reservation we waited probably 20 minutes. Then, a couple in our group brought their baby and it was like there had never been a baby in the building before. The high chairs were too low for our booth so I asked the hostesses to brainstorm other solutions (another table, perhaps or re-arrange seating). They literally didn't reply so I said "What would you recommend? What would you do in my situation? Still no reply. They just shrugged. I couldn't believe it.  I would go again for the food but I'd never, ever book a group there again.

Went here on a Tuesday night to enjoy a casual diner style meal. The service was great and we were sat right away. I loved the diner style booths and seating options.

The burger I got was amazing. I would definitely recommend to anyone looking for a casual and quality meal with a great atmosphere.
Great place for a quick bite.  Everything on the menu is solid.  Really enjoyed the nachos.

Came to Little Goat with a coworker for lunch. I wasn't sure how packed it'd be, but glad we made reservations because it was a full house that day. I ordered off of the secret vegan menu and got vegetable tostadas and a side of mac and cheese. The food came out fast and the portions were huge. I fell in love with the mac and cheese! So creamy and delicious. The perfect pairing for the crummy weather we were having outside. The tostadas were good, but a little hard to eat and the shells were pretty oily, but the vegetable mix and seasoning was on point and I packed up my leftovers to eat later. Love the variety in their menu and will definitely be coming back.

I came to Little Goat for breakfast on a Saturday morning and had a very enjoyable meal.

Deocr: It should come as no surprise that this place has a hipster vibe to it. The décor doesn't really allude to it that much, it feels a bit more like a '70's diner to be honest, but you can feel the vibe. You shouldn't hold that as a negative, however, because it is very well lit (via natural light from the windows and HUGE skylight) and everything is very clean and open. The setup is nice too, there are plenty of tables and booths of different sizes along with a counter you can sit at if rolling solo (like I was).
Bathroom: unknown

Staff: My waitress was very nice but she didn't really check in on me too much. Normally that wouldn't be an issue, esp b/c she did keep my water glass filled, but this time I would've preferred it (see food section for reason).

Food: I started with the cinnamon bun and WOW was it tasty! Much of the deliciousness can, and should be, attributed to the frosting thought because the bun itself was not very good. In fact, mine was cold and pretty hard... it almost seemed like it was leftover from the previous day. For my meal I had the Corned Beef Hash and it was OUTSTANDING! This was my first time having CBH and it was a treat. The hash browns were very thinly sliced and crisped to perfection and the corned beef was so tasty. Additionally they have two eggs on top (I had mine poached) but really it could use probably four total - the yolk adds such good flavor to the whole dish.

Value: The prices, given this place's popularity and location, are not bad and very in line with what you'd expect.

I only came for breakfast but I really enjoyed it. Not only do I want to come back with others for breakfast, I want to try other meals as well (which, apparently, they serve all day!)

Couldn't get reservations for the Girl and the Goat so my friends and I tried the next best thing. We got reservations and still had to wait about 15 minutes, which is understandable given the popularity of Little Goat.

We ordered the Bulls Eye French toast that came with fried chicken and strawberries. This was by far my favorite dish. The French toast had more egg content than normal French toast, but it worked and I really liked it. The fried chicken and strawberries and syrup perfectly complemented the French toast. SO GOOD. Definitely hit the bull's eye on this one.

We also ordered the Fat Elvis Waffles. The peanut butter-butter was delicious, but I felt like there was not enough of it! Maybe because it was so good.... The dish also had bananas which went well with the waffles. Overall a good dish, but more peanut butter-butter please!

In addition, we ordered two sides. Mac n Cheese and the Cheesy grits. The Mac n Cheese was really good! The Cheesy grits were just average and nothing really special.

Wow, Chicago has such good restaurants and this is definitely one of them! I look forward to coming back when I visit Chicago again!

pics.caption: BULLS EYE FRENCH TOAST. MUST GET.

review.des: The French toast with fried chicken and a fried egg in the middle is absolutely fantastic! It was fairly large so I had enough for leftovers. My companions each had the blueberry pancakes and both were happy with their choices. The pancakes looked deliciously fluffy! Can't wait to bring my boyfriend here for breakfast!

pics.caption: French toast with fried chicken and a fried egg in the middle with a side of BBQ maple syrup

review.des: It's a Stephanie Izard restaurant, so can't be bad. Service was a bit slow and kind of like "you're going to deal with it because we are a popular place." I dig that they serve breakfast all day, although I am more of a lunch person myself. Everything is ala cart so if you order one of their amazing sandwiches, be prepared to order a side of fries for eight dollars. I have to say though for what it is worth, they have the best fountain Diet Coke I have ever had!

What an incredibly cool and hip restaurant. I loved their thick ceramic coffee mug so much I actually ended up buying in their gift shop. Now, I need to buy another one cause my husband keeps using it for himself!

I was overwhelmed by their food choices, so I decided to ask the waitress her top choices. My eyes kept glancing at their apple granola pancakes (and I'm salivating just thinking about it) I was happy to hear that was her top choice, and my god, it was the best pancakes I've ever had.  I don't even know where to begin -- the crunchy tasty granola on top...the fluffy thick pancakes, the syrup...man, it was that good and I will get it again when I come back.

Unfortunately I don't remember what my sister got, but it was an egg with a biscuit and Mexican spices. I tasted it and it was also excellent.

My mom ordered their oatmeal and we shared a side of eggs and bacon -- because, why not?  Wish I could fit in dessert...another reason to come back here!

americaninvienna.com

pics.caption: Breakfast was so so good (my favorite was the apple granola pancakes)    instagram.com/michelle_t…

review.des: This was my first time at little goat and I enjoyed it. It was a cozy atmosphere, good customer service and the food was tasty and filling!

The Little gout was pretty good.  This us not the place if you're in a hurry but a great place uf you are ready to be full.  All of the food I tried was great.  I had the Korean Burger with Beef and loved it.  I also had the Home Fries that I add whichbwas more than I could eat.

The pork tastes amazong that is on the All Mighty Goat.  You will likely have left overs if you order that.

The hash browns were also really popular among my group.  It was a consensus to stay away from the Smoke Fries.  They weren't very good but did deliver on the taste of smoke but I wouldn't say in a good way.
Great environment and the staff was ok.  I'd come back next time I'm in Chicago for sure.
Amazing. There's nothing much else to say. I had the Fat Elvis and it had bacon syrup. Who does that?! lol. If you have the chance to eat here do it!

Went for breakfast. Loved the cheesy hash browns and their special bagel (can't remember what it was called but it was a creative combination of ingredients). They get five stars for having gender neutral bathrooms. THANK YOU!
One complaint about those bathrooms though was the very strong air "freshener" that wafted into the dining room each time someone opened the bathroom door. So I suggest ask for a seat away from the bathroom.

Also service was excellent.
They are so sweet and kind here. I got to try a lot of good food with a friend and I can see what the hype is. Delicious! Loved it. Thankful for their hospitality!

I know most people come here for brunch, but their dinner is equally good. My guy was craving something wholesome and we ended up coming here on a Thursday night around 6:30pm. There was no wait for the counter. The food here reminds me of a up-scale diner with unique combo of choices!
We started with the biscuits and gravy, and the gravy was hearty and the biscuit so flaky, it was a good start. Then I had the special menu's lamb with sauted veggies, and my companion got the beef stew. The lamb was tender, and with the contrast of the crunchy veggies, and thin sweet potato glass noodles with some peanut sauce, it was a tasty bite! The meat itself was a little under-seasoned, but everything together tasted great.
I also tasted the beef stew- which was hearty with pull-apart meat and mashed potatoes underneath. It tasted ever better the second day (leftovers).
Overall, out service was good, the food was great, and I know we will be back!

little goat is one of my favorite restaurants in chicago! i've been countless times- on one of my first dates with my boyfriend, when my cousin came to town for dinner, and to brunch with a friend of mine. to be honest, i've only had three things on the menu after all this time: bloody mary, bibimbap, and the kale chickpea salad.

the bloody mary is perfectly spicy, and always makes the time go by when i come in on a whim for brunch and have to wait for a table. love it! the bibimbap is pretty good, and i especially love it because it has cauliflower rice instead of normal rice.

however, the main dish to write home about is the salad. i know it sounds crazy to write about a salad, but this is no ordinary salad. i truly think it is the best salad in chicago! i used to add chicken on it, but with the chickpeas and falafel bites, there's really no need for extra protein- it's HUGE. and so, so delicious. PLEASE go get it. you wont regret it!!
Little goat is a cool diner that has unique diner food. I personally enjoy the nachos. They have great beer and really good brunch. They also have a photo booth to enjoy with friends.

1st review, 2nd visit to Stephanie Izard's Little Goat in the West Loop. Went for brunch with two friends around 9:30-9:45 on a Saturday morning. My half-asleep and disheveled self was rewarded by us getting seated immediately. Score. The wait was muuuuuuch longer by the time we finished eating.

Started off with their version of a cinnabon. It was really good and definitely big enough to share. For entrees we shared the double chocolate chip pancakes, the tasty Asian breakfast thingy and the french toast. The pancakes were great, perfect consistency and the right amount of chocolate. French toast was amazing and the friend chicken piled on top was perfectly crispy. The wild Asian breakfast plate was a fun combination of kimchi, pancakes, eggs and bacon. Lots of flavors but not overwhelming!

Little Goat has one of the more unique and creative brunch menus in Chicago. If not for really slow service throughout our entire meal I would have given it 5 stars. Would definitely go again!

I have not found a cinnamon roll better than a Cinnabon (as much as I hate to admit this chain had the best cinnamon buns I ever had), until I came to Little Goat Diner and had their Ooey Gooey Cinnabun!  Hard to find one that is as soft and chewy and oh so gooey with the right kind of cream cheese icing but they nailed it!  We were lucky enough to snag an early RSVP and one of the 50 cinnamon rolls they make daily on the weekends (only 25 made daily on the week days). Definitely best eaten at the diner as it's served hot n' fresh!  The lusciously overflowing icing is just what it needs to elevate this to top notch without being overly sweet. Do yourself a favor and get in early!  

As you'll come to find, one of the types of cuisines that excites me the most is Asian fusion!  Fusions inspire culinary creativity, and that makes my blood rush! Little Goat did it again with this twist on breakfast. "This Little Piggy Went to China" (sesame cheddar biscuit. sunny eggs. Szechuan pork sausage. chili garlic chive sauce. blackberries.) Different ingredients married together to create this fun play on the traditional eggs, sausage, and biscuit dish.  Blackberries? (Shrugs) It worked.  Nothing boring here.

Best hash brown potatoes!!  I like my string hash browns CRISPY and theirs is the crispiest I've yet to have.  Nice touch of cheese that helps get it crispy.

Cute ambiance.  Love their shirts.  Was sad they didn't have a larger selection for me to buy one!  Great service!  Our waitress took the time to explain how Little Goat came about and about the 3 restaurant total (The Girls and the Goat and Duck Duck Goat).  Such a lovely experience for our first visit to Chicago!

Quite a busy spot on Sundays, after a short wait was seated at the bar. As someone with a food allergy, I was impressed by their "dairy free" specific menu, which I have never seen at any other restaurant. I ordered a pork belly pancake that was delicious and reasonably priced. My girlfriend ordered fried chicken waffles and she was also impressed. Would highly recommend if you are visiting Chicago

We had a group of 8 last Thursday at Little Goat and it was a wonderful time.  I would rate this a 4.5 Diner+.  Really good food, lots of fun and a lot more than a diner (I'm from the East and we know diners!).  I recommend Little Goat highly and will be back again.  Great compliment to  The Girl when you can't get in (and we couldn't).  Win win here.

We loved the atmosphere and the concept at Little Goat when double dating here last night. The bright but dim simple decor is very calming and relaxing. We stopped at the bar while waiting for our table and enjoyed the chance to try a few specialty cocktails.

For our meals we decided to share an entree and a salad between the two of us. My husband picked the Shrimp and Pork Belly entree and I tried the GoatoGoato salad. The salad was big and ingredients nice and crunchy fresh. I tasted mint and fennel although the server described the dressing as being an Asian flavor. I couldn't find any cheese but had hoped with the name there may be some goat cheese (?) or cream.

The Shrimp and Pork Belly entree was served over noodles and was the fan favorite at the table! We agreed with the server's recommendation for this dish.

For dessert we tried a banana cake with a layer of bacon and peanut butter frosting. I was skeptical of whether a dessert could be truly heavenly without chocolate but alas it is true! I could have died and gone to heaven if eating this for breakfast. I think it'd be a great addition to a brunch menu as well.

Little Goat is so adorable! I loved the name of the diner, the atmosphere, the decor and the more importantly the food. Everything on the menu looked so tasty, but I decided to go for 'The Little Piggy that Went to China' and boy was I pleased. It was so flavorful, not too spicy (not into spicy things) and packed with flavor. From the biscuit to the szechuan sausage, I was having a party in my mouth till the last bite! My sister went with the biscuits and gravy and it was delicious but very heavy. Luckily she went for the half portion but still gobbled it up.

My only small complaint was our waiter was very unenthusiastic and it seemed like that was the last place he wanted to be. He was still nice and we still have a good experience.

Definitely recommend this place and will certainly be back next time we make a trip to Chicago!

pics.caption: This Little Piggy Went to China/Biscuits and gravy creeping in back
This Little Piggy Went to China

review.des:
Go here to indulge, brunch was fantastic, you will definitely come out full and satisfied. I had the Bull's eye French toast which didn't need the fried chicken, and was delicious with the bbq maple syrup (sweet/salty combo). The pork belly pancake and regular pancakes were a favorite, the Little Piggy went to China was heavier on the flavor/meat side. If you want to be daring, go for the Little Goat latte (made from goat milk, which is really more of an after taste)

While there were Asian flavors, I thought this was a well executed menu of slight-fusion brunch plates, still felt like I was in an American diner.

I had the grilled cheese. It was awesome. My wife had los drowned. She was equally impressed. We had a 10 minute wait for seating at 11:00 pm. Might want reservations for busiest times. Service was helpful and timely.

Went here at 12:30pm for lunch. Wow, extremely loud place and hard to hear each other speak. I'd prefer the bar next time. Overall though, Large servings, Great service with a good looking menu. I had the kimchee burger and my guest had the banh mi burger. Both were good and tastes fresh but it didn't blow my mind. Kimchee was surprisingly good.
Greasy and gross, I dont understand why everybody likes this place. Maybe it was good at one point, but it is a total disappointment nowadays.

We were actually trying to go elsewhere and they had too long of a wait, so we went to the Little Goat. Their wait was supposed to be twenty minutes, but it was more like five.

Service was okay, not too overbearing.

Food was good. I had a patty melt, my partner had some gigantor sandwich. Remarakably, he finished the whole thing. The fries were great. Coffee was good.

If I lived in the area I would probably go there more often.

Oh how excited I was about this place when it first opened! Getting into Girl and the Goat was like trying to get a sit down for life advice from the Dalai Lama, but when this little place opened, I thought maybe there's a chance I can get at least a small taste of what the rave is all about. Sure, I'd have to wait over an hour to get in, but comparatively a one hour wait sure beats a one and half month wait. I was sold!

The craziness of this place shortly after opening was a little/a lot overwhelming. Everyone had the same thought I did, so wait times were kind of/definitely insane. That being said, I've been here many times since then and the wait times, depending on when you get there, have become completely reasonable.

The place is perfect for groups because of the sheer size of the dining room, just be sure to gauge your timing so you aren't showing up with 8 people at top traffic time. They also have a little bakery/bar next door that's great for waiting and drinking good beer if you happen to get stuck at dinner rush hour. Get drunk, and all of sudden your table is ready. Yeehaw!

I've tried so many things on the menu that I've loved here. From the Sloppy Goat to the Bull's Eye French Toast to the This Little Piggy Went to China, all the dishes shy away from regular old diner food to give you something that you most likely have never tried before. And if you're looking closely at the menu, you'll probably notice a milkshake that has pork in it. Yes, it's delicious.

Verryyyy crowded on the Thursday before Christmas, that's for sure. We waited 30 minutes for a table for two. The atmosphere is cool, big and airy and crackling with chatter and kitchen clangor. Our waiter was great; very sweet, even when he had to deliver a real blow: no cinnabuns or 3 sisters oatmeal after 11am.

We ordered apple pancakes which were delicious and filling, and the bacon was good, but scant for $6. All in all we enjoyed our experience, but don't let "diner" in the name lull you into thinking the prices are low.

We held our wedding ceremony and reception at Little Goat on the second floor private dining/outdoor terrace. It was absolutely perfect and everything that we had envisioned. We worked with Tiffany for about a year and she was so extremely kind, thoughtful, knowledgeable, and helpful throughout the entire process. Working out all of the little details was a breeze and ultimately we knew everything was going to be taken care of so we could enjoy ourselves on our day. Little Goat also provided all of the food and cakes for our wedding and are guests are still raving about how good everything was! I would highly recommend Little Goat for an intimate wedding celebration (or brunch, or lunch, or dinner, or just the bakery...)!!
All I have to say was "meh". The Bloody Mary was basically Campbells soup in a pint glass.

Very pricey but the food is only marginally better (if that) than you'd find in most other good diners in Chicago.  If you're looking for brunch food (eggs scrambles, fancy waffles or pancakes), there's better at Wildberry, Bongo Room, or even White Palace Grill.  Skip this elevated diner.
Best "diner" around. Great takes on the traditional, with an excellent cocktail and beer menu to boot

On word.....FANTASTIC!

We finally had the chance to stop in Little Goat Diner for lunch on Saturday. The place was bustling. We checked in around 11:30 and the host said there was a 45 minute wait. The good news is they do have a texting system that will text you when your table is ready. Also the bakery/bar/cafe is next door if you want to grab a quick drink while you wait which is what we did. The wife had a Bloody Mary and I had a coffee and piece of the white chocolate Rosemary bread which was amazing. After waiting about 35 minutes we were seated in a nice cozy table for two in the center of the restaurant. They definitely designed this place for maximizing space and efficiency. The interior has a nice contemporary design. Love the skylight in the center of the place which allows a ton of natural light.

On to the meal. We ordered the little trip to China and brioche French toast. The French toast was unique in that the center was medium cooked egg topped off with strawberries and fried chicken. Utterly delicious.

Everyone should check this place out!

pics.caption: Skylight in center of dining room

review.des: I just had breakfast here, but it was pretty amazing. Get the bullseye french toast, decadent egg in the basket french toast, covered with fried chicken bits, syrup, and strawberries. If you don't like a runny yolk, I suppose this could gross you out, but otherwise this is a must-get item. Throw in a side of the hash browns because this isn't your local diner's hash browns...there's cheese in them thar hash browns.

pics.caption: Bull's Eye French Toast - get this.

review.des: Great customer service. Happy waitresses. Food was delicious as well. They also have unique drink concoctions that they offer seasonally. If you are dining with a large group, their booths are large enough to accommodate you as well as the tables.

pics.caption: Fish tacos, shrimps and grits, check pea salad

review.des:
Not jumping on the bandwagon of others that seem to be following the herd of high ratings.   We were some of the refugees that Girl & The Goat turned away after giving away our reservations that were made in person hours before on the same day.  

Apparently I don't care for goat (Capra aegagrus hircus) aka chevon, cabrito or capretto.   I also do not care for servers that are littered with tattoos and body odor.      

Want a $12 small serving of crab dip complete with 12 Ritz crackers?   Oh this place will hook you up no problem.  

This is a spill over restaurant where Girl & Goat over books and doesn't honor reservations and expects people to go across the street like we did.    

Nothing about any of the food was impressive nor worth the price.  

We just wanted good food in the area and were not coming down from an LSD like dream of spiders.  

The high rating of this place is group mentality, community manager excepted of course.  ;)

Over priced and over rated.   If Girl & Goat across the street fucks you out of your reservation like they did to me, just get back on the Pink line and head back to downtown.  You and your wallet will thank me.

Menu was extensive and food tasted amazing. Made a reservation and went there for dinner on a Friday evening. Service was good although the restaurant was packed. We had the reuben, sloppy goat, fried chicken and smoked fries. All were amazing and I especially loved the smoked fries. I would recommend Little Goat to anyone who is looking for an unique brunch/diner option.

On the eve of Christmas Eve, I decided to take my mom out and try Little Goat since I've heard others rave about it.

We had a reservation and were seated right away. The server was quick to the table to take our drink order and was patient as we looked over the menu and we didn't feel rushed.

I ordered the Fat Elvis Waffles because bacon maple syrup and peanut butter butter. My mom ordered some shrimp salad, lame I know.

While waiting I indulged in an alcoholic beverage; Scotch in the Morning. It's basically Dewars, lemon, and smoked maple syrup; it's pretty good.

When the food came it was loaded with syrup, bacon, bananas and a giant glob of peanut butter butter.

My heart nearly stopped on the first bite and not from the fat content but how thoroughly awesome it was. The portion size was a bit much though, it could've been 1/2 the size and I would've been able to finish it, instead I gave up half way through.

My moms salad was enormous, the bowl was like the size of her head. She said was very good but was also unable to finish.

Overall, excellent food and attentive server made for a great experience.
Just do yourself a favor and come here! Those Japanese pancakes are insane! Elvis waffles over the top and smoked fries were awesome

Hm. Would I go back? Probably not. I'm sorry Little Goat, aesthetically I think you're a very cute diner, but the food was sub par. The staff? Very nice. Our server? Attentive, polite, funny. The atmosphere? Has this cool vibe like "am I at an upscale Denny's with hip music?" But I just keep going back to the food and it was just - meh. I did order a salad, which I guess isn't the best thing to order at a dinner, but still, it should be good, right? The shrimp on the salad wasn't good - didn't taste especially fresh and wasn't seasoned. I think the part that really threw me was the cheddar cheese shreds on a salad with shrimp... with peanuts. I did order one of the speciality drinks (can't remember the name ) and it was decent.

pics.caption: Speciality drink (can't remember the name). Pretty good.

review.des: Great customer service. Bulls eye French toast is a just try! Perfect combination to start your day right!

Do yourself get the Goat Almighty! If you are a burger buff, this is a must try from Stephanie Izard. She's got a goat burger which is rather flavorful packs it in with brisket/beef. It's a feast for 1.

On another note, my wife and I have dined here for brunch, lunch, dinner, after hours and tried about 2/3 of menu. Most of the food is pretty good. 4 stars for food and experience. 5 stars for the goat almighty.

pics.caption: Inside of a good goat burger. Get it!

review.des: Great place to eat if you love MEAT.  Anyone else can skip the entire chain of Goat restaurants.

Snagged a reservation for a Saturday afternoon, and I'm sure glad I did because the wait was for folks without reservations was super long upon arriving! We had a very nice waiter and all of the food options were great.

My friend got the fried chicken and I got the lox platter - we were both really happy with our meals and left stuffed. Also highly recommend the Chai latte if you like a little spice in your drink!

We had to wait a decent amount of time for our food to actually come out, but the place was packed so I understand why.

Overall, definitely recommend and will be back!
This place is fun for the kiddos. The servers are nice and they have good Mac and cheese :). Also the cups they bring you for kiddos have goats on them.

The best Rueben I have ever had with Kimchi and perfect sauce. We had been there before and had the cinnamon bun that was delicious.
The french toast with fried chicken, maple syrup and strawberries was a yummy balance of salty and sweet.
I wish i could go there more often!
Enjoy it for me.

There was an hour wait at noon on a Saturday, but we were seated after about 40 minutes. We ordered the Little Pig Went to China (yes that is what it's called), the Bull's Eye French Toast, and the Pork Belly Home Fries. The Bull's Eye French Toast featured fried chicken and strawberries over what was probably the best french toast I've ever had. The combination of chicken and strawberries may sound odd, but it was actually phenomenal with the super fluffy french toast.
The Little Pig Went to China was a miss for me. The Szechuan sauce was odd and overwhelming, and I didn't quite understand the mixture of flavors. The home fries were a bit on the oily side, but they were pretty good.
Even though the Little Goat is a diner, the decor is very charming and classy. The menu features unique Asian fusion brunch/ breakfast foods, some of which can be hit or miss. Overall, highly recommend for a mid- priced meal that is a bit different from your standard brunch!

pics.caption: Little Pig Went to China (yes that is what it's called), the Bull's Eye French Toast, and Pork Belly Home Fries

review.des: Rude service . I over heard the hostess tell another to seat someone ahead of me because they were tourists and in a hurry . When I confronted the hostess she just looked at me and said nothing. Then the waitress gave us attitude . Would have expected more from a place owned by a celebrity chef . Won't go back . Not worth the wait .

1. VERDICT/VALUE: It's a diner done well - With an eclectic choice of breakfast, burgers/sandwiches, entrees, and desserts, the Little Goat goes big in providing great tastes at reasonable prices!

2. FOOD: on this visit, it was breakfast for dinner with the Bull's Eye French Toast.  Egg-washed Texas toast, served with an egg over-easy, smothered with melted cheese, strawberries, chopped chicken tonkatsu (think deep fried chicken breast meat) and maple syrup.  Yum - if only they served it with a third piece of French toast!

A nibble of a friend's Shrimp and Cheesy Grits revealed plump shrimp bites with creamy yet al dente grits.  A delight to try whole during the next visit!

3. SERVICE: Despite the busy-ness of the packed restaurant, it was always prompt, attentive, and professional - full stars here, especially when they accommodated a friend's surprise birthday well with a candle-lit dessert!

4. ATMOSPHERE: It's a diner - old-school meets clean and swanky under classic lights and it has a fun photo booth at the entrance to boot.  The dressed-up can look towards the affiliated Girl and the Goat across the street while the Little Goat provides great times and great food in a casual environment.

pics.caption: Bull's Eye French Toast: fried chicken meets, egg, French toast, strawberries and maple syrup for a party.  YUM!

review.des: Amazing ambience, service, and food for the whole family. This place never disappoints. We love the blue fish, kimchi, goat burger, and Mac and Cheese. YUM!!

pics.caption: Amazing food, service, and ambience. 1 fish, 2 fish, 3 fish, 4 bluefish is a perfect balance of sweet and savory. Delicious!!

review.des: Never ever disappointing. The handsome server (I hate that I never got his name, ugh - beard and Tats!) remembered my drink choice from the last visit and that was all we needed for setting up a great lunch.  Dry cider and a decadent breakfast hash.  One of Chicago's best.

i love the diner vibe not to mention the staff is amazing! Waitress gave great recommendations and offered awesome suggestions of drinks to pair with the meals.  Had the seared scallops and shares the cheesy hash and both were amazing.  would definitely go again to try the breakfast options.
Service was excellent and food tasted great. I was even able to get a reservation on opentable. I also got food poisoning. Don't order seafood.

This place is a great lunch spot! I have been to girl and the goat and was excited for this concept. We sat at the bar while everything looked amazing ordered the Patty Melt, Hot crab dip, fried pickles and onion rings. Everything was on point and delicious. I actually couldn't get enough of the crab dip - I think I could eat that often with a side salad and be in my happy place.

I really wanted to love this place since we loved our Girl & the Goat experience. The crab dip was nothing special which was a bummer. My husband got the fried chicken and I got the pork cemitas sandwich. Both entrees were perfectly cooked, but both lacked some serious flavor. Our waitress talked up the seasonings on the pork and none of them came through. We will not return.

It was worth the 45 minute wait! We sat at the counter and saw how dedicated and hard working the staff is.
Food was great, service was fast and friendly.
Will definitely go back when we're in Chicago.
One negative thing was that we didn't find coat hangers and were sitting on our coats at the counter.

We loved the decor which makes this an atypical diner.  The okonomiyaki dish was the most memorable because it was not heavy unlike most breakfast items.  The dark chocolate chip crunch pancakes were good but not special. The Fat Elvis waffles were heavy (as the name implied) and the sauce didn't cover the bottom so well.

Cool diner setting in the West Loop. Some traditional diner staples with lots of creative additions. Food and service quality top notch the half-dozen times we've been there for breakfast and for lunch.

Really great brunch spot! I came here the other day with a group of friends and they were very accommodating to us even though we didn't make a reservation. The food is pretty straight forward but well made and delicious. They have a great bar that seems nice to just chill at if you are not in a group. Try their Bloody Mary for sure it's really good. Nothing was over the top exceptional but I do like this place and will be back for sure.

Excellent service is the name of the game at Little Goat. Came in on a Sunday morning a little before 11. Although I wasn't able to put in my name before the rest of the group arrived, I told the host that the rest of the group would be there around 11. I killed time at the connected coffee bar and watched the bakers make Little Goat's bread.

When my friends arrived, we were seated immediately, despite there being nearly a full house. This was phenomenal, and it started the brunch on a positive note. During the meal, our server was charming, funny, and attentive. Awesome service all around!

The food was great - I had the Asian style breakfast tasty thing, and my friends had the Parthas Burrito and Chocolate chip pancakes. The Asian style breakfast tasty thing was tasty: savory, funky, and sour. I only wished there was more of it! Chicago has ruined me for normal portion sizes, apparently.

My friend didn't like all of the arugula on her Parthas burrito, but she enjoyed the rest of the dish. My friend who had the chocolate chip pancakes enjoyed her dish. All of us were pleased at how much thought went into building the flavors and textures of our dishes.

I ended up buying a loaf of the miso brioche at the coffee bar. This was also amazing - it was like a loaf-sized croissant.  

Atmosphere is clean and classy, with a lot of natural light. I would take my parents here or a date here.

Overall, the food was awesome, the service was impeccable, and the atmosphere very nice. Can't wait to go back again!

pics.caption: Kimchee & bacon & eggs & pancakes Asian style breakfast tasty thing. Savory, sour, funky, and delicious!

review.des: Been there 3 times, thrown up afterward 3 times. Not sure what the deal is but it is not enjoyable.

Not worth it, period. Food was completely amateur. Not only that but even though we made reservations, still had to wait half an hour for our table.

Food has ambitions but is lacking in intellect and flavor. I had the fish tostadas and they were really, really bad. Undercooked fish (yes, I know my fish), topped with raw chick peas, chopped cabbage and thousand island dressing. I would have trusted a drunken mate with cooking up something more quality. Yes this place is seriously pretentious and a complete waste of money.

As for the dishes my friends had they were: pulled pork sandwich, the French toast, and the Japanese pancake starter. Only one was worth anything at all and it was the toast. Avoid all else

One of my favorite diners, 10000%.

Everything was great. My girlfriend and I will definitely be coming back.

Certainly, the food is of great value given its proportion and price. However, the food itself is just so-so in my opinion. Five of us went there and we ordered pancakes, lamb burgers, shrimp starters, special dish of some crab cakes etc. It is quite greasy and salty.

My friend and I were showing our two friends from out of state around Chicago and we picked this place for dinner. Valet parking around this area is $12 for the first 4 hours. Or, if you are feeling lucky, you can try to find street parking, I think it was $4/hour, 2 hours max.

We went for an early dinner on Friday so finding street parking wasn't too bad if you don't mind walking for about five minutes.

We got seated right away when we arrived around 5 PM but when we finished eating and left around 7 PM, we noticed there was a group of people waiting to be seated so if you want to beat the crowd, come before 7 or make reservations!

I ordered the Reuben sandwich since I have never had a Reuben before and wanted to give it a try. The corned beef was good but I don't really like the kimchi and kraut that was also in the sandwich. It made it very sour and tangy. It was a good portion for a sandwich, I was pretty full after eating half of the sandwich.

I also got to try a bite of my friend's Los Drowned and I definitely liked that one more. It had more flavor and I enjoyed the braised beef that it had. This sandwich did get soggy pretty fast so you should eat fast with this one if you don't like soggy sandwiches.

My other friend ordered the breakfast spaghetti w/ clams & crab and he said it was horrible. He did not enjoy his meal at all. And from the looks of it, it did not look appealing at all.

Overall, service was great but the food, not so much. Total came out to about $80 for 4 people with food and drinks. Note, Little Goat Diner is a less upscale version of Girl & Goat. I believe they have the same chef.

We visited this spot for breakfast while visiting from out of town, and were a little underwhelmed.  The food was decent, just not anything memorable-- and for those prices, I expect to be blown away.  Still, I like the focus on local ingredients, and I appreciate the hipster vibe.

We had breakfast here.. more like brunch or even lunch.... it was our first meal of the day, how's that?   Anyway, this is a pretty darn decent place to eat whatever meal of the day you're having.   We had a bit of a wait.. 20 minutes or so.  What do you expect when you arrive at 11 am on a Saturday, this is not an original idea!  

While waiting I wandered to the bakery that's attached to the restaurant to get a coffee.  Their coffee is DELICIOUS!!!  It's roasted by Dark Matter Coffee so says their 'cup condom'.  Terrific stuff... good for dusting cob webs from your head, warming you ever so nicely and will probably take paint off walls.  The good stuff!!!!  

We had great service from Jessica, a lovely serving professional who claims to read Yelp reviews  and is well versed in the restaurant biz.  Not afraid to give you a little lip back, if you're the lip type. ( I am  )  

We had their Macho Nachos and even with splitting the meal, we couldn't finish it.  It was darned good, their pulled pork is wonderful and the homemade chips are superb.  We both thought they could use a little heat in their mystery white sauce.  There were a few pickled jalapeños scattered about, but not enough for my liking.   All in all, wonderful food, wonderful service, wonderful coffee.  The wait was certainly acceptable for a top notch food place on a Saturday.   I love the interior of the building, too.  I'm not sure it's deco but it is certainly retro.  Great lines!
Great food, and so many veggie options. My carnivorous SO loved his Okonomiyaki plate, and the spiced apple pancakes were lovely. Nice ambience as well: not too noisy or rushed. We'll be back.

I've been wanting to try this place for awhile and had the opportunity to do so after Yelp's 10th anniversary party.

My friend and I had a 30 minute wait which wasn't that bad for a weekday in the summer. We sat outside on a bench talking and before we knew it we were getting called to come be seated. Since it was such a nice night we elected to sit outside. Our server was awesome (I wish I could recall his name). He was funny, personable, gave me a detail rundown of the menu and even gave me a milkshake on him as a treat for this being my first time there. I love milkshakes and I love them more when they are FREE.

For my meal I had the Bull's Eye French Toast and it was DELICIOUS! The egg and crispy chicken inside the French Toast was magical. This dish is sweet so if your teeth are on their last legs you may not want to order this dish.

There are so many other dishes on the menu that I want to try so I will for sure be going back to Little Goat!
Perfect diner food.  Each layer of flavor and texture is well thought out. Great service and upbeat atmosphere.  Back for sure.

I really wanted to fall in love with the food at "Little Goat Diner", the same way I had fallen in love with its name. But, maybe the day wasn't just right. I did read about the place after paying it a visit, it definitely is interesting. It is one of Top Chef's first female winner Stephanie Izard's restaurants. It's a very nicely done space, not sure if I would call it a diner though :)

We arrived at peak brunch hours on a Sunday and requested a table for 3. They said it would be a 30 to 45 minutes wait and we decided to wait. We waited in the "Little Goat Bakery" that is attached to the diner. We ordered a couple of coffees and a croissant as we waited. It was some real good coffee! The wait was really long. I have usually seen that they exaggerate the wait time so as to not disappoint you, but this was a different case altogether. We got a table after a long wait of 50 minutes. I just wanted some food at that point.

We were seated and handed a few menus. The service was pretty slow, but it's understandable given the crowd. We ordered:
Chocolate Malt Milkshake (I saw this on the menu and couldn't not order it. It was AMAZING!)
Omelette (I was expecting a lot of variety in this section. But they just had 2 options on their menu and I just chose to do it my way. I ordered an omelette with eggs and mushrooms and cheddar cheese. It was okay, not really the best. I had them with rye toast.)
Parathas Burrito (Being an Indian, I can understand why a fellow Indian would order this. I did not taste it, but he seemed to like it the normal amount and nothing out of the ordinary. He ordered a side of hash browns which was pretty decent.)
Bibimbap (My friend who doesn't eat eggs or meat ordered a vegan Bibimbap. He wasn't mighty impressed with it but nevertheless finished it. BUT, the highlight was definitely the side of Garlic Mashed Potatoes he ordered! It was BRILLIANT! Creamy and garlicky and just perfect.)

Although everything we ordered didn't really wow me, I still feel there's something that is unexplored. I want to definitely try the "Girl & The Goat" and I am sure I will swing by the "Little Goat Diner" again, maybe after I am done trying all the other brunch places.
Maybe pay it a visit if you are in the neighborhood and try their amazing Chocolate Malt Milkshake!

After a disheartening flight to Chicago, a desire to eat my feelings led to Randolph St. It was very late, but Au Cheval still had an hour wait, so we ventured into Little Goat. Our sleepy host promptly guided us to a table near the back of the restaurant where I had a good view of the kitchen staff, all of whom were wearing either bandannas or hats. No worries of sweaty food here. The menu is in a true diner style with a laminated triptych. I was mainly interested in the breakfast section, which is served all day, and decided to order Biscuits and Gravy along with French Toast.

While waiting for our food, I noticed that Kanye West was blaring on the sound system. The music was a little loud for my taste, but I did like the contemporary selection on the playlist. The restaurant had warm lighting and high ceilings. Although our table shared a partition with another dining party, I was not at all distracted by their conversation (probably because the music drowned them out). The attire of the staff gave me a country western vibe. Our server was attentive and I loved how often my glass of water was refilled.

Our meal was pretty simple, so it came out quickly. The biscuits and gravy were very good. The sausage within the gravy was not too salty and the two biscuits were firm and did not become soggy under the blanket of gravy. I was halfway through eating a biscuit, when our Bulls Eye French Toast arrived. I have a devastating sweet tooth, so the appearance of syrup drenched French toast with fresh strawberries pleased me. The French Toast was delicious and the bite-sized pieces of fried chicken strewn atop went surprisingly well with the sweetness of the bbq syrup. After this carbo-load, I felt pretty full, but pretty good and almost forgot all my worries. I would definitely come back and try more items and probably the French Toast again.
Great brunch! I especially liked the shake with malt and vanilla gelato! Plates are big and very filling. There was a wait but we headed to the coffee and bakery bar and time flew! Reasonably priced!

Wonderful food and even better service, I would absolutely come again. The bloody Mary's are some of the best I've had in the city. The menu is diverse enough for everyone to have something they can eat while simple enough to be able to make a decision.

pics.caption: This Little Pig Went to This Little Piggy Went to China - phenomenal

review.des:
This restaurant is one of my top brunch spots in West Loop and even downtown Chicago. The menu is overwhelming with options. Always difficult to choose breakfast or lunch, so I recommend ordering a few plates for the table to share. You can't go wrong with any of the options - there is something for everyone at this restaurant. Make sure to save room for the cake of the day. Enjoy!

Favorite plates:
-THIS LITTLE PIGGY WENT TO CHINA
-PARATHAS BURRITO
-BI BIM BOP BREAKFAST BOWL
-REUBEN
-MACHOS NACHOS
-GOAT CHILI

I have heard all the good things about this place and had to try it out for myself. I must say, few times in my YELP life have places not only met the expectations but blew them out of the water...this place did both.  Chill, great food, amazing waitress, fantastic environment. Fantastic spot for breakfast.  

Highly recommend the corned beef hash and eggs.  They were both delicious and well-cooked.  Enjoyed my time here and will most definitely be back.

SLOPPY and Worth It!

If sloppy joes made with Manwich sauce make you smile with nostalgia, hurry to Little Goat Diner. Just off the plane, I savored views of the river and stunning architecture during my 2 mile walk to the restaurant. I joined nearly two dozen diners experiencing a mid-afternoon meal (2:30 pm) under the skylit ceiling with an occasional glimpse into the open kitchen. Torn between 75 options from breakfast indulgences, burgers & sandwiches to dishes that blurred the lines between AM and PM (e.g. Breakfast spaghetti 'n clams n' crab), I took a risk. Go simple and hope for spectacular.

Sean delivered in service and nudged me toward the Sloppy Goat over the Goat Burger. Right on! Succulent and served on a squish squash roll (buttery brioche) with tangy slaw on top. Although I loved the spices, this made the goat more subtle in taste - if there's a way to make the goat more prominent, just imagine. Wait, there's more. The Corn Elote side dish was heaven...fresh grilled corn sliced off the cob and I'm guessing tossed in a creamy chili sauce with a squeeze of lime and a sprinkling of cheese. Crunchy, spicy, nutty and tart -- no better way to taste the final days of summer.

Thanks to Top Chef Stephanie Izard for my new food memory. 74 more dishes to try...

pics.caption: Roasted corn, spicy and crunchy. Fantastic!

review.des:
A million reviews cant be wrong!

The food is so good, slightly different take on classics but things you should never change (like gooey sweet roll buns) stay the same.

I think the best breakfast time, just like everyone else on yelp is the egg in a hole. Goodness is it good. Not overly sweet or savory it is the perfect combo! The BBQ maple syrup puts it over the top. If you dont like it, please mail me your leftovers!

Went with a few friends for brunch to this place. There is an hour wait. About food, didn't find anything special...the food was mediocre.. I ordered corn beef hash. It came out so greasy, so much potato hash, asked for egg o/e, it was barely cooked!  My friend got "the little pig went to china" she said it was decent! It's ok for an experience, but don't think I'll go back! Left this place still hungry and not happy! Definitely there are better places than "little goat".

On a whim, we decided to eat lunch at The Little Goat. We walked in (not knowing what to expect) and were pleasantly surprised by the unique ambiance and the yummy smells. We were seated at a two person table rather quickly, less than 20 minutes. We ordered a cinnabun and a crab dip for a "snack" (appetizer) and something else with a very long interesting name pronounced "yum" and the corned beef hash.

The frosting on the ooey gooey cinnabun was tasty and cream cheesey but the actual roll was soooo DRY. I have never not eaten the center of a cinnamon roll and yet I did just that and left it on the plate. The cheese crab dip was ok, but not great. It boasted lump crab but I could barely even notice any pieces in it. The "yum" dish was a textural delight. It's a rather small dish and maybe 2/3 of it was eaten. The corned beef hash needed salt, bad! And the weird noodle looking hash browns were undercooked and sooo greasy; they were glistening. The eggs were ok. I ordered over easy but they were over cooked with little yoke to break open. The corned beef was good. It was just sliced like for sandwiches.

Drinks are not free refills; except the water.

We left most of the food on the table.

Pricey and left us with tummy aches the rest of the day.

pics.caption: The corned beef hash. So VERY greasy and not flavorful.
The "yum" dish. It was a textural delight but one could only eat so much of this weird delight.

review.des: Great experience. A different kind of dinner.  Great ambiance, great design, different food, original, eell executed.  Will be bsck

We've hair finished our meal and I'm still drooling! If you want a traditional breakfast, this is not the place for you. The menu options are so creative and sooo good. We had the chorizo maple crumpets and this little piggy went to China. Both were phenomenal! We also had a side of grits which were perfectly salty and perfectly cheesy. We decided also to get a drink, mezcalata. Amazing! Perfect mix of spice and tang. Not quite a bloody marry but not a chalata. Chili fuzed tequila, beer, and tomato juice. The only problem is they stop serving it for the spring! We'll be dreaming of the place until our next visit! The service was equally amazing! JP gave was very friendly and gave us great recommendations for the city!

pics.caption: This little piggy went to China, cheesy grits, and chorizo maple crumpets

review.des:
Had a great time here. We actually started going to a different restaurant but the wait for six people was over two hours. We've wanted to try Little Goat and it was just down the block. After putting our name in at the other place, I ran down the street and was told Little Goat could seat us right away. We only had to agree to sit at a communal table, but there were at least four seats between us and the other diners at our table.

We started with a few appetizers. The one that was most memorable was the fried pickles and onion rings. I'm not big on deep fried foods but the coating was delicate and crisp. It was really good. For my meal I ordered "Los Drowned", which is a sort of a mix between Italian Beef and French Dip. The meat is sliced thick, they add kimchi and pickled vegetables, and they serve as jus on the side. The meat in the sandwich could have been more spiced and there was not quite enough as jus. The kimchi and pickled veggies really added a lot though.

Service was great, and my compliments to the kitchen staff.

Can I just say BEST BREAKFAST EVER? Okay, maybe that's a little extreme, but it was definitely a memorable meal.

I was visiting Chicago for the weekend and was looking for somewhere to get breakfast/brunch. I stumbled across Little Goat Diner, and I just knew I had to come based on the photos and reviews.

You have the choice of sitting at the counter, the communal tables, or having your own table. It would have been faster if we we went for one of the first two choices, but we decided to get our own table, and ended up waiting 30-40 minutes. We ended up being seated at a huge booth.

There is both the normal menu and the special menu, and the options involve your typical brunch items with a twist, which I really enjoyed. Much of the twists involve some kind of Asian-inspiration.

We ordered:
+Pork Belly Croquette: Oh my gosh, this was so delicious. The croquette and the smashed avocado had a really rich flavor and a mushy texture, but it was perfectly balanced out by crunch and acidity of the pickled vegetables on top. There were also two runny eggs that normally I would feel slightly queasy about, but I didn't even mind them at all! I would totally order this again.
+The Corned Beef Hash ($14): Classic dish, but somehow so much better. I don't know, it was just somehow extra delicious. I think I would've like a little more potato to beef balance, but hey, that's just me.
+Bull's Eye French Toast ($16): This was a last minute addition since everyone seemed to be raving about it. Honestly, I was not really a fan of it, but I think that may just be my preference of keeping sweet and salty separate. But looking at the individual elements and how well this dish is executed, I could definitely see why this is so popular. So even if it didn't work out for me, I would say it was a good experience and I would recommend others to check it out.

Overall I enjoyed myself a lot. The restaurant is beautiful, the servers are friendly, and the food is delicious. What else can you ask for? It definitely is a bit on the pricier side, but well worth it!

pics.caption: Pork Belly Croquette (off the special menu)--so good.

review.des:
The pinnacle of our culinary experience in the last few years! As has only been said about a couple of restaurants before this, I would name a child after this place if it were socially acceptable!

After friends and my wife had raved about the girl and the goat, we decided to come over here for breakfast based on Yelp reviews and word of mouth. A short cab ride from downtown, this is a place I would hike to if it were located on the top of a mountain- anyone who seen me knows that Papa is not a hiker!

Upon entering, you're greeted by a majestic Diner that's reminiscent of some of the old school spots you see in small towns, and while maintaining the rustic charm, it's got a very cool vibe that you'd expect from a place of this caliber. Hipster trending, but not pretentious - very good stuff!

The menu is as close to perfection as we've seen for a breakfast spot. Familiarly eclectic the description that comes to mind.

We came at about 7:30 on a Saturday morning and it was absolutely perfect for my better half, myself and our two little dudes. This was absolutely the time when everybody with kids goes out to eat as the place was pretty well full of families. Our waiter, whose name I can't remember but who was a rockstar, was fantastic with the kiddos and in taking care of us.

We decided to sample the fat Elvis pancakes, which included peanut butter and banana as well as a maple bacon syrup. They were delicious and great for all of us to share. The most memorable thing that we had, and seriously one of the best things I've had to eat in the last five years, was the this little pig goes to China. It was an absolute flavor symphony that worked just about everywhere in my mouth! It included a sesame cheddar biscuit, some boss sausage, an egg over top and some delicious sweet and spicy chili garlic chive sauce. This is the sort of thing that I could write a book about.

The mimosas were delicious and the hot chocolate has just the right amount of whipped cream over top! After our experience here, I don't understand how anybody could give it less than 5 stars. This is absolutely what a restaurant should be and the place we're going to be coming back to any time we are in Chicago!

I dined here for Sunday brunch and loved every bit of it!  This is one of the restaurants Stephanie Izard (Top Chef Season 4 winner) co-owns and is the executive chef at.

We were told the wait would be around 30 minutes so we headed to the back bar, coffee bar and merchandise shop.  We ordered bloody marys and mimosas, and I purchased a masala rub for $6 to take home and try.  We were seated probably within 15-20 minutes.

Everything on the menu looked delicious, but I ended up ordering the Bulls Eye French Toast (per a recommendation from the waiter).  It was AMAZING.  It's french toast with a circle cut out of the middle and an egg cooked inside, topped with lightly fried chicken and strawberries.  I was worried it might be heavy but it was the perfect amount of cube shaped fried chicken pieces.

My friends ordered the Fat Elvis Waffles (peanut butter, bananas, bacon maple syrup) and the Kimchee & Bacon, Eggs, & Pancakes Asian Style and both of those were also delicious.  

We asked the waiter if Stephanie was in the restaurant and she was working an event upstairs but took a few minutes of her time to come by and say hello.

This was an all around amazing dining experience, complete with delicious food and friendly service.  I would definitely recommend checking it out!

pics.caption: Stephanie Izard - Co-Owner and Executive Chef!

review.des: Very nice brunch place! I know it is famous for dinner but never got the chance to try. I had a few times of brunches in Sunday morning. Never let me down. Highly recommend this place especially you like lamb.

I love the concept and did think the recipes were creative and sounded delicious, I just thought the execution fell short, and the service was terrible.  We were rushed in and out by an apathetic table-turning waitress who never came back to check on us (I waited to eat for nearly 20 minutes because I wanted salt and pepper shakers, finally gave up and ate eggs that were unseasoned...strange for a pretty nice place).

The food was decent, but the portions were quite small and everything seemed a bit bland.  We only got a chance to try one of the cocktails because when the waitress finally did come back (after we frantically waved her down), she dropped the check on our table and walked away before we could get a word in... I wanted to order something else, but that wasn't an option.

We were there around 10:30 pm on a Friday night, so even though they were busy, it wasn't slammed like it would be during dinner hour.  Overall it felt very corporate and the staff was not nice, we tried to flag down other waiters during our short time there but no one seemed to notice or care.  I won't be back.
Great brunch place! Love the atmosphere of this place. Get the Hot Crab Dip! So good!! Also try their Bull's Eye French Toast.

Great diner concept from Stephanie Izard. The restaurant has a retro diner feel and is casual. Huge menu with tons of options ranging from all day breakfast to sandwiches, burgers, and main plates.

Portions here are GENEROUS! Our waitress suggested my husband and I might share one dish and then supplement with a side or "snack," she was spot on. The dish we ended up choosing was the Shrimp and Pork Belly which she warned us was on the lighter side so that we could go with the heavier appetizer/snack of the Goat Chili Cheese Fries.

Goat Chili Cheese Fries were thinner fries with a pretty good crisp to them covered in a red bean, tomato, goat chili and some sort of cheesy sauce. They were good but next time I'm ordering something else to explore the menu as they weren't earth-shattering. Chili had a fairly goat forward taste and the cheese was milder than anticipated.

Shrimp and Pork Belly was great! Lighter in flavor it was thin Asian style noodles with mushrooms, radish, cucumber, and other veggies and had 4 perfectly grilled shrimp and thick cuts of pork belly.

We will be back. After eyeing the GIANT stacked burgers, one of those is next on my list.

pics.caption: Goat Chili Cheese Fries. Good but not my personal favorite, more goaty and less rich and cheesy than I would like.
Shrimp and Pork Belly dish. Highly recommend!

review.des: We came in for brunch during my bachelorette party. Our waitress was super friendly and very attentive. Food was delicious. Would definitely recommend!

I really love the diner feel and I've been meaning to go to one of Stephanie's restaurants for awhile.  We initially wanted to go to Girl and the Goat but we were unable to get a dinner reservation at the time we needed.  We substituted Little goat instead and it did not disappoint!!!
We tried several drinks but my favorite was the 'el diablo'.  It was refreshing but with a kick. Other favorite drinks at the table were, the 'we be jammin' and the '1.21 gigawatts!'.    
For dinner I had the pork belly pancake and it was exceptionally delicious - I wish I had a pork belly pancake right now actually!!!  My friends both had the los drowned sandwich and said they were really happy with their choice.  We split a side of tempura mashed potatoes and, while they were not at all what I expected, they were very good. We also, split the 'not Chinese broccoli' and the smoked fries.  I was not a fan of the fries but the broccoli was very flavorful (***caveat, I am a terrible judge of French fries as I am not fond of them to start with so consider that while weighing my French fry opinion).
Conclusion: Yes, I would happily go back from breakfast, brunch, lunch, dinner, snacks and/or drinks.  And...I'm even more excited to try Girl and the Goat now!!!

Had a great time here this past weekend. It was busy and there was a wait for our table of 2, so we headed over to the bar in the other room and had some breakfast cocktails while we waited, which helped time pass very quickly.

I had the Bullseye French Toast (get it! you'll love it!) and my date had the Asian Style Breakfast TastyThing. He said mine was better.

Service was good, prices were good, meal was delish. Can't complain!

Just to give you a sense of my current mental state...This restaurant experience had me tossing and turning in bed.  I just woke up at 1:15am and downloaded Yelp just to clear my mind.  

Im spending only a few meals worth of time in Chicago and went looking for 'Girl and Goat' on a friend's suggestion.  I know what you're thinking, this isn't a review for Girl and Goat...But just so we're clear...This place has a giant spinning goat head on the roof and very little additional signage.  If I wanted to front like I was another restaurant maybe I could spin a giant golden M in front of my house and call it a McDougals Diner.   I didn't discover this major red flag until I commiserated with a local on how bad my food was.  

I sat and was greeted by the waitress.  She asked what type of food I'm allergic to or dislike- I say onions.  Everything from there on out was covered in onions.  Fine, I can pick them off.  Doesn't even scratch the surface or give me reason enough for a poor review.  I also asked 'what are the best things on the menu...I want those'.  I typically order that way because I expect the wait staff to know what people like/what's fresh/what looks good coming out of the kitchen.  

She told me the very best thing was the special Mole Sea Bass.  Great, it sounds like a lot for me to enjoy.  I love a good mole.  

You could put a leash on a stick and walk it around the block at a brisk pace and I would more likely believe it was a dog than this dish was mole.  What arrived was Chocolate Fish with Pico.  Ingredients:. Fish with skin on it, a milk chocolate flood, diced tomatoes, a nice coating of onions and mushrooms. There was so much milk chocolate on this poor fish. I don't understand why someone would put that much chocolate on a fish. That's not how mole happens.  Price tag: $23

Waitress said I would love the roll.  It was so salty that  I had two bites and needed 8 glasses of water.  Thankfully it came with a heavy onion aioli.

The chili was acceptable.

I left confused and ate a whole pizza to cleanse my pallette.

Fun spot - fun menu - great staff.  We went with a big group (12?) - they handled the situation really well.  Good beer selection, crab dip to start (good, not great), I had the Goat Almighty burger - awesomely large, but tasty.  I finished most of it! All the dishes around the table were a hit - chicken pot pie, omelet, etc.  We shared a peach pie/cobbler. Very good.  Pricing was reasonable.

Review from last year:

3 college students heard about the Au Cheval burger and made the trek to West Loop to taste it. Excited and eager the hostess said it would be a 3 hour wait... Defeated and hungry we stood outside contemplating what to do. WE JUST PAID FOR AN UBER FOR A BURGER.

BUT I spy a cartoon goat down the street and instantly recognize it as the Stephanie Izard establishment. As a big fan of hers when she was on Top Chef I told my friends to pick up their heads and try it.

GOAT ALMIGHTY: we set the night on Au Cheval but we ended up getting a burger bigger than our heads. My first goat experience was amazing and this was absolutely delicious. What really brings it together is the salsa verde. The acidity woks very well with the rich menage of pork, goat, and beef.

Fried pickles (not pictured): Perfect appetizer to share on a brisk night and had a very nice sour complimented by the creamy dipping sauce.

Hospitality: This was a big part of my 5 stars. As I explained our plight and failed quest of AC to the hostess she laughed and said it would be also a 3 hour wait. As soon as she saw our shocked faces she quickly laughed and quipped that she'll have us seated in 5 minutes. From there she was very diligent in explaining the menu to us and making sure we redeemed our night. Very nice and explained the quirkyness of the diner.

What could have been a somber night was turned into one of my favorite college memories. Lost in an unfamiliar area, hungry, and determined, Little Goat provided me with a great meal, fun service, and a new place to recommend to my friends.

pics.caption: The Goat Almighty Burger. My first goat meat experience and hot damn this hit the spot

review.des: Little goat is fantastic but you little stinkers are in such high demand I'll starve to death waiting. Plan ahead with a reservation and prepare to wait a little but once inside it's worth it and the staff is so wonderful.

I truly enjoyed Little Goat, not only because the food is delicious but also because the portions are HUGE. I got the sausage and biscuits which were so creamy and delicious, and extremely filling. We also got the pork belly pancake which was full of flavor and the melt in your mouth chocolate crisp pancakes. If you're ever in the West Loop area and choosing from the plethora of restaurants there, definitely try Little Goat!

LIttle Goat stands as proof in life that names and titles mean very little. While I admit that the building and atmosphere were pretty cool (reminiscent of some grand hipster places like the Ace Hotel NY with high ceilings, expertly placed white and navy tiles, and copper lighting), the food and service (but mostly the food) left something to be desired.

After a wait at the cute coffee bar next door, where we got two pretty-good drinks, we headed over to the diner for a just-alright brunch. Perhaps starting off on the wrong foot, the service was only lukewarm from the beginning onward: Our waitress ran by to tell us she'd be right with us. And then again to say she'd be "right with us" a second time (Hey, at least she said something?)

Once we got our food, the omelettes were disproportionately eggy and hammy (and light on the flavorful sauce and mushroom innards). The loco moco was a mockery of any loco moco we've ever experienced. Moco was over-designed with an emphasis on greens, making us miss the Hawaiian simplicity of the usual easy island dish, while the omelette suffered from the opposite issue and was too unadorned and unimaginative. Someone else in our party ordered a chicken salad and the chicken was far too breaded.

In the end, everything was a nice thought, but was consistently forgettable and never quite made it into the fully realized stages of an original and complex adult dish. To top the experience off, at the end of the meal, we asked for a split check, which our waitress promptly forgot about. Perhaps Seattle has spoiled me with its devilishly thought-out details, but sad to say, in a city that's supposed to be a foodie town, I wasn't all that excited about the food at Little Goat.

Surprisingly has a lot of great vegetarian options if you ever need it. Breakfast served all day. Service was okay but they were very busy when I went. I really enjoyed the veggie burger chop chae, though don't expect it at all to seem like a burger (more like a bowl of good stuff). None of us at the table could eat the brussel sprouts. The fish taste was too strong and the vegetable undercooked/too hard.

What an amazing lunch we had. I ordered the Cubano special which came with braised beef instead of Pork. It was cooked to perfection. The beef was juicy and flavorful and overall just wonderful.

I also ordered the dark chocolate pancakes. They were topped with dark chocolate crisps adding ny a unique texture and flavor to the pancakes.

First time here after recommendation from my daughter. So fun and delicious! Had the cauliflower rice bi bim bop. What an amazing dish. Guilt free dining. The sauce is tangy and not too spicy. And I would love to go back and eat the corned beef hash. Ordered a little goat latte with my dinner. Love that too.

Just got back from Little Goat Diner. I ordered the Crispy Creole Chicken sandwich, it does not come with fries, which is actually a good thing.  Most of the time when you order a sandwich or burger, fries are included. But, I've come to realize that I don't really need them.  Anyway, the sandwich was hot, temparature wise and hot, pepperwise.  I really enjoyed it.  It's just a wonderful sandwich.  My wife got the Los Drowned, which is a take on the classic French Dip sandwich, she was generous enough to let me have a taste. Just like my sandwich, hers was flavorful and on super soft, fresh bread.  We also ordered muffins, which were slightly above average.  Little Goat Diner is a gem, I can't wait to go back and try more of the offerings.

Love this spot. Creative menu, stellar quality dishes, flawless fast service.
This is a must try in the West loop.
I like this place for brunch or a late lunch whenever I have friends in town.

Little Goat is one of my new favorite places to brunch in the city! I love the diner atmosphere and feel. To me, Little Goat is a classic brunch spot that I think everyone needs to try! It is a popular spot so there's typically a decently long wait on the weekends. I went with a group of 10 for brunch on Sunday and we had an hour and a half wait. But it wasn't a problem because they take your phone number and text you once your table is ready so we just went to Bar Siena next door and had a few drinks while we waited for our table. A few bloody marys later and we were able to sit down so not a bad wait at all.

We ordered the Fat Elvis Waffles and Dark Chocolate Chip Crunch Pancakes to share with our table. I ordered the corned beef hash for my personal meal. I highly, highly recommend all three of these! The Fat Elvis Waffles are topped with peanut butter-butter and bacon maple syrup....my mouth is watering typing that. So yes, they were incredible. The chocolate chip pancakes were also excellent! Definitely order one of these (or both!) and split with your party. If you're deciding one over the other, I'd go with the waffles simply because the peanut butter-butter.  They were both the perfect mix of sweet with a savory dish. Also, I loved the coffee here. Hopefully I'll be back soon because I have a feeling I'll be craving all of this soon. Definitely worthy of 5 stars!

Just ate at Little Goat last weekend. My wife and I thought it was excellent. We met a group of 10 friends on a Sunday. There was a little wait but nothing too terrible. I thought all of the food was excellent including their Dark Matter Brew of coffee.

My wife and I had the Fat Elvis Waffles, Shrimp and Grits and ordered a Cinnamon Bun. I loved the waffles-didn't think it would work given the description but it did. Shrimp and Grits were as good as you can find in Chicago and the Cinnamon Bun is a must try.

Other dishes we go to try through friends, Little Piggy Goes to China, Spanish Omelette and the Chocolate Chip Pancakes. I thought they were all excellent. Would definitely like to go back.

Chef Izzard's take on diner food is so  innovative and forward thinking. The creative dishes here are completely unexpected and completely delicious! This  is another must stop when in Chicago for us.

pics.caption: PB & PB & PB & J Sundae...amazing! Concord grape gelato?!?!

review.des:
Large portions but pricey.  Definitely the look of a diner but not the feel of a diner.  Service was a bit slow but we also had a large group.  

I had the pork belly and pancake.  It was just ok.  I probably could get something cheaper and better in Chinatown.

We made reservations for 2 at 8:15am and we were running 15 mins late that morning, called in, and they were quite nice and accommodating about it.

I enjoyed the layout of the seats in the restaurant and the place was well lit with natural sunlight.

Right off the bat, I saw that they serve horchata shakes and jumped right on it.

We ordered "This Little Piggy Went to China" and "Bull's Eye French Toast." I didn't like either of the two.

The first dish which comprised of sesame cheddar biscuit, sunny eggs, Szechuan pork sausage, chill garlic chive sauce, and blackberries seemed like the most promising out of this rather eclectic menu. Unfortunately it was too salty for my friend and I.

The French toast which comprised of eggs, crispy chicken, sweet onion brioche, and bbq maple syrup was too sweet for me.

Man do I sound like Goldie Locks! This dish was too salty. This dish was too sweet.

That horchata shake though...was jusssst right.

I gave it a 4 because of the horchata shake and it is one of those must try places in Chicago.
Absolutely awesome! Do try the nachos, don't expect to eat anymore after that, so filling!
