An improved performance from my first visit soon after Little Goat opened more than three years ago.  We stuck to a couple of now-popular staples, including the Bull's Eye French Toast and the Chickpea Salad, and they were both fantastic.  The Tempura Mashed Potatoes were a miss but everything else about our visit last week was very strong, and you get a lot of food for these prices.  Great for kids, since it's so loud in this place, and during the work week, getting a rezzie on OpenTable is pretty easy nowadays.

If you like salty and expensive diner food and can't afford a proper Girl and the goat or Duck Duck Goat. This is the place for you.

Seriously don't go here unless you're desperate to bandwagon onto Stephanie Izzard and trying to impress you're match.com date from Naperville.

Get the real reservation and enjoy all of Stephanie's finer foods at the other locations.

I had heard a lot of great things about this restaurant (and others in the group) but unfortunately it was a terrible experience.

- The wait: Despite having a 7pm reservation and checking in 5 min prior, we had to wait 20 minutes to be seated. It seemed like many of those around us were in the same boat. The host at the front offered to comp a drink for us each, but my friend and I did not want to drink. He offered instead to comp some appetizers for us to be ready when we finally got seated, but these never showed up. The restaurant did give us a free dessert at the end of our meal, but it was ice cream and I am lactose intolerant... Thanks.
- "Medium rare only": This was truly bizarre. I ordered the skirt steak and asked for it to be done medium, but was told the kitchen does medium rare and does not like to change this (? why is this the case?). Waitress said she would check with the kitchen and let me know before ordering anything. She didn't come back so I assumed everything was ok. Got my dish and of course, medium rare. It seems like this chef cooks for the kitchen and not the customer who is actually eating.
- Rushed service: I think the entire restaurant was running behind (perhaps this happens a lot here). So as a result, everything was rushed. Waitress came by to take our plates when I was done but my friend was clearly still eating. Waitress swooped in to take our check when I had just set down my credit card but my friend was still fetching hers, leaving me to get up and run after her. Waitress promised to check with kitchen on cooking my steak medium before placing my order and didn't!

Very inconsiderate restaurant. Don't think it's worth it.

we have eaten her several times. Always excellent. many tasty choices. The staff is always helpful. Sitting outside is great as well.
we have been here for brunch as well as dinner. yummy!

I had a great walk getting to this place! its right across from it's sister restaurant and down from au cheval. Man, that place had a huge line forming before it was even open, but no surprise, so did this place! Lucky i was by myself this trip and got seating right at the bar! The service here was great and i was greeted promptly, recommended the little goat coffee drink (their own hand made salted caramel with goats milk latte. SUPER DELISH) and told personal favorites on the menu. I decided to get the shrimp and grits with poached egg and a fresh biscuit on the side. The first bite was amazing! but sadly as i kept eating it, i just felt like something was missing. salt? more pepper maybe? i don't know, but just something was missing. maybe more cheese on the grits, but i just can't give it more than the three stars for this place, especially once the bill came out and i found that the eggs were extra. Now that biscuit was superb. so i'll give em that, definitely come by and grab a baked good and some coffee and you'll be happy. but as for the food my personal opinion is its just okay. Try for yourself!

happy eating :D

While I think of this place as more of a hip, breakfast diner, one evening we sat outside under a shiny, bright moon and had a delightful dinner here.

I had the pork belly pancake which was tender pork belly served open-faced and piled onto a scallion pancake then topped with a crunchy bok choy salad and ginger maple dressing.  

My husband had the bahn mi burger with a goat patty.  He loved it.  I couldn't get any more descriptive words from him then that.  I can tell you, though, that it was served with pickled veggie slaw, orange mayo, mint, cilantro and served on a bolillo - a better than average bun.

Sometimes I regret going out to eat because I know I could have produced something much more interesting/delicious at home.  In this case, I could never have produced something this good in what I would consider normal, reasonable dinner preparation time.  Moreover, it would have taken far too much creative effort and thinking.

We also shared a side of crispy, smoked fries, each had a beer and called it one fine night.

Yes, this is a diner with panache and we look forward to our next meal here.

Service is kind of slow but I still really enjoyed the food. If you're hungry go next door to get some pasties.we got a seat right away at 930 but the line grew immediately after us. No reservations!!

Smoked fries are. Still a definite must get.

I also enjoyed my brandade and belly, the belly is so soft and tender and well caramelized. Love it!

Cookies Shake was delicious too.. Many cookie bits, not just the black and white cookies and cream shake!

Also tried the kimchi Asian anything omelette - surprisingly light and delicious

For yelpers with a sweet tooth, the chocolate chip crunch is awesome. Amazing chocolate butter ganache thing to spread on your pancake sprinkled with coco crunch. Yay.

Another note, portions are definitely too much for an average person, bring a to go box or share!!

pics.caption: Brandade and belly. Can't really taste the brandade but love the biscuit eggs and belly!!!!
Asian style anything omelette with pork belly kimchi and veggies

review.des: The food was very rich in flavor here! I had he nachos and they were delicious but definitely meant to be shared. It wasn't the most affordable meal but was still a good place!

Great little diner for a casual weekend breakfast! I had the shrimp and cheesy grits, and they did not disappoint. We had a 9:45 reservation, but had we not come in with the reservation we probably only would have waited 20-30 minutes; Not a bad wait for a Saturday morning. Prices are moderate - Expect to spend $10-20 per person. We will definitely be taking friends and family here when they come visit from out of town!

My husband made reservations for my birthday and with my food allergies, I'm quite apprehensive to eat out. Little Goat has a dairy-free menu (bonus) and since I have a soy allergy the waitress  knew already that the kitchen used soy oil to fry--awesome. Many places don't know so I was thrilled.
I ordered the burger and it was absolutely delicious. As did my son. My husband loved his fish tacos. We will definitely return.

Real cool place where you feel like you're in an upscale diner. Came in and had the nachos, fat club, and sloppy goat. All were really good. The nachos are with pulled pork and the meat was fantastic!

There is also a bar in the back where you can wait for your table. They sell breads and homemade sauces and rubs for cooking.

All in all real good place, just make sure you come hungry because the portions are big.

Lots of places to breakfast/brunch/lunch in Chicago, but this place is definitely a must try.

This is the best breakfast you can buy for the meager price of "only" $55. If I lived in Chicago I would go bankrupt eating here.

Edit: this was for 2 people. I went with my wife.

I really wanted to like because of non-conventional menu.  But while the menu would suggest four - service, ambience and food all second rate.

Paratha burrito pretty good, but shakes small and mediocre for $9!!!

They throw some smoke flavoring on lukewarm not real crisp fries.  Hamburgers standard diner fare ... not high end diner fare.  Hash browns overly greasy.  Pancakes and biscuits and gravy solid.

If their prices were reasonable probably a three.  Solid diner food with a twist, but not what it could be.

A bit away from downtown area and further to the west but definitely worth visiting. The food dishes are original and delicious. Wide variety of drinks. You won't regret it. Plenty of other restaurants around as well.

The wait here is bad just like any popular restaurant in Chicago.
Everything I've tried here has been pretty damn tasty though!
-Goat chili which was delicious but pricy for a tiny cup that you finish in two bites
-Kimchee pancakes was so good! You wouldn't think fermented cabbage would taste good in slightly sweet pancakes but it's a perfect balance of salty and sweet for savory pancakes!
-Kimchee burger was delicious and you can customize them a little w the different type of patties you want.

Besides..
-Los drowned hoagie.  It was heavy and nothing especially amazing. Probably wouldn't get again!

pics.caption: Yum! burgers!  Also should try the Kimchee pancakes

review.des: Whitefish tortas were AMAZING (although I don't recommend for a first date-very hard to eat)! Service was great as well.

Disappointing and unimpressed.  I would definitely skip this place and save your money for Stephanie Izard's other restaurant, Girl and the Goat.  It is soo much better.  Everything we tried here was mediocre and there was not really any dishes I really favored.

Things we ordered:

Corned beef hash
Tempura mashed potatoes
This Little Piggy went to China
Pork Belly pancake
The wait is not terrible and their fries and bull-eye French toast is so good! A must try!

This place was great.   Very much a real (but better quality food) diner.     Lunch was excellent and they give you a larger portion - server knew the menu super well and was very attentive even though it was super busy.   Prices weren't cheap but definitely not out of line at all.     Would definitely go again.

Came here with a friend who was visiting Chicago. I figured it would be a good spot since it is a sister restaurant of Girl and the Goat. We had a reservation for dinner and were seated right away.

The spot is really well decorated and felt like an upscale diner. It was busy for a Thursday around 6:15 pm which is always a good sign.

I ordered the Los Drowned sandwich with braised beef, havarti, avocado, pickled peppers and onions. I was expecting to love this sandwich because it had all my favorite things. However, the beef was dry and fatty. This was really disheartening because of what it could have been. I only finished less than half of the sandwich. I wish that the waiter had noticed that I had hardly touched my food and could have offered something else.

My friend ordered the Patty Melt and that looked good. I wish I had tried it.

Sandwiches and burgers come a la carte so I would recommend splitting a side. We got fries which were really salty. Not a good type of salty, but the fries were overcooked and drowned in salt.

I'm really disappointed with my experience but would give it another chance for brunch.

Hands down the best Bloody Mary to ever touch my lips.  I've been here in several occasions for brunch. Everything on the menu is great their inlets tend to have a lot of cream cheese in them if you're into that. I prefer more of the savory things fro the "cereal killers" side of the menu. I've gotten 2 if their sandwiches and did not enjoy either of them. Los drowned was good but their breakfast items are better. I also got the tonkatsu and it was no Bueno. The slaw had way too much vinegar in and didn't compliment the sandwich.

Today I had the fat Elvis and it lived up to its name. Just the right amount of syrup. Furthermore the waffle stayed crispy and intact which was a plus. Also the peanut butter butter was amazing. I want to eat a tub of it as a meal.

If you go at a normal brunch time you'll be swamped with a 45+ min wait. However if you're there around 9-10 the wait is tolerable. Go. It's well worth it. Try to seek out the bar area for a seat too!  The bartenders are great.

pics.caption: Fat Elvis waffle will leave you feeling fat and like Elvis. It's amazing.

review.des:
This was our first time here. All of our drinks were good (beer, arnold palmer and a lemonade). The server was attentive and was great with suggestions but had to ask about ingredients on a few items. (maybe some further training would be nice)

My stepfather ordered a shrimp dish special, my mother the waffles with bacon and I had the pulled pork pancake. We loved all of our dishes. The flavors were really great. I loved the pancake! We all agreed we would order them again and would like to try more on the menu.

It has a fun casual atmosphere which contrasts with a lot of the trendy places up and down Randolph. The downside is that it's incredibly LOUD there. We had to practically shout at each other the entire meal. By the end we had hoarse voices. It is a reason we may not return soon.  Wish they could solve that issue.

Overall good food, good service and a little too loud.
Love the biscuits here. Also at any given time you'll see the owner. Drinks at the bar are great and dessert is amazing. Love love love!

If you're trying to be the touristy Chicago visitor, you have to stop by Little Goat and try their nachos. Hands down, best in the city. As a heads up, if you're eating it alone, you won't finish them. Also try the bullseye French toast. I personally wasn't a big fan of it, but the rest of my table thought it was fantastic.

Service there is great. Very friendly and the ambiance speaks to the laid back side of the city. Hot spot for lunch and dinner.

pics.caption: Best nachos you can have in the city

review.des: This place is great. The staff is knowledgeable and courteous and the food was great. I will definitely come back often.

I am generally a fan of Stephanie Izard's but have just found the dishes at Little Goat to be bland and oversalted. The Goat Almighty was particularly tragic, an egregious exercise in the "bigger must be better" school of thought. I made several attempts at Little Goat, and the one reliable standby I found were the fried pickles and onion rings.

The Private Upstairs Dining Room and Rooftop is the perfect summertime intimate wedding reception venue!  We held our brunch wedding here in June and were highly impressed with the entire staff, from booking to the day of. Our guests raved about the food and the cakes from their bakery were top notch!  My wife was able to put her own design touches on the decor and flowers. Highly recommend if you're a foodie and looking for a beautifully designed space.
We went here for dinner last night.  No wait which was surprising.  We had the chicken tenders and a brisket sandwich that we out of this world.  I will definitely be back.

Little Goat Diner is great. I used to live in the neighborhood, and this is probably my most visited restaurant in Chicago. The menu is extensive, so you have the chance to keep coming back and trying new items. On my most recent visit, I got the Parathas Burrito. The flavor was pretty good, but I did not realize how bean heavy of a dish it would be. I am not particularly a bean person, so that was not ideal. However, there are some other dishes that I would recommend over and over again. "This Little Piggy Went to China" is one of the most flavorful dishes I have ever tasted. I have also really enjoyed the Banh Mi burger, crab dip, Brussels sprouts, and fish tostadas. Perhaps most delicious of all are their milkshakes. Last time I got the cookies and cream, which I am still having dreams about. It was packed with ice cream and a bunch of actual, crumbled up cookies. Please do yourself a favor and save (or make) room for this at the end of your meal!

Not sure if some of the reviews are expecting Little Goat to be Girl and the Goat but I found this Diner to be amazing. To drink, I ordered an old fashioned, while is wasn't the best old fashioned I have ever had, it's obvious the bartender is used to making great cocktails. For dinner, I had the "all american burger" while my friend had the mushroom ragu; both tasted amazing. On the side, we also had elotes and while I'm not the biggest fan, the entire plate was gone within 10 minutes. Finally, for desert, we had the sprinkle cake (forgot what the actual name of it) and it was a great way to top off a fantastic dinner!

First off, I wanted to apologize that I accidentally took the cloth napkin out the door with me.  But if you want it back, you'll have to track down my Lyft driver that day.

This is not your typical brunch meal where it's bacon, eggs, and waffles.  Well, I mean you can be basic and get those items but YOLO. We came on New Years' Day around lunch time and was told the estimated wait was 45 mins.  Too bad they don't use the Nowait App.  I gave them my phone number & they would text us when our table is ready.  You can kill a lot of time by walking around & check out other nearby shops or walk 5ish minutes to the nearby Whole Foods OR stop into their bakery & grab a coffee!
I hear great things about the Bulls-Eye French Toast but didn't want sweet so I got This Little Piggy Went to China.  My BF had to be a basic b**ch and got the corned beef has.  WHY AM I WITH HIM.  Anyways, the food came out in a reasonable amount of time.  The piggy was delicious! The sauce has so much flavors & it was STRONG.  The kind where it'll linger on your tongue for a while.  I do recommend you share this dish with someone & share the bulls-eye maybe because it's too much.  Our friend couldn't finish it because it was that strong.  The corned beef hash was meh.  I would say to skip it! As for the Blood Mary's, those weren't crazy good but it was pleasant.
Service is good but not over the top which is why I docked off one point.  Other than that, I would definitely recommend the Little Goat Diner to anyone who visits Chicago & really want to try Girl & the Goat.  If brunch was this good, can ya imagine how great dinner would be? :D

pics.caption: This Little Piggy Went to China ()

review.des:
Hands down one of the best teams to work with on an event!

I hosted an event at LG this weekend for a baby shower and from the events team, food, service, drinks they killed it on all fronts. The guest of honor had some dietary restrictions which they were incredibly accommodating to as well as some picky eaters which they were able to accommodate as well. Our bartender for the event was proactive to ensure that all guests were comfortable, topped off and I have to say he makes a killer ginger-something-or-other mock-tail. He also was a big help with helping us set up some of the decorations as were the point of contact/day of event manager and the server/cook who did a little magic on our cake topper. This team was amazing and we were a bit of a pain in the ass so I can't thank them enough.

Thank you to the entire team - Lucy, Brandi, Heather(?), Jeremy, the stellar cook, Mimi (pastry chef), David & anyone behind the scenes/that I missed. I hope I got the names right.

Call Little Goat your upscale whatever goes diner. Practically everything is available 24/7 on the menu - so whether your heart desires breakfast, brunch, lunch, dinner....order as you please. They've got a good mix of savory and sweet unconventional items such as GOAT and their bakery fresh crumpets.

Every time I'm a first-timer at a restaurant, I've got to choose the one exotic item off the menu. This time, I went with the crumpets with chorizo bathed in maple syrup garnished with bite-sized tomatoes. While 3 miniscule crumpets may look like it may not fill you, rest assured, it was the perfect portion without feeling overly full. My companion went all out with the goat almighty burger stacked a skewer's length high with braised beef, bbq pork, and some sweet fixin's. He was only able to finish 1/2 of that monster, and I chowed down the other 1/2. Goat patties are a little different...more chewy and lean texture-wise. Now, what would've been nice is the option to add an a la carte item to your meal at a reduction. $6 for smoked fries, which were addictively good and non-greasy.

While it was a nice brunch/lunch, I can't justify spending $40 on 2 people unless it was some special occasion. Thus, minus 1 star for value. If you're from out of town, the streets are kind of strange there and parking is probably 1/2 a block down where they have the pay-to-park stations. I'd probably come back in the future, just that there are so many other unique breakfast options in Chi town I've got to try before stumbling back here again.

For being as popular as it is, I was impressed that the wait at 10am on a Saturday was only about 30 minutes.
The service was good and the drinks were pretty tasty. I tried This Little Piggy Went to China which was a unique combo something between biscuits and gravy and eggs Benedict with a Chinese flair. (Note, those strong Chinese peppercorns are mixed in with the sauce - the ones that kind of make your tongue go numb. If you aren't a fan I would ask if they can remove them or maybe pick something else.) An overall enjoyable experience and I would go back to try some more items on the menu.

pics.caption: This little piggy went to China

review.des:
The hostess had an attitude as we came in.  And the food is ok but it seems over rated.  We had porkbelly pancake and the fish tostadas. They were ok but not great, i wouldn't wait 40 minutes for this food. The waitress was not very helpful either after we asked for recommendations.
Not going back.
Love the breakfast! Definitely try out the cinnamon French toast with fried chicken! I love the atmosphere too!

Little Goat is the sister restaurant to Girl & The Goat, which is located right across the street. It's a fun environment with a modern clean look. It's what all diners should look like. Meagan was our server and she was phenomenal - she was engaging, funny, and attentive. Plus, she's from the Bay Area!  My family and I ordered the pork belly and chive pancake, the nachos, the burrito, and the tempura mash. Note before proceeding - portion sizes are huge here!  I am a big guy and normally I can polish off a plate, but these portions were even a lot for me.  All the food was delicious and well balanced, if not on the heavy side. Majority of the dishes had an accompaniment of a pickled slaw or onion, which was a welcome element to help cut the fattiness of the other ingredients. My family and I enjoyed our meal here and the next time I am in Chicago I want to try GATG across the way.

pics.caption: Hard to see, but this is the pork belly with chive pancake, hoisin sauce, and sesame-soy aioli.
These are the insanely large and delicious nachos.

review.des:
Delicious!  The "Little Piggy Went to China" dish is one of the best breakfast meals I've had in a long time.  My wife had the breakfast burrito which was also a new and delicious experience.

You can eat at the bar (they serve the full menu there) or order a drink there while you are waiting.  We ordered a large hot chocolate while we waited and it was excellent as well!

It's a little off the beaten path in Chicago, but you can take a taxi/Uber or just walk the two miles from downtown.  Totally worth it!

Missed it last time I was there and was bummed.

We heard from a bartender on the Navy Pier that we should try one of the goat restaurants and when the wait at Au Chavel was five hours it was an easy choice for us to hop on over to this location. We kept saying we were so thankful for the five hour wait. This place was amazing! The French toast and the Los Despados (Mexican French dip) was amazing! Don't miss this fancy diner stop!

This review is for their breakfast only which was Da Bomb.com! The hubby and I split cheesy hash browns and the dark chocolate chip crunch pancakes. We each also ordered scrambled eggs with bacon on the side.  I thought it would be too much food but we devoured it all!  The pancakes were my favorite! Light and fluffy with a great chocolate flavor. Hash browns tasted great with their homemade hot sauces, make sure to ask for them.

pics.caption: Hash browns, chocolate chip pancakes, scrambled eggs, and bacon.

review.des: WOW, the cheesy grits are spectacular. My best advice, try the weirdest sounding thing on the menu. It is all amazing.

4.5 stars

I went here with friends for our platonic date night. We had reservations and were seated right around that time in a booth. We ordered mac and cheese, hot crab dip, sauteed brussel sprouts, and goat chili cheese fries to share. The hot crab dip was the stand out by far. To. Die. For. ORDER IT!!! The goat chili cheese fries were good not great and the mac and cheese was only okay.

Goat O Goat O salad 4.5/5 stars: I had the salad with dressing and wontons on the side because my body desperately needed the veggies. It was a big bowl of raw veggies and freaking delicious shrimp. Loved it. Would definitely order it again if I wanted a big bowl of healthy goodness. Tried my friends

KIMCHEE & BACON & EGGS & PANCAKES ASIAN STYLE BREAKFAST TASTY THING 5/5 stars:  it was bomb.com. If I wasn't on a diet, I'd order that 10/10. It was nothing I expected with no visible kimchee but the taste explosion in my mouth made me almost regret my quest for a Hawaii body in 2 weeks.

Cake of the day 5/5 stars: I forgot what we got but goodness gracious it was good.

Choc Taco 3/5 stars: we could have done without this because it was a little uninspired and our tummies didn't feel the need to squish this bad boy in.

Will I come back? Of course! When? I have no clue. Come one, come all to this fabulous unpretentious joint.

Bright and clean with plenty of tables and comfy booth seating.

Our server was both attentive and friendly. I requested an espresso while I looked over the menu's many options. It turned out to be one of the best espressos I've had outside of a local coffee shop.

Off to a good start with the coffee, I settled on the corn beef hash topped with two over easy eggs. Absolutely delicious! The best hash I've ever had out. Perfectly cooked, tender corned beef with crisp potato hash browns beneath two rich, runny eggs. I also ordered a side of their house made breakfast sausage. These were just ok. A bit mushy on the inside.

Nonetheless, a great breakfast / brunch option in Chicago.

Cool spin on American diner cuisine, Little Goat is a great night out. The service is friendly and quirky with waiters putting their own flair on the t-shirted uniform.

Decor includes snug banquettes, long share tables, wallpaper, wood and open kitchen. There's a photo booth and cute as a button machine that spits out cute as a button little goat pins for your lapels.

Food wise, the goat o goat o salad was a standout. Yummy Asian flavours with heaps of crunch and a good amount of shrimp. The goat chilli fries were great but rich. The fried chicken was crisp and moist and served with coldslaw. Only criticism is that accompanying a lot of the dishes was a liberal scattering of fried wonton crisps. Perhaps nix the wontons on the slaw because there's enough fry on the chicken.

Pro tip - make a reservation. This place is always packed and there's nothing more awesome than walking in on time and skipping the line.

Menu is as inventive as all the reviews say. You're in for lots of interesting surprises. I got a gigantic avocado club sandwich and ended up taking half of it home. Got a shake to split with the girlfriend!

Interesting experience...good deal on appetizers during happy hour. Los Drowned was as a tasty as other reviewers claimed. Peach pie much better than the cake of day (sprinkle).
Biggest down side was service...place was pretty empty and yet server wanted entree order when we placed appetizer order and managed to deliver first round of drinks after appetizers arrived. Still practically a ghost town at 6 pm when server wanted us to place dessert order-despite recent arrival of second round of drinks(after half table had finished eating).
Still we persevered, had coffee and split a couple desserts and left a tip over 25%...for which we never received a thank you or even a wave goodbye.
This place is amazing! Definitely worth the hype. Delicious cocktails and great food! I would definitely recommend!

Awesome! The food here is very unique and locally sourced. The ambience is fantastic, too. It's a bit pricey, but it is worth it when you consider the ingredient quality. I highly recommend checking this place out if you're in the area. Shout out to Rebecca for providing us awesome service.
I highly recommend coming here for brunch! One of the best breakfast meals I have ever had! The fried chicken French toast is out of this world!

Today I had the best breakfest I have probably ever had in my life. After going to probably all the other breakfest spots in Chicago I can say this is the best in terms of flavor, ambience, and uniquness. I had the Spanish omlette and the Omlette of the day they were both phenomenal.
The coffee here is really great as well probably best mocha I have had in a while.
P.s. I am usually extremely critical and I almost never leave a breakfest place this happy. You have you have to try this place!

Love love love this place. Servers are knowledgeable and super helpful. Out of my party of four, all vegetarian or vegan, one gluten allergy, and one but allergy (I know super high maintenance) they gave us so many options. Food is AMAZING too. The chocolate pancakes are to die for.

I've been to Little Goat twice-once for breakfast and another time for lunch. This place has completely amazed me both times. They have a great outdoor patio that is the perfect place to enjoy a little people watching and an amazing culinary creation.

On my latest visit, I met a friend for a farewell Chicago lunch. I'm so glad that I got to eat at Little Goat one more time before relocating. The menu is so varied that I had a hard time making up my mind about what to order. I was deciding between ordering the tuna melt and a "healthy" chickpea salad. I asked the server for her recommendation, and she raved about the tuna melt that is served open-faced and topped with their mac n cheese sauce.

I am so happy that I went with the server's recommendation. It. was. amazing. Seriously, amazing. Normally, tuna melts are served in a greasy spoon and aren't anything to write home about.  this was not the case at Little Goat.The mac n cheese sauce was phenomenal. I can't even think about it without my mouth watering.

I will definitely be back next time I'm in Chicago. And seriously, get the tuna melt!

pics.caption: Reuben easy on kimchi/no kraut for my friend

review.des:
I'm a fan of Randolph street solely because of its exotic and diverse culinary scene, including Little Goat diner! I have to say, I was more than eager to try it out and had very high expectation, mostly from friends' recommendation and terrific online reviews. So when my friend had a short and sweet transit in Chicago on her way back to WI, I suggested Little Goat for breakfast. My bf and I got to the place at about 9 am, didn't realize that most parking on Randolph is valet, so we did meter parking on Washington street, less than 2 blocks away, and saved $14. My friend was already there, so we got seated almost immediately. Don't get me wrong, the place was almost packed, so if we had gotten there closer to brunch time, I'm sure we would wait a little longer.
The waitress was welcoming, but in terms of helpfulness when I asked about her recommendations since it was our first time there, I didn't think she elaborated enough about their popular dishes or seasonal offers. That said, she did advise us to narrow down to about 3 choices, then she would be able to make further suggestion. So, that was a great alternative.
The 3 of us ended up ordering the special omelette (which came with smoked salmon I believe), this little piggy went to china (my dish), and the parathas burrito. Food came out in what felt like 10 minutes or less, super savory-looking and actually in the perfect portion. My dish was a little on the salty side, probably from the heavy chili garlic chive sauce, but I enjoyed the biscuit and 2 perfectly-cooked eggs, and instead of gooseberries, grapefruit chunks.
Overall, it was a satisfying, nutrient-filled breakfast! I liked the fact that the size of our food was perfect, enough to make everyone full and happy. However, I thought the price could be a little lower, since we could probably get a bigger portion had we gone to a different breakfast place. Easy parking was another bonus! Our waitress brought out one bill but was willing to split it accordingly to our preference, so we appreciated the service. Will make it back another time to try the extensive cocktail menu!

pics.caption: This little piggy went to China.

review.des: The menu here is delicious. I have only tried the take out menu and a couple of drinks from the bar but it was all good. It is crowded. I would recommend ordering ahead and or make a reservation for here. For me it is a must stop now when I'm in Chicago.

LOVED IT! I was in town for a quick weekend getaway with my boyfriend and several friends recommended this place. It did not disappoint. It was a Sunday after the Cubs clinched the NLCS and the place was completely packed, but that's what we were expecting. We went to the bar and got a bloody mary and an old fashioned - both great. The bar is open seating so two people luckily were getting up when we finished our drinks. I had the creole crumpets and John had a special breakfast Chicago dog in honor of the win. All of it was great, the place was cute, and the staff was friendly even though they were so busy. When we are back in Chicago, we will absolutely return.

Brought some friends here that were in for out of town.  It was a Friday morning, and we had a reservation.  There were definitely a good amount of people waiting so were were happy that we made a reservation; our table was ready for us right away.  We started our meals out with a few cappuccinos and a cinnamon bun.  Regretting nothing both were to die for.  When you see this bun you are like whoa thats too much I made a mistake,, and then you taste it and you're like whoa no mistake this thing is DA BOMB!! Perfectly hard on the outside with delicious doughy inside is only made perfect with the not too sweet cream cheese icing.  Its perfect.  Making a choice on the menu is always hard because, duh you should want one of everything.  Finally I decided to go with the daily omelette special.  Oh-mah-gawd.  I feel bad because I don't 100% remember what all was in it, but long story short it was a sweet onion cream cheese filling with eggplant and tomatillo mixture with fried onions on top.  It was so good everyone at my table wanted to help me with it.  HINT: When Stephanie Izard has a special: TRY IT!! Also we got the fried potatoes with cheese, duh so good, so perfectly cooked.  I want to eat here everyday forever and ever: THE END.

What more can you really add to the commentary on a restaurant that has already received over 2,000 reviews, most of them glowing? If I'm being honest, likely nothing. That futility won't prevent me from join the praise chorus lauding Little Goat Diner however.

Although complaints about waiting seem common, we were lucky enough to be seated almost immediately at the diner counter. At noon on a Friday. There are definite benefits to being only a group of two.

We started with a cup of the goat chili, which had a great flavor and the additional texture of the various toppings really made the dish stand out as more than just a cup of soup. Main courses included the Fat Elvis waffles and pork belly pancake.

The pancake was awesome--a savory scallion pancake with a well-prepared slice of pork belly and absolutely loaded with slaw. The great thing about the pork belly was that it properly walked the line between meaty and fatty. It really showed why pork belly can be so delicious when cooked properly. A quibble, if only a minor one, was that the pancake was a tad chewier than I would have liked.

The waffle was, wow, it was great. Honestly, it should qualify as a dessert given how decadent and rich it was. The whipped peanut butter was addictive, and the bacon syrup was just incredible. Together the combination of flavors was terrific.

Thankfully, I only shared a few bites of the waffle. That way I could justify ordering dessert. The pork and toffee sundae sounded like nothing I'd ever had before, so I had to try it. And, while tasty, it was perhaps the least stand out of the dishes we tried. Not that it was BAD, oh no. It's just that it tasted largely like a toffee milkshake. The pork flavoring was subtle enough that it largely got lost amidst the other flavors.

This review is for the 2nd floor private dining. This was such an amazing experience! Even tho it was for work, I had a great time. I mean, I probably wouldn't have been (or will not ever in the future be) able to experience this again, since it's for a larger group. And it's kind of expensive..

Anyway. The chef from Girl and the Goat prepares each dish here in the kitchen, and you can literally watch the magic happen in the open kitchen! I had a fabulous time watching as they prepared each dish, and then enjoying the food as well. I could only stay for a few of the dishes, but my favorite was definitely the goat empanada. For anyone dining at Girl and the Goat, I highly suggest you order it! I don't even care for goat (it's too gamey for me), but there is absolutely NOT gamey-ness to this, and it's SO delicious!

Thanks for the awesome time "pretending" to help in the kitchen and for the delicious dishes! And for the fun experience of watching a professional chef in the kitchen.

I was just passing through Chicago recently and decided to treat myself along the way. I've been to the Little Goat before, so I kinda knew what I was getting into.

While I rode into the city on the Amtrak, I got a reservation online for 1:30 a couple hours ahead. I would recommend always getting a reservation for this place.

As soon as I got there, I was seated - there was a short wait for those without a reservation. The service was amazing. The food was delicious. I ordered "The Little Goat" latte, "This Little Piggy Went to China," and the hash browns. I would recommend all of them.

This stop got me through the rest of my journey.

pics.caption: This Little Piggy Went to China. Amazing!
The Little Goat latte. Espresso, steamed milk, salted caramel, and whipped cream. So good!

review.des:
Ended up here after becoming impatient with the 5 hour wait at Au Cheval, and was not disappointed. Little Goat has a diner feel to it, but the lights are dim and the music is fairly loud.

We ordered the Los Drowned, Machos Nachos, Patty Melt, All American, Banh Mi Style, and Loco Moco. All the food was unique, flavorful, and very filling. The portions were, in true diner style, huge. The menu features classic American food with an unexpected twist. However, the menu lacks detail, so I would recommend asking your waiter/waitress for more information. For example, my friend thought she was ordering a burger and it ended up being served without a bun, but she thoroughly enjoyed her meal regardless.

Overall, the food was great and I plan on trying their brunch in the near future :)

Ps. The food is super messy. Would not recommend coming here with someone you want to impress lol.
Exceptional diner fare. I had a fancy cheeseburger with fries, and it was delicious.
Great food - great service - the place was hopping on a Wednesday at 2:30.  Definitely coming back

Little Goat diner is a unique experience. All of the fun food that Girl & the Goat would offer, but a more relaxed atmosphere. You can go for breakfast, lunch or dinner! The menu is there all day! I love the meatloaf. You can't go wrong with any of their dinner classics. Stop over at the bar/bakery/coffee bar next door before or after you arrive. You won't be disappointed.

We dropped in for drinks and a quick bite while in queue for nearby Au Cheval (which was a 3-hour wait!). There was no wait to be seated when we walked in. We quickly ordered a few drinks - the Moscow Goat, old-fashioned and a honey whiskey cocktail. Then we ordered our "snacks" - Macho Nachos and fried pickles and onion rings.... dang. Those nachos were NO JOKE - they were massive & soooo good.

Our server Ben was AWESOME. He was so friendly, knowledgeable and fast! We got the call from Au Cheval before we were even able to take our second bite and as soon as we let him know, he was on it. He moved swiftly to get us out and into his recommended cheeseburger & bologna sandwich down the street.

Definitely recommend the "Los Drowned" sandwich. The beef was tender and the avocado complimented the sandwich perfectly. One of the best sandwiches I've had in a while. Service was  great and very responsive, and didn't have to wait to be seated.

I have heard a lot about Little Goat and its sister restaurant before I went to Chicago, so we wanted to try it out. We went in on Sunday for brunch and were immediately seated even though it was super crowded with large groups waiting outside.

We ordered:
KIMCHEE & BACON & EGGS & PANCAKES ASIAN STYLE BREAKFAST TASTY THING
THIS LITTLE PIGGY WENT TO CHINA

We got served pretty quickly and the restaurant was really cute. The food was delicious with Asian fushion in the dishes. This little piggy went to China has szechuan pork sausage. And, if you haven't had it before, it's a very particular spice that changes how your taste buds will taste other foods. I really like it, but it can be a little surprising if you haven't had it before. The breakfast tasty thing had these HUGE slices of bacon. I typically don't care whether a dish has bacon (crazy, I know), but the bacon thick slices were super tasty.

I would definitely come here again, but probably stick to a small group.

pics.caption: We came in at 10 on sunday and were seated right away! Better to come in small groups (aka 2 people).

review.des:
I cannot tell you the number of times we tried to dine here but were too hungry and impatient to wait for an available table. So, you can just imagine my happiness!

They offer valet parking for those of us who commute the hard way. The valet parking attendant has a designated area for motorcycles. By this I mean, you self park it across from the restaurant but still on Randolph in a valet parking designated area so they can keep an eye on your prized possession.

I am a bit overwhelmed by the name of my order and don't even know if I'm hungry enough for it today. My desire for French toast outweighs any negative thoughts I may be having about it. I don't remember the names of our orders but I have pictures!

The staff is super cool to our furry companion. The hostess gave her a dog treat from their bakery and another stopped by with a bowl of cold water.

I don't know of any other place I've ever been to where I left feeling like I've made friends with complete strangers. From the guy sharing the bench outside with me as I waited to be seated inside and he waited for his blind date to show up, to the girls we shared our table (a long diner like counter or picnic table with very comfortable stools) but not our checks with, to the hostess, to the other diners who came by to pet our service dog.

pics.caption: French toast with fried chicken, eggs, strawberries and BBQ syrup

review.des:
I have been to this restaurant MULTIPLE times and it never fails to impress me.  First off, the coffee here is great - deep roasted flavor that isn't bitter and tastes good with or without milk/cream.  Secondly, whatever you decide to order, just have it with a side of hash browns.  Trust me.  They're delicious, salty, crispy and aren't in the least bit soggy.  I've ordered the corned beef hash twice and that's amazing.  My boyfriend has ordered the Fat Elvis, which wasn't overwhelming in the PB flavor but had a nice creaminess to the dish.  

Whenever we have friends come into town or I need some brunch after class, this is my go-to place.

What took me so long to get here? Ah yes, the wait scared me. They've been open for over a year now and it will still at least a 30 minute wait on a cold random Friday afternoon.  I put my name in (with a big sigh) and headed over to the bar area. And that's when I saw 2 seats at the bar (full menu available) with my name on them. Score!

I took one look at the menu and said ta ta to my eat healthy New Years resolution (at least on this particular day). After deciding I wanted to go the lunch route (over breakfast) I narrowed it down to the tuna melt and fish tostadas. I decided to let our waitress choose between the 2 and she opted for the fish tostadas. And even another waitress who overheard enthusiastically shared that the fish tostadas were her favorite thing on the menu.  We couldn't help, but get not 1...but 2 orders of them! One for a very hungry me and one for my colleague.

The fish tostadas were perfection. While still happy we got those bar seats very quickly, I can see why people are open to waiting for food this good. Stephanie Izard has made her very large fan club (myself included) very happy once again.

The Good:
Fresh squeezed orange juice! Good coffee. Menu has a sense of humor! ("cereal killers" "sammiches" "taters") Fresh hashbrowns. Fresh homemade breads, bagels, pastries! Beautiful modern, clean, open dining room with open kitchen so you can watch the cooks!

The Bad:
Expensive prices (cup of fruit was six dollars!!!!!) Heavy food.
I don't usually eat breakfast but if I do, I eat pretty light. Kinda hard to find lighter options on this menu, not many egg-less/meatless options....I love pancakes and French toast but all those options seemed overwhelmingly heavy & complex (but were indeed creative)....so I went with sides (fruit, bagel, hashbrowns)

The Food: Hashbrowns are freshly grated to order and come automatically with cheese (I got mine without, as a light breakfast eater) -- portion was huuuge and the hashbrowns were for some reason so long I had to twirl them like spaghetti around my fork!  Breakfast was definitely fresh, yummy, and filling.

The Service: Professional, courteous, efficient, fast, coffee refilled, -- no complaints!

Overall:
Not cheap but hopefully worth it! I like the creativity, freshness and homemadeness. Nice modern restaurant, clean and bustling, pleasant atmosphere, good service, good coffee, good food. Recommended if you want to drop some cash on breakfast! Next time I go I'll try to be more hungry!

pics.caption: Little Goat's menu; breakfast of fresh-squeezed OJ, coffee, fresh hashbrowns, homemade bagel, bacon

review.des: Everything we ordered was absolutely fabulous!  I went with the bullseye French toast - not disappointed!

The lady upfront wasn't terribly nice and we waited for 20 minutes before our waitress got us water and took our order. We went lunch time so as expected from previous yelp reviews, service wasn't that great. However, all the food was yummy! That included the summer shrimp salad, veggie burger (Asian condiments) and the smoked fries. Wouldn't mind coming back.
SUCH GOOD FOOD!!!!!! Order the nachos. They will NOT disappoint!  Not typical diner food so if you're looking for something delicious, different and amazing come here!!!
Megan was was an absolute super star in helping us choose our food, recommending the pork belly pancake... AMAZING! Would recommend for sure and Megan was LEGIT! I would come back alll the time!!!!

YUM....just yum. This place is great, I have yet to have a bad meal.  Service is excellent.  My only complaint is that they look my favorite thing off the menu.....Stephanie, please, please, please bring back the bbq pulled pork!!!  It's so damn good!!!  Tred the crispy pork belly this last time last week and it didn't disappoint!!  Mac and cheese is the bomb too!!

My first visit with two girlfriends. Lunch time and you will need to be prepared for a 20 to 30 minute wait. Went to bar, bartender a bit disinterested yet we finally got his attention although felt we were bothering him perhaps because we were just waiting for a table. He ended up warming up a bit and got us a table.
I need to say once we sat, service was fantastic!!  I'm vegan and the waitress made a selection for me. At once the waitress found out my girlfriend was having a birthday she surprised us with a couple of their specialty cookies. Everyone enjoyed their meals and overall this is a fabulous place

I'm full just thinking about the feast we had at Little Goat.

It goes without saying that Stephanie holds a special place in my heart as one of my fave Top Chef contestants. Of course, I was excited to try one of her restos and am still recovering from one seriously hearty meal that warmed my soul -- head to toe. I think we ordered nearly every appetizer on the menu so our entrees were in excess. Pure gluttony all around. That's how I want to spend my days in Chicago or anywhere for that matter.

- I think Little Goat should be dubbed my personal fave nachos, like ever. The refried beans were the best part or maybe it was that uber flavor packed tender pulled pork... wait, the homemade tortilla chips? Yeah, let's just go with all of it, topped with a hefty dollop of guac.
- Mac and cheese a must. I think I asked for more than my helping -- seconds, thirds, the last bite.
- Entree: half order of biscuits and gravy with a side of cheesy grits: whaaaat. Amazing. This is my fave thing to order, always for a little southern comfort. Little Goat delivered a slightly upgraded version of B&G with pork sausage & mushroom gravy atop a flaky, buttery biscuit.
- Fried pickles should be on your radar. Awesome batter, that's not too heavy and the perfect salty complement to the tangy pickle.

I had a beer too... something local, but it was overshadowed by my desire for all of the carbs.

Loved the swanky diner vibe. I can't wait to go back.

pics.caption: Half order of biscuits and gravy

review.des:
I thought it was JUST a diner. I thought it was irrelevant to Girl & the Goat (the menu is completely different and it is essentially a diner), but this place did not disappoint. It borrows great food concepts from it's sister restaurant, but with a diner-twist. This is not your average plate of pancakes and bacon.

The service was incredible. Our waiter was super outgoing and nice and very timely despite the crowd.

The only thing I did not LOVE was the drink menu. Their version of a bloody mary tastes very watered down. I just wanted the originals when it comes to brunching! Mimosa and a Bloody and I will call it a day.

Not impressed and SO Disappointed. I was really looking forward to coming here after seeing all of the positive reviews. First, all the hostesses seemed to be in a very cranky mood. They said the wait would be ~20 minutes and so we sat at the bar hoping for a baked good and drink while we waited. The bartender was cleaning glasses, while we sat for a few minutes waiting for someone to clean up the leftover mess from the customers sitting before us. He never said that he would be with us in a moment. After 5 minutes of waiting, I got a text that our table was ready. Went to the hostess and she said that it would be ready in a moment. We then stood for another 5 minutes at the hostess' desk waiting. As I was sat at the booth, I took my hand to brush off the crumbs on my seat.

We first ordered a cinnamon bun. We were only given 1 napkin, and after waiting for a few minutes, I went to an empty table and grabbed one for myself. The cinnamon bun while it looked great, was mediocre at best. Dry, doughy, and could barely taste the cinnamon.

The mimosa was served in a small water glass, very unattractive for an alcoholic drink.

Onto the meal... The French toast was very disappointing, especially served with a chicken finger on top. Cool concept to have an egg cooked inside the French toast, but would have preferred them separate.

I had to ask if there was cheese on the hash browns and they told me it was inside. I hardly noticed any cheese, however the hash browns were good and crispy.

The only good dish we had was the shrimp and grits. Savory and nicely balanced.

Once the food was brought to the table, we had to wait a good 5 minutes for someone to look at me to ask for utensils. After getting someone's attention, someone other than my waiter, I asked, "Can I please have some utensils?" He gave me a dirty look and said "Do you mean you want silverware?" Our waitress was nice and sweet, but definitely not on the ball.

It was also quite fitting that the Little Goat had flies buzzing all around, landing on both me and the table occasionally during the meal.

The restaurant was quite loud, but didn't bother me as it was a casual diner atmosphere.

The meal was definitely not worth $80!!! Will not be going again. I was really hoping this was going to be a great meal and disappointed about the bad service.

Do you like gooey cinnamon rolls and from scratch biscuits? Me too and just about every one in the West Loop!  It's always packed... always!

Don't let the name "Diner" fool you. This is extremely elevated food.  

Everything I have had here I would recommend, from the veggie quesadilla to the vegetarian burger, to the peanut butter waffle! They are very accommodating to food allergies as well. Just plan on at least a 30 minute wait on the weekends!
They have amazing pancakes and hash browns!  Plan to get there early because they fill up quickly for lunch.

Great place to eat If you want a comfy, relax, and extremely tasty diner style experience. The service was great and the food was really tasty. I had the vanilla milkshake hmmmm so good even the whipped cream was tasty. Then I had the goat almighty one pound of amazingness. My girlfriend had the fat club which was crunchy and super tasty and not to mention huge. Even the chicken tenders were moist and cocked to perfection. We also tried the macho nachos and omg the home made chips with the meat and melted cheese was to die for. I can keep going but it's not worth it, you need to check this place out for yourself it won't disappoint!!!

Hip place with a huge flavorful menu of comfort food. Everything looked so good I didn't know what to order. We had a nice quiet afternoon lunch here. I ordered the Tonkatsu (a breaded pork cutlet with Asian BBQ sauce and cabbage on bread - yum). I was surprised how big my sandwich was. The service was great and I enjoyed the spacious restaurant with its open kitchen and the attached bakery. They even have dining on their rooftop that is also used for parties (and yoga too!). I'm hoping to try the corned beef hash next time I'm in.

I love love this place. The service is always amazing, the prices are reasonable for the area, and the food is just perfect.  Ive been there about three times and have not been disappointed. Yesterday I got the Pork Cemitas, the shrimp and pork belly entree, and the breadsticks. Oh so delicious, all of it! It's hard not to eat everything at once.  It's basically upscale comfort food done right.

Came here when visiting some friends in Chicago, and I was really impressed with our brunch! Ordered a Bloody Mary and the omelette of the day: bacon cream cheese on the inside with tomatoes, fresh basil, and small, crispy onions on top. Wow, I think this is the best omelette I've ever had! The creamy inside with large bacon pieces was perfect and savory, and the crispy onions provided a good texture contrast to the creaminess. The taste was stellar. Service was prompt too!

The only thing preventing this from being a 5 star review... That Bloody Mary. I asked for it extra spicy, he told me it had a kimchee base and was naturally spicy, I said great. I was wrong. It was not great. The kimchee provided a spiciness but the flavor was not good. It was hard to finish.

But the food was so good, it's on my list of places to revisit.

super good scallion pancakes and crumpets were AMAZING. both were ordered vegan style and was the pinnacle of my brunching in chicago. also got a grapefruit juice which was yummy and highly recommend

wait staff is a little (a lot) slow but understandable because it's packed in there
Yummy food, but pricey for what you get. Service was great! I wish I could remember the name of our waitress, she was amazing and patient. We'd go back, for sure.

So I'm the type of person that hardly ever branches out or changes my meal at a certain restaurant. At little goat for instance I know the elvis waffles are amazing...I get them everytime. I keep saying next time I will try this or the sandwiches but I never do. I miss little goat since I moved, might bring my husband here on our next visit.

This was my second time eating at Little Goat. I went for brunch a couple years ago and remember absolutely loving my french toast. This time, I went back for lunch. I ordered the Banh Mi veggie burger and I was amazed. Veggie burgers are hit or miss, but this was a hit. I could tell they use fresh vegetables to prepare them and the flavor of the banh mi was spot on. Our service was speedy, and even though we sat at the bar, we were always given attention. The only reason I give it four stars is because the side of fries that we ordered was $6, cold, and had so special sauce/seasoning. They just tasted like fries from McDonald's

I have a confession: we were in Chicago for 4 day and ate here 2 mornings in a row.

We got here "early" both days, around 9/9:30 for breakfast, and didn't really wait for a table either day. The specialty bread was a lemon-rosemary focaccia, which was to die for. So good, we ordered it both days. Whoops!

I ordered 1) This Little Piggy Went to China and then 2) Kimchee & Bacon & Eggs & Pancakes Asian Style Breakfast Tasty Thing. It's like someone dug deep into my brain and found the venn diagram that includes breakfast, Asian-inspired food, and savory dishes.. Both were so unique, exciting, and delicious. My favorite of the two would be the This Little Piggy... it's a renegade of intense Asian flavors (sesame, chili garlic chive sauce, Szechuan pork sausage) all topped with a runny egg and a SUPER delicious biscuit. The blackberries are a weird but delicious addition that tie the whole dish together.

The Kimchee/Bacon/Eggs...Tasty Thing was good - different than what I expected, but not in a bad way. It was all mixed together, part crepe, part casserole, part layered-omelet. The flavors were great, and the side of vinegar was a nice touch.

I really can't say enough good things about Little Goat. Across the board we enjoyed both of our meals (my boyfriend ordered the Shrimp & Grits, and the Biscuits & Gravy) and had good, casual service each time.
Such a long wait for just an average service and food. The concept is cool but there are many other breakfast spots with better food.

For someone who stays in burbs, I am not familiar with a weekday dinner in the city limits. This place was crowded for a Thursday night and we had to wait for like 40 mins for table for 3.

Meanwhile we bought a couple of drinks at the bar/bakery at the back of the restaurant. The staff were really friendly and explained what specials were on and what we could get.

We ordered the nachos for starters and it was a mountain. Three of us just managed to finish half of it and packed the other to go.
Main course, everyone ordered different things - sandwich, pasta and I ordered the fish tostadas, which I knew I could finish. They were pretty good. It's slightly expensive, but I guess it's expected since it's in the city.

I am embarrassed to say we "settled" on this place as a backup plan because there was nothing  to second guess about it.  At the height of the lunch rush, our hostess was pleasant without being bothered by the same old questions.  It was at least a 30 minute wait but that was to be expected.  We lucked out and  scored a bar seat when ordering drinks.  The bartenders were so nice to talk to about baseball, beer, you name it, they engaged in conversation and I liked that!  The Vandermill cider was so delicious-clear, crisp and not too sweet.

The patty melt had amazing crunch that only good bread can give, a real tasting patty not frozen or overly seasoned to mask sub quality meat.  Th fries were good but a little thin for my liking, fresh cut thicker potatoes would have sent them to the stratosphere.  The tuna melt was not your mama's tuna melt but it was the best my husband had ever tasted.

Purchased a pint glass for $9 which I thought was a bit steep but enjoyed walking away with a glass for our bar collection.

Enjoyable lunch!

So good! Small wait for lunch as we didn't have a reservation but it was worth it. Big portions of fresh, delicious food. No one was disappointed and our server was awesome. Even treated us to dessert as we were new to Chicago. Can't wait to go back and try something else because the menu is gorgeous.

okay, I'm gonna be honest - it's not that great. I'm not just saying that because girl and the goat is so amazing; I actually came to little goat first. I haven't had an entree here that I've liked yet, after multiple trips, and I usually end up eating off of my friends' plates or filling up on drinks. I will say the milkshakes are absolutely worth it, but the asian fusion items on the menu are big misses. if I want an affordable but upscale brunch in west town, I'd go to flo instead.

This place left me feeling so full and so happy! I immediately knew I'd want to come back, without ever eating a bite. The classic interior and friendly, helpful server instantly impressed me.

I made a reservation online, so easy! Way easier to get in than Girl and the Goat, and supremely satisfying. So you look at the menu and you're like yea, it's a diner. Which it is. And it's so much more!

When I couldn't decide between a few things, our server strongly encouraged me to get the pork belly atop a green onion pancake with this crazy delicious slaw. And I hate slaw. I made zero modifications, and nervously awaited my food. Ordering this was legitimately one of the best ideas ever. It was so very delectable! I want to go back and try more things, but I don't know that I can not order this when it's right freaking there.

The fiance got shrimp and grits, which I didn't try, but which promptly disappeared. Must've been good.

When it came time to order dessert, I couldn't help myself. I ordered the cheez-its and strawberry sundae concoction, while I wondered who in their right mind would order such a thing. Another solid decision.

A guy sitting across from us ordered a burger that was no joke, 7 inches tall. And he ate the whole damn thing.

Make a reservation. Or don't. But get the hell over here and eat. And if you don't make a reservation, then don't bitch about waiting. The place is good. It's popular. You know this. Don't be an idiot.

My boss asked me out to coffee and then fired me at one of the booths on the Randolph side. And I still give it five stars.

That story is 100% true.

Easily one of my favorite restaurants in Chicago. The veggies are delicious- specifically the Brussels sprouts. I also am a huge fan of their goat chili! You'll do good to stop by the bakery after your meal and grab a cookie, too. Enjoy!

Went here with my cousin on a rainy Monday. She was telling me all about it as we were headed out of our morning at the Art Institute.
I had the pork/chocolate shake and fat club. I'm in love with everything about this place. EVERYTHING! The ambiance, decor, concept, mood, staff, food....oh goodness I could go on and on with the adjectives. Gosh, you know it's an amazing place when I can't even properly type a coherent review. My heart is here. Glad I was a tourist in my hometown. New favorite must visit place whenever I go home!

Great little eatery, very cute, would go back for the ambiance and food!  If that was it, 4 stars without a doubt...

Few hiccups to begin messed it all up.  I checked in and they said a 40 minute wait... then we were forgotten about.  This was ok, that happens.   Two things bugged me however.  Once they noticed the error, they chose to seat another group of 3 before ours.  In addition there was no compensation for waiting another 20 minutes, no drink, just a quick "oh sorry"

The bloody wasn't quite my style, too thick and not enough spices, but from there on the food was great.  This is a fantastic place to get brunch!  The Bull's Eye Fench toast was quite awesome as was the tempura mashed!

Didn't have a reservation and, to avoid a 45-60 min wait since this restaurant is worth the buzz, my friend and I sat at the "diner counter" in Monday night. Sitting at the counter may now be favorable way to eat at Little Goat when with a party of 2.

Our server was on it, as always, regarding the flow of when to refill drinks, ask if we needed anything, interaction/conversation with us, and recommendations for my friend who had never been.

The food was great. We got the tenders for an app and fries (the fries are a must). He ordered the pot pie and could've licked the plate clean. I got the fried chicken with a biscuit; it was good but not filling in the best way possible- stuck to your bones but didn't make me feel stuffed.

The only reason this isn't 5-stars is because there was a delay on my entree for some reason; it came out a good bit after my friend got his, but our server checked on it asap and gave a very honest and legit approximation on when I would get it.

Watching the cooks at work- had a great view of them at the counter- was like watching a well oil machine that watched for every detail. I saw the head back server ask that a plate be re-plated because the plate the food was on had a minor chip on it- major points for detail on that.

This was my 10th time there and will continue to go back. Easily one of my top favorite places to eat in Fulton Market/West Loop/Union Park.

Solid three stars-- maybe 4 if you order extremely well.  We actually came because the famous burger joint a few doors down had a 3 hour wait- no thanks.

The food we ordered was a bit mixed.  The pork belly sandwich was very tasty.  This was the highlight of our meal. Chili cheese fries was made with a white cheese which set it apart from any id eaten before.  This wasn't bad but can't say I'd order it again. The fried shrimp appetizer was good and made with a strand like batter.  We also got a burger which was just average.

All in all I liked Little Goat but can't say I come back unless I was nearby and other options were not available. On the plus side service is quick, friendly and the restaurant open and bright.

Yaaaas! This is my favorite place, like honestly! Amanda was our waitress, and was so helpful and very kind. The menu has a lot of variety, so Amanda let us know what her favorites were. The French Toast is amazing, and so are the Nachos! Definitely coming back again. Awesome Food, Awesome People!

One of my favourite spots to eat in Chicago, when I have the money.

In Short: Great food, semi-affordable prices (good for the West Loop), cool ambience, great for young people (very few middle aged-old people here), good for mid sized groups (3-5), menu has nice variety, innovative and creative takes on classics, easy to get into (although i usually try to make a reservation if its the weekend).

I would like to note that I have only been here for dinner and have never ordered breakfast or brunch here (wow im such a bad millennial lol) although their brunch menu also looks varied and yummy. Their bakery also looks adorable and sells sandwiches (good for on the go and throwing down less $$)
Warning: this place gets LOUD and is not a good place to bring your grandparents visiting from Canada. This is not an intimate environment;I've had times where I couldnt hear myself speak.
If Im ordering an entree Il go for the spring shrimp and pork belly or the fried chicken with a biscuit (their housemade hot sauces are great.) Great place to order a lot of different items and share.
Over all highly recommend if youre looking for a 'west loop dining experience' without breaking the bank, setting reservations months in advance, or waiting forever to be seated.

This was a decent place to enjoy an evening meal, but didn't quite meet the expectations I had either. First of all, as some previous reviews have mentioned, I think "diner" is a bit of a misnomer. Although the interior looks like the traditional American diner, the Little Goat is far from being a local greasy spoon. In terms of price and food, they are clearly aiming for a higher quality market. The place is popular- we had a thirty minute wait for a table after arriving (although this was a lot better than the 3 1/2 hours we were quoted down the road).

When we eventually got seated, the three of us ordered burgers, beers, and some fries to share. The food was decent, but not exceptional, and none of us left feeling quite as satisfied as we had hoped. It was also slightly more expensive than I had expected, but as I already suggested, this may just be because I was under the impression it was a typical diner, which it isn't.

Overall, I think the Little Goat Diner is probably worth a visit, as long as you know what to expect. The popularity of the place is very clear, so it's probably worth everyone visiting to form their own opinion.
Great food here, just happened to be walking in the area... hamburger with noodles was the best!!! Make sure you See Bear at the Bar for drinks...
Excellent food...every dish was amazing from the goat burger to shrimp salad.  Service was top notch as well! Thank you for an amazing meal!

Immediately after I ate here, I began to experience some very serious pain in my stomach. It got so bad that I literally passed out. After waking up and being sick for a few days, I ended up in the hospital.  

I think this sums everything up pretty well.

I was in Chicago this past weekend and came here on Friday night with 3 friends, 2 of which are gluten-free. They take reservations which we made like Thursday night for dinner on Friday, otherwise the wait is pretty long. My friend called to make the reservation, I don't know if you can make them online.

Place was definitely crowded so good thing we had a reservation. The hostess got very confused about the gluten-free menu situation but that was resolved. We order the brussels sprouts and broccoli to shear. I ordered the duck which was amazing, and my other non gluten free friend the ravioli which was amazing. My two gluten-free friends ordered the chili which was great and the tomato apple soup. Which  she said was a little weird at first taste but she liked it by the end.

Only complaint was service was a little slow, the waitress took are order and only came back once to check on us after we got our food. Had to flag people down to get refills on our drinks.

I would go back though, food was great, have to try some of the baked goods next time, and need to go to girl and the goat now.
This place is not open on Sundays past 1 pm. I made reservations for 2 pm on a Sunday using my open table app. I'm giving a one star so they can change their information. It was very inconvenient.

This restaurant is one of my favorite for brunch in Chicago. Their staff is incredibly accommodating and kind and the food is amazing. I'd recommend ordering something totally unhealthy and fun, it's definitely worth it. The best meals I've had here are the Spiced Apple Pancakes and the Fat Elvis Waffles.

This place is great.  The atmosphere is like a typical diner.  The service is quick and polite.  If you have a group larger than 4, expect to wait quite a while.  Luckily they have a bar and bakery attached to the diner.  We had a group of 8 people so we waited over an hour for a table.  We spent the time in the bar and it flew by.

I got the Bull's Eye French toast.  It was French toast with eggs and chicken in syrup.  The food was delicious and the portions were large.  I would definitely eat here again.  I love breakfast food and it's served all day here.

We fought traffic, huge crowds, and paid outrageously to park so we could eat here. Server was just rude, intentionally. She cut me off as I asked a question and refused to make eye contact.  It is one's choice to work in a busy establishment.  If you are unable to deal with the public perhaps you should seek other employment.  Really disappointed.

All I can say is WOW! We stumbled upon this hidden gem while looking for a place to eat. We walked in with no reservations and had a seat within 30 minutes. It was a Sunday and was very busy so I recommend reservations on any day if you want fast seating. I had a reasonably priced pint of beer for around $6 and the Goat Almighty burger for $20. Everything is a la cart, so we ordered the pork belly fries to share. I wish the waitress would have warned me how big my burger was going to be. It was HUUUGE! It was layered as a normal burger patty, a bunch of roast beef and topped with chicks of goat meat. All of the meat was delicious and very tender. The bun was amazing and all I can say is that it defeated me. I didn't even make it half way through before I gave up. The fries were great with chucks of pork belly mixed with the potatoes. Before we came here, we did not realize that the executive owner was the winner of Top Chef on TV. Now I can understand why. This lady has some talent and I feel honored and very lucky to have experienced her skills. If I lived in Chicago, I would be a regular here. Highly, highly recommend. P.s. The service was fantastic also, but overshadowed by the quality of the food.

Our family recommended this lovely little diner. We sat outside and enjoyed the sights and sounds of Chicago. The food and wine is great! Benjamin our server was awesome!  Thank your Little Goat Diner for showing us some Chicago love

To set the stage I am a self admitted Breakfast burrito nut. I came here for a work meeting with a large group. No idea what to expect, eggs, bacon, french toast, the usual diner experience right? Way wrong!

A lot of people in my party ordered traditional breakfast but the menu is something you have to experience. It's Asian inspired american breakfast. Consider me floored. I got the Parathas Burrito (indian flatbread . sunny side eggs . avocado-bean salad . chili pepper sauce . sheep's milk cheddar). Changed my life! It was outside of my comfort zone but I took a chance and was thrilled. It was delicious! Make a point to give this place a try and order something that sounds good that you normally may not eat. You will not regret it.

I went to Little Goat for dinner a few weeks ago at the urging of my friend. She had been there plenty of times while I had Little Goat on my list of places to still try in Chicago. We made a reservation before hand so when we arrived at 7pm on a Saturday our wait for a table was only a few minutes. The first thing I noticed about this place is how cool the decor is. The tables and booths all look like they belong in a diner however the fixtures and lighting make this place very classy. We managed to get a booth which was really comfortable however the bar area by the kitchen looked like a cool place to dine.

The menu itself is quite vast with plenty of different options. I ordered the beef ravioli while my friend ordered the smoked corned beef hash with eggs. The food came out quickly and was very good! My friend loves the smoked corned beef hash and gets it quite often at Little Goat and it didn't disappoint this time around. As for my beef ravioli, I thought the sauce was delicious however I would have liked a little more beef and ravioli in the dish. I walked out of Little Goat feeling like I'd barely eaten anything and a few hours later I was starving again.  

All in all, this place is pretty good! At first glance everything on the menu seems pretty simple and synonymous with a diner however when it came out it was way beyond any traditional diner fare. The staff was really friendly and prompt and our waitress was very accommodating of a food allergy one of us has (they have a huge gluten-free menu) and gave us plenty of time to read the menu. This place is great if you're looking for some comfort food with class. I'll definitely go back however next time I'll try something that'll fill me up.

I had really high expectations from this place when I heard that it was from the same owners of the Girl and the Goat.

High expectations, dashed.

It has many non-standard breakfast/brunch fare entrees that you would not see in other diners which is always fun. The Bull's Eye French Toast was good... but...

DO NOT order the Bi Bim Bop Breakfast Bowl. It was extremely disgusting, unsatisfying, and even frustrating. But it was definitely our fault for thinking that it would be similar to bibimbap from a Korean restaurant. Still... a very soupy mess.

The service was very nice, on point, and thoughtful for taking out the bi bim bop from the check. However, it is with regret, that when we are looking for a quality brunch restaurant in Chicago, we'll wake up early and stand in line to go to Three Arts Club Cafe, or even Denny's.

Atmosphere: Really loud. When we dined, there were crying children and angry parents in the booth behind us.

Service: A bit rushed, but acceptable

Food: Average quality and way overpriced. Think Disney World prices meet Red Robin
CRUMPETS. GRAPE SAC SAC. Get ready to sit in the most comfortable chairs of your life. Couldn't be happier. 10/10

I can't believe how amazing the food is at the price point. If you like smoked salmon, please please try the everything everything crumpets!! A good portion (my friend shared some and it was still plenty) and the crumpets were heavenly and not too rich! I had such an all around amazing time, I would've expected to pay a lot more that $15 for the meal quality!

Worth the wait!

The menu is huge with all sorts of unexpected variations on classic dishes. Started with their rosemary and white chocolate scone which was AMAZING. Scones are truly hit or miss, and this place has got scone making down. I ordered the crispy shrimp cocktail, but it was not your normal shrimp cocktail. They were rock shrimp wrapped and then fried in somen noodles,  with a homeade cocktail sauce. I was blown away by how good they were. My friend ordered the breakfast spaghetti with clams and crab, which was more similar to an omelette than anything else but definitely not an omelette. It was very interesting. Their moscow mules were great, and so was their spicy ginger ale. I would go back just for the ginger ale.

We waited 45 mins for a table but it noon on valentines eve and most definitely worth the wait.

pics.caption: crispy shrimp cocktail & a moscow mule!

review.des: Came here especially to try the cinnamon bun and was not disappointed. We came at 7:30, so I can't speak to how quickly they run out, but we were able to order two at that time. It was absolutely delicious, and I could've easily eaten two more. We also ordered a biscuit along with some of their other breakfast dishes, but I think where they truly shine is the bakery. Would definitely recommend coming here when looking to indulge in some decadent baked goods.

Little goat latte. What they serve is a little on a heavy side with the spice mix but still amazing.
