On a cold day, creamy goat milk, sweet cream topping and the fragrance of spice take you to another place. Get a goat latte or the little goat latte. Stumptown beans they use are top notch, so any coffee drink should be on par with the Allis or La Colombe. But if you like your black, the latter is my first choice in the immediate area.
Did I mention the Little Goat Latte?
Omg.  If I ever am on death row, this will be my last meal.  The bullseye French toast thing was phenomenal.  Staff was amazing. Coffee killed it.  Please come here.  Like yesterday.
This place is so good! My favorite has browns anywhere. Great selection of food, friendly people, fun atmosphere. Can be a bit loud and busy - get a reservation.
Great place to eat and laugh, don't forget to check out the rooftop!

Unbelievable food, baked goods, service, and atmosphere. AMAZING breakfast and lunch, super creative menu, well done. Best restaurant I've visited in chicago! I would eat here everyday of I lived here, every plate of food coming out of the kitchen looked phenomenal.

pics.caption: Nice job with logos on everything

review.des:
I've had this place bookmarked ever since reading Brian K's review & his 10/10 rating for the fat Elvis waffles. Finally came here with a friend- 30min wait for 2 on a Friday at 8pm, compared to 3hrs at Girl & Goat. The place was bustling and a bit loud, but it was still a fun, lively experience.

fat Elvis waffles ($11) - 5 stars. Unforgettable. Crisp outside with a chew that made me wonder if the batter uses bread flour. I need to get this again.

tonkatsu sandwich ($12) - 4.25 stars. Fan of the milk bread and tangy slaw. Delish.

Bleinheim gingerale ($4) - 4 stars. Yum, spicy gingerale.

cheesecake pie ($8) - 4.25 stars. About the size of a baseball. Ritz cracker crust, topped with thick honey and pears.

Friendly, upbeat waitress. Can't wait to eat here again, huhuhu T_T

pics.caption: Goat cheese cheesecake pie topped with honey & pear ($8). Ritz cracker crust. Yum to try

review.des: We went to this place several years ago and loved it but this trip was a huge disappointment. The machos nachos were delicious, but everything else was not. First, our server was not good. She had a bit of an attitude, never checked on us and didn't refill our iced tea unless we tracked her down and asked for one. Even more disappointing were our entrees. The French toast would have been good but it was drenched in syrup (ask for syrup on the side). The los drowned was below average. There was too much going with it, and the flavors didn't really work. Plus, there was more fat than beef. The BLTA was ok. The bacon was good but there was too much mayonnaise, and the bacon got lost in the other toppings, plus there wasn't enough bacon. The mashed potatoes were weird. We didn't care for it. That said, the hash browns were good. Overall, a real disappointment.

This is not a kid-friendly (i.e., infant/toddler) place. Parking is difficult, there is usually a long wait, and you feel kind of rushed during your experience. However, the food, ambiance, and service is wonderful. I love their shrimp and grits, and blueberry pancakes. The cinnamon rolls are amazing. And, I believe they serve breakfast all day.
We waited awhile, even with a reservation. However, the food was pretty spectacular. I had the paratha burrito, and a side of smoked fries. Ask for the special dipping sauce.

This cute diner puts a trendy, hip spin on breakfast food. After hearing that the owner of Girl and the Goat had this sister restaurant, I knew we had to come here for breakfast! Overall, all of the dishes had really rich flavors and we left satisfied.
- Los Drowned Sandwich (My favorite!!): extremely tender and juicy braised beef with so many different levels of flavor and depth in every bite. Possibly one of the best sandwiches I have ever had. I'll be telling everyone about this and coming back just to eat this amazingness again.
- Goat Chili: Hearty chili, a little salty for my taste, but I think it probably would have been good with a piece of bread or crackers to balance out the salt.
- Hashbrowns: not your typical soft on the inside crisp on the outside diner hashbrowns. These come out crisp all around and seemed so light that we kept reaching for more.
- Bulls Eye French Toast: a mix of sweet and savory. If the sweetness level was toned down a notch or two, this probably would have blown me away.
- Breakfast Spaghetti: This dish was definitely different from anything I've tasted before. The flavors hit you from your first bite. - very rich

Bull's eye french toast: interesting idea, eggs in the middle becomes too over cooked and would suggest putting syrup on the side very rich and ruines the experience of the good bread.

Porkbelly homefries: please don't bread your home fries or use a lighter bater

Biscuits and gravy: why don't people know how to get the gravy right

One of my favorite places to eat in Chicago! One of the only places my family can always agree on, too. Heehee.....

It is hard to try new things on their menu because I am so stuck on my favorites.

*Bull's Eye French Toast - sweet, savory.... chicken + french toast perfection.
*Pancakes - changes seasonally but always perfect.
*Fat Elvis Waffles - oh. Come on. Peanut butter. Bacon maple syrup. Bananas. I LOVE YOU.
*Patty Melt - hits the spot every time.
*Smoked fries, Hashbrowns, and Mashed potatoes = potato heaven.
*Chicken Fingers - best paired with the mashed potatoes + gravy. Eating like a four year old has never been more fun.

Soda is always super fizzy and the coffee is strong and delicious. What more could you want? Fancy diner dreams come true here.

Get the French toast with fried chicken !! You won't regret it , I think it's called the Bulls eye French toast.  My favorite part was the pork belly home fries , but I'm a sucker for anything potato. But like previous reviews , be prepared to wait cause there was a lonnng line .

I've visited 3 times now for breakfast and have yet to be let down be it by food, service or overall experience. Their coffee is great (locally roasted), the booths are comfy and the menu is nothing short of amazing. I've had the corned beef hash and two omelets of the day, which all were amazeballs. Also, you'll never wait as long as they say you will when you put your name in (bonus).
Order the French toast; egg, chicken and strawberries come on it. Lattè was perfect. Sausage links house made

Food is amazing, creative and high quality. The interior is trendy without being pretentious. The wait staff is friendly and attentive. I will be going back here and recommending it to friends and family.
We loved the food. It is diner food but with a twist. You might have to wait a  it but walkins are great. Their cocktails are a must  try too

FLAVORS (4 Stars)
The flavors here are rather bold and had me drooling the first time around. It was good the 2nd time around but not the same. I took away a star for the lack of consistency.

Here are some personal favorites, tips & tricks-

Food
1.Piggy went to China
Flavors were great over the summer with blackberries but lacked a  little something today. Let's just say I couldn't finish it :/ I mean why waste those calories
2.Chili Cheese Fries
This was great but the portion was too big for the two of us.
3. Horchata Shake
This concoction was delicious for a cheat day but then again I am biased because I'm a sucker for horchata. It had the right amount of sweetness
4. Los Drowned
This sandwich just melts in your mouth. I'm still drooling about it

Drinks
If you can have a house special. They  won't do you wrong.

SERVICE (5 Stars)
The food is so great that you don't notice the staff much until you're dying of hunger to order some yummy food. The servers give great tips on what to order definitely ask if you are torn between items.

ATMOSPHERE (5 stars)
This place is always packed but I've never had to wait more than 5 minutes. The seating seems cramped but it is just right.

ACCESSIBILITY (5 Stars)
Being right on Randolph Street is the perfect prime location- plus a lot of free parking in West Loop

**********************************************************
Deserves 4.75 stars but Yelp doesn't allow me to give half ratings so had to round down.
everything is way too salty. Tuna melt is disappointing, could not even tell how different with subway. Hash brown was ok, had cheese inside which is good, but again too salty.

pics.caption: Tuna melt,nothing special, way too salty

review.des:
We chose Little Goat as our dining spot for a pre-theatre dinner.  The place upon entrance gave off a good vibe and we liked the decor.  Definitely trendy and nicely decorated.  We were seated at a booth for our party of 6 near the window which allowed for good people watching out the window.  The staff were friendly and referred to their menu  as a "traditional diner menu".  Well, being that I am from the northeast which is a haven for diners I would disagree with the "traditional" part.  It is more of a trendy diner-inspired menu.  I ordered a signature drink ( smoking cherry bomb?) that I had to return because it was not drinkable.  I opted for a sauvignon blanc instead.  Wine is served in a juice glass... I found that odd.
Our teenage girls opted for breakfast options (served all day) of sourdough pancakes and chocolate chip crunch pancakes.  Two girls ordered Caesar salad with chicken.  I had the shrimp and cheese grits, and my friend had the Fat  Club.  All of the food was tasty but nothing over the top amazing.  After sampling all of the dishes we all agreed that the breakfast items were the best call.  
Overall I would say the menu has a lot going on.  Perhaps a true "foodie" would be more excited, but I will say if you are dining with kids that they may likely be put off by some of the items as there are a lot of extra ingredients/condiments in some of the traditional sounding offerings like the grilled cheese and veggie quesadilla.  Unfortunately, dinner service took so long (for just one course) that we did not have time to try out some of the desserts or shakes even though we had allotted an hour and a half for dinner.    
I would say this was a fun "one and done" for us.  Maybe I would go back for breakfast or to try dessert, but I am not feeling compelled to return for dinner.

Little Goat has the ability to make me cry. Not because of physical pain (even though I was oh-so-full), but I left with an exhausted mind after being incredibly overwhelmed by the sheer size of the menu and the incredible portions provided. My buddy Breanna B & I were practically shedding tears when faced with the decision of what to choose for our meals. I was almost incapable of choosing. But choose I did...thanks to our stupendous server, Carl.

The decor is modern diner. The staff is incredibly welcoming. As mentioned, the portions are impressive. And the food. Oh the food is mouth-watering. The menu is filled to the brim with cool takes on diner classics - goat burger, mac 'n cheese, scallion pancakes, tempura mashed taters, hot crab dip and about a billion other items.

Let me run down the list of items I sampled that practically popped the button off my jeans...

*Bullseye French Toast: Sweet and salty at its best. Huge, thick slices of perfect French Toast topped with strawberries, bananas, syrup, egg and fried chicken.

*Mac n cheese: Kraft who?!

*Machos Nachos: Dayum, Stephanie Izard. Girl - you MAKE those nachos! Chips are piled high and topped with deliciousness.

*Broccoli puff: A flaky pastry puff stuffed with creamy goodness and brocolli. This was still tasty, but not my fave.

*Hot crab dip: Served with Ritz crackers, you'll want to dive in.

*Crispy shrimp cocktail: I gotta give an enthusiastic nod to my girl, Candice G, and say yes, yes indeed this is one of the best items on the menu. It may sound basic, but the flavors are incredible. I would absolutely eat this for a main dish next time.

So, you can see why I was full. Therefore, do yourself a favor and get ye to Little Goat with your stretchy pants and a few friends to share some plates.

Nice new approach on the classic diner atmosphere.  Everything we had was delicious, and I wouldn't mind another round of their shakes. I have to go back there if for nothing else but to try all of their items.  I am being honest when I said that I sat there for a good 10 minutes because I didn't know what I wanted from all the good looking food.

This review is for private events at Little Goat.

My husband and I have eaten at Little Goat many times and have loved the food for years.  When we were deciding on a wedding reception venue Little Goat was on our list of places to check out.  We had planned for a very small guest list so places like LG and Girl and The Goat fit the bill.  I initially inquired about dates of availability and prices and got info right away.  We were able to schedule a visit with ease and went to see both spots at the same time, ultimately picking LG because... well that terrace, man! How can you not love it! Plus the space is super intimate and they cook everything right in front of you.  My one "must have" for the day was to be able to eat dinner at one table together (we ended up with two which was still perfect) and really be able to talk, hang out, and have fun.

The day-of coordination was handled by Tiffany who was absolutely perfect.  Really, everything about the day and choosing things like menu items, timing of events, seating, etc. was done with ease.  We did everything over email and Tiffany was kind enough to answer all of our questions in a timely manner.  Her and the team helped set up the space and it looked absolutely perfect with our decorations.  Service was wonderful, the food was AMAZING, and we had the best weather possible so we got a lot of use out of that wonderful terrace.  Our guests could not stop talking about how great everything was.

Thank you Little Goat for a fantastic, intimate, delicious wedding reception!!!

Cute little offshoot of Girl and the Goat. I had the Okonomiyaki which is a sort of savory pancake with bits of pork and veggies. It was delicious and came out pretty quickly. I went during the lunch hour on a Sunday. There were plenty of servers but I felt as though my service was sort of slow. The waitress kept walking past our table which was right next to the register. It was slightly irritating but did not take away from the overall experience. Plus it was moderately busy so I understood why they may have been overwhelmed. They have a pretty expansive breakfast menu and the environment seemed very kid friendly. They decor is definitely very old school diner feel without trying too hard.

This place is overrated, but I do enjoy the shrimp wrap dish they have on the menu.  Other than that... their chai lattes are TERRIBLE and they rest of the food is so/so, but nice to have around if you need an occasional change in pallet.  I say occasional as it's a heavy, rich, murky food that you will probably only be able to put down once or twice a year.

Cool concept though, like the name, the décor is somewhat flattering and the location is boss.

I would give Little Goat 4.5 stars if I could. Incredibly creative, delicious food and great service in a really fun space. It's diner-esque, but really well done. We ended up going twice in 24 hours--the first time while killing two hours between drinks at The Aviary and a late dinner at Girl and the Goat, and then again the next night for dinner.

Both times the service was great. Camille especially was absolutely wonderful.

There are lots of breakfast options that are served all day ("Cereal Killers"). We wanted the Bull's Eye French Toast, but they were out (sad face), so we had the Crumpets with Chorizo Maple Syrup instead. The crumpets are made to order, topped with crumbles of chorizo, maple syrup, and sliced gooseberries. Perfect combination of sweet and savory.

The Shrimp and Cheesy Grits were incredible. In. Credible. Savory, shrimpy, with a little bit of heat, seafood stock, braised pistachios, Brussels sprouts leaves, stewed tomatoes, scallions. Unprentious, shockingly flavorful comfort food.

The Reuben, with smoked corned beef, kimchi, saurkraut, cheese, and yellow mustard on pretzel rye was really something. The kimchi is a great addition to a traditional-ish reuben, and it's ridiculously delicious.

We had the side of Glazed Root Vegetables (parsnips and carrots), which were fine but not exciting, especially compared to everything else we had.

The seasonal cocktail, Fall in a Cup, was disappointing, but that was after drinks at The Aviary, so it was probably not a fair assessment. It was too sweet for me.

The Cheez-It Sundae (Cheez-It elato, strawberry quick ice cream, chocolate/peanut butter covered Cheez-Its, peanut caramel sauce, whipped cream, and, of course, a cherry) received mixed reviews at our table. I really liked it, but I'm partial to salty desserts.

The Little Goat is like a diner in the sense that it has a huge, bright interior with a raucous and cheerful vibe.  It is like a diner in the sense that it seems to be home to everybody -- couples with kids, couples on double dates, older folks, and a pack of almost a dozen teenagers at a giant table together.  And it is also like a diner in that it has a giant menu, with both breakfast dishes and savory dishes served all day, and a dizzying organization that makes it hard to even decide what kind of meal you are eating.  (Cinnamon bun?  Cocktail?  Sandwich?  Salad?  Coffee?  Fried pickles?  All six at once?)

It is unlike a diner in the sense that the food is intensely flavorful and really really good, from start to finish.  The coffee is dark and strong, the cocktails are well-balanced, the fried pickles are briny and crunchy, the cinnamon bun isn't too sweet, the salad is packed with both vegetables and more decadent treats, and putting kimchi in a reuben sandwich was an inspired idea.  (Yes, we did get all six at once.  It was one of those days.)

And all of this was cheerfully and enthusiastically provided by a helpful server who helped us navigate the menu, finagled multiple substitutions in our order, and otherwise shattered all of the usual diner stereotypes.  After one visit, I already wish I went more often.  Indeed, I wish I lived next door.

Aside from the fact that I love the fabulous interior and the branding of this place, I couldn't stop saying "wow" to everything that kept coming out and and going in my mouth. At a group dinner, I think my dining partner next to me must have thought i was insane and probably wished I would just shut up so he could enjoy his own meal...ha!

The benefit of dining in a large group means there are plenty of appetizers (snacks) to go around. We ordered the following starters to share:
* Hot Crab Dip:
Not sure about the Ritz® crackers.
* Fried Pickles & Onion Rings:
I tried the pickles, and in writing this I wish I had a plate of them in front of me right now! Oh wow, it was my first fried pickle...ever...and I want more. Tangy in a perfectly salted batter.
* Crisp Shrimp Cocktail:
I didn't try these, but the noodle wrapped shrimp presentation was beyond divine.
* Machos Nachos:
The name indicates a certain nacho sophistication. The homemade corn tortillas were memorable.
* Side of Mac 'n' Cheese:
It was just okay for me. Compared with the other foods, I found it to be bland.
* Side of Pork Baked Beans:
A tangy/sweet blend of yumminess

For those of you who've dined here, you know that the above list is more than a lot of food to go around prior to actually getting to the meal. Yes, I was more than stuffed and aching in delight by the time I got around to my Sammiches, so they came home with me. I did a plate share with one of my co-workers. We shared the Reuben with smoked corned beef and the Los Drowned with braised beef. Wow wow wow! I'm glad I had a couple bites of each before I packed 'em up to-go. The Reuben was salty/smokey in flavor and piled high with ingredients and the Los Drowned with a side of au jus was loaded with this pieces of beef. I remember looking across the table at another coworker, and she had the look of pain on her face as she looked down at her chicken with waffle meal (wonderful pain that is). We were just SO STUFFED!

Note: They have a Green River drink here. I didn't get it, but I wish I did. Talk about nostalgia and remembering being with my parents as a kid while they ordered these with Brown Cow shakes.

Our server was terrific. He immediately asked whether anyone at our table had allergies. This was a first. I have a soy allergy, so he immediately went back and made sure to come tell me what dishes I might want to stay away from.

Dining here is an experience. If I lived in the city I would no doubt come here often. But, for now I'm glad that it remains a special treat.

What's that? We're eating at Little Goat, ya say? Huh, I'm pretty sure I've heard of it...and now, well now, dear readers, I'm pretty sure I'll never forget Little Goat and here's why:

-sleek diner vibe that cleverly teeters between classy and casual all rolled into one (be sure to step next door and check out the bar area with bottled made in-house products)

-we're talking scallion pancakes topped with pork belly, tempura mashed potatoes topped with Asian bbq and fresh sweet corn off the cob mixed herbs and who knows what else that made it mind-blowingly delicious and refreshing.  

-who says you have to blow a shitload of money for awesome eats? Dishes at Little Goat fall in the $13 - $17 price range and will knock your socks off twice as fast as those highfalooting restaurants with a heavy sticker price

-open kitchen with a classic diner-style pass through window for high visibility

-bottom line: Can't wait to take all of my friends here. Good news is, it's close enough to the core of downtown that you can easily walk or cab it over.

pics.caption: Chive pancake with pork belly and bok Choy salad

review.des:
The Girl and the Goat comes up on many foodies' lists for must visit restaurants in Chicago. Since I knew I would be dining solo, I thought their more casual sister restaurant, Little Goat, would be a better fit.

I got sat at the last seat of the bar right next to the loud busing station. I was hoping for a better spot since I made reservations. It was a busy Sunday night though so there weren't many spots available.

My waitress pointed out all the good vegetarian choices on the menu, and I realized I would be just as spoiled with choice as I had been at the veg restaurants I had already visited. After much internal debate, I went with the parathas burrito since it seemed like the least likely thing I could find at home.

The burrito was indeed unique and tasty, especially with the kidney bean salad topping. The only thing that stopped it from being a "wow" dish was the overcooked eggs. I really wanted some runny yolks.

Little Goat also has a nice cocktail menu. I started with their spicy coconut drink which was ok, but  my second drink, Eastwood's Ride, kicked major ass. It's their spin on a Moscow Mule. Usually I don't get excited about vodka drinks, but I would suggest seeking this one out.

I was feeling pretty piggy after my meal and inquired about a to-go cookie, but they were already sold out. Maybe next time.
The sandwich was 5, crumpets 5, salad 4, atmosphere 5. Great experience for Sunday brunch!

Came here again and ordered the Korean burger, and unfortunately, I wasn't as impressed this time around by the food. The patty for the burger came out rather dry and slightly charred--and while I did ask for a medium well cook, I've definitely had patties elsewhere done medium well and still juicy. I also wish the patty itself was flavored with kimchi as well--the beef was rather plain and definitely needed the help of some seasoning. In fact, I found the entire burger was very dry overall--dry bun, dry patty, and the small amount of kimchi didn't help the situation much either.

Fantastic service as usual, but food just wasn't up to par this time around.

Really really yummy food. Chilli cheese goat fries are the absolute best. Their broccoli and cheddar soup is out of this world. Also had the crab dip which was super yum! Place is crowded during weekends and has a considerable wait time but it's really worth it. Great place for a casual date night as well as to hang out with friends. Don't forget to check out BomboBar next door for dessert!

I've followed Stephanie Izard's career since Top Chef Season 6. Two years ago my boyfriend took me here as a surprised and we've been back countless times since. I don't have anything bad to say about this place. Regardless of time of day we go the wait is always reasonable or short. The food is stellar. It's all food you're familiar with but just with an elevated twist. I'm not sure what is in the gravy but I could put it on anything. Waitstaff is always pleasant and cheerful. I recommend Little Goat to anyone visiting Chicago and everyone has nothing but rave reviews.

Amazing!!! Attended a bridal shower in the upstairs and it was awesome!! The food was so delicious, esp the Kale salad.  Would highly recommend this space for a party, the staff and bartenders were great, and I can't wait to come back!

Went here before a Hawks game for lunch. The food was all very good! I loved that the restaurant had a diner feel but with food that was better than diner food. I ordered a cheeseburger, fries and a chocolate shake. It did not disappoint. The only downside was my boyfriend left feeling sick and had pretty bad food poisoning. However, he would go back and so would I, that speaks for how good the food was!

I am glad Little Goat was there to catch the overflow from Girl across the street.  I've been wanting to try Girl & the Goat for quite some time and thought tonight was the night as I've trekked a mile on foot and in the rain with determination to get here.  But alas, the waiting list at the Girl was "uncomfortably long" when we arrived and so we made our way across the street.

Little Goat welcomed us with open arms, quoting a 45 minutes wait for 2 people.  However, we were seated 5 minutes later, it was a miracle!  It was late, and we were hungry.

Mac and Cheese $7 - It was cheesy (hint of goat cheese) mac with bread crumbs sprinkled on top.  Simple but oh so delicious.  My favorite of the night.

Reuben $13 - Smoked corned beef, kimchi, kraut, cheese, mustard, special sauce, pretzel rye.  The first bite was extremely delicious.  I got bored by the 3rd bite, though.

Kalbi Beef Ribs $18 - Dirty rice, cantaloupe and watermelon, crispy onions.  The beef had really good flavoring.  Overall, it was ok.

The booth we got can easily seat 6 and was comfortable.  The service was very good.  There were free street parking if you want to drive.  It's about a 10 minute walk to the Grand Blue Line train.

I love the creative menu options, but thought the dinner I had was a bit overpriced and underwhelming.  I might want to come back and try the breakfast dishes, if Girl rejects me again.

My wife got the tuna melt and she loved it.  It had arugula, eggs, olives, and roasted red peppers.  

I got the American burger and was disappointed.  The burger was cooked well, but the bread is a bad combination.  It's too dense and squishy - didn't enjoy it.

The smoked fries were tasty.  A nice hickory flavor that makes it taste like it has BBQ sauce on them.  They're shoestring and enough to share between two people.

The service is really good there and decor is also nice.  Would not order the burger again.

The sickest sh*t happened to me the other day, guys.

I was sitting on my couch late at night when my head started itching. At first, no big deal. I hadn't washed my hair for an extended and undisclosed number of days, it's probably just, you know, build up or whatever. So I continue to sit there and I'm working, typing away when this little thing glides into my frame of sight and then disappears. Maybe a fuzzball? A Gnat? I swat the air once as a precaution and get back to work.

*Maybe* 8 seconds later, I see the spot again, only it's swinging... because it's a motherf*cking spider! Trying to eat my face. And it's so close to my melon that I don't even have time to freak out. I just start clapping both my hands into the air in hopes of nabbing it and smooshing it to death. And because I believe I was brought into this world to be a natural born (spider) killer, I succeeded. Dead as a f*cking doornail.

... But then... Arachnophobia. 2013. Starring Candice G. John Goodman is nowhere to be seen. It's all up to me. And there's about a million (like 4 or 5) little spiders coming down from the AC vent above my head. F*ck. Obviously those little f*ckers just got borned in there and I don't know if generic Target brand Lysol is strong enough to kill them all. And I have no idea how many are already nesting in my weave. Now I have to move. You can't undo that. Am I going have to disclose this incident to the next renters? What happens next? Where is my life going? I gotta get out of here. Gotta get outta this town.

Far away.
Far, far away... sort of like Jenny from Forest Gump.
Far and away... but with less Tom Cruise & Nicole Kidman.
Off to the city, where there are no spiders, (that's a thing, right) but there are goats. Little ones. And one in particular always knows how to cheer me up. Makes me feel warm. and safe. and at home... but sans spiders.

So I make my way to Little Goat, which is a haul for me coming from the suburbs, but it fits both my main criteria of being far away from my apparently insect-ridden apartment and it's spider-free, to my knowledge. It's not home, but it feels like home. Better than home at this point, actually.

Now, I've done this LG dance a few times so I'm pretty well-versed in what I NEED to order... brace yourself, it's a lot, but keep in mind that I'd just been through a very traumatic experience and eating my feelings was necessary.

Get this:
* Crispy Shrimp Cocktail - somen noodle wrapped shrimp, cocktail sauce, lettuce wraps. Best thing on the menu. Hands down.
* Hot Crab Dip - served with regular ole Ritz crackers, not house-made anything, but the Ritz are perfect and there's so much crab that you won't bat an eyelash at the price. Totally reasonable.
* Shrimp and Cheesy Grits - insanely good, very filling
* Smoked Fries - meat-free, but tastes like meat in the best possible way and the bowl is huge.
* House-made veggie burger with the Korean set - kimchi, bacon, egg, spicy mayo, squish squash roll... but I get it sans bacon.
* Veggie Chap Chae - spring onion, patty pan squash, fennel, tomato, sheep's milk cheese, cashews. It's like a pasta-y thing, but it's super fresh, farm-y and full of veggies and queso.
* Choco Taco dessert. Heaven in a float glass.

Okay, okay... I'll admit it. I've had a dining partner with me on every one of my visits so I've technically split all this and I don't actually have the manly appetite that I've led you to believe I have. In fact, I usually have leftovers so this probably enough food for 3 people, but more importantly, it's exactly the amount of food a person needs to forget about a personal tragedy (Re: spider demons). Amen.

This is my new favorite restaurant in the Fulton Market District! We had reservations and were seated within 5 minutes of arrival. Before being seated I enjoyed the cute custom little goat photo booth! The waitress was friendly and offered some great recommendations and we decided to order the jerk chicken sandwich, machos nachos, and the Mac n cheese. I highly suggest trying the machos nachos! The chips were crispy and the cheese on it is addicting. Great upscale diner and the prices aren't bad! Perfect for a casual date.

The food was yummy. We had the shrimp + grits, Cinnabun, and biscuits + gravy. Locally farmed food that's seasoned perfectly. Food was delicious and definitely recommend to my foodie friends.

They take reservations as early as 7:00am. They aren't that busy early in the morning but if your waiting, you can kill time by taking pictures at their photo booth.

pics.caption: It the little details that make this place so cute.
Restaurant interior is really chic. Love the natural light.

review.des: I really wanted to like this place, but was not so satisfied. We ordered the chili cheese fries, which were excellent! But the little piggy went to china was just salty! I couldn't eat the whole thing. I read some other reviews here, complaining the food was salty. Maybe the management takes notice, and does something about it. I really liked the over all ambiance, and interesting variety in their menu. I would give this place another chance, after I get that salty taste still lingering off.

I had the Fish Tostados here which were pretty good... nothing extraordinary, but pretty good. Alcohol here was tasty too... not sure if I would recommend since the place was jam-packed when I came in and we had to wait... not what I was used to back in my home town in Austin.

Love!

Everything was wonderful! The smoked pork & toffee milkshake was sooooo good! It just has a hint of bacon & not overwhelming. Loved the little pig went to China...the diverse flavors explode in your mouth! And the fat club so tasty...the best blt variation I've had. The fat Elvis waffles were killer sweet but very good for those with a massive sweet tooth. Great service too.

Can't wait to go back!

My husband and I came to Little Goat on a Sunday morning, and we were seated right away for our 10:00 reservation. The place was buuuuuusy, so I was happy to have made reservations because it looked like the wait would've been a while.

The vibe is great in this beautiful space, and you can tell a lot of work went into the design. It's well lit and comfortable, and the finishes are beautiful.

I ordered the This Little Piggy Went to China, and my husband had the Parathas Burrito. We started with a white chocolate rosemary scone, which was pretty shrug-worthy, but hit the spot because we were hungry.

Our entrees were pretty good, but our server was sloooooowwwwww and our water glasses were empty pretty much the whole time. I enjoyed our time at Little Goat and I'm happy we got to try it, but I definitely wasn't blown away by the food or the service.

This was just ok. We got the patty melt and dark chocolate chip crunch pancakes. The patty melt wasn't anything special, just very average. The pancakes were good but not the best I've ever had and certainly didn't live up to expectations. The interior is cute but the food isn't worth the wait in our experience.

I'm a Top Chef fan so I was really excited to try this place. When walking in, the place is comfortable and you are warmly greeted. My server was awesome, he was a sweetie! I had the Kim chi asian breakfast thingy because I wanted something different. What a savory and sweet delight!  The flavors are creative and the textures keep things interesting.  The cappuccino was delicious and my server brought me a yummy complimentary scone as his gift. Love it!  Great environment and food.
Great wholesome food! Even has a vegan option! Cant wait to come back again! For 2 people at lunch you can have a full meal and wine for $55 :)

The menu at Little Goat is so UNIQUE. I love going there for brunch. However, I try to go on a weekday because weekends always have a 1hr wait or longer. If you want to wait that long, it's ok because little goat is never disappointing but I always tend to go for a much calmer environment which is usually on the weekdays.

This was described by my friends as one of the must-visit diners in Chicago, and I wholeheartedly agree that the Little Goat Diner encompassed some of the most unique brunch items I've ever had. For those of you who follow my reviews, I am not a brunch person, no siree, so when I am fronted with a menu consisting of pork belly overlying a bed of crunchy cabbage and scallion pancake, the well-reviewed This little piggy went to China and the meat-inspired milk shake, I was completely hooked. First of all, the establishment has an incredibly cute goat avatar above the building, which certainly adds to the experience. Our waitress was incredibly friendly and helpful and helped us navigate through the menu. My wife and I ordered the two aforementioned meals, as well as the tempura mashed potatoes. I really enjoyed the pork belly dish, although the scallion pancake served more as a thick slab of wrap as opposed to the crunchy, flaky marvels served at most Asian restaurants. My wife loved the Piggy-China-dish, which was a combination of Chinese sausage, scallion biscuits, egg and waffle. The dish relied a bit too much on sesame oil and was just a tad saltier than I had preferred. I did order a small side of the whipped peanut butter spread, only to realize that it was actually flavored butter, but peanut butter. At the end of the day, I'm really glad I came here, and I am excited to try out some of the other popular dishes, such as the Fat Elvis, or the strawberry-fried-chicken waffle or the crazy epic goat burgers.

Food: 4 stars
Service: 4 stars
Price: 3-4 stars
Ambiance: 3-4 stars

I'm going to start my review by saying I am a Girl and the Goat fan and all of Stephanie's restaurants. My husband moved out of Chicago 3 years ago and every time I visit I look forward to either seeing what she has that is new or visiting my old favorites. We went on a Sunday so naturally I expected it to be a long wait. However, when we got there it was 1.5 hours, once again, not a surprise. However, while we were waiting there, you could see seats open (wasted in my opinion) for long periods of time. In fact, the 2 seats at the counter that we were sat in stayed open for 30 minutes before we were sat in them. They need to get their front of the house in order. Also, when you sit at the counter you see a lot. I ordered the bim bim bop and my husband the bull's eye french toast. I saw there for 15 minutes and could see our orders sitting under the heat lamp and sure enough, when I got my dish, the 2 eggs on the top were over cooked. You can't have bim bim bop without the runny egg. My husband's egg were the same within the bull's eye french toast, not runny. I'm not sure I will wait this long again if the service and quality continue on this path.

This is my second visit to the little goat. I no longer live in Chicago so everytime I visit, this will be my Togo place for brunch! And if I live here, I will come here all the time! The food here is outstanding! And the service is lovely!

This time we tried 4 dishes

Bull's eye French Toast ( the egg yolk bedded in the fluffy toast and with deep fried chunk of chicken that make it looks like banana is so brilliant and delicious!)

Kimchi & Bacon & Eggs Pancake Asian Style Breakfast (Hands down the best dish, similar concept to Thai frying oyster dish ( ), great combination, everything is going well together, the kimchi and vinegar sauce help balance the fatty crispy bacon and the pancake perfectly!

Breakfast Spaghetti & Clams & crab ( This is my least favorite dish, didn't taste much of the clams and crab)

This little piggy went to China ( The meat patty, egg and biscuit in hot sweet sour Asian sauce, super yummy!)

We also ordered the croissant and homemade sausage link. The best breakfast sausage I ever have!

This diner is probably the most chic diner you will ever step foot in. A friend was visiting town this past weekend and we wanted to go to a yummy place to eat.We chose the Little Goat Diner.

The ambiance was on point. It still had a diner feel but not grimy or dirty, the decor was very trendy. We split 4 dishes which was definitely enough for 3 people. The breakfast items are quite exotic. If you like more basic diner dishes options are slim.

But the whole point of a restaurant like this is to experience new and exciting flavors!

Food wise this is a 4 star restaurant. Select dishes on their wide ranging menu are clear winners while others are just good. However their hours, hospitality, menu diversity and elevated nostalgia earn it an additional star.

pics.caption: Little Piggy Goes to China. Best dish on their menu.

review.des: Treated me and my kids like people, not lepers, as most places do when they see children. Got news for them... my growing pups eat more than dad! Great pancakes, loved the croque monsieur, and nice dessert selection. Don't miss if you can't go to Girl !

I was under the impression that it may be impossible to get into Girl and the Goat so I decided that I was going to Little Goat for breakfast.  More my speed anyhow.
Walked in to a super cute, hip, clean diner and a welcoming staff.  Sat right at the counter which is A-OK with me and watched the kitchen energy and banter (made me miss working in a restaurant....just a little).  Amanda my waitress was super cute and friendly and overly animated but I liked it.  Ordered the cold brew iced (I heart cold brew) and this did not disappoint.  Also ordered the Kimchi bloody mary.  it was tart and spicy with yummy little garnishes.  
Ordered the Kimchi/bacon/pancake thingy.  It's definitely something I make on a daily basis.  A fridge cleaning meal but in a good way.  The sauce that came with it was a bit too vinegary and maybe could have used a sweet element (maple syrup?) to jazz it up..but it was yummy and I cleaned my plate.
If I lived in Chicago...I'd come here on the reg.  I'd bring all of my out of town guests... it's that cool.
I appreciate the charm and the touches and the hip hop music in the background.  Oh and the cute little cloth napkins wrapped in a little paper stamped with a goat..CUTE! :)

Was here on a Friday night for diner - we came out with a reservation for a table on the terrace, and they were kind enough to hold it for us even though we were 30 minutes late (I greatly appreciate that!)
Firstly, the restaurant is located on a very cool place. Halsted and Randolph is a nice place to go out, so the atmosphere was really nice, not only in the restaurant, on the terrace, but also in the street.
For diner, I had the All American burger, some fries... unfortunately I cannot remember what my friend ordered, but it looked delicious. Anyway, everything on the menu looked appetizing and delicious!
We also had a few beers, they were good. And the waiter was extremely nice!
In overall, the experience was very good. I recommend this restaurant.

Walked in on a Sunday night around 7:30pm right after a big storm had passed through so we weren't sure what to expect in terms of wait time. I live nearby and the place always looks jammed - so try to avoid going during premium hours. There were a lot of people waiting around the front door but I figured I would ask if they had a spot for two, which it turns out they had more seats than that open at the bar near the kitchen. For drinks we ordered a Moscow Goat (Grapefruit Juice, Gin, Ginger Beer) and a BBQ Picnic (I think thats what it was called) which tasted just like you were sipping Sweet Baby Ray's. I mean that in a good way, it was a great combination of juices/spices and local Chicago Distillery's "Finn's Gin" that left a pleasant mesquite lay's potato chip flavor lingering in your mouth. Seriously - nice job whoever came up with that.

For food I really wanted to try the goat because... well you get it. I ordered the Patty Melt and subbed out Slagel Farms for goat, medium. It was very tasty and if you close your eyes you'd be hard pressed to tell me it was goat. I can't decide if this makes me happy or disappointed, but either way it was definitely a stronger taste than your every day beef patty. Had a decent amount of grilled onions and a few large slices of pickle which added a nice balance. It was juicy and reminded me a bit of lamb, my only negative comment is I think the bread to meat ratio is a little off as at points I got huge mouthfuls of goat meat while at others I was rounding the corners of the bread. My girlfriend wanted breakfast and ordered the Bull's Eye French toast - which came with a egg cooked in the center of a waffle, fried chicken pieces, and strawberries. Each item was great on its own so the combination set sweet, salty, fried, crunchy, ooey, gooey, etc. Oh we also ordered the elotes to share which was very tasty and just what you'd expect from the geniuses in the kitchen. I'd recommend Little Goat to anyone because their menu is extensive, inexpensive, and not for the apprehensive.

Five stars for the food and server, 2 stars for the wait and rude hostess.  Heres why: I had a reservation at 8:30, we arrived about an hour and 15 minutes early.  After a long day traipsing around the city we decided to see if we could get in earlier.  The hostess said 20-30 after that another 20 after that another 20 until finally many non reservation parties were being served before us.  What the heck?!   We finally got seated after a hour and ten minutes.
The food was a different story, it was amazing.  Very flavorful with unique food choices that surprisingly taste really good together.  The servers were lively and helpful as well.  It is a bit loud, but overall not too bad.  
To recap, great food, great servers, good atmosphere, horrible hostess...  For such a friendly place, why have some rude snarly young lady in the front setting possible misperceptions of the place?

Little goat is probably one of my favorite things about Chicago. The food is AMAZING every time I go. Today was the fish tostadas and a Bloody Mary. As per usual it was delicious. I try to get different items each time I come in. Slowly working my way thru the menu. It's all worth it.

I have liked everything I have had there!  Always ask what their specials are.  I have only been here for brunch and lunch.  If there is a longer wait, you can walk through to the coffee "shop" area and get a coffee while you wait.  They also offer outdoor seating in the nicer months.  The servers are always friendly and helpful with recommendations.  The Bacon Hash is YUMMY...it is a bit salty and greasy, but a great hangover meal.  The sandwiches and meals I've had are all banging with flavor.
Good food and drinks. Fun places. On the bar side around closing time we got complementary cookies and whoopi pies. The bartender was really nice as well.

pics.caption: Jameson and ginger and a LIIT

review.des:
The service here is wonderful. The food was exquisite.

The manager was kind enough to accommodate a large group of us for a weekend brunch (celebratory/going away). We didn't have to wait longer than half hour (11ppl) to be seated.

Everyone loved everything. My favorite was the paratha eggs breakfast. It was delicious, fresh and flavorful. The grilled cheese was very good. The coffee and spiced chai was great. If you're a chocolate lover then the dark chocolate pancakes won't disappoint.

We had some mishaps with a few people's meals and they were very quick and understanding with replacing and correcting. We were patient as it was a busy Sunday and appreciated them comping the meals they messed up on.

The prices are very reasonable and typical for the area. Would highly recommend for brunch but their lunch options looked delicious so can't wait to go back!

pics.caption: Parathas eggs avocado salad (whatever it's called) Sooo good!

review.des:
Place was packed. Was told an hour and 30 mins wait. At least they face us an option to sit at the community table. We sat at the end of table close to breakfast bar. We were luckily enough to see Stephine Izard owner make our food. Had fillet O fish sandwich, goat chili, Mac and cheese, and Reuben sandwich. Food ok, recommend goat chili and Reuben sandwich. Mac and cheese not gooey enough for me. Fish sandwich bread was a bit too hard to eat.
I don't like the cloth napkins that they give us. It left white lint on our clothes especially around my husband face, what's that stuff on your face?
Overall an OK experience.
What can I say that hasn't been said? Fantastic and creative food in an upscale diner with friendly service. That's all you need to know. Now GO!

Although the menu and booths/tables look like standard diner stuff, the food here is excellent! The upscale ingredients and creative dishes make this place great, and the food is actually really affordable compared to other places in the area. Would really recommend this place!

I was excited to try Stephanie Izard's restaurant and was quite impressed with their brunch. Reservations are recommended as the place does look like it gets pretty packed during prime hours. The menu is extensive with a ton of delectable offerings. Do yourself a favor though and order the hash browns, as they are life changing! A hint on the salty side, but I can easily say it's the best I've ever had in my life.

For my entree I ordered the 'This little piggy went to China' and it was amazing. It's a sesame cheddar biscuit served with Szechuan pork sausage, chili garlic chive sauce, blackberries and sunny eggs. The flavors may seem a bit confusing at first but it actually works pretty well together. The blackberries give a nice tartness and offer a good contrast to the spicy and salty Asian flavors. The oozing egg yolk adds a delightful richness to the dish

The girlfriend ordered the bull's eye french toast served with eggs, crispy chicken, and sweet onion brioche all drizzled with BBQ maple syrup. It definitely ate more on the sweeter side than savory (which I would've preferred) but overall a pretty tasty dish.

I wanted an iced coffee drink and the Thailander looked interesting on the menu. Sadly, I can only say it was ehh and probably a bit too experimental for my tastes. The chile flavor is quite prominent on the after taste and just didn't work for me. Overall though, the food is amazing and would love to come back sometime to try more of Little Goat's delicious offerings.

pics.caption: This Little Piggy Went to China

review.des:
Stephanie, the Little Goat Diner is hurting your "brand".  Marginal food+marginal experience = meh.  Great drinks...but it stops there.  Maybe just a breakfast place?

Won't be back again....quality has slipped

We accidentally came across this restaurant, as tourists in this big city. They were packed, but able to seat the two of us immediately at the bar without reservations. The cinnamon roll was great and the service was good.

One of my very good friends had been trying to take me here for the past few weeks. It took a while, but once we had finally found the time, I was not disappointed.

We were seated right away. I didnt get to see much of the inside of the resturaunt, but the outside aesthetic and seating were wonderful. Our food took a little while, but our waitress kept coming by and making sure we were all good. When it had arrived, we dug right in.

I had ordered biscuts and gravy (breakfast all day!) with toast and gritz on the side. The gravy was a perfect tempurature, and the biscut was crispy on the outside and soft on the inside.  The gritz was great, and by the time I got to the toast, I was pretty full. I could only eat one piece, but that one piece was fantastic.

Little Goat is an incredible experience. Though the food took a bit to come, we were constantly tended to. The pricing was great for the portion size, and the quality of food is unmatched. Do not pass this diner up.

pics.caption: Toast, biscuts and gravy, and some gritz.

review.des:
....Toffee pork bourbon milkshake, Toffee pork bourbon milkshake, Toffee pork bourbon milkshake...

The Finale - Free Fallin'!

Oh no...the "Toffee pork bourbon milkshake" chant again. Ever since I'd seen a fellow yelper's photo of this delight...the mental syllables running around in my head keep rearranging themselves into this salty mantra.

So, what the hell is a girl without a goat to do when she finds herself lolling along one happy Friday night in the vicinity of the place where the actual "Toffee pork bourbon milkshake" comes to life? You guessed it!

I insert myself into the one-and-only-empty-and-made-for-me-place at the Little Goat bar.  Seriously, I filled in the only gap left between couples and friends hanging out. It was a place no two could fill - only me - as if it were hallowed "Toffee pork bourbon milkshake" ground. So you can imagine how shocked I was - that when I ordered it...I failed to say aloud, "bourbon" at first.

When the bartender repeats my order, only then do I hear the absence of the  "bourbon" and I say, "It has bourbon in it, right?" He comes back, "Oh you want bourbon in it!?"  **Whoa, who would drink that without bourbon in it!?** I guess someone who doesn't want to pay $15.28 for a milkshake! LOL Normally, this over expenditure would cause me to freak out a bit. I mean..FIFTEEN BUCKS? Levity then embraces me and I'm 'Free Fal-lin' like everyone around me. . .

Tom Petty playing, couples around me in intense in conversations that I'm not even trying to overhear: "You know if a guy spends more than $100 on you...he likes you." That line works and they are now exchanging a tongue text. Oh yeah, this is a good place to be and a milkshake to savor.  What a laid back but energetic bar scene, where people may just be falling in love. I recommend a visit here even if you aren't waiting to dine. It's small, intimate - just a row of seats at a bar - and a couple of two tops off to the side - couple of patio tables when the weather's right. (Rumor has it...there's even rooftop seating now.)

Later in the week when I went back for a loaf of bread - something serendipitous happened and there I was holding a free loaf of bacon gruyere. Dollar-cost average that with the milkshake and It all works out. This place will do you right.

PS I really think there should be four separate categories here: LG Bread, LG coffee bar, LG bar and LG Diner. There's so much goodness in this relatively small space!

pics.caption: Toffee pork bourbon milkshake toffee pork bourbon milkshake toffee pork bourbon milkshake
Took some of that $15 shake home!

review.des: My experience could have been better if they didn't seat us at the bar. After waiting for 45 minutes for a table we were seated at the bar which was the most uncomfortable seat of my life. Stools and bar table were too short and there was not enough leg room between our bolted seats and the vertical part of the bar table, so we both( I'm 5 7 and my husband is 6 2) had to fold our legs under the bar and basically sit sideways. I didn't enjoy my food at all.  As far as the food goes, I ordered the " little pig went to China" and that was descent. A bit on the salty side but descent and my husband ordered the pancake. Nothing extraordinary about his pancakes. Overall a very disappointing experience. Bathrooms were clean though.

This place is amazing. They were even great with my food allergies even though I was in a decent sized group. I went with a work event and it was a much better time than I usually do at new places in groups. The burgers are super creative and of course really tasty.

LOVE this place! Great atmosphere and amazing food!

This is considered a diner, but the menu is very innovative and the atmosphere is trendy and classy. The menu is huge- everything from breakfast to dinner. My mom and I finally narrowed down the choices to 3 items and our  waitress helped us choose 2 items - los drowned and the pork belly pancake. After we ordered, Rod Stewart walked past our table on his way out and my mom embarrassingly chased him down for a picture. After this she said she was too excited to eat, but as soon as the food arrived her appetite quickly returned! Everything was delicious and the portions were generous. I will definitely be back so I can explore the rest of the menu!

I've come here a few times now and I really can't say a bad thing about this place!

Korean Burger - Who would have thought kimchi on a burger would be so good?? But it works.

Hot Crab Dip - so effing creamy and delicious, I had to restrain myself from shoveling into my face with my hands. It's a really good size portion too

This Little Piggy Went To China - this is an absolute must order! My absolute favorite dish, the cheddar biscuits are like those from Red Lobster, but topped with eggs and pork sausage. It's topped off with a splendid sauce that you will be licking off your plate! Even the blackberries seem right at home on this plate

Desserts - I'm not much if a dessert person, but maybe it's because I haven't been eating these desserts. Their Elvis cake is a banana bread cake with a peanut butter creme with caramelized bacon bits!!! Seriously, need I say more?!  The Turtle Pie and Golden Graham Cake  - equally as delicious. Even if you can't save room for dessert, take some to go because you won't regret it. If I recommend a dessert, it must be good because I never want dessert

Drinks - excellent and the bartenders go out of their way to make drinks that you will enjoy. Not only are you going drink some really delicious things, but you'll learn a lot too, if you just ask some questions

Thoroughly impressed everytime I've been!

What a letdown. Heard good things so checked them out.  Nothing special - food was rather bland. And so overpriced.  We tried pancakes, corned beef hash, french toast, bacon, coffee.  None of us really liked any of it.
Amazing food! Good service! Good environment! First time here today and would definitely come back

I'm so disappointed in my experience last night. I tipped over a full glass of water all over the counter and the floor and not a single employee noticed... leaving us without a rag to wipe off ourselves, the counter and the floor with napkins... Now for the kicker, our server didn't even offer to refill my glass. So I left wet, thirsty and very annoyed. The worst service I've had in the last year. The food was still good but I can't overlook the fact that several staff walked past us cleaning off the counter and floor and didn't offer to lift a finger to even grab a rag.

I wish I could remember our server's name. They were awesome.

The food here was terrific. I got the Pork Belly Home Fries and the Fat Elvis Waffles. It was a LOT of food, but I powered through because it really was just that tasty.

Our server was funny, but helpful. And, I thought the prices were well within reason.

I will definitely be going back to Little Goat Diner.

I was really looking forward to trying this place out, because I had heard so many great things about Stephanie Izard's restaurants. Girl & the goat is almost impossible to get a reservation at, so I decided to come here instead! Overall, the food was very unique, I just didn't completely love what I ordered (Little piggy goes to china). The waiter even warned me about the dish as he said people either love it or hate it. My friend on the other hand ordered the french toast & LOVED it. So maybe I just had a meh experience and should've listened to the waiter's warning. Overall, super cute restaurant and good food!

We love going to this place. It has some of the best breakfast food I've ever had. It is so good that I haven't been able to get away from it and order anything else off the menu.

I would highly recommend the French toast. How can you go wrong with delicious French toast covered with maple syrup and really good pieces of crispy chicken?

Everything else we've gotten here has been amazing too such as the biscuits and gravy and the crumpets with chorizo sausage.

Definitely go here.

I'm a huge fan of reuben sandwiches and there is definitely a delicious twist here with Kimchi! It's so good and so are the drinks. I was also here for a couple of private events on the roof and they were just the best experiences too! Good place all around.

Came here for brunch with a group of 12, the food was excellent, quick, and came out at the same time! We waited 20 min to sit, even with a reservation, but the staff was great after that and even gave the group free cinnamon buns. Great food and experience overall.

At 3:30 PM, the place was still hopping with a long wait but the food is well worth the wait. We decided to go with both a lunch item and a breakfast dish. The lunch dish was the "Los Drowned" which is a braised beef sandwich with havarti, avocado, pickled peppers & onions and spicy mayo on a hoagie. For the breakfast dish, we wanted to get the bull's eye french toast which is basically chicken and waffles but they were out of that so we settled on the "Fat Elvis Waffles". These waffles are topped with banana, peanut butter-butter and bacon maple syrup. I'm not usually a sweet breakfast person but I could eat that again. Definitely a must visit when in Chicago.

The food was really unique and we enjoyed looking at he menu items.  We were told a thirty five minute wait and that was pretty much on target.   The food did come out quickly but they were a bit behind on the fries.    We all enjoyed our meals and only one of finished the meal (but it took her awhile).  Was really closer to a 4.5 but we can't rate 1/2 stars.

Our party of five ( including a young child) had dinner at the Little Goat last evening. Dinner was a " tale of two cities" ---- terrific food with a poor overall dining experience.  Management at the front of the house was nonexistent. The two women at the front desk were unpleasant, indifferent, clearly bored and seemed to want to be anywhere but working at TLG.  They were having air conditioning problems ----- the place was stifling --- but rather than being upfront about it, the hostesses sat us silently, leaving us to wonder why we were so warm.  Our server tried valiantly but was clearly over burdened and warm.  Something was off throughout the meal. Even getting ice in our water proved challenging.

No thanks for coming or any comment at all upon departure.

The food was fine but if you care about a pleasant evening you might think twice

This place is a cute breakfast spot but it is so noisy! I felt like I had to scream out every time I had to say something. I came here on a Saturday afternoon and it was about a 10 minute wait. Not bad! There were a lot of people waiting too. Found this place on yelp and decided to try due to its highly rated reviews.

I ordered the cheese grits, corned beef with eggs and bulls eye French toast

Cheese Grits
I love grits! so all grits taste great to me. It was cheesy, loved the proportion of it since I ordered it as a side. The grits came with unmelted shredded cheese on top. I did think this was more dry than the grits I am use to having but it is still good.

I was actually almost going to order the shrimp and grits which is a regular sized plate but I'm glad I didn't. I can't eat too much grits in one sitting

Corned Beef with Eggs
I was done eating this after a few bites. The meat was just too smokey and it was pretty much a smokey taste throughout even though I ate it with the eggs and the shredded potatoes. I wasn't a big fan of this plate at all. It's pretty much a plate of meat. Too much meat for the morning and afternoon. I have to say that the potatoes were pretty good if u ate it alone.

Bulls Eye French Toast
This plate is the same concept as chicken and waffles--sweet and savory. The syrup is a must try because it was so different than regular syrup. I was trying to figure out what it was because it tasted so familiar! So it's pretty much bbq sauce and maple syrup! I was done with this plate after a few bites as well since the sweetness was good enough for me

Price
I don't think the food was worth what it's priced at because the food was only decent, nothing extraordinary

Not sure if I'll come here again the next time I'm in Chicago

pics.caption: Corned beef with eggs, cheese grits on the side

review.des:
PandaPop views this LITTLE GOAT as: A GO TO PLACE......just hard to get in.  Gonna have to go during off hours.    PandaPop hates waiting.    

Except for the Asian stuff ( c'mon man) everything else is terrific.         Great diversity.    Try the daily bread.   Try the salads, fish tacos    I almost always get the corned beef and hash.

Man, where do i start?!! First of all, the interior decoration is on par. Love the furniture and ambiance the owner decided to go with. Really fits the whole diner feel. Anyways, my friend and I got to this place right when it opened on a Wednesday and it wasn't busy at all. Service was great and our waiter gave us several recommendations for the city. I ordered the okonomiyaki and it was delicious! The texture and flavors had me smiling during my whole stay. Also, i had an iced mocha. It was normal and nothing extraordinary. Overall, I would come here again and try the tempura mash potatoes. Few of my friends are telling me to get it before I come back home
The nachos - get the nachos. Otherwise, your standard American dining experience (that's delicious). Food is very heavy, so come hungry

Food was delish. We arrived around 9:30 and was able to sit right away at the counter (true diner experience) place is lovely, and food exceptional.  Smoked corn beef hash and eggs was perfect.  The burrito was exceptional too. Just when you wonder why something is on the plate it makes sense.  Flavor was hearty, savory and refreshing. It's a lot of food so go hungry.

Ordered sloppy goat, very salty, does not taste good. Mini crab dip does not taste good either. Smoked fried taste all right. Ketchup does not taste good as well.
Strawberry pie was fine.

Luckily that our server was nice. I tipped her 20% because of her service and her hard work.

The environment is fine. The location is good.

I feel this restaurant use their reputation to print cash from people. In matter of taste and quality of food, this restaurant does not deserve to be even 3 stars restaurant.

Technically I am giving this place 4.5 stars.

Nothing to hate, everything to love. I hope it's stays around for many decades to come so I can tell my kids, this is where mommy used to go on dates, girls nights, late night after many drinks, and was never ever disappointed.

Went here for my birthday last week.  Wanted something good but not fancy.  This was perfect!   The drinks- to die for.   The food- even better.   I had the fish tostadas and crab drip, I've been craving this ever since last Friday.

The food is good. The service lacks. We informed our waitress that this is our first time here. She encouraged us to order sides with every one of our five meals. The sides are enormous! One side can easily be shared by 3 people. Instead we ended up with 5 sides for each person in our party, including children. We walked out with bags of expensive leftovers, which we kept in the car all day as we were spending the day out and about. Mimosas were not served in champagne flutes. Not the special feeling we were hoping for.

This is now a must when in Chicago. Went for brunch with some friends.  Started with the cinnamon roll, delicious, and we then moved onto savory- the parathas burrito (with bacon!), a Reuben (with kimichi, harvarti and pretzel rye), the omelet daily special and the Goat'o-Goat'o salad.  We all gobbled the food down with no complaints while enjoying coffee and the cocktail of the day - Scotch in the Morning. Happily "rolling" out of our booth at the end of the meal.

Good place for breakfast and beer (or wine) if you are in the area. The menu has many tasty choices, like everything on it. Pancakes come out hot and fluffy, waffles topped with yum, the omelettes bursting with flavor and sammiches that I just can't help but omnomnom. Don't forget the burgers! The almighty goat burger needs to be tried at least once in your life. It would make the Little Goat happy you did. Baaaa!

So this might be too exagurated but...I am a huge fan of chocolate and a huge fan of chocolate cake, so there!

I stopped in last minute late on a weekday to share dessert with my friends for a birthday. We ordered their Mexican Chocolate cake and it was AMAZING. It has a perfect blend of chocolate, cinnamon, moisture and even a little dab of kick. The service was super friendly and the diner ambiance is super casual. I truly loved it even though I did not have a full meal but I will be back for one for sure!

I love this place and think it's a perfect lunch spot! I tend to visit here when the wait at the surrounding restaurants are ridiculous and we're always seated within 10 minutes. The menu uses a lot of interesting/tantalizing flavor combos (I may be biased bc of my love for kimchi).

The portions are generally just right and the price is not bad considering the quality of the food. My favorites are the SMOKED CORNED BEEF HASH WITH EGGS and KOREAN BURGER but I have yet to try everything (which I intend to)!

The space is cool with its diner feel but I wish rooftop patio was open for regular diners (it's generally used for private parties). It would make the whole experience even better. Either way, I consider myself a regular here and always leave happy.

Amazing. We ordered the Rueben and "three little piggys in China"? Something like that. The Reuben was amazing , the piggys was weird at first bc of the spices and herbs- it doesn't taste like breakfast if that makes sense but once you keep eating, it's really good. We wanted to try the tempura mashed potatoes- sure glad we did! They are to die for

pics.caption: The Rueben and Three Little Piggys went to China - something like that. Also, because we're pigs, tempura fried mashed potatoes

review.des: What can I say besides amazing? I thoroughly enjoyed my dining experience here. The service was incredible, the food was excellent and the experience was more than up to par. We had the crab dip; which I strongly recommend. I had the Sloppy Goat - YESSSSS - we also had BBQ Pork, Pork Belly Pancakes, The Fat Club, and The Chickpea salad! All were awesome. If you don't know, this restaurant is owned and the menu is created by a Iron Chef winner, so I recommend you go. I don't know why it took me so long.
Overrated. Bartender was obnoxious. Waitress was no help in deciding what to get from the large menu. Food was just okay.

1 word, YUM! My friend and I waited for about 30-45 min on a Sunday at about noon (it wasn't a problem because we weren't starving and knew we would work up an appetite. We ordered the omelette of the day which was fresh tomato, green onion and tzatzki cream cheese, it was delicious!!! We also ordered the Bulls eye French toast (highly recommend), major party flavor in my mouth! I wanted to order a goat milk latte but I chickened out last minute and ended up with a regular latte, it was still delicious but it gives me a reason to go back and try the goat milk latte.

Loved this twist on the Goat and twist on a diner. Great menu loaded with choices from breakfast served all day to sammies to special treats like pot pie. Service is very good, what we've come to expect from the owner of this little chain of eateries.
Went there for a brunch with friend and got a Brussels sprouts salad, was okay but a little bit oily.

So happy I finally made it to Little Goat. The fish tostadas were AMAZING. I also had the "It's A Pie" malt shake which was delicious. All the shakes are $8 which is kinda pricy but I would definitely recommend it. You'll want to make a reservation beside this is a very popular venue and parking in the area is limited.

We went for Sunday brunch and the 30 minute wait was worth it. The atmosphere is bright and comfortable. The service was quick, and the waitress knowledgable. The food, of course, amazing. A+ on overall experience.

Started with the bread of the day, which was the buffalo cheese bread with ranch and bacon cream cheese. Subtle buffalo flavor to the bread, and the cream cheese topping was ridiculously good. I had the patty melt, which was by far one of the best I've ever had (and I've had a LOT). My wife decided to try something different, and the risk was rewarded. She had the parathas burrito - perfectly cooked eggs, sharp goats milk wrapped in crispy naan and topped with the most amazing avocado bean salad with chili pepper sauce. She could have eaten just a bowl of that salad and been happy!

If you are looking for extremely well done, familiar comfort food with a creative twist, this is the place. Family friendly as well.

Nicely done, Chef Stephanie. We will be back!

pics.caption: Parathas burrito. Light, flavorful, and amazingly delicious.

review.des:
Definitely my favorite place for lunch on the west side despite the 15 minutes hike plus 20 minutes wait time.

Two of us arrived shortly after 12pm. They have a nice lobby with a traditional diner touch. A nice gentleman told us about 20 minutes wait time. Left my cell # then just walk out to see what are place around here. Found a butcher place nearby selling fresh goat meat. Need to stop by later to get something.

We received a text msg and went back to be seated outside. It was a pleasant day to be outdoor. I immediately decided on Pork Belly Pancake. My friend opted for the special of the day: Pulled chicken on pita bread. We decided to split the smoked fries as well.

We kind of shared both entrees and totally agree on Pork Belly was the excellent choice. Pork was flavorful and not greasy. I have not figured out if the pork was braised, steamed or baked. Anyway it was so tasty with shredded cabbage and crispy noodles. The grilled Scallion pancake was the perfect wrap for those. The very light touch of housin sauce was just right. This should be a perfect oriental dish but I have not seen anything like this at any Asian place I tried. Absolutely delicious.

Pulled Chicken with pita was pretty good but not as impressive as the Pork Belly. I liked the diced tomato and arugula on the top.  I was not impressed with smoked fries which I could not really tell the difference from the regular fries. That is pretty much left untouched.

Our waitress was lovely and efficient. It was a perfect lunch for us. I will be back really soon.

pics.caption: Pulled chicken on pita. Today's special.

review.des: Halve been wanting to eat at one of Stephanie Izard's restaurants for a very long time! Couldn't get into Girl & Goat so tried this instead. I was not disappointed! Excellent cocktails, nice menu selection. I got the Banh mi Goat burger and tried to lick my plate as the waiter took it away! My husband got a braised beef sandwich that he raved about. And then to top it off we got the Cheezit sundae. It sounds weird to have an ice cream sundae with cheezits but it was amazing- more plate licking needed! I want to go back and have breakfast!
I went here because of the reviews. I was happy to see a unique menu for breakfast. I get tired of the same menu items for breakfast. So, in short, this place will not disappoint. Very good.

Note to anyone wanting to go here in the next few days and can't stand the heat:  their AC isn't strong enough to cool the restaurant down so expect to sweat!
They did make up for this horrible oversight, and there is no way that this would stop from me going again... just call before you go to see if their AC problems are fixed.

Anyway, this is my second time here and the food here is so fantastic especially for the price.  You can't beat a ridiculously tender flavorful piece of pork that melts in your mouth and is swimming in their house kimchi that is so jammed packed with flavor it would make you believe that you are ready to die and go to heaven because you just ate one of the the best things that you will ever taste in your life.  This of course is the Fork Pork Chop.  It is so good and it was the perfect serving..just enough to make me full.  My dad really liked his pork belly pancake and my mom loved her BLT with fresh Avocado.  They also have plenty of Vegan options which is great for my SIL.  

Service was okay, but they are always busy, so you can't really expect white tablecloth service.  Wait wasn't too terrible for arriving for lunch at 11:00 - it was about 45 minutes.  It's nice that they text you when you're table is available so you can walk around on Randolph... when it's not during a heat wave!!  

I can't wait to eat here again!

I was, unfortunately, underwhelmed. That's really the bottom line. If I'm eating somewhere that I'm going to pay $50 for breakfast, regardless of what part of the city the restaurant is in or who the chef/owner is, it better be pretty damn good.

Unfortunately, I just didn't feel that way. I ordered the "This Little Pig Went to China." I thought certain elements of the meal were really good, and others weren't. I was disappointed. We ended up stopping next door at the bakery where I got a Mexican chocolate scone, which was very good, to erase the food memory.

I will say the service was very friendly and answered all of my wife's questions.

Absolutely horrible. My chicken was undercooked. A manager and waiter insisted that it's just the way it's served. Both manager and waiter opted to give me a lesson in their way of preparation.. I'm leaving the restaurant with flames coming from my ears. I'm hungry and disgusted.

Wife and both had barbecue pork sandwich for lunch and shared a milkshake.  Very little meat and took a very long time.  Nice atmosphere but not impressed with the sandwich.  Don't believe we will return.
Ordered the this little piggy went to china after our waitress recommended it. Probably the best brunch I've had in a long time

We went to this place after a Bears game on a Sunday night. It was one of the few places in the neighborhood that did not have a wait.

It is a neat diner set up with interesting food choices (breakfast is served all day) and good beer.

We had the :
- Fat Elvis Waffles - banana, peanut butter, and bacon maple syrup
- Los Drowned - braised beef, havarti, avocado, pickled peppers & onions, and spicy mayo on a hoagie (like a French dip already dipped)

We would totally recommend this place especially due to the shorter/no wait of other places.

For more information and pictures check out our site : thegreatcubeescape.com

Loved it! I've wanted to go to Girl and the Goat for a while because I loved Stephanie on Top Chef. This was a great substitute. Its her food in a more casual atmosphere. The decor was 60s daytime sleek, and was light and airy. I had the bullseye French toast. It had poached egg in the center of each bread slice, sliced strawberries,  and perfect fried chicken chopped into smaller pieces. Everyone loved what they ordered. We also got dessert--the fat Elvis cake was to die for : moist banana with peanut butter bacon frosting. Deslicious!

Guess all the hype from the mother store - "Girl and the Goat" got to me to try little goat and there is no line to grab a bite here. We got a seat right away and near the kitchen where I like to see the real action that prepares everyone dishes. To my surprise that day I actually saw Stephanie in the kitchen (it was a plus to see the owner/celebrity and actually working in the kitchen).

It was hard to pick a item off the extensive menu that was offered, too many items that I wanted to try out - usually for breakfast I go for the pancakes / french toast but what caught my eye was the smoked hash in duck fat, not sure why I picked it maybe because it sounded good. The food came fast and at first glance, looks very appealing but after a few bites, the dish started to accumulate grease and getting heavy to eat, though washing the food down with coffee did not help the cause. What helped me finish the dish was to tilt the entree in a slant to help drain the duck fat.
